Secondary outcomes include frailty index, loneliness, self-reported health, physical activity, self-efficacy, depression, anxiety, sleep, and physical performance measures. The study aims to assess the feasibility and acceptability of the AGE SELF CARE program for frailty prevention in older adults.

This is a pan-European observational cohort study aimed at understanding the course of functional and medical recovery, as well as the treatment modalities and organization of geriatric rehabilitation, for patients admitted to geriatric rehabilitation facilities across Europe due to COVID-19 morbidity. The primary objective is to gain insight into the functional and medical recovery of these patients, while the secondary objective is to understand the treatments and rehabilitation services provided. Patients recovering from COVID-19 and requiring geriatric rehabilitation were enrolled from October 2020 to November 2021. Data was collected at admission, discharge, 6 weeks, and 6 months, including demographics, hospital stay details, functional assessments, quality of life, frailty, cognition, and complications. The primary outcome is change in activities of daily living (ADL) functioning, measured by the Barthel Index. The secondary outcome is change in quality of life, measured by the EQ-5D-5L. The study aims to model the recovery trajectory and impact of factors like frailty and delirium, while also describing the rehabilitation therapies and professionals involved in different countries.

The PREPARE-iVAC trial is a multicentre, open-label, controlled, randomized study evaluating the replacement of mycophenolate mofetil/mycophenolic acid (MMF/MPA) with everolimus in kidney transplant recipients on the immunogenicity and safety of COVID-19 and herpes zoster vaccinations. The primary objective is to investigate if replacing MMF/MPA with everolimus results in superior neutralizing antibody titers against the Omicron XBB.1.5 strain after COVID-19 vaccination. Secondary objectives include assessing humoral and cellular immunogenicity against SARS-CoV-2 and varicella zoster virus, as well as evaluating safety parameters such as acute rejection, kidney function, and adverse events. Eligible kidney transplant recipients will be randomized 1:1 to continue MMF/MPA or switch to everolimus. After a run-in period, participants will receive a bivalent COVID-19 mRNA vaccine, with an optional part involving two doses of the recombinant zoster vaccine. The study aims to determine if replacing MMF/M

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of resistance exercises on liver enzymes in burn patients. The study will involve 60 patients aged 20-45 years with partial thickness burns covering 30-50% of their body surface area. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the study group (n=30) or the control group (n=30). The study group will undergo an 8-week resistance exercise program using dumbbells and sandbags, in addition to standard physical therapy and medical treatment. The control group will receive only standard physical therapy and medical treatment. The primary outcome measure is the plasma level of liver enzymes (AST and ALT) after two months. The study aims to determine if resistance exercises can reduce liver enzyme levels in burn patients.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of upper trapezius stretching exercises on neck pain, range of motion, and disability in patients with cervical spondylosis. The study involves two groups: an intervention group receiving upper trapezius stretching exercises guided by a physical therapist, and a control group receiving standard care including heat treatment and strengthening exercises. The primary outcomes measured are changes in neck pain intensity using a numerical rating scale, and changes in neck range of motion measured by a goniometer. A secondary outcome is changes in the Neck Disability Index questionnaire. Assessments are done at baseline, after 4 weeks of intervention, and at 3 months follow-up. The study includes patients aged 40-65 years with a confirmed diagnosis of cervical spondylosis and chronic neck pain for at least 3 months. Key exclusion criteria are recent neck trauma/surgery, certain medical conditions, pregnancy, and cognitive impairment.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study investigating the effectiveness of tecartherapy, a form of deep thermotherapy using radiofrequency electrical currents, on the performance of amateur athletes aged 18-30 years. The primary outcomes are changes in 30-meter sprint time and electromyographic activity of the quadriceps during sprinting, measured immediately before and after the intervention. Secondary outcomes include countermovement jump height, electromyographic activity during jumping, isometric leg extension force, and electromyographic activity during isometric leg extension. The experimental group will receive a single 25-minute tecartherapy session on both legs, while the control group will undergo a sham procedure without active treatment. The study aims to evaluate if tecartherapy can improve functional variables related to sports performance in amateur athletes.

This is a basic science study investigating cell-free DNA levels in patients with endometriosis undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) treatment compared to patients with other causes of infertility. The primary objectives are to quantify cell-free DNA in serum before starting IVF stimulation and in follicular fluid on the day of oocyte retrieval. The study has two parallel arms: an experimental arm with patients diagnosed with endometriosis and an active comparator arm with patients having other infertility causes. Blood samples (10ml) will be collected from participants in both arms before starting IVF and on the day of oocyte retrieval to measure cell-free DNA levels using real-time PCR. Additionally, cell-free DNA will be measured in follicular fluid collected during oocyte retrieval. Secondary outcomes include oocyte quality measures, embryo development, clinical pregnancy rates, and live birth rates, which will be compared between the two arms over one year. The study aims to investigate the potential association between cell-free DNA levels and endometriosis, as well as its impact on IVF outcomes.

This is a 10-year prospective comparative study evaluating the outcomes of maxillary implant overdentures retained by either bar attachments or solitary Locator attachments in edentulous patients. The primary outcome is the change in marginal peri-implant bone level after 10 years. Secondary outcomes include implant and overdenture survival rates, peri-implant tissue health parameters (probing depth, plaque, and gingival indices), and patient satisfaction. Eligible participants were edentulous in the maxilla for at least one year, had sufficient bone volume, and were treated with four dental implants and a maxillary overdenture 10 years ago due to problems with their conventional denture. The study compares the long-term performance and outcomes of the two attachment systems for implant-retained maxillary overdentures.

This is a randomized clinical trial investigating the efficacy of a designed exercise program on pain and sleep quality in adult patients with sickle cell disease anemia. The study involves 50 participants aged 18-55 years, randomly assigned to an experimental group (n=25) or a control group (n=25). The experimental group will receive a 6-week exercise program consisting of diaphragmatic breathing exercises, progressive muscle relaxation, stretching/stabilization/strengthening exercises for the pelvic-lumbar region, and daily walking for 30 minutes. The control group will not receive any exercise intervention. The primary outcomes are sleep quality measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index and pain severity measured by the Visual Analog Scale. Secondary outcomes include quality of life (WHOQOL-BREF), fatigue (Fatigue Scale), and perceived stress (Perceived Stress Scale). Assessments will be done at baseline and after the 6-week intervention period. The study aims to evaluate if the designed exercise program can improve pain and sleep quality in sickle cell disease patients.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group pragmatic trial investigating the effects of cognitive stimulation therapy (CST) on cognitive decline in patients with mild cognitive impairment or mild to moderate dementia. The trial has two arms: 1) Referral for CST, where physicians will review eligibility and offer referral for CST based on clinical judgment, and 2) Standard of care without CST referral. The primary outcome is clinically meaningful cognitive decline measured by an increase in Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA) score from baseline to 6-month follow-up. Secondary outcomes include cognitive improvement measured by MoCA score decrease, referral acceptance rate, participant attendance, and participant attrition from the CST program. The study aims to assess if CST referral can reduce cognitive decline and improve cognitive function in patients with mild cognitive impairment or dementia compared to standard care.

This clinical trial aimed to assess the levels of anxiety and depression in patients with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) and investigate the correlation between anxiety and the severity of reflux symptoms. The study was a prospective observational cohort study conducted at the University Hospital of Cologne, Germany, between January 2020 and July 2021.

Participants were patients referred to the Reflux and Swallowing Problems Center who underwent diagnostic tests, including esophagogastroduodenoscopy, 24-hour pH-metry, high-resolution manometry, and esophagography. Anxiety and depression levels were assessed using the Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS).

The study measured anxiety and depression levels during the diagnostic workup of patients with GERD. Patients were categorized as anxious or depressed based on their HADS scores, with scores ≥8 indicating anxiety or depression. The severity of anxiety and depression was further classified as mild, moderate, or severe.

The DeMeester score, a measure of esophageal acid exposure time, was used to differentiate between physiological and pathological reflux. The

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a self-guided, personalized treatment for women with disordered eating delivered through mobile technology. The study is designed as a single-arm, open-label intervention. Eligible participants are women aged 18-65 who endorse disordered eating symptoms, have access to a smartphone or tablet, and meet other inclusion criteria.

The intervention involves two weeks of self-monitoring using a smartphone app to identify target problems, followed by the delivery of two self-guided treatment modules tailored to the individual's needs directly to their smartphone. The primary outcome measures include changes in disordered eating symptoms (assessed by the EDE-Q6), anxiety (PSWQ), depression (BDI-2), clinical impairment (CIA), and quality of life (QOLS) over an 8-week period.

The study aims to explore the potential of personalized, self-guided treatment delivered through mobile technology for addressing disordered eating and associated symptoms in women.

This is a randomized, parallel-assignment clinical trial evaluating the effectiveness of the CAD-EYE system, an artificial intelligence-based device, for detecting neoplastic lesions during colorectal cancer screening in patients with Lynch syndrome. The trial has two arms: the experimental arm receives colorectal cancer screening with the CAD-EYE colonoscopy system, while the control arm receives standard indigo carmine chromoendoscopy. 

The primary outcome is the adenoma detection rate, comparing the CAD-EYE group to the indigo carmine group. Secondary outcomes include detection rates of specific lesions, diagnostic performance of CAD-EYE in characterizing polyps, feasibility of a "resect and discard" strategy based on CAD-EYE predictions, and procedure times.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18-90 with confirmed Lynch syndrome mutations, without conditions like inflammatory bowel disease or inadequate bowel preparation. The trial aims to assess the utility of the CAD-EYE system as a screening tool for colorectal neoplasia in this high-risk population.

This is a prospective observational study conducted across nine children's hospitals to evaluate the use of an enteral contrast-based protocol in the management of pediatric adhesive small bowel obstruction (ASBO). The study included children aged 1-20 years diagnosed with ASBO and undergoing non-operative management. Patients were divided into two groups: those who received an enteral contrast challenge (contrast group) and those who did not (no contrast group). The contrast protocol involved administering a water-soluble contrast agent (diatrizoate meglumine or ioversol) enterally, followed by X-rays at 8-12 hours and 24 hours to assess the progression of contrast to the colon. The primary outcome measure was the number of patients requiring an operation due to failure of non-operative management. Secondary outcomes included total hospital length of stay and adverse events related to contrast administration. The study aimed to enroll 314 patients and was powered to detect a 15% difference in operative rates between the two groups. Data were collected on patient demographics, clinical presentation, management approach, and hospital course. The study aimed to assess the utility of the enteral contrast protocol in guiding the

This is a Phase 1, single-center, open-label, randomized, parallel group, single-dose study to compare the pharmacokinetics of subcutaneous itepekimab administered with an autoinjector versus a prefilled syringe in healthy participants. The study aims to assess the primary pharmacokinetic parameters of itepekimab, including maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUClast and AUC), when administered via autoinjector or prefilled syringe. Secondary outcomes include time to reach Cmax (tmax), AUC0-28days, terminal half-life (t1/2), apparent total body clearance (CL/F), apparent volume of distribution at steady state (Vss/F), incidence of anti-itepekimab antibodies, and safety assessments such as adverse events, serious adverse events, and adverse events of special interest. The study includes two parallel arms: one receiving itepekimab via autoinjector and the other receiving itepekimab via prefilled syringe. Eligible participants are healthy adults aged 18-65 years.

This is a multi-site, open-label, randomized, three-arm, 8-week, prospective observational study to assess the relative impact of availability and use of different e-liquid flavors on changes in cigarette consumption among U.S. adult smokers. The study involves providing adult smokers aged 21-60 years with an electronic nicotine delivery system (ENDS) product called P12, which has 12 cartridge variants with different flavors (tobacco, menthol, and non-tobacco/non-menthol) and nicotine concentrations (1.5% and 5%). Participants will be randomized into one of three arms, each offering four flavor variants within a specific flavor category (tobacco, menthol, or non-tobacco/non-menthol). During a 6-week actual use period, participants can use the provided ENDS product and other tobacco/nicotine products ad libitum and self-report their product use daily via an eDiary. The primary outcomes are the number and proportion of participants who reduce their cigarettes per day by at least 50% at week 6 compared to baseline, and the mean percent reduction

This is a multicenter, randomized, open-label study comparing the efficacy of subcutaneous infliximab monotherapy with subcutaneous infliximab and concomitant immunosuppression in the treatment of moderate to severe Crohn's disease. The study aims to investigate if infliximab monotherapy is non-inferior to infliximab with immunosuppression in inducing corticosteroid-free clinical remission (CDAI<150) and endoscopic response (≥50% reduction in SES-CD) at week 26.

The study involves 158 patients with moderate to severe Crohn's disease, aged 18-80 years, who are starting infliximab treatment. Patients are randomized 1:1 to receive either:

1) Subcutaneous infliximab 240mg at weeks 0 and 2, then 120mg every other week (monotherapy group)
2) Subcutaneous infliximab 240mg at weeks 0 and 2, then 120mg every other week plus concomitant immunosuppressive agents (combination therapy group)

The primary

This is a pharmacokinetics study aimed at evaluating the pharmacokinetic profiles of the direct oral anticoagulants rivaroxaban and apixaban in adult cancer patients with venous thromboembolism or atrial fibrillation. The study will enroll cancer patients aged 18 years or older who are being treated with either rivaroxaban or apixaban. The primary outcome measure is the estimated area under the curve (AUC) of each drug, which will be used to assess their pharmacokinetic profiles. The secondary outcome measure is the occurrence of any thromboembolic events or major bleeding, which will be used to evaluate the safety of these drugs in this patient population. The study aims to identify factors that may influence the pharmacokinetics of rivaroxaban and apixaban in cancer patients, such as age, weight, renal function, and co-morbidities. The study is designed to provide real-world data on the use of these direct oral anticoagulants in cancer patients, as current guidelines suggest caution due to potential drug-drug interactions with anticancer therapies.

This is a randomized, triple-masked, crossover study evaluating bronchodilator response in patients with bronchiectasis. The primary objective is to determine if bronchodilator response, measured by changes in forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1) and forced vital capacity (FVC), is influenced by factors other than the direct effect of bronchodilators. Participants will undergo spirometry testing at baseline, 15 minutes after receiving either a bronchodilator (salbutamol) or placebo, and again 15 minutes after receiving the opposite intervention. The study will assess if bronchodilator response differs between bronchiectasis patients and healthy controls, and if it is associated with factors such as age, sex, specific bronchiectatic disease, baseline FEV1, use of inhaled steroids, history of allergy, pseudomonas infection, and bronchiectasis severity.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of gender identity, genetic sex, and hormone status on pain sensitivity, as well as the contributing social, psychological, and immunological factors. The study involves six groups: cisgender men, cisgender women, transgender men, transgender women, transgender men on testosterone replacement, and transgender women on estrogen replacement. Participants will undergo quantitative sensory testing, including heat, pressure, and cold stimuli, to assess pain thresholds and sensitivity. Blood samples will be collected to measure hormone levels and analyze immune cell populations and activity. Questionnaires will be administered to assess factors such as sleep quality, depression, social support, perceived discrimination, and quality of life. The study hypothesizes that gender identity, rather than genetic sex or hormone levels, will primarily influence pain sensitivity, and that social and psychological factors will also play a role. Additionally, the study aims to explore the relationship between hormone levels and immune cell populations and activity.

This is a feasibility study investigating the use of technology-enriched stroke rehabilitation during the acute and sub-acute phases after stroke. The study aims to assess the feasibility of implementing a technology-based rehabilitation model, which includes the use of robotics, adapted treadmills, virtual reality, and mobile digital devices, in an inpatient stroke unit at University Hospital Wishaw, Scotland.

Key aspects:

- Participants will be inpatients with a diagnosis of stroke, medically fit for rehabilitation, and able to provide informed consent.
- Participants will receive technology-enriched rehabilitation in addition to usual care, prescribed and supervised by NHS physiotherapists, occupational therapists, and speech and language therapists.
- The primary outcomes include duration of time spent on technology-enriched activities, movement repetitions, rates of recruitment and attrition, and adherence to sessions.
- Secondary outcomes include assessing the acceptability of the intervention through semi-structured interviews with participants, family/carers, and NHS staff.
- The study aims to bridge the gap between recommended levels of rehabilitation intensity and current NHS resources by incorporating rehabilitation technology.
- It is a mixed-methods feasibility study, following the Medical

This is a randomized, open-label, crossover clinical trial investigating the effect of immersive virtual reality (IVR) and music therapy on alleviating persistent dyspnea (respiratory discomfort) in amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) patients treated with non-invasive ventilation (NIV). The study aims to evaluate the impact of IVR, based on medical hypnosis, and music therapy on the sensory, affective, and emotional components of dyspnea in ALS patients with respiratory failure receiving NIV. Eligible participants will undergo two 15-minute sessions, one with IVR and one with music therapy, in a randomized order separated by 60 minutes. The primary outcome is the effect of IVR on respiratory discomfort measured by the A1 scale of the Multidimensional Dyspnea Profile (MDP) questionnaire. Secondary outcomes include evaluating the effects of IVR and music therapy on other components of dyspnea, comparing their evolutionary profiles, assessing patient preferences, and evaluating the acceptability of IVR. The study aims to explore therapeutic alternatives for persistent dyspnea

This is a randomized, parallel-group, double-blind study investigating the impact of selective reporting for antibiotic susceptibility testing on general practitioners' (GPs) prescribing of broad-spectrum antibiotics in women with Escherichia coli urinary tract infections (UTIs). The study involves two arms:

1. Intervention arm: GPs will receive an antibiotic susceptibility testing report with a list of antibiotics restricted according to four E. coli susceptibility profiles, emphasizing narrower-spectrum antibiotics for each positive E. coli urine culture analyzed. This selective reporting was developed through literature review and expert consultation.

2. Control arm: GPs will receive a standard antibiotic susceptibility testing report for each positive E. coli urine culture.

The primary outcome is the rate of broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing (amoxicillin/clavulanic acid, fluoroquinolones, third-generation cephalosporins) prescribed by GPs within 3 days before to 5 days after the susceptibility testing report, relative to the total number of urine cultures. Secondary outcomes include directed broad-spectrum antibiotic dispensing, anti

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial investigating whether sodium valproate, an anti-epileptic drug, can improve clinical outcomes in patients with acute ischemic stroke. The study aims to evaluate if sodium valproate can increase levels of anti-inflammatory CD177+ neutrophils and reduce neuroinflammation caused by infiltrated peripheral immune cells.

Patients aged 18-75 years with acute ischemic stroke within 24 hours of symptom onset, not eligible for thrombolysis or thrombectomy, will be randomly assigned to receive either low-dose (10mg/kg) or high-dose (20mg/kg) sodium valproate, or placebo (normal saline), intravenously for 3 consecutive days, in addition to conventional stroke treatment.

The primary outcome is the proportion of patients with a favorable outcome, defined as a modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score ≤2, at 90 days. Secondary outcomes include mRS score distribution at 30 and 90 days, NIH Stroke Scale scores, changes in lesion volume from baseline to day 7, and length of hospital stay.

The study aims to determine

This is a non-randomized, parallel assignment, open-label clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of a virtual coach (MyChart-enabled) compared to standard preoperative weight loss tools for weight reduction in obese patients scheduled for elective ventral hernia repair surgery. The primary outcome measure is the average net amount of weight change per group over 6 months. Secondary outcomes include the number of interactions with the virtual coach, quality of life measured by the HerQLes survey, and satisfaction with the virtual coach. Participants in the experimental arm will utilize the MyChart-enabled virtual coach, while those in the active comparator arm will use standard weight loss tools. The study includes obese adults aged 18-90 years scheduled for ventral hernia repair, excluding certain conditions like pregnancy, severe mental disorders, and substance use disorders.

This is a multicenter, randomized controlled, single-blind clinical trial to evaluate the safety and efficacy of nebulized umbilical cord mesenchymal stem cell-derived exosomes combined with conventional therapy for treating moderate, severe, and critically ill COVID-19 patients.

The study involves two parallel groups:
1) Experimental group receiving nebulized mesenchymal stem cell exosomes twice daily for 5 days along with conventional treatment. 
2) Control group receiving nebulized saline solution twice daily for 5 days along with conventional treatment.

The primary outcomes measured are symptom remission time, improvement in serum inflammatory markers, and CT scan comparison (if baseline available) over 3 months. Secondary outcomes include length of hospitalization and time to negative nucleic acid test over 3 months.

Eligibility criteria include age 18-75 years, moderate/severe/critical COVID-19 infection, positive nucleic acid/antigen test, and no prior treatment with mesenchymal stem cell exosomes. Exclusion criteria involve conditions like pregnancy, severe comorbidities, immunosuppression, allergies to treatment, and mental disorders

This clinical trial compares the effectiveness of calcium silicate-based sealers (CSS) and epoxy resin-based sealers (ERS) in single-visit root canal treatment for irreversible pulpitis. Eligible participants aged 18 or older with irreversible pulpitis and healthy periodontal tissue undergo randomization to receive either CSS or ERS after root canal preparation. The primary outcomes measured are changes in pain intensity, pain relief, and treatment outcome evaluation over time using self-assessment scales, clinical symptoms, and Strindberg's criteria at various time points up to 6 months post-treatment. The study aims to determine the clinical effectiveness of these two sealer types in managing irreversible pulpitis through single-visit endodontic treatment.

This is a multi-center, open, prospective cohort study aimed at evaluating the immunogenicity and immune persistence of two domestically produced bivalent HPV vaccines (Wozehui® and Cecolin®) compared to imported HPV vaccines in adolescent females aged 13-14 years. The study recruited 3,000 participants who had previously received either a domestic bivalent HPV vaccine (1,000 in Wozehui® group and 1,000 in Cecolin® group) or an imported HPV vaccine (1,000 participants). Blood samples were collected at 30-60 days, 12 months, and 36 months after the last vaccine dose to measure neutralizing antibody levels against HPV types 16 and 18. The primary outcomes were the geometric mean titers and antibody positivity rates for HPV 16 and 18 at baseline, 12-month, and 36-month follow-ups. The study aimed to evaluate the immunogenicity differences between the domestic and imported HPV vaccines in this age group.

This is a feasibility study evaluating the integration of a homeopathic approach as a supportive and palliative care option for cancer patients at a comprehensive cancer center in Israel. The study aims to assess:

1. Patients' main concerns for seeking homeopathic treatment.
2. Patient acceptance and adherence to the prescribed homeopathic remedies.
3. Subjective changes in quality of life and distress levels using validated questionnaires (MYCaW, Distress Thermometer, and ESAS-R) at initial evaluation and follow-up visits.

The study involves cancer patients aged 18 or older, with an ECOG performance status of 0-2, treated at the oncology division of Rambam Health Campus. Patients with psychosis, severe cognitive impairment, frailty, or unstable medical conditions are excluded.

The study is observational, with a single arm evaluating the feasibility of integrating a homeopathic approach as a supportive care option. The primary outcomes are the feasibility of the approach, assessed through questionnaires, and changes in quality of life and distress levels measured by validated questionn

This is a non-randomized, open-label, parallel assignment diagnostic study investigating septic thrombophlebitis on central venous catheters and midlines. The primary objective is to evaluate the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis from the day of diagnosis until disappearance, measured up to 90 days. Adult hospitalized patients with a central venous device or midline catheter and catheter-related bacteremia are eligible. The intervention group undergoes Doppler ultrasound assessments at days 8, 15, 30, 45, 60, and 90 to detect the presence of thrombosis, while the control group has no intervention. The primary outcome measure is the duration of ultrasound signs of septic thrombophlebitis from diagnosis until resolution, assessed up to day 90.

This is a Phase 3, open-label, randomized study comparing the efficacy and safety of odronextamab (an anti-CD20 x anti-CD3 bispecific antibody) in combination with lenalidomide versus rituximab in combination with lenalidomide in participants with relapsed/refractory follicular lymphoma and marginal zone lymphoma.

The study has two parts:

Part 1 (safety run-in): Participants with relapsed/refractory indolent lymphoma will receive odronextamab plus lenalidomide to evaluate dose-limiting toxicities and treatment-emergent adverse events.

Part 2: Participants will be randomized 1:1 to receive either odronextamab plus lenalidomide or rituximab plus lenalidomide, followed by lenalidomide monotherapy in the rituximab arm.

The primary outcome measures include incidence of dose-limiting toxicities, treatment-emergent adverse events, and progression-free survival assessed by independent central review. Secondary outcomes include overall response, duration of response, complete response, overall survival, event-free survival, time to next anti

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled parallel-group study investigating the effect of Proliverenol supplementation on liver function in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study involves four treatment arms: 1) 1 caplet of Proliverenol 500 mg twice daily, 2) 2 caplets of Proliverenol 500 mg once daily, 3) 2 caplets of Proliverenol 500 mg twice daily, and 4) placebo (2 caplets daily). Each treatment arm will have 20 subjects. The primary outcomes are changes in serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT) and aspartate aminotransferase (AST) levels from baseline to weeks 4, 8, and 12. Secondary outcomes include changes in controlled attenuation parameter (CAP), transient elastography (TE), and AST/ALT ratio. The study duration is 12 weeks, with assessments at baseline and every 4 weeks. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years or older with NAFLD diagnosed

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the impact of ozone application in the treatment of periodontitis. It is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study involving two groups: an experimental group receiving ozone therapy along with non-surgical periodontal treatment, and a control group receiving only non-surgical periodontal treatment.

The primary outcome measures are probing pocket depth, assessed at baseline and 3 months after treatment. Secondary outcomes include plaque index, gingival index, bleeding on probing, proportions of bacterial species (Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans, Porphyromonas gingivalis, Prevotella intermedia, Tannerella forsythia), and inflammatory parameter levels (tumor necrosis factor-alpha, interleukin-1beta, interleukin-6, interleukin-8) in gingival crevicular fluid, measured at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months.

The study includes systemically healthy adults aged 18-65 years with periodontitis, excluding smokers, pregnant or lactating individuals, and those with certain dental conditions or recent antibiotic/

This clinical trial aims to investigate the expression of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in pterygium tissue. The study will enroll 60 patients with pterygium and collect conjunctival samples from 30 patients as a control group. The participants will be divided into three groups: control group (normal conjunctiva from 30 patients), group 2 (primary pterygia samples from 30 patients), and group 3 (recurrent pterygia samples from 30 patients). The study will use immunohistochemical staining techniques to evaluate the expression levels of CD44, PCNA, and E-cadherin in the pterygium tissue samples. The primary outcome measure is the immunohistochemistry analysis, which will be performed on thin sections of paraffin-embedded tissue samples using primary antibodies against CD44, E-cadherin, and PCNA. The findings will be reported using a Nikon light microscope and an image analysis system. Statistical analyses will be conducted using IBM SPSS version 26.0.

This clinical trial, titled "TINO: Identifying the Underlying Mechanisms and Consequences of the Loss of Nasal T Cells in Vital and Frail Older Individuals," aims to investigate the frequency, phenotype, functionality, transcriptomics, and clonality of nasal and blood T cell populations in young adults, healthy older adults, and frail older adults with or without recurrent respiratory tract infections.

The study involves three participant groups: young adults aged 18-30 years, healthy elderly aged >65 years, and frail elderly aged >65 years. The primary outcome measure is the frequency of nasal CD8+ T cells in young adults and frail older adults. Secondary outcomes include phenotyping, functionality, transcriptomics, and clonality of nasal and blood T cell populations, as well as comparisons between the groups, cytokine and metabolite concentrations, microbiota profiles, viral infections, and the effect of sex on aging immune populations.

Participants will provide nasal and blood samples at baseline and, for a subset, at 3 months. If respiratory symptoms develop within 3 months, additional samples will be collected at sympt

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the usefulness of platelet-to-lymphocyte ratio (PLR) and monocyte-to-lymphocyte ratio (MLR) as predictors of response to treatment in cirrhotic patients with spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP). SBP is a serious complication of ascites in cirrhotic patients, characterized by an acute infection of the ascitic fluid. The study involves diagnostic testing of ascitic fluid in cirrhotic patients with untreated SBP. The primary outcome measure is the ability of PLR and MLR to predict response to treatment in these patients over a period of approximately one year. The study excludes patients with non-cirrhotic ascites, tuberculous peritonitis, secondary bacterial peritonitis, sepsis, unrelated infections, those already on treatment for SBP or prophylactic antibiotics, and those with hepatocellular carcinoma or other malignancies/immunological diseases. Participants aged 15-100 years of both sexes with liver cirrhosis (Child-Pugh class B or C) are eligible for the study.

This is a prospective observational study evaluating the added diagnostic value of point-of-care ultrasound (POCUS) in adult patients presenting to the emergency department with acute dyspnea. The study aims to assess whether POCUS performed by emergency medicine physicians (specialists and residents) increases diagnostic accuracy compared to routine assessment alone.

Key aspects:

- Study population: Adult patients presenting to the emergency department with acute dyspnea, meeting specific triage criteria.
- Intervention: Emergency physicians will perform a structured POCUS protocol including focused lung, heart, and inferior vena cava ultrasound examinations.
- Procedure: Physicians will first assess the patient using routine diagnostic procedures and estimate the likelihood of specific diagnoses (e.g., heart failure, pulmonary embolism, pneumonia). After performing POCUS, they will re-estimate the likelihood of these diagnoses.
- Outcome measures: The primary outcome is the discharge diagnosis, including conditions such as decompensated heart failure, pulmonary embolism, COPD exacerbation, asthma exacerbation, pneumonia, pleural fluid, and pericardial fluid.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the use of respiratory training and relaxation techniques to improve deep inspiration breath hold (DIBH) during adjuvant radiation therapy for left-sided breast cancer patients. The primary aim is to reduce the maximum radiation dose (Dmax) to the heart by enhancing patients' ability to perform DIBH through training and relaxation interventions.

The trial has two arms: 
1) Experimental arm: Patients receive respiratory training, relaxation techniques (e.g., music, nature sounds), and encouragement for daily practice starting one week before radiation planning CT scan. 
2) Standard arm: Patients receive conventional DIBH instruction without extended training.

The primary outcome is the change in Dmax to the heart during radiation treatment. Secondary outcomes include quality of life, mean radiation doses to heart and other cardiac structures, clinic workflow metrics, patient satisfaction, and doses to other organs at risk.

Standardized questionnaires are used to assess quality of life, satisfaction, and well-being at multiple timepoints (baseline, during treatment, 6-week follow-up). The goal is to develop an integrative training regimen to improve cardiac dose reduction and overall health in

This is a Phase IB open-label, single-arm study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy of the combination of canakinumab, tislelizumab, nab-paclitaxel, and gemcitabine as neoadjuvant treatment in patients with resectable or borderline resectable pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. The primary objectives are to determine the dose-limiting toxicities and the number of patients who proceed to surgical resection after receiving the quadruplet regimen for up to 4 cycles. Secondary objectives include assessing overall response rate, R0 resection rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, and any delays or changes in surgical outcome attributed to the study treatment. Eligible patients are adults with previously untreated, localized pancreatic cancer deemed suitable for surgical resection. The study aims to evaluate the safety and potential benefit of adding immunotherapies canakinumab and tislelizumab to standard chemotherapy prior to surgery in this patient population.

This clinical trial aims to develop and test an innovative digital tool called "Connected for Wellness" to support mental health navigation and improve access to mental health services for youth aged 13-22 years. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Co-design the Connected for Wellness app with youth, caregivers, clinicians, and stakeholders using participatory design and community-partnered participatory research approaches.

2. The app will use algorithms to provide personalized mental health and social determinants resources, resiliency tools, and navigation activities.

3. Implement and evaluate two mental health navigation models (family and youth navigation) along with the Connected for Wellness app.

4. Assess the effectiveness of the intervention in improving connections and access to prevention resources, mental health services, and social supports for youth and families.

5. The study will be conducted in 10 Los Angeles County schools and 10 Riverside County/University of California Riverside primary care clinics, serving predominantly Black, Latino, and Asian youth.

6. A stepped-wedge design will be used, with sites randomized to cross over from control (usual care) to intervention (navigator plus app) at different time points

This is a double-blinded, randomized, comparative clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of intramyometrial tranexamic acid injection versus intramyometrial oxytocin injection in reducing blood loss during and after elective cesarean section in term primigravida women. The study will be conducted at Kasr Al-Ainy Maternity Hospital, Cairo University, Egypt, from October 2021 to October 2022. A total of 50 women will be randomly allocated to receive either 1g tranexamic acid or 5IU oxytocin injected into the uterine cornu before placental delivery. The primary outcome is to assess intraoperative and postoperative blood loss up to 24 hours after cesarean section. The secondary outcome is the need for additional uterotonics within 2 hours. The study aims to evaluate which intervention, tranexamic acid or oxytocin, is more effective in reducing blood loss and the risk of postpartum hemorrhage after cesarean delivery in primigravida women at term.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment study investigating the use of the ReceptIVFity test, a vaginal microbiome swab, in women undergoing IVF or IVF/ICSI treatment. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of using shared decision-making based on the ReceptIVFity test results versus postponing treatment until a favorable microbiome profile is achieved.

The study includes two experimental arms: 1) Shared-Decision-Making group, where treatment decisions are made based on the ReceptIVFity test results and predicted chance of pregnancy, and 2) Physician decision group, where treatment is postponed until a favorable microbiome profile is observed.

The primary outcomes include the rate of successful pregnancy (positive heartbeat at 12 weeks), the number of successful IVF/IVF-ICSI cycles, and the total number of treatment cycles per patient. Secondary outcomes include patient satisfaction scores, total treatment costs, and pregnancy rates in non-European women (observational part).

The study targets women aged 18-42 years undergoing IVF or IVF-ICSI treatment, excluding those

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the lipid-lowering effect of fenugreek seed tea in patients with hyperlipidemia but without diabetes. The study aims to recruit 114 participants aged 18-70 years with high triglyceride levels (1.7-4.5 mmol/L), who will be randomly assigned to receive either fenugreek seed tea (5g/day, consumed as 2.5g twice daily for 8 weeks) or a control black tea. The primary outcome is the change in serum triglyceride levels after 8 weeks. Secondary outcomes include changes in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, non-HDL cholesterol, HDL cholesterol, apolipoprotein B, and plasma microRNAs (miR-122 and miR-34a) as potential biomarkers. Study visits will be conducted at baseline, 4 weeks, and 8 weeks to collect demographic information, anthropometric measurements, blood pressure, and fasting blood samples. The study aims to investigate the lipid-lowering potential of fenugreek seed tea and establish non-invasive therapeutic biomarkers

This is a prospective, randomized, open-label clinical trial investigating the role of pioglitazone in vascular transcriptional remodeling in individuals undergoing coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG). The study aims to enroll 20 male participants aged over 40 years, non-diabetic or with diabetes duration less than 10 years, and meeting specific eligibility criteria. Participants will be randomized to receive either pioglitazone hydrochloride 45mg/day for 5 days before CABG surgery or no intervention. The primary outcome measure is the change in S1P content of isolated HDL between baseline and after pioglitazone treatment. Secondary outcomes include differences in SPHK1 and S1PR1 expression in various vascular tissues (internal thoracic artery, saphenous vein, aortic artery, and atrial appendage) between the groups. The study aims to investigate the role of pioglitazone in vascular transcriptional remodeling and its potential effects on myocardial reperfusion injury.

This was a single-dose, randomized, open-label, five-treatment, five-period, five-sequence crossover study to assess the pharmacodynamics and pharmacokinetics of three new developed coated glucose bead formulations (containing 8g glucose and caffeine), one coated glucose bead formulation (containing 8g glucose), and one uncoated glucose bead formulation (containing 8g glucose and caffeine) in 20 obese healthy subjects under fasting conditions. The study evaluated the effects of these formulations on glucagon-like peptide-1 (GLP-1) levels, caffeine pharmacokinetics, glucose pharmacokinetics, appetite, stomach rumbles, and safety parameters like ECG, vital signs, lab tests, physical examination, and adverse events. Blood samples were collected at various timepoints up to 10 hours post-dose for measuring GLP-1, caffeine, and glucose levels. Subjects underwent a screening process and were randomized to receive the five formulations in different sequences across five treatment periods separated by washout periods.

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of using different types of strips (celluloid matrix, chewing gum, and fruit leather) in reducing the palatoglossal air space shadow error during panoramic radiography. The study involved 270 patients aged 15 years and above, who were randomly assigned to three groups: celluloid matrix group (90 patients), chewing gum strip group (90 patients), and control group (90 patients). Patients in the intervention groups were instructed to place the respective strips on their tongues and hold them against the palate during panoramic imaging. An oral and maxillofacial radiologist assessed the panoramic radiographs in a single-blinded manner to identify and record the palatoglossal air space shadow errors. The radiographs were classified as diagnostically acceptable, unacceptable, or excellent based on the degree of the error. The study aimed to investigate the effectiveness of using these simple and inexpensive strips in reducing the most common error in panoramic imaging, thereby improving the diagnostic quality of the radiographs.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the acute effects of extracorporeal shock wave therapy (ESWT), ESWT combined with Kinesio Taping (KT), and placebo ESWT on pain severity, lower extremity functionality, and plantar fascia flexibility in patients with plantar fasciitis. The study involves three groups: ESWT group receiving a single session of ESWT, ESWT+KT group receiving ESWT followed by KT application for a week, and a placebo/sham group receiving simulated ESWT without the device operating. The primary outcome measure is the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) for pain assessment, and the secondary outcome measure is the Lower Extremity Functional Scale. Assessments are conducted at baseline and one week after treatment. The study includes adults aged 18-65 years diagnosed with plantar fasciitis, excluding those with foot/ankle surgery, sensory deficits, communication difficulties, pregnancy, local infection, tumors, circulatory disorders, bleeding, anticoagulant use, or history of systemic, inflammatory, neurological, or vascular diseases.

This clinical trial aims to establish a Couple Intervention Program for adults with Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). The study involves a single group of couples where either one partner has an ASD diagnosis or scores above 26 on the Autism Spectrum Quotient. The intervention is a couple group therapy that focuses on communication skills, emotion acknowledgment, teamwork, and cooperation. The primary outcome measures include the Autism Diagnostic Observation Schedule (ADOS), Autism Spectrum Quotient (AQ), Empathy Quotient (EQ), Social Responsiveness Scale (SRS), and Quality of Socialization Questionnaire (QSQ), which are assessed at 6 weeks. The study is designed as a single-group, open-label intervention with the primary purpose of treatment. Eligible participants are adults aged 20-60 years without psychiatric disorders or communication impairments.

This is a randomized controlled study investigating the effects of an individually tailored physical exercise program on patients with postural orthostatic tachycardia syndrome (POTS) following COVID-19 infection. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the exercise intervention on time spent in an upright position, health-related quality of life, physical activity, physical and psychological function, and work ability in these patients.

The study will recruit 60 adult patients diagnosed with POTS after COVID-19. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an intervention group receiving a 16-week individually tailored exercise program supervised by a physiotherapist once a week, or a control group receiving standard care. Various outcome measures will be assessed, including time in upright position, quality of life, walking distance, oxygen saturation, dyspnea, fatigue, anxiety, depression, POTS symptoms, physical function, blood pressure and heart rate responses, physical activity, orthostatic symptoms, insomnia, work ability, muscle strength, post-exertional malaise, and pharmacological treatment.

Measurements will be taken at baseline, after the 16-week intervention period, and at 6 and 12

The BRANT study is a multicenter, randomized, open-label, blinded endpoint, parallel-controlled trial investigating the efficacy and safety of tirofiban in patients with acute branch atheromatous disease (BAD)-related stroke. The primary objective is to determine whether intravenous tirofiban (a loading dose of 0.4ug/kg/min for 30 minutes followed by a maintenance dose of 0.1ug/kg/min for 47.5 hours), initiated within 48 hours of stroke onset, increases the proportion of excellent functional outcome (modified Rankin Scale score 0-1) at 90 days compared to standard antiplatelet therapy based on guidelines (aspirin or aspirin plus clopidogrel for 48 hours). Patients aged 18-75 years with acute BAD-related stroke meeting specific diagnostic imaging criteria will be enrolled and randomized 1:1 to either the tirofiban or standard antiplatelet therapy group. The primary efficacy outcome is excellent functional outcome at 90 days, and the primary safety outcome is the proportion of major bleeding at 90 days. Secondary outcomes include early neurological

This is a clinical trial studying the effects of personalized pacemaker lower rate settings on quality of life and other outcomes in patients with sinus node dysfunction (SND). The trial has two arms: a personalized lower rate (PLR) group where the pacemaker lower rate is set at 75 bpm and may be adjusted based on the physician's assessment, and a control group with a fixed lower rate of 60 bpm. The primary outcome measure is quality of life assessed using the SF-36 questionnaire within three months after pacemaker implantation. Secondary outcomes include left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF) and 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure measurements to evaluate the correlation between elevated blood pressure and bradycardia. The study includes patients aged 60 years or older with SND, resting heart rate ≤60 bpm, and hypertension, but excludes those with heart failure, atrial fibrillation, organic heart disease, and other specified conditions.

This is a randomized controlled study investigating the effect of remote diagnosis and treatment on 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure rhythm in patients with obstructive sleep apnea (OSA). The study aims to compare the improvement in 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure after 3 months of automatic continuous positive airway pressure (APAP) treatment between a telemedicine group and an outpatient group. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the telemedicine group, where they receive remote diagnosis and treatment, or the outpatient group, where they receive in-person treatment at a sleep center. The primary outcome measure is the change in 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure, including mean blood pressure, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and rhythm pattern analysis. Secondary outcomes include APAP treatment compliance, sleep apnea-related dysfunction, sleepiness symptoms, blood lipids and fasting blood glucose, and cost-effectiveness analysis. The study will also explore the mechanism of APAP treatment in improving blood pressure rhythm and evaluate the response of different OSA subtypes to blood pressure improvement after APAP treatment.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the influence of communication between nursing staff and patients on analgesic response following caesarean section. The study will be conducted at Carmel Hospital's maternity ward, involving 80 female patients aged 18-50 undergoing elective caesarean section under spinal anesthesia. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an enhanced communication arm or a normal communication arm. In the enhanced communication arm, nurses will provide positive reinforcement about the efficacy of the analgesic medication during administration. The primary outcome measure is the change in pain intensity on a 0-10 scale, one hour after analgesic administration. Personality traits related to self-consciousness and suggestibility will also be assessed using validated scales. The study aims to determine if positive communication from nursing staff can improve analgesic response and pain relief in post-operative patients.

This is a clinical trial aimed at assessing novel biomarkers in participants undergoing targeted lung health checks for lung cancer. The study includes adults aged between 55 and 74 years who attended the NHS Targeted Lung Health Check (TLHC) programme and have the capacity to provide written consent. The primary outcome measure is to identify novel molecular, immune, and clinical biomarkers to improve the sensitivity and specificity of lung cancer screening beyond conventional risk prediction models and low-dose CT scanning. This will be achieved through proteomics, metabolomics, genomics, and immune repertoire characterization performed on peripheral blood samples over a period of 5 years.

This is a randomized clinical trial evaluating the effectiveness of telepharmacy compared to in-person pharmaceutical care on clinical outcomes of elderly patients with uncontrolled hypertension. The primary outcome is the rate of patients achieving blood pressure control targets after 3 months. Secondary outcomes include adherence to treatment, patient satisfaction, and the clinical significance of pharmacist interventions. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either telepharmacy-based pharmaceutical care or in-person pharmaceutical care, in addition to usual care. The study aims to characterize the patient population, compare acceptance and clinical importance of interventions between the two groups, evaluate adherence and satisfaction, and compare satisfaction between groups. Eligible participants are elderly patients aged 60 or above with uncontrolled hypertension, access to a cell phone, and no previous pharmaceutical care. The study findings may inform the use of telepharmacy services for hypertension management in the elderly population.

This is a prospective, international, multicenter observational study investigating the relationship between implementation of evidence-based and supportive intensive care unit (ICU) care and outcomes of patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study aims to:

1. Evaluate the current epidemiology and treatment strategies for ARDS patients after the COVID-19 pandemic. 
2. Assess compliance with lung-protective ventilation strategies within the first two weeks of ICU admission.
3. Determine the implementation rates of the ABCDEF bundle (a bundle of evidence-based ICU care practices) and its components within the first two weeks.
4. Examine the incidence of post-intensive care syndrome (PICS), including physical, cognitive, and mental health impairments, at 3 months after hospital discharge.

The primary outcomes are mortality at hospital discharge, compliance with lung-protective ventilation, implementation of the ABCDEF bundle, and incidence of PICS at 3 months. The study will enroll patients aged 16 years and older who are on invasive or non-invasive ventilation within 24 hours of ICU admission, expected to require vent

This is a randomized, parallel, placebo-controlled, single-center, triple-blind clinical trial investigating the effect of two doses of Pomanox® pomegranate extract on skin aging in women aged 30-65 years. The study has three arms: 367 mg Pomanox® group, 700 mg Pomanox® group, and a placebo control group receiving maltodextrin. The primary outcome is change in skin melanin index, and secondary outcomes include changes in wrinkles, hydration, elasticity, erythema, pores, acne, keratin, collagen and hyaluronic acid metabolism markers, oxidative stress markers, anti-glycan effect markers, inflammatory markers, intestinal and skin microbiota composition, and urinary metabolites of Pomanox®. Participants will undergo assessments at baseline, day 29, and day 85 of the 12-week intervention period. The study aims to evaluate the potential beneficial effects of Pomanox® on various aspects of skin aging through its proposed mechanisms of action.

This is a non-randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial investigating the effects of prostate medications on gut microbiota and metabolic characteristics in men with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and prostate cancer.

The study has two arms:

1. BPH arm (n=50): Participants will receive 5-alpha-reductase inhibitors (finasteride, dutasteride, or a combination of dutasteride and tamsulosin) for BPH treatment. Gut microbiota and metabolite samples will be collected before and 2 months after starting medication. Prostate size and PSA levels will be measured at baseline, 2 months, and 6 months.

2. Prostate cancer arm (n=50): Participants will receive androgen deprivation therapy (ADT) with the LHRH antagonist degarelix. Gut microbiota and metabolite samples will be collected before and 2 months after starting ADT. PSA levels will be measured at baseline, 2 months, and 6 months.

The primary outcomes are gut microbiota signatures before and after

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) and other MRI techniques as markers for glioma genomics. The study involves two groups of participants: 1) those with suspected grade II/III glioma scheduled for surgical resection, and 2) those with histologically confirmed grade II or III glioma with known IDH1/IDH2 status, who have not received any treatment other than surgery and are about to start a non-surgical treatment.

The primary outcome measure is the correlation between the concentrations of 2-hydroxyglutarate and cystathionine measured by MRS and the IDH mutational status and 1p19q codeletion status derived from tumor tissue samples. Secondary outcomes include the correlation of diffusion MRI metrics with 1p19q codeletion status, and the changes in metabolite concentrations, diffusion MRI metrics, and amide proton transfer signal during anti-tumor treatment, compared to changes in tumor volumes and clinical response.

The study involves a single group assignment with an MRI examination without contrast agent. The primary purpose is basic science, and the study is open-label with no

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the long-term efficacy and safety of combining hydroxyurea and thalidomide in the treatment of beta-thalassemia patients. The study involves administering hydroxyurea monotherapy for 6 months, followed by the addition of thalidomide to the treatment regimen. The primary outcomes measured include the frequency of good responders, responders, and non-responders, as well as changes in laboratory levels (hemoglobin, platelets, leukocytes, urea, creatinine, and ferritin) and changes in liver and spleen size over a period of 1 to 3 years on combination therapy. The secondary outcome is the comparison of XmnI polymorphism with treatment response. The study includes specific inclusion and exclusion criteria for participant eligibility, with ages ranging from 2 to 50 years. Safety parameters, such as renal function, liver function, and blood cell counts, are closely monitored, and the intervention may be discontinued or put on hold if certain thresholds are exceeded.

This is a study aimed at determining the current practices and diagnostic approaches for patients presenting with suspected venous leg ulcers in primary care and vascular scientist departments across the UK. The study involves two components:

1. A one-off questionnaire for primary care practitioners to assess the current practice in primary care for venous leg ulcer management and availability of services for onward referral.

2. A Delphi consensus questionnaire for vascular scientists to determine the current practice for diagnosis and management of suspected venous leg ulcers in vascular scientist departments across the UK.

The primary outcomes measured are:

1. For primary care practitioners: Determining the current practice in primary care for venous leg ulcer management and availability of services for onward referral through a qualitative analysis of responses to a multiple-choice and free-text questionnaire.

2. For vascular scientists: Achieving a 70% consensus on the current practice for diagnosis and management of suspected venous leg ulcers through three rounds of online questionnaires.

The study aims to establish the minimum diagnostics required for patients with suspected venous leg ulcers, including the appropriate scans and criteria to be applied. Additionally, it seeks

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of a virtual reality (VR) intervention on substance use and related outcomes in individuals in early recovery from stimulant use disorders. The study has two arms: an experimental group receiving a VR experience with an avatar resembling themselves in a park setting, and a control group receiving only a VR park experience without an avatar. The primary outcomes measured include reduced drug use days, increased length of abstinence periods, increased overall abstinence, increased future self-identification, increased future time perspective, and increased preference for delayed rewards. These outcomes are assessed at the study day visit, 30-day follow-up, and 6-month follow-up. The study aims to evaluate whether the VR avatar experience can enhance prospective thinking and improve recovery outcomes in individuals with stimulant use disorders.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial comparing the stability and performance of short (6mm) dental implants versus standard length (10mm) implants placed with an internal sinus floor elevation procedure in the posterior maxilla (upper jaw) region with limited bone height. The study aims to evaluate the crestal bone level around the implants after 1 year using standardized radiographs. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-60 years with a single edentulous (missing tooth) site in the posterior maxilla, having 7-8mm residual bone height below the maxillary sinus. The study has two parallel arms: one receiving short 6mm implants, and the other receiving standard 10mm implants along with an internal sinus lift procedure. The primary outcome measure is the crestal bone level around the implants assessed radiographically at 1 year post-operatively.

This is a phase I dose escalation study investigating the use of Wharton's Jelly Mesenchymal Stromal Cell (WJ-MSC) infusions as prophylaxis for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) in patients undergoing haploidentical allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The primary objective is to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of WJ-MSC infusions, defined as the highest dose level where no more than 1 out of 6 patients experiences dose-limiting toxicity within 7 days after any of the 3 weekly infusions. Key secondary outcomes include incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, transplant-related mortality, relapse incidence, overall survival, GVHD and relapse-free survival, and poor graft function at 12 months. Eligible patients have hematological malignancies requiring allogeneic transplant but lack a matched related donor, with specified inclusion/exclusion criteria related to disease status, organ function, and comorbidities.

This clinical trial aims to rapidly deploy and evaluate the impact of a machine learning-based clinical decision support tool called eCARTv5 for identifying hospitalized patients at increased risk for intensive care unit (ICU) transfer and death. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. eCARTv5 is a gradient boosted machine learning model trained on a multi-center dataset of over 800,000 patient records, with 97 variables, to predict clinical deterioration.

2. The trial will implement eCARTv5 in the electronic health records (EHRs) of multiple medical-surgical units across different hospitals.

3. The intervention arm will have eCARTv5 actively monitoring adult medical-surgical patients, while the control arm will follow standard care without eCARTv5.

4. The primary outcome measure is hospital mortality for patients identified as high-risk by eCARTv5.

5. Secondary outcomes include total hospital length of stay, ICU-free days, and ventilator-free days for high-risk patients.

6. The study hypothesizes that implementing eCARTv5 will be associated with decreased

The African-American Social Support Effectiveness Treatment-Partners Alleviating Perinatal Depression (ASSET-PPD) is a pilot randomized controlled trial aimed at reducing perinatal depression in African-American mothers by involving and training their partners (fathers or non-romantic partners). The study will enroll 50 parent dyads (100 individuals), with mothers receiving psychiatric treatment for depression and fathers randomized to either the ASSET-PPD intervention or a control group.

The ASSET-PPD intervention consists of four prenatal modules and two postpartum review sessions for fathers, focusing on increasing their prenatal and postpartum family involvement, mental health psychoeducation, interparental communication and relationship skills, and balanced division of family tasks. The intervention is based on stress-generation and cognitive-behavioral theories.

The primary outcomes are maternal depression (measured by the Inventory of Depressive Symptoms-Self-Rated) and maternal anxiety (measured by the Generalized Anxiety Disorder-7-item scale). Secondary outcomes include breastfeeding (assessed by the FeedCat Tool), infant affect and mood regulation (measured by the Infant Behavior Questionnaire-Revised),

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study evaluating a digital mental health intervention (Moodivate app) for addressing unmet psychosocial needs and depressive symptoms in individuals living with cancer. The study aims to assess the feasibility of proactively identifying and recruiting eligible participants, as well as the preliminary efficacy of the Moodivate app, which is based on behavioral activation therapy principles.

Participants will be adults with cancer, elevated depressive symptoms (PHQ-9 score ≥10), and willingness to use a mobile app. They will be randomized to either the Moodivate app intervention or a treatment-as-usual control group receiving educational materials about mood management.

The Moodivate app focuses on tracking daily activities, recording daily mood, identifying values, and scheduling activities to improve mood. Participants in both groups will complete weekly questionnaires for 4 weeks, with the Moodivate group having an additional follow-up at 12 weeks.

The primary outcome measure is the proportion of eligible participants who enroll in the study, assessing the feasibility of the proactive identification and recruitment approach.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate algorithms for detecting insulin pump malfunctions in individuals with type 1 diabetes using an automated insulin delivery (AID) system. The study consists of three phases:

1. Preliminary Data Collection: Participants use their AID system in free-living conditions for one month to collect data on glycemic trends and insulin administration.

2. Induction of Hyperglycemia: Participants visit the clinic, where insulin infusion is temporarily suspended according to a protocol, simulating a pump malfunction. The resulting hyperglycemic episode is closely monitored under medical supervision.

3. Retrospective Data Analysis: The collected data is analyzed to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithms in detecting insulin suspension (simulating a pump malfunction).

The primary outcome measure is the sensitivity of the tested algorithms in correctly detecting insulin suspensions. The secondary outcome measure is the number of false alarms per day during the baseline pre-intervention phase.

The study includes adults aged 18-70 years with type 1 diabetes, treated with an AID system for at least 3 months, and meeting specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to their health status and diabetes management.

This is an open-label, single-group study to evaluate the effect of Funk It Cycle Bites, a dietary supplement, on premenstrual syndrome (PMS) symptoms in women aged 18-40 years. The study will enroll female participants who experience mild to moderate menstrual pain, mood swings, and/or hormonal acne related to their menstrual cycle. Participants will consume one Cycle Bite per day for 4 months. The primary outcomes measured include changes in PMS symptoms, acne, pain levels (including menstrual cramps), mood stability, and energy levels, assessed through various survey-based tools. Secondary outcomes include participant enjoyment of the product. The study aims to investigate the potential benefits of Funk It Cycle Bites in alleviating PMS-related symptoms in women with regular menstrual cycles.

This is a parallel cluster randomized trial assessing the (cost)effectiveness of using a personalized risk assessment tool (PERSARC) in treatment decisions for high-grade extremity soft-tissue sarcoma patients compared to standard care. The primary outcomes are decisional conflict and informed choice measured one week after the treatment decision. Secondary outcomes include decision regret, cancer worry, involvement in decision-making, patient-reported outcomes, utilities for cost-effectiveness analysis, healthcare costs, and productivity costs measured at various timepoints up to 12 months. The study will enroll at least 120 adult patients with newly diagnosed high-grade extremity soft-tissue sarcoma across 6 Dutch hospitals, which will be randomized to either use PERSARC during multidisciplinary tumor boards and patient consultations (intervention) or provide standard care (control). A process evaluation will assess the use, satisfaction, barriers and facilitators of PERSARC integration.

This is a cross-sectional epidemiological study and a randomized controlled trial investigating the prevalence of early childhood caries (ECC) in Jordanian children attending kindergartens, its associated risk factors, and the effectiveness of silver diamine fluoride (SDF) as a caries control material. The study involved 887 children aged 3-5 years who were examined for ECC prevalence and completed questionnaires on demographic, socioeconomic, oral hygiene, oral health, nursing, and nutritional habits. A subset of 159 children with ECC were randomly assigned to either receive a single application of 38% SDF (study group) or no intervention (control group). The primary outcomes measured were ECC prevalence, prevention of new cavities, and arrest of existing cavities after one year. Secondary outcomes included risk factors for ECC and parental acceptance of SDF application. The study aimed to report the prevalence of ECC in Jordanian children, identify associated risk factors, and determine the effectiveness and acceptance of SDF as a caries control measure.

This is a retrospective study evaluating the effectiveness of Pfizer's ABRYSVO vaccine against severe respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) infection in older adults. The primary objective is to estimate the vaccine's effectiveness against RSV-related lower respiratory tract infections requiring hospitalization among eligible individuals. The study employs a test-negative design and a retrospective cohort design. The test-negative design assesses RSV-related outcomes, while the cohort design evaluates all-cause outcomes and may also assess RSV-related outcomes. Standard RSV testing and re-testing of remnant specimens will be used to define RSV-related endpoints. Secondary objectives include estimating vaccine effectiveness against various RSV-related and all-cause respiratory outcomes, such as hospitalizations, emergency department visits, and deaths, stratified by factors like age, frailty, and comorbidities. The study aims to provide insights into the vaccine's performance in preventing severe RSV infections in older adults.

The OSsIRIS Study is a post-market clinical follow-up investigation to confirm the performance and safety of the bone substitute b.Bone in extremities and pelvis. The study aims to treat surgically created bone defects or bone defects/voids resulting from traumatic injury using b.Bone as a bone grafting material to promote healing in the pelvis, upper and lower extremities.

Key aspects:

- Inclusion criteria: Patients undergoing standard bone grafting with b.Bone for defects in extremities and pelvis, aged ≥18 years, willing to attend follow-ups.
- Exclusion criteria: Conditions where b.Bone is contraindicated, enrolled in interfering studies, pregnant/breastfeeding, inability to complete questionnaires or attend follow-ups.
- Intervention: Bone grafting with b.Bone, used alone or as a graft expander, in conjunction with fixation devices.
- Primary outcome: Radiographic healing/union after surgery, evaluated by modified radiographic scales.
- Secondary outcomes: Patient-reported pain, quality of life, adverse events, reinterventions.
- Study

This is a 1-year prospective cohort study investigating the prognostic significance of acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness in patients with acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF). The primary objective is to study the change in liver and splenic stiffness values at day 7 from baseline (day 1) between those with or without transplant-free survival at day 90. Secondary objectives include evaluating the association of baseline and changes in liver and splenic stiffness with various factors such as etiology of ACLF, severity scores, organ failures, inflammatory markers, and esophageal varices. The study plans to enroll 200 consecutive ACLF patients aged 18-70 years. Liver and splenic stiffness will be measured using Fibroscan at days 1, 7, and 14, along with other clinical assessments and laboratory tests. The study aims to determine if acute changes in liver and splenic stiffness can predict transplant-free survival and explore their associations with different aspects of ACLF.

This is a randomized, triple-blinded, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of two different injection depths of onabotulinumtoxinA (Botox) for the treatment of glabellar frown lines.

The study aims to compare the effectiveness of injecting onabotulinumtoxinA at a depth of 2mm (superficial dermis) versus 4mm (intramuscularly) in improving glabellar lines. Participants aged 18 and older with glabellar frown lines will be randomly assigned to receive a single administration of onabotulinumtoxinA injected at either 2mm or 4mm depth into the corrugator supercilii muscles bilaterally.

The primary outcome measure is the improvement in glabellar lines assessed using the Merz Aesthetics Scale (0-4 scale) at 120 days after treatment. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of adverse effects and a comparison of efficacy between the two injection depths.

The study aims to determine if a more superficial injection depth of 2mm is as effective as the deeper 4mm injection for treating glabel

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study investigating the use of music therapy as a tool for reducing anxiety in patients with localized breast cancer undergoing adjuvant or neoadjuvant chemotherapy. The study has two arms: an experimental arm receiving music therapy before the first 3 chemotherapy cycles, and a control arm receiving standard care without any intervention. The primary outcome measure is the change in anxiety levels, assessed using the State Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) score, before the first and third chemotherapy sessions over a 5-month period. The study includes female patients aged 18 years or older with localized breast cancer eligible for curative surgery and chemotherapy, excluding those with metastatic or triple-negative breast cancer, prior chemotherapy, deafness, pregnancy, depression, psychosis, cognitive impairment, or inability to understand French. The study aims to evaluate the impact of music therapy on reducing anxiety in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study evaluating different conditioning regimens for HLA-matched donor transplantation in patients with severe aplastic anemia (SAA). The study aims to compare the efficacy and safety of conditioning regimens containing busulfan (Bu/Flu/Cy/ATG or Bu/Cy/ATG) versus regimens without busulfan (Flu/Cy/ATG or Cy/ATG) in patients with SAA undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HSCT) from an HLA-matched sibling or unrelated donor.

The primary outcome measure is failure-free survival at 1 year post-HSCT. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of mixed chimerism, regimen-related toxicity, myeloid and platelet engraftment, graft-versus-host disease (GVHD), cytomegalovirus (CMV) and Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) reactivation, transplantation-related mortality, and overall survival at 1 year post-HSCT.

Eligible participants are patients aged

This is a single-arm, open-label study investigating the safety and tolerability of switching from emicizumab prophylaxis to fitusiran prophylaxis in adult males (≥18 years) with severe hemophilia A, with or without inhibitors. The study has a pre-fitusiran treatment period where participants receive on-demand or prophylactic clotting factor concentrates or bypassing agents. This is followed by a fitusiran treatment period where participants receive subcutaneous fitusiran prophylaxis every 2 months or monthly for 18 months, with option for antithrombin concentrate. There is also a follow-up period to monitor antithrombin activity recovery. The primary outcome is incidence of adverse events during the first 4 months of fitusiran treatment.
