Secondary outcomes include thrombin generation, antithrombin levels, emicizumab concentrations, treatment satisfaction, treatment preferences, pain intensity, physical functioning, joint health, and annualized bleeding rate during the extension period. The study aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of transitioning hemophilia A patients from emicizumab to fitusiran prophylaxis

This is a study aimed at translating the painDETECT questionnaire into the Malay language (PDQ-M) and validating its reliability and validity for use in the Malaysian population. The study involves two groups of participants: those with neuropathic pain and those with nociceptive pain. Participants will complete the Malay version of the painDETECT questionnaire (PDQ-M), as well as the Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) and the SF-36 questionnaire. The primary outcome measure is the total score of the PDQ-M, which will be assessed within 2-5 weeks. The study aims to determine the validity and reliability of the PDQ-M in identifying neuropathic and nociceptive pain in the Malaysian population.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the safety and effectiveness of a community-based complex exercise program for stroke patients. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the exercise program on various outcomes, including functional mobility, balance, muscle strength, physical activity levels, quality of life, and depression.

The study involves two groups: an experimental group that will participate in the stroke complex exercise program and a control group that will continue with their daily life activities. The exercise program consists of warm-up exercises, aerobic exercises (using a stepper or treadmill), strength and balance exercises, and cool-down exercises. The program is designed to be performed three times a week for six weeks.

The primary outcome measure is the 6-minute walk test, which assesses functional mobility. Secondary outcome measures include the Modified Rankin Scale (disability), Berg Balance Scale (balance), Functional Ambulation Category (walking ability), Manual Muscle Testing (muscle strength), Timed Up and Go test (fall risk), grip strength, body composition, physical activity levels, quality of life (EQ-5D), depression (Geriatric Depression Scale), sit-to-stand test (lower extremity strength), flexibility test, and coordination test.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-finding study to evaluate the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV-552 in participants aged 50 to 90 years with mild Alzheimer's disease. The study has four arms: three experimental arms receiving different doses of ABBV-552 (Dose A, Dose B, and Dose C) orally once daily for 12 weeks, and a placebo comparator arm receiving placebo for the same duration. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive Subscale (ADAS-Cog 14) score from baseline through week 12, which assesses cognitive impairment. Participants must have a diagnosis of probable Alzheimer's disease according to specific criteria, a Mini-Mental State Examination score between 20 and 26, and a Clinical Dementia Rating global score of 0.5 or 1.0 with memory and functional impairment. The study aims to assess the safety, efficacy, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of ABBV

This is an observational study aimed at evaluating cases of acute liver failure (ALF) and acute-on-chronic liver failure (ACLF) admitted to intensive care units. The key objectives are:

1. To determine the most likely causes of severe acute liver disease in different age groups.
2. To assess complications associated with the disease.
3. To evaluate mortality and morbidity rates.
4. To assess in-hospital and six-month follow-up outcomes based on guidelines.

The study includes patients aged 18-75 years with reduced consciousness, jaundice, abnormal liver function tests (aminotransferase levels >25 times upper limit), coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure. Patients with known cirrhosis or pre-existing renal disease are excluded.

Participants will undergo thorough history taking, clinical examination, imaging (ultrasound, X-ray, echocardiography), and laboratory investigations (liver function tests, renal function tests, urine analysis, albumin-creatinine ratio, and special scores).

The primary outcomes include assessment of liver function, kidney function, and fluid overload at 2 weeks after ICU

This is a descriptive study aimed at determining the predictive effects of impulsivity and coping skills on quality of life in patients with bipolar disorder. The study will be conducted at Adıyaman Besni State Hospital in Turkey between October 2023 and February 2024. The target population consists of individuals aged 18-65 years, receiving outpatient treatment for bipolar disorder according to DSM-5 criteria, and in a euthymic mood state during the study period. The sample size is calculated as 54 participants. Data will be collected through face-to-face interviews using the Personal Information Form, Brief Quality of Life in Bipolar Disorder Scale, Barratt Impulsivity Scale-11 Short Form, and Coping Attitudes Evaluation Scale. The primary outcome measure is the predictive effect of impulsivity on quality of life, while the secondary outcome measure is the predictive effect of coping skills on quality of life in bipolar disorder patients. Data analysis will be performed using descriptive statistics, t-tests, ANOVA, correlation, and regression analyses.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the 2-year clinical performance of two different single-color universal composite resin restorative materials, OMNICHROMA (Tokuyama Dental) and Zenchroma (President Dental), in the restoration of non-carious cervical lesions. The study will compare these two experimental groups with a control group using Filtek Z250 (3M), a multi-color composite resin material.

The primary outcome measure is the clinical performance of the restorations according to the modified United States Public Health Service (USPHS) criteria, which will evaluate retention, marginal discoloration, marginal adaptation, secondary caries, and postoperative sensitivity. These factors will be scored as Alpha (best), Bravo (acceptable), or Charlie (unacceptable) at 6, 12, 18, 24, and 36 months.

The secondary outcome measure is the clinical performance of the restorations according to the World Dental Organization (FDI) criteria, which will score the same factors as clinically excellent, good, sufficient, unsatisfactory, or poor at the same time points.

The study is a double-blind

This is a randomized, triple-masked, parallel-group study evaluating the effect of neuromuscular reversal agents (sugammadex and neostigmine) on the time to first available neurological assessment after endotracheal intubation in critically ill adult patients. The primary outcome is the time from administration of the neuromuscular blocker (rocuronium) to the first time the patient can make a directed movement (Motor score of 6 on the Glasgow Coma Scale), assessed up to 48 hours. Patients will be randomized to receive either sugammadex, neostigmine with glycopyrrolate, or no reversal agent (control group) 30 minutes after rocuronium administration. Neurological assessments using the Glasgow Coma Scale, processed electroencephalography, and cerebral regional oxygen saturation will be performed at various time points before and after intubation and reversal agent administration. Secondary outcomes include time to spontaneous eye opening, changes in processed electroencephalography and cerebral oxygen saturation values, time to extubation, length of hospital and ICU stay, and in-ICU and in-hospital mortality.

This is a randomized, open-label, crossover study investigating the effectiveness of a telemedicine behavioral weight loss intervention in promoting uterine preservation and primary prevention in premenopausal women with obesity and endometrial hyperplasia or grade 1 endometrial cancer. The study has two arms: Arm 1 receives a levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (LNG-IUD) and a telemedicine cognitive behavioral coaching program for weight loss, while Arm 2 receives LNG-IUD and enhanced usual care with handouts on healthy eating and exercise. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants with atypia-free biopsy and uterine preservation at 2 years. Secondary outcomes include time to resolution of hyperplasia, change in weight, change in cancer worry impact, and atypia-free or endometrial cancer-free survival. Participants in the enhanced usual care group who do not achieve atypia-free uterine preservation by one year can cross over to receive the telemedicine behavioral intervention for the second year.

This clinical trial describes a new laparoscopic technique called the "Coconut technique" for performing safe cholecystectomy (gallbladder removal) in cases of acute cholecystitis (inflamed gallbladder). The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Inclusion criteria: Patients aged up to 50 years with stage II acute cholecystitis according to the Tokyo guidelines, within three days of symptom onset.

2. Intervention: The Coconut technique involves cutting 3-4 cm of the inflamed gallbladder wall using an electrocautery hook, making an incision at the junction of the infundibulum and body of the gallbladder, separating the outer and inner layers, and identifying the confluence between the cystic duct and the gallbladder body. After successful identification, the cystic duct is clipped, and the gallbladder is lifted and turned over, leaving the common bile duct untouched, allowing for careful cholecystectomy.

3. Primary outcome measure: The study evaluates the effectiveness of the Coconut technique as a new method for subtotal cholecystect

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of a Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT) protocol enriched with virtual reality (VR) in addressing psychological problems faced by athletes after anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) surgery. The study will involve 60 professional athletes aged 18-45 from Turkish leagues in football, volleyball, and basketball who have undergone ACL surgery.

The study has four parallel groups: 1) CBT+VR group receiving the CBT protocol with VR, 2) VR group receiving only the behavioral intervention part in VR, 3) CBT group receiving the CBT protocol without VR, and 4) a control group. Each group will have 10 weekly sessions of 50 minutes each.

The primary outcomes measured are re-injury anxiety, rehabilitation adherence, self-efficacy, and kinesiophobia, assessed through various scales at multiple time points throughout the study duration of approximately one year.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the CBT+VR protocol in addressing psychological issues faced by athletes during rehabilitation after ACL surgery, with the goal of improving the quality of physical rehabilitation and facilitating a positive return to sports.

This clinical trial aims to analyze the implementation and effectiveness of the PT-PENCIL (Physical Therapy Frequency Clinical Decision Support Tool), an electronic clinical decision support tool integrated into the electronic health record (Epic). The PT-PENCIL uses a statistical model to identify patients who may benefit from daily physical therapy to facilitate discharge home from the hospital.

The study has two primary aims:

1. Analyze the effect of using the PT-PENCIL on the proportion of patients discharged home versus to a post-acute care facility.

2. Assess the reach, adoption, acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the PT-PENCIL among physical therapists.

The study design is a stepped-wedge implementation trial, where the PT-PENCIL will be gradually introduced across different hospital units over time. The primary outcome measures include the effectiveness of the PT-PENCIL in facilitating discharge home, its reach (number of patients for whom the algorithm ran), adoption (number of therapists acknowledging the tool), and the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the tool as rated by physical therapists.

The study aims to optimize the role of physical therapists in acute care hospitals by

This is a single-arm, prospective, exploratory study to evaluate the feasibility and effect of a 7-Form Medical Tai Chi Exercise Healing program in treating metastatic colorectal cancer (mCRC) patients. The primary objective is to assess the adherence rates of participants to the 8-week Tai Chi intervention, which involves 60-minute sessions three times a week led by an experienced instructor. Secondary outcomes include fatigue (Brief Fatigue Inventory), sleep quality (Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index), quality of life (EORTC QLQ-C30), anxiety (Self-Rating Anxiety Scale), and depression (Self-Rating Depression Scale). Eligible participants are mCRC patients aged 18-75 with an ECOG performance status of 0-2 and adequate organ function. The study aims to explore the potential benefits of Tai Chi exercise as a supportive care intervention for mCRC patients.

This is a health services research study that aims to evaluate the effectiveness of an educational intervention called "Survivorship ECHO" in improving provider knowledge and implementation of best practices for cancer survivorship care. The study involves providers from The James Cancer Network in Ohio, including nurses, advanced practice providers, nutritionists, radiation oncologists, and oncologists. Participants attend six 1-hour educational sessions over 12 weeks and may optionally participate in a 30-minute one-on-one interview to provide feedback. The primary outcomes measured are changes in provider knowledge and comfort levels with core cancer survivorship competencies, as well as qualitative assessments of the intervention's acceptability, met/unmet needs, and barriers to access. The study uses pre- and post-enrollment surveys and qualitative analysis to evaluate the intervention's impact.

This is a randomized, controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of post facilitation stretch and Maitland mobilization techniques in improving range of motion and reducing disability in patients with post-traumatic stiff elbow. The study included 32 participants aged 18-35 years with a limitation of elbow joint range of motion greater than 30 degrees in extension and less than 120 degrees in flexion, 2-3 months after immobilization. Participants were randomly assigned to either the post facilitation stretch group or the Maitland mobilization group. The post facilitation stretch group received 6-10 seconds of isometric contraction followed by 15 seconds of passive stretch, repeated 4-5 times per day, 5 days a week for 4 weeks. The Maitland mobilization group received 2-3 oscillations per second for 1 minute, 5 sets each day, 5 days a week for 4 weeks. Both groups also received hot pack application and active/active-assisted exercises for elbow, wrist, and forearm movements. The primary outcomes measured were pain, elbow flexion and extension range of motion

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study aimed at evaluating a multidisciplinary approach for early diagnosis of heart failure in high-risk Canadian patients. The study involves two arms: an experimental arm (ACTIVE) and a control arm (routine care). In the ACTIVE arm, participants with elevated NT-proBNP levels (≥125pg/ml) will undergo an AI-enabled handheld echocardiogram (Us2.ai) within one month, followed by a standard echocardiogram if the AI-echo is non-diagnostic. The control arm will receive routine care, with NT-proBNP and conventional echocardiography prescribed as per usual practice. The primary outcome is the diagnosis of heart failure within 6 months from randomization, determined by outpatient diagnosis, heart failure visit, or hospitalization. Secondary outcomes include the diagnosis of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction (HFrEF) within 6 months and the proportion of HFrEF patients receiving guideline-directed medical therapy within 6 months. The study targets high-risk patients aged 40 years or older with at least two risk factors for heart

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, single-center, crossover study investigating the central and cerebral hemodynamic effects and volume kinetics of Ringer's acetate solution compared to no intravenous fluids, during experimental hypovolemia induced by lower body negative pressure (LBNP) versus euvolemia, in healthy human volunteers.

The study has four arms: 1) LBNP 0 mmHg (euvolemia) + no intravenous fluid, 2) LBNP 0 mmHg + Ringer's acetate, 3) LBNP 40 mmHg (hypovolemia) + no intravenous fluid, and 4) LBNP 40 mmHg + Ringer's acetate.

The primary outcome measure is the half-life of change in cardiac stroke volume over 120 minutes. Secondary outcomes include the half-life of changes in intravascular volume and middle cerebral artery blood flow velocity over the same time period.

The study aims to explore the time-dependent effects of an intravenous fluid bolus on volume expansion and

This is a naturalistic, multicenter, open-label study evaluating the effects and cost-effectiveness of a guided internet-delivered psychological treatment called "eMeistring" for moderate depression, social anxiety disorder, and panic disorder. The study involves an initial face-to-face visit, followed by 8-9 modules of therapist-guided internet-based cognitive behavioral therapy (ICBT), and a final face-to-face visit. The primary outcomes include depression severity (PHQ-9), social phobia (SPIN), and panic disorder symptoms (PDSS-SR), measured at baseline, post-treatment (up to 14 weeks), 6 months, and 2 years. Secondary outcomes include health-related quality of life (EQ-5D-5L), work and social adjustment, anxiety severity (GAD-7), system usability, cost of healthcare services, medication use, work participation, and sickness absenteeism. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness, predictors of dropout and adherence, and cost-effectiveness of the eMeistring program across multiple centers.

This is a randomized controlled study comparing the efficacy of two ultrasound-guided regional anesthesia techniques, Thoracolumbar Interfascial Plane (TLIP) block and Erector Spinae Plane (ESP) block, for perioperative analgesia in patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery. The study involves three groups: TLIP group, ESP group, and a control group receiving local anesthetic infiltration. The primary outcomes measure the extent of sensory blockade, intraoperative analgesic requirements (fentanyl usage and Analgesia Nociception Index scores), postoperative analgesic requirements (morphine consumption and Visual Analogue Scale pain scores) up to 24 hours, and side effects. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of TLIP and ESP blocks in providing perioperative analgesia compared to the control group in patients undergoing lumbar spine fusion surgery.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the accuracy and safety of a novel wearable device called MABOS (Melanin-Adjusted Blood Oxygen Sensor) in measuring blood oxygen saturation levels and epidermal melanin concentration in individuals with different skin tones. The study will enroll 12 healthy participants, with 4 participants each from African, East Asian, and European descent, and an equal gender distribution.

The trial will involve placing the MABOS device and an FDA-approved pulse oximeter (Nonin PureSat) on the participants for 90 minutes to acquire biometric data. The primary outcomes include assessing the safety and comfort of the MABOS device through qualitative surveys, and the secondary outcomes involve evaluating the device's accuracy in estimating epidermal melanin and blood oxygen levels compared to a spectrometer and the FDA-approved oximeter, respectively.

The study aims to determine if the MABOS device can provide more accurate blood oxygen saturation measurements for individuals with diverse skin tones by accounting for epidermal melanin concentration.

This is a phase 1/2 dose-escalation study evaluating the safety, feasibility, and efficacy of interferon-beta-1a (FP-1201) in preventing toxicities after CD19-directed CAR T-cell therapy in patients with recurrent or refractory B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia, B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma, or mantle cell lymphoma.

Patients receive FP-1201 intravenously for 3 or 5 days before receiving lymphodepletion chemotherapy followed by axi-cel or brexu-cel (CD19-directed CAR T-cell products) on day 0. Various procedures like imaging, lumbar puncture, bone marrow aspiration/biopsy, and biospecimen collection are performed for screening, treatment monitoring, and follow-up.

The primary outcomes are dose-limiting toxicity rates and incidence of adverse events. Secondary outcomes include rates of cytokine release syndrome, immune effector cell-associated neurotoxicity syndrome, cumulative corticosteroid dose, overall response rate, and complete response rate.

Patients undergo long

This is a randomized, open-label, multicenter phase III clinical trial investigating the use of camrelizumab plus chemotherapy in combination with or without famitinib as neoadjuvant therapy in participants with triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). The study aims to evaluate the pathological complete response (pCR) rate, event-free survival (EFS), disease-free survival (DFS), distant disease-free survival (DDFS), and objective response rate (ORR) in TNBC patients receiving these treatments before surgery. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either camrelizumab plus chemotherapy (albumin-paclitaxel and carboplatin) and famitinib or camrelizumab plus chemotherapy alone. The study has specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to factors such as ECOG performance status, tumor stage, prior treatments, and comorbidities.

This is a study investigating early prediction of postpartum glucose metabolism abnormalities in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM). The study aims to identify serum lipid and metabolic markers during pregnancy (24-28 weeks gestation) that can predict abnormal glucose metabolism after delivery. Participants are pregnant women aged 20-49 years with GDM but without other major medical conditions. The study involves collecting questionnaire data, blood samples during pregnancy, and placenta/cord blood at delivery. Participants will be divided into two groups based on their postpartum oral glucose tolerance test results at 6-12 weeks after delivery: those with abnormal glucose metabolism and those with normal glucose metabolism (control group). The primary outcomes are serum lipidomics and metabolomics profiles measured from the pregnancy blood samples, which will be analyzed to identify potential predictive markers for postpartum glucose abnormalities in women with GDM.

This clinical trial aims to assess the sleep quality of hospitalized patients in the intensive care unit (ICU) when treated with EEG-guided sleep protection procedures. The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving EEG-guided sleep protection, and a control group receiving usual care. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of continuous sleep on the first day. Secondary outcomes include sleep fragmentation, environmental factors (noise and light), sleep interruptions by caregivers, sleep quality on subsequent days, workload assessed by nurses, patient agitation, performance of the algorithm, patient-reported sleep quality, anxiety level, respiratory status, presence of delirium, length of ICU stay, and safety of the procedure. The study is designed as a non-randomized, open-label, sequential assignment trial involving adult patients admitted to the medical ICU who are unsedated and meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, dose-ranging study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of SAR441566 plus methotrexate in adults with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis. The study has four experimental arms receiving different dose regimens of SAR441566 and one placebo arm. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants achieving at least 20% improvement in the American College of Rheumatology (ACR) score at week 12. Secondary outcomes include change from baseline in Disease Activity Score-28 C-reactive protein (DAS-28 CRP) at week 12, proportion achieving ACR50 response, treatment-emergent adverse events, and pharmacokinetic measures. The study duration for each participant is approximately up to 149 days.

This is a prospective, single-arm, open-label clinical study evaluating the diagnostic performance of the MaGIA IBC in-vitro diagnostic device for combined screening of HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C infections. The primary objectives are to measure the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (ROC AUC), sensitivity, and specificity of the MaGIA IBC test for diagnosing HIV, HBV, and HCV infections using capillary blood samples, compared to a reference standard. Secondary objectives include assessing the concordance of diagnostic results across different sample matrices (capillary blood, venous blood, serum, and plasma) and evaluating the safety of the device by monitoring adverse events. The study will enroll male and female participants aged 18 years or older who are receiving care at Hôpital Européen de Marseille and are known or suspected to have HIV, HBV, or HCV infections, or have given consent to participate. The study aims to evaluate the diagnostic performance and safety of the MaGIA IBC point-of-care test for combined screening of HIV, Hepatitis B, and Hepatitis C

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study investigating the effects of the dietary supplement Endocalyx Pro™ in patients with chronic heart failure. The primary objective is to assess whether Endocalyx reduces sodium and water excess in these patients, measured by the percent change in NT-proBNP levels from baseline to week 8 compared to placebo. Secondary objectives include evaluating improvements in physical limitations, fluid overload symptoms, quality of life, microcirculation, inflammation, and safety. The study involves two parallel arms: the experimental arm receiving Endocalyx (4 capsules daily for 8 weeks) and the placebo comparator arm. Multiple outcome measures are assessed, including 24-hour blood pressure, total body water, body weight, hemodynamic parameters, biomarkers, monocyte activation, hospitalization rates, 6-minute walk test, quality of life questionnaires, adverse events, pharmacokinetics, and skin biopsies for sodium content and monocyte/macrophage analysis in subsets of patients. The study aims to determine the working mechanisms of Endocalyx and its potential benefits in managing chronic heart failure.

This is a feasibility study investigating the use of nasogastric (NG) tubes and water-soluble contrast (Gastrografin) in the management of adhesive small bowel obstruction (aSBO). The study aims to optimize the treatment of aSBO by comparing three groups:

1. Patients treated without NG tubes
2. Patients treated with NG tubes and Gastrografin (water-soluble contrast)
3. Patients treated with NG tubes and saline (placebo)

The primary outcome measure is the quality of life assessed using the PROMIS-29 HRQOL instrument, which will be measured at various time points, including baseline, postoperative period, follow-up visits, and 30 days after surgery.

The study includes male and female participants aged 18 years or older with documented aSBO, evidenced by clinical features such as nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, and distended abdomen, as well as CT evidence of aSBO. Pregnant, breastfeeding, or patients with certain medical conditions are excluded from the study.

The study is designed as a randomized,

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial investigating a novel combination therapeutic strategy aimed at achieving functional cure (sustained hepatitis B surface antigen [HBsAg] loss) for chronic hepatitis B virus (HBV) infection. The study involves two treatment arms:

1. Experimental group: Combination therapy with nucleos(t)ide analogs (NAs) like entecavir (ETV), tenofovir disoproxil fumarate (TDF), or tenofovir alafenamide (TAF), anti-PD-1 antibody (given subcutaneously/intravenously once every two or three weeks at a lower dose than used in cancer patients), and pegylated interferon-alpha (Peg-IFNα) (180μg once weekly, subcutaneous injection).

2. Active comparator group: Combination therapy with NAs and Peg-IFNα.

The primary outcomes measured are serum HBsAg, HBV DNA, and alanine aminotransferase (ALT) levels at baseline, 24 and 48

This clinical trial aims to compare the wound healing outcomes of two different suture techniques, simple and continuous, in oral surgery procedures. The study involves patients aged 40-65 years undergoing full arch alveoplasty, randomly assigned to receive either the simple suture technique or the continuous suture technique for closing half of the surgical flap. The primary outcomes measured include wound healing scores (Laundry Healing Index and Early Wound Healing Score) at days 1, 3, and 7 post-surgery, suturing time, knot looseness, pain at suture removal, and suture removal difficulty. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with a single-blind masking approach. The goal is to evaluate the effectiveness and potential advantages of the two suture techniques in promoting optimal wound healing and patient comfort after oral surgery procedures.

This is a pilot study exploring the feasibility and utility of using an in-home body weight support harness system in children with Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA) Types 1 and 2, who are receiving treatment with nusinersen, onasemnogene abeparvovec, or risdiplam. The study aims to assess the potential benefits of the harness system on motor and non-motor skills, as well as the ease of use and enjoyment for the participants.

The study involves a single group of participants who will receive the in-home body weight support harness system, which is a portable, adjustable system that allows 360-degree mobility within its footprint and adjustable weight support.

The primary outcome measures include a caregiver survey evaluating the perceived impact on motor and non-motor skills, enjoyment, ease of use, and overall benefit. Additionally, changes in various motor function scales, such as the Neuromuscular Gross Motor Outcome (GRO) scale, Hammersmith Functional Motor Scale Expanded (HFMSE), Revised Hammersmith Scale (RHS), Bayley Scales of Infant

This is a prospective study evaluating the serious complication rate and visual efficacy of Descemet Membrane Endothelial Keratoplasty (DMEK) in patients with a history of anterior or posterior segment surgery at 12 months follow-up. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence rate of at least one serious post-operative DMEK complication, which includes rebubbling, graft failure, graft rejection, and macular cystoid edema. Secondary outcomes include rates of individual complications, surgical complexity, procedure duration, visual and refractive outcomes, endothelial cell loss, corneal thickness, and posterior keratometry changes over 12 months. Eligible patients are those scheduled for corneal endothelial transplantation with a history of vitrectomy, trabeculectomy, large iris defects, anterior synechiae, or pseudophakia/aphakia, excluding certain corneal, retinal, and glaucoma conditions.

This is a clinical trial investigating the impact of oral antibiotic prophylaxis on the microbiome and surgical complications in patients undergoing elective colon and rectal surgery with primary anastomosis. The study aims to analyze the correlation between septic complications, such as anastomotic leak, and changes in the microbiome after surgery. It also aims to identify factors that may influence the microbiome, including comorbidities, previous operations, oral antibiotic prophylaxis, and systemic intravenous prophylaxis.

The study has two arms: one group receives oral antibiotic prophylaxis (neomycin sulfate and metronidazole) in addition to mechanical bowel preparation, while the other group receives only mechanical bowel preparation without oral antibiotics. The primary outcome measure is the microbiome, and the secondary outcome measure is the factors affecting the microbiome.

The study includes adult patients undergoing elective colon and rectal surgery with primary anastomosis, excluding those with certain conditions such as recent antibiotic use, allergies, abdominal sepsis, pregnancy, or immunosuppression. The study will follow participants for 30 days postoperatively

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the utility of measuring the median nerve stenosis at the point of maximal compression in the carpal tunnel for diagnosing carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS). The study involves two groups: patients with CTS confirmed by nerve conduction studies (NCS) or ultrasound (US), and healthy controls. Both groups will undergo NCS of the median and ulnar nerves, as well as US of the median nerve, with measurements of cross-sectional area, diameter, and echogenicity at various points, including the point of maximal stenosis. The location of the maximal stenosis will also be evaluated. Participants will complete the Boston Carpal Tunnel Questionnaire (BCTQ) and a demographic questionnaire. The primary outcomes are the differences in median nerve diameter, cross-sectional area, and echogenicity at the site of maximal compression between CTS patients and healthy controls. Secondary outcomes include correlations between these US measurements and BCTQ scores or electrophysiological severity grades in CTS patients. The study aims to assess the diagnostic utility of measuring median nerve stenosis at the point of maximal compression for CTS.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial investigating the safety and symptom burden optimization of tocilizumab in autologous stem cell transplantation (ASCT) following high-dose melphalan conditioning in patients with multiple myeloma. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of tocilizumab, an immunosuppressive drug, in reducing ASCT-related symptoms and adverse events in multiple myeloma patients undergoing ASCT after high-dose melphalan conditioning. The primary outcomes measured are the M.D. Anderson Symptom Inventory (MDASI) questionnaire scores and adverse event rates. Eligible participants are multiple myeloma patients aged 18-70 years, meeting specific disease and treatment response criteria, and scheduled for ASCT. Participants will be randomized to receive either tocilizumab (8mg/kg) or no intervention 7 days before stem cell transfusion. The study will assess symptom burden and adverse events from day -7 to day 100 after stem cell transfusion.

This clinical trial aims to compare the outcomes of intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) using testicular sperm aspiration (TESA) versus microfluidic sperm separation (MSS) in couples with high sperm DNA fragmentation (>20%). The study has two arms: TESA-ICSI and Zymot-ICSI (Zymot is a microfluidic sperm separation device). The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate, evaluated approximately 8 weeks after the intervention. The secondary outcome measure is the number of utilizable blastocysts obtained, assessed around 20 days after the intervention. The study includes men aged 18 years or older with high sperm DNA fragmentation undergoing ICSI, excluding cases of advanced maternal age (>40 years) or egg donation cycles.

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effect of stabilization and stabilization-related parameters on shooting performance in archery athletes aged 10-18 years. The study included 40 archery athletes who had been professionally engaged in archery for at least 1 year. The athletes underwent various assessments, including musculoskeletal system evaluations, Upper Extremity Closed Kinetic Chain Stability Test, Hand Grip Strength test, Lateral Scapular Slide Test, Craniocervical Flexion Test, Scapular Muscle Endurance Test, Abdominal Drawing-in Test, Sahrmann's Core Stability Test, Corbin Postural Rating Scale, Stork Balance Test, Upper Extremity Y Balance Test, and the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index. The primary outcome measures were cervical stabilization, lumbar stabilization grade, lumbar stabilizer muscle contraction, scapular dyskinesis type and amount, and sportive performance assessed by shooting 72 arrows at a target and recording the total points. Secondary outcome measures included balance assessments, posture, disability, upper extremity performance, hand grip strength, and

This clinical trial aims to develop and test an artificial intelligence (AI) communication training tool to improve contraception discussions between pediatricians, adolescents, and their mothers. The study has three stages:

Stage 1 (formative): Characterize communication content and styles during 50 real-life clinical encounters involving pediatricians, adolescents, and mothers. Identify optimal communication strategies through surveys and group interviews.

Stage 2 (development): Create an AI communication training tool using de-identified vignettes from Stage 1. Refine the tool through iterative testing with advisory boards and 10 pediatrician learners.

Stage 3 (proof-of-concept): Evaluate the effectiveness of the AI communication training tool by comparing 50 pre-training and 50 post-training clinical encounters. Assess communication interactions, acceptability, and feasibility through surveys.

The primary outcome is the quality of communication interactions, measured by aggregated survey responses. Secondary outcomes include acceptability and feasibility of the intervention.

The study aims to advance pediatrician communication training, empower adolescent sexual health, support mothers' priorities, and test how AI communication training tools can improve triadic

This study aims to investigate healthcare disparities in vitiligo, a skin condition characterized by the loss of skin pigmentation. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Estimate the cumulative lifetime risk of developing vitiligo in the overall population and across different sociodemographic groups, including age, sex, ethnicity, and deprivation levels, using survival models and competing risk analysis.

2. Perform a subgroup analysis within the vitiligo population to identify health-related disparities across different deprivation, sex, and ethnic groups, focusing on:
   a. Mental health conditions
   b. Healthcare utilization (primary care encounters, dermatology referrals, mental health referrals)
   c. Work impact (unemployment, time off work)

3. The study will use data from the Optimum Patient Care Research Database (OPCRD) in the UK, covering the period from 2004 to 2020.

4. The study population includes adolescents and adults (aged 13+) with newly diagnosed vitiligo during the study period, as well as individuals without vitiligo for comparison.

5. The primary outcome measure is the total disease burden

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effects of a behavior modification program delivered through a hybrid mode (online and in-person) on self-efficacy, stress, relationships, and conflict in caregivers of children with developmental delays. The study involved two groups: a hybrid group and a self-learning group. The hybrid group received a combination of online audiobook sessions, role-playing, games, online schedule reminders, and individual counseling sessions (online and in-person). The self-learning group was provided with a description of the course goals and the book "Atomic Habits" for self-study.

The primary outcomes measured were intervention fidelity, parenting sense of confidence, and parenting stress. Secondary outcomes included conflict tactics, satisfaction with the program, and habit schedule records. The study used various scales and questionnaires to assess these outcomes before and after the 8-week intervention period.

The study aimed to examine the effectiveness of the hybrid mode of delivery in improving self-efficacy, reducing stress, enhancing relationships, and managing conflicts in caregivers of children receiving early intervention services.

This is a Phase I/Ib clinical trial investigating the combination of trotabresib (an oral BET inhibitor), vinorelbine (chemotherapy), and radiation therapy for the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer patients with central nervous system (CNS) or leptomeningeal metastases.

Key aspects:

- Phase I: Dose escalation to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase II dose of trotabresib in combination with vinorelbine.

- Phase Ib: Expansion cohort to evaluate progression-free survival, overall survival, response rates, and safety/tolerability in patients with brain metastases and/or leptomeningeal disease.

- Two cohorts: 
    1) Patients receive trotabresib, vinorelbine, and radiation therapy. 
    2) Pre-surgical cohort receives trotabresib and vinorelbine before and after tumor resection, with optional radiation therapy.

- Primary endpoints: Dose-limiting toxicities (Phase I), adverse events (Phase Ib).

- Secondary endpoints: Progression-free survival, overall

This is a feasibility study examining a digital health intervention called "Centering Appetite" for treating binge eating and obesity in Black women. The key aspects are:

- Aims to modify and adapt an existing program to be culturally relevant for Black women with obesity (BMI ≥30 kg/m2) who binge eat.
- Will conduct focus groups and usability testing to identify barriers, facilitators, and optimize the digital tool.
- A randomized clinical trial to evaluate the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of the 6-month digital "Centering Appetite" program, which combines Appetite Awareness Treatment and behavioral weight loss treatment delivered remotely.
- Primary outcomes are feasibility of recruitment, retention, and attendance. Secondary outcomes include changes in weight regain and number of binge eating episodes.
- Eligibility criteria include Black women aged 18-75 years, BMI ≥30, report weekly binge eating, have a smartphone, live near study site.
- Exclusions include pregnancy, substance abuse treatment, other weight loss programs, history of anorexia or purging, excessive alcohol use.
- Participants will be randomized to either

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of different doses of nitrate-rich beetroot juice supplementation on neuromuscular performance during resistance exercise in recreationally active males. The study has a double-blind, randomized, crossover design with four experimental conditions:

1. BR-HIGH: Participants will ingest an elevated dose of nitrate (26 mmol) from 4 nitrate-rich beetroot juice shots 2.5 hours before exercise.
2. BR-MOD: Participants will ingest a moderate dose of nitrate (13 mmol) from 2 nitrate-rich and 2 nitrate-depleted beetroot juice shots 2.5 hours before exercise.
3. BR-LOW: Participants will ingest a low dose of nitrate (6.5 mmol) from 1 nitrate-rich and 3 nitrate-depleted beetroot juice shots 2.5 hours before exercise.
4. PL: Participants will ingest a placebo of 4 nitrate-depleted beetroot juice shots 2.5 hours before exercise.

The primary outcomes include plasma nitrate

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of two different intra-abdominal pressure levels (12 mmHg and 14 mmHg) on mechanical power during laparoscopic cholecystectomy surgery under general anesthesia. The study hypothesizes that higher intra-abdominal pressure may increase mechanical power, which is associated with an increased risk of ventilator-induced lung injury (VILI) and other pulmonary complications. The primary outcome measure is the mechanical power values recorded during the operation, which will be calculated using a specific formula. Eligible participants are ASA 1-2 patients aged 18-75 years undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Patients will be randomized to either the 12 mmHg or 14 mmHg intra-abdominal pressure group, and mechanical power will be measured at various time points during the surgery. The study aims to determine if there is a significant difference in mechanical power between the two pressure levels and potentially identify the optimal intra-abdominal pressure to minimize the risk of VILI.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) as an alternative to Cone Beam Computed Tomography (CBCT) for assessing furcation involvement in molars. The study includes patients aged 18-120 years with grade II or III furcation involvement, who require a CBCT scan and have no contraindications for MRI. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of horizontal furcation defects according to the Hamp 1975 classification on day 1. Secondary outcome measures include horizontal and vertical bone loss measurements on day 1. The study is designed to compare the efficacy of MRI and CBCT in diagnosing furcation involvement in molars in patients with periodontitis or periodontal diseases.

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate and compare the plaque removal efficacy of electric and manual toothbrushes in children with Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) and healthy children. The study included 52 children aged 8-10 years, with 26 diagnosed with ADHD (experimental group) and 26 healthy children (control group). Each group was further divided into two subgroups, one using electric toothbrushes and the other using manual toothbrushes.

The primary outcomes measured were the Gingival Index (GI), Turesky modification of Quigley-Hein Plaque Index (TQHPI), and Approximal Plaque Index (API) at baseline, 1 month, and 3 months. These indices evaluated gingival health, plaque removal efficiency from labial, lingual, and proximal surfaces of teeth, respectively.

Secondary outcomes included the DMFT (Decayed, Missing, and Filled Teeth) index and dft (decay filled teeth) index to assess the risk of dental caries in permanent and primary dentitions, respectively. A

This is a prospective, single-arm, open-label, non-randomized, multi-center study investigating the feasibility and stability of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) using a conventional bipolar, active fixation pacing lead (Solia S) in symptomatic bradycardia patients. The study aims to enroll approximately 150 patients across seven clinical sites in Taiwan. Eligible patients will undergo LBBAP implantation with one or two Solia S leads and a BIOTRONIK pacemaker system. The primary outcome is the implant success rate, defined as the ability to appropriately sense and deliver pacing at 12 months post-implant. Secondary outcomes include intraoperative fluoroscopic exposure time, intracardiac electrograms, post-operative imaging data, serial ECG and echocardiography changes, and changes in pacing parameters over 12 months. The study will evaluate the performance and safety of LBBAP using the Solia S lead in patients with symptomatic bradycardia.

This is a randomized, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of two sonic electric toothbrushes (Sonicare DiamondClean 9000 and HydroSonic Easy) and two manual toothbrushes (Oral-B 123 and Curaprox CS 5460) in reducing gingival inflammation in pregnant women aged 18-40 years over a 3-month period. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of gingival bleeding from baseline during pregnancy. Secondary outcomes include effects on bleeding on probing, gingival index, plaque index, clinical attachment loss, periodontal pocket probing depth, and customer satisfaction scores. Eligible participants are pregnant women between 15-18 weeks gestation without severe periodontal disease or other complicating factors. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of different toothbrush types for oral prophylaxis and gingival inflammation control during pregnancy.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of yoga-based breathing styles, specifically nasal and mouth breathing, on memory performance and subjective stress levels in adults without prior experience in yoga, meditation, or similar disciplines, and without existing health problems that could hinder the breathing exercises.

The study involves three groups: a nasal breathing group, a mouth breathing group, and a control group. Participants will complete a memory test while performing controlled nasal or oral breathing. After the initial test, they will undergo a two-week training period with daily nasal or mouth breathing training, or no training for the control group.

The primary outcome measure is the improvement in memory performance, assessed by the correctness of mapping learned images promptly after the learning phase and two weeks later. The secondary outcome measure is the reduction in subjective stress levels, determined by a subjective stress statement before and after each learning and retrieval phase, at the first appointment and after two weeks.

The study aims to determine if nasal breathing training results in a significant improvement in memory capacity compared to mouth breathing training and the control group. It also aims to assess if controlled yoga-based breathing styles lead to a relevant reduction in subjective stress levels.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of calisthenics exercise and pulsed electromagnetic therapy on liver function in burn patients. The study involves three groups: a calisthenics exercise group, a pulsed electromagnetic therapy group, and a combined calisthenics exercise and pulsed electromagnetic therapy group. The participants are burned patients aged 20-45 years with a total body surface area (TBSA) burn of 30-50%. The primary outcome measure is the concentration of liver enzymes alanine transaminase (ALT) and aspartate transaminase (AST) in blood plasma, which will be measured before and after a 3-month intervention period. The calisthenics exercise program consists of medium-intensity exercises for 60 minutes, 3 days per week, while the pulsed electromagnetic therapy involves exposing the upper abdominal area to very low frequency (15 Hz) and intensity (20 G) electromagnetic fields for 20 minutes, 3 sessions per week. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of these interventions on liver function in burn patients.

This is a feasibility study investigating the effects of a nutritional intervention on the clearance of pembrolizumab, an anti-PD-1 immune checkpoint inhibitor, in patients with non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The primary aim is to assess the variability of pembrolizumab clearance during a 12-week nutritional intervention period. The secondary aims are to evaluate the feasibility of patient recruitment and compliance with the study protocol.

Patients with stage IV or recurrent NSCLC who are eligible for pembrolizumab treatment will be enrolled. The intervention involves consuming two 200 mL bottles of a study nutritional supplement daily, in addition to receiving pembrolizumab with or without chemotherapy as per standard of care.

Blood samples, questionnaires, and fecal specimens will be collected at multiple timepoints to assess pembrolizumab clearance, nutritional status, immune parameters, and microbiome changes. The study will measure the variability of pembrolizumab clearance during the nutritional intervention period as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include the recruitment rate and patient compliance with the study procedures and nutritional supplement intake.

The

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of integrins and protocadherins in glutamatergic circuits and identify common signaling pathways and molecular targets in anxiety and major depressive disorders. The study involves two parts: a human study and a murine model study.

In the human study, 10 patients with anxiety-depressive disorder and 10 healthy controls will be recruited. Participants will undergo structured clinical interviews, psychopathological assessments, and a multimodal neuroimaging session using a 7T MRI scanner. The neuroimaging session will include T1-weighted imaging to study volumetric differences in white and gray matter, functional MRI to assess functional connectivity in the prefrontal-limbic pathway, and proton magnetic resonance spectroscopy (1H-MRS) to study glutamatergic neurotransmission in the anterior cingulate and dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.

In the murine model study, electron microscopic analyses will be performed in Pcdh9-knockout mice to assess the effects of Pcdh9 deficits on excitatory synapses. Glutamatergic signaling

This clinical trial aims to investigate the association between cardiovascular and nervous system diseases and the intestinal microbiome using multi-omics big data. The study involves collecting blood and stool samples from patients with idiopathic ventricular tachycardia, restenosis after coronary artery stenting, moyamoya disease, and carotid atherosclerosis, as well as healthy controls. The collected blood samples will undergo genome and transcriptome sequencing, while the stool samples will undergo metagenomic, metametabolic, and proteomic sequencing. The study will analyze the multi-omics data using machine learning methods to identify key genes, microbes, and pathways associated with these cardiovascular and neurological diseases. The goal is to develop predictive models for early disease prevention and diagnosis, as well as to provide insights into the mechanisms by which gut microbes influence these diseases.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the prognostic value of combining KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutation status and pre-treatment FDG-PET/CT radiomic analysis in advanced non-small-cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients with PD-L1 expression ≥ 50% treated with pembrolizumab. The study is designed to identify biomarkers that can predict response to pembrolizumab, as only a fraction of patients with high PD-L1 expression respond to this immunotherapy. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and the secondary outcome measure is overall survival. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with stage III unresectable or stage IV NSCLC, PD-L1 expression ≥ 50%, and no prior systemic treatment for NSCLC. The study aims to establish a predictive model based on KEAP1/NFE2L2 mutations and pre-treatment FDG-PET/CT radiomic analysis to predict survival outcomes in advanced NSCLC patients treated with pembrolizumab.

This is a phase II, open-label, non-randomized trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of sacituzumab govitecan (SG), an antibody-drug conjugate targeting Trop-2, with or without the PD-L1 inhibitor atezolizumab in patients with rare, advanced/metastatic genitourinary tumors. The study has two arms: Arm 1 receives SG monotherapy, while Arm 2 receives the combination of SG and atezolizumab. The primary outcome is objective response rate. Secondary outcomes include duration of response, overall survival, progression-free survival, clinical benefit rate, and safety/tolerability. Eligible patients have locally advanced/metastatic small cell carcinoma, squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma of the bladder/urinary tract, renal medullary carcinoma, or penile squamous cell carcinoma. The study aims to determine the clinical efficacy of SG alone or with atezolizumab in these rare tumor types lacking standard treatments.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two interventions, proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) and eccentric exercises with electrical stimulation, in improving ankle dorsiflexion range and vertical jump performance in professional paddle tennis players. The study has a parallel-group, randomized design with two arms: the PNF group receiving proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation for ankle dorsiflexion, and the experimental group performing eccentric exercises and electrical stimulation for ankle dorsiflexion strengthening. The primary outcomes are ankle dorsiflexion range, measured using the weight-bearing lunge test, and vertical jump performance, assessed through the drop jump test from a height of 25 cm. The study includes professional paddle tennis players aged 18-50 years, with no history of musculoskeletal or neurological conditions that could affect exercise performance. The trial aims to determine the most effective intervention for improving ankle dorsiflexion range and vertical jump ability in this population of professional athletes.

This is a 12-week multicentre randomized parallel-group open controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of dietary counselling promoting adherence to the Mediterranean diet as an adjuvant treatment for major depressive disorder (MDD) in adults with elevated inflammation biomarkers. The primary objective is to assess if the dietary intervention can decrease depressive symptoms in MDD patients with elevated C-reactive protein (CRP) or interleukin-6 (IL-6) levels. Participants will be randomized to either the intervention arm receiving 6 nutrition consultations promoting the Mediterranean diet along with treatment as usual (TAU) for MDD, or the control arm receiving only TAU. The primary outcome is change in depressive symptoms measured by the Beck Depression Inventory-II (BDI-II). Secondary outcomes include changes in inflammatory biomarkers CRP and IL-6. The target sample size is 190 participants (95 per arm). Assessments will occur at baseline, 12 weeks, 6 months, and 12 months. The study aims to evaluate if promoting the Mediterranean diet can improve outcomes in MDD treatment by reducing inflammation and depressive symptoms.

This is a community-based participatory study aimed at supporting parenting and improving family mental health in refugee shelters in Tijuana, Mexico. The study involves a randomized controlled trial with two groups: an experimental group receiving a culturally adapted parenting curriculum twice a week for 4 weeks, and a waitlist control group receiving a handout on parenting techniques initially and then the same parenting curriculum after the experimental group.

The study has several key components:

1. Engaging community stakeholders to prioritize 3-5 parenting skills through focus groups.
2. Recruiting 120 parents from refugee shelters and dividing them into 8 groups of 15.
3. Participants vote for 1-2 interventions from a list of 5 previously studied refugee parenting curriculums to adapt to the local context.
4. Randomizing participants into an experimental group (Group 1) and a waitlist control group (Group 2).
5. Group 1 receives the adapted parenting curriculum for 4 weeks, while Group 2 receives a handout on childhood nutrition.
6. Collecting data on parenting knowledge, child behavior, par

This is a prospective longitudinal qualitative study across three regions of North England, accompanied by co-design workshops. The study aims to understand and identify priorities for improving healthcare experiences of people with incurable head and neck cancer (HNC).

Key aspects:

- Study Design: Longitudinal interviews with incurable HNC patients and family carers (Work Package 1a), online focus groups with healthcare professionals involved in HNC care (Work Package 1b), and co-design workshops (Work Package 2) utilizing findings from Work Packages 1a and 1b.

- Setting: Three HNC centers in Northwest, Northeast, and Yorkshire regions of England.

- Methods: 
    - Work Package 1a: Up to 60 longitudinal interviews with 18-25 incurable HNC patients and/or family carers at 4-month intervals.
    - Work Package 1b: Up to 5 online focus groups with around 20 healthcare professionals involved in HNC care.
    - Work Package 2: Initial virtual meetings, followed by two in-person co-design workshops with patients, carers, healthcare professionals, and other stakeholders to identify priority areas

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the use of indocyanine green (ICG) fluorescence imaging to assist in the identification of nerve roots during endoscopic spinal surgery for lumbar disc herniation.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ICG fluorescence imaging in visualizing nerve roots intraoperatively, compared to standard endoscopic spinal surgery without ICG. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: a control group receiving standard surgery, or one of three experimental groups receiving different doses of intravenous ICG (0.5 mg/kg, 1 mg/kg, or 2 mg/kg) before surgery. The surgeons will use a fluorescence imaging system to identify and protect the nerve roots during the procedure.

The primary outcomes include the fluorescence imaging rate of nerve roots, the fluorescence signal ratio of nerve roots to background, and the time taken to find the nerve roots endoscopically. Secondary outcomes include ICG-related adverse reactions, pain scores, disability scores, surgical complications, and length of surgery.

The study aims to determine the optimal dose of ICG and assess the potential benefits of fluorescence

This is a non-randomized, parallel-group study evaluating the effectiveness of a home-based parenting support program called "Parenting Young Children" (PYC) for parents with intellectual and developmental disabilities (IDDs), including intellectual disability, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, and autism spectrum disorder. The study aims to assess the impact of PYC on parenting performance, satisfaction, sense of competence, and child behavior compared to treatment as usual (TAU) provided by social services.

The PYC intervention involves weekly one-hour sessions over 3-6 months, focusing on parent-child interaction and child care skills and safety. The TAU group receives various interventions typically provided by social services, such as counseling, practical support, skills training, and compensatory strategies.

The primary outcomes are changes in the Canadian Occupational Performance Measure's performance and satisfaction subscales. Secondary outcomes include changes in the Parental Sense of Competence Scale and the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire.

The study includes parents with IDDs who have children aged 0-9 years living at home and are assessed by social services as eligible for tailored parenting support. Exclus

This is a prospective observational study aimed at collecting data on male patients undergoing surgery for stress urinary incontinence using either artificial urinary sphincters (AUS) or male slings. The study will gather information on patient characteristics, surgical details, and outcomes through questionnaires and follow-up assessments. The primary outcome measure is the success rate (cure plus improvement) based on 24-hour pad use at 5 years after surgery. Secondary outcomes include time being continent, time being revision-free, revision-free rate, patient-reported quality of life, and post-operative adverse events. The study will follow patients for up to 5 years, with assessments at 12 weeks, 12 months, and yearly intervals thereafter. The goal is to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of these surgical interventions for treating male stress urinary incontinence.

This is a clinical trial evaluating the use of 68Ga-NOTA-H006, a radioactive tracer, for PET imaging in detecting malignant tumors. The key aspects are:

- The trial aims to assess 5T4 expression in pancreatic, lung, and colorectal cancers using 68Ga-NOTA-H006 PET imaging.

- Eligible participants are between 18-65 years old with confirmed or suspected pancreatic, lung, or colorectal cancer.

- Participants will receive a single intravenous injection of 68Ga-NOTA-H006 at a dose of 1.8 MBq/kg for PET imaging.

- The primary outcome measure is establishing and optimizing the imaging method for 68Ga-NOTA-H006 PET by analyzing the standardized uptake value (SUV) on lesions and comparing it with 5T4 expression in pathological specimens.

- The study is an open-label, single-group assignment trial with a diagnostic purpose.

- Participants will also undergo 18F-FDG PET/CT

This clinical trial aims to investigate the biological mechanisms behind cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) in heart failure patients. The study involves two groups: a CRT group receiving CRT implantation and a control group receiving medical treatment for heart failure. Participants will undergo assessments, including echocardiography, ECG, blood sampling, and endothelial function tests, at multiple time points (before treatment, 3 months, 6 months, and 12 months). A subset of the CRT group will also undergo heart biopsies before implantation and at 3 months. The collected blood samples, heart tissue, and clinical data will be analyzed for proteins, exosomal miRNA, RNA, and contractility. The primary outcome measure is identifying biomarkers (proteins or exosomal miRNA) from blood samples that can distinguish CRT responders from non-responders. The secondary outcome measure is evaluating endothelial function and red blood cell studies to separate CRT responders from non-responders. The study aims to provide insights into the biological mechanisms underlying the effectiveness of CRT in heart failure patients.

This is a study investigating medication strategies for heart failure patients who are intolerant to guideline-directed medical therapy (GDMT). The study aims to provide evidence on effective medication approaches for these patients.

The study has two arms:
1) Heart failure patients tolerant to GDMT (ACEIs/ARBs/ARNI, beta-blockers, SGLT2 inhibitors, and MRAs)
2) Heart failure patients intolerant to one or more GDMT medications due to hypotension, hyperkalemia, or renal insufficiency

The primary outcome is the risk of all-cause mortality, heart failure readmission, or need for intravenous diuretics within 180 days. Secondary outcomes include changes in heart failure symptoms, NT-proBNP levels, echocardiographic parameters (LVEF, LVEDD, LVESD, LVFS), blood pressure, and potassium levels.

The study includes heart failure patients with reduced ejection fraction (≤45%) aged 18 years or older, with elevated NT-proBNP levels. Key exclusion criteria are preserved ejection fraction, severe lung

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating strategies to improve patient adherence to patient-reported outcome (PRO) monitoring in cancer care. The trial has three arms:

1. Usual practice (encounter-based PRO monitoring)
2. Encounter-based PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts for severe symptoms
3. Remote weekly PRO monitoring with patient reminders and triage nurse alerts

The primary outcome is PRO adherence, measured as the proportion of expected PRO questionnaires completed by each patient over 3 months. Secondary outcomes include documentation of PROs in clinical notes, time to alert response, acute care utilization, treatment delays/modifications, and duration of therapy. 

The trial aims to address limitations of current PRO approaches, such as suboptimal clinician engagement, lack of longitudinal monitoring outside of clinic visits, and insufficient automated linking of reported symptoms to clinical response. By employing behavioral strategies targeting clinician engagement, remote monitoring methods, and automated triage alerts, the study seeks to improve sustained patient-level PRO adherence and potentially reduce disparities in symptom management among historically marginalized groups.

This is a cross-sectional prospective study aimed at understanding the prognostic awareness of patients with advanced cancer referred to the Enhanced Supportive Care (ESC) service at University College London Hospital. The primary objective is to assess patients' level of prognostic understanding using the Prognosis and Treatment Perception Questionnaire. Secondary objectives include evaluating the relationship between prognostic awareness and psychological distress, quality of life, trust in medical professionals, and perceived quality of care. Eligible participants are adults with advanced cancer referred to the ESC team, excluding those with cognitive impairment or already receiving community palliative care. After obtaining informed consent, participants will complete a questionnaire covering prognostic awareness, psychological symptoms, and quality of life. The study aims to include 100 patients and will use regression analyses to identify factors associated with prognostic unawareness and psychological burden. The findings will inform strategies to improve care and communication for patients with advanced cancer.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of direct-from-blood bacterial testing using the T2Bacteria® Panel on antibiotic administration and clinical outcomes in patients with suspected bloodstream infections or sepsis. The study involves two parallel arms: 1) Usual care with standard blood cultures, and 2) Direct-from-blood testing with the T2Bacteria® Panel in addition to usual care. The primary outcome measure is the time to the last dose of intravenous vancomycin within 14 days of randomization. Secondary outcomes include the time to the last dose of systemic anti-pseudomonal beta-lactam antibiotics within 14 days. The study is conducted in the Emergency Department of Vanderbilt University Hospital and includes adult patients who have been ordered blood cultures and intravenous vancomycin. The trial aims to evaluate the impact of direct-from-blood bacterial testing on antibiotic administration and clinical outcomes in patients with suspected bloodstream infections or sepsis.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of temperature-elevating armbaths (Hauffe-Schwenninger baths) as a complementary therapy for regulating blood pressure in people with arterial hypertension. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of this hydrotherapeutic approach in reducing blood pressure.

The trial will enroll 50 adult participants diagnosed with arterial hypertension (stage I or higher). Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group or a waitlist control group. The intervention group will perform temperature-elevating armbaths at home, starting with water at 37°C and gradually increasing the temperature to 42°C over 30 minutes, 5 days per week for 8 weeks. The control group will continue their usual treatment.

The primary outcome measure is blood pressure, assessed through 24-hour ambulatory blood pressure monitoring at baseline, 8 weeks, and 6 months. Secondary outcomes include health-related quality of life, sleep quality, heart rate, adverse events, and changes in medication.

After the 6-month follow-up, participants in the control group will be offered instructions on performing the armbaths

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of acupuncture and mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) on perceived stress and health in military service members and veterans. The study has two parallel arms: an experimental group receiving both manual standardized stress acupuncture (MSSA) and MBSR, and an active comparator group receiving only MBSR. The primary outcome measure is the Perceived Stress Scale (PSS), while secondary outcomes include the Insomnia Severity Index, the Short Form (SF) Health Survey, and journal log entries. Participants in the experimental group will receive 4 weekly sessions of MSSA and 4 sessions of MBSR group psychotherapy, while the comparator group will receive only the 4 MBSR sessions. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, 2 weeks post-interventions, and 4 weeks post-interventions. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of acupuncture and mindfulness-based interventions in reducing perceived stress and improving overall health in military personnel and veterans.

This is a prevalence study aimed at determining the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in adults aged 18-100 years in Punta Arenas, Magallanes and Chilean Antarctic Region. The study will identify participants who had at least one positive SARS-CoV-2 RT-qPCR test between July 2022 and July 2023 from the COVID-19 database maintained by the local health authority. The primary outcome measure is to determine the prevalence of persistent COVID-19 in this cohort. Secondary outcomes include collecting sociodemographic data, assessing psychological profiles, sleep quality, psychosocial exposures, standard laboratory parameters, inflammatory biomarkers, immunological repertoire, musculoskeletal function, and clinical determination of persistent COVID-19 diagnosis. The study involves questionnaires, cognitive and psychological tests, blood tests, DNA sequencing, flow cytometry, and physical assessments over a period of 8 months.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial comparing two interventions for managing unintentional dural puncture (UDP) during labor in obstetric patients: resiting the epidural catheter versus intrathecal catheter placement. The primary outcome is the incidence of post-dural puncture headache (PDPH) at 24 hours after UDP occurrence. Secondary outcomes include PDPH intensity at 24 and 48 hours, quality of analgesia during labor, adverse events, chronic pain at 1 and 3 months, hospital readmissions, and patient satisfaction. Eligible participants are females aged 18 years or older with confirmed UDP during labor. They will be randomly assigned to either have the epidural catheter resited or an intrathecal catheter placed for analgesia maintenance. The study aims to determine the better approach for managing UDP and preventing PDPH in obstetric patients.

This is a randomized, parallel-group clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of sectional matrix versus circumferential matrix for reconstructing proximal contacts in Class 2 restorations. Patients aged 18-60 years with compound Class 2 cavities in fully erupted premolars or molars will be randomly assigned to receive either a sectional matrix band or a circumferential matrix band secured by a retainer. Local anesthesia, caries removal, cavity preparation, and composite resin restoration will be performed following standard procedures. The primary outcome is the tightness of the proximal contact, categorized as optimum, tight, or open, evaluated immediately after the procedure using dental floss. The trial aims to determine which matrix system better reconstructs optimal proximal contacts in Class 2 composite restorations.

This clinical trial evaluates the effectiveness of a pay-for-performance (PFP) program called "Partners in Wellness" for high utilizers of mental health services in Santa Clara County, California. The trial compares the PFP program to usual care (UC) in reducing the total cost of 24-hour psychiatric services over 12, 24, and 36 months post-enrollment.

The PFP group receives tailored services like assertive case management, crisis intervention, substance use counseling, mental health treatment, peer support, and care coordination from a contracted provider agency. The provider agency is incentivized with financial rewards or penalties based on whether their enrollees utilize more or less care compared to a historical cohort.

The UC group receives the standard outpatient and inpatient mental health services offered by Santa Clara County.

The primary outcomes measure the total cost of various 24-hour psychiatric services, including emergency psychiatric services, inpatient care, residential facilities, and state hospitals. Secondary outcomes examine costs for specific services like acute inpatient care and incarceration rates.

The study includes adults aged 18-65 with psychotic disorders, bipolar disorder, or substance use disorders who

This is a large multi-center randomized controlled trial investigating the clinical efficacy and cost-effectiveness of culturally adapted cognitive behavioral therapy (CaCBT) and culturally adapted family intervention (CulFI) compared to treatment as usual (TAU) for individuals with first-episode psychosis in Pakistan. The study aims to enroll 390 participants across 10 centers who will be randomly assigned to receive either CaCBT + TAU, CulFI + TAU, or TAU alone. The CaCBT intervention consists of 12 weekly one-on-one sessions, while the CulFI intervention involves 10 weekly sessions with patients and their caregivers. The primary outcome is change in positive and negative symptoms measured by the Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale (PANSS) at 3, 6, and 12 months. Secondary outcomes include depression, quality of life, disability, insight, caregiver experiences, and treatment adherence. The study will also conduct economic evaluations of the interventions' cost-effectiveness and cost-utility. Process evaluation will assess implementation across study settings.

This is a Phase 1/2 multi-center study evaluating the safety and efficacy of IMPT-314, a CD19/20 bispecific chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy, in participants with relapsed or refractory aggressive B-cell non-Hodgkin lymphoma (NHL). The study includes participants aged 18 years or older with histologically confirmed aggressive NHL, including diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL), primary mediastinal large B-cell lymphoma, high-grade large B-cell lymphoma, and transformed follicular lymphoma, who have received at least two prior lines of therapy.

The study has a Phase 1 dose-finding part with two dose levels (1×10^8 and 3×10^8 IMPT-314 cells) and a Phase 2 part with a single dose determined in Phase 1. Participants are divided into CAR T-experienced and CAR T-naive cohorts in each phase. The primary outcomes include incidence of dose-limiting toxicities, complete response rate, and proportion of participants receiving the target dose in Phase 1

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of metabolic syndrome (MetS) and its components on cognitive performance and physical activity levels in middle-aged individuals. The study involves two groups: an intervention group consisting of participants diagnosed with MetS between the ages of 18 and 50, and a control group of healthy individuals within the same age range. The primary outcome measures include evaluations of MetS components (waist circumference, blood pressure, triglyceride levels, HDL-C, and fasting plasma levels), MetS severity score, cognitive assessments (Montreal Cognitive Assessment, Stroop Test), and physical activity measures (International Physical Activity Questionnaire Short-Form, pedometer). Secondary outcome measures include the Mini-Mental State Examination and a visual reaction test. The study aims to assess the impact of MetS on cognitive function and physical activity levels by comparing the two groups.

This clinical trial aims to test the effectiveness of two brief digital interventions in increasing COVID-19 vaccine uptake among individuals with anxiety or depression. The study will recruit undervaccinated participants from the CHASING COVID Cohort, a large US community-based cohort. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three intervention arms: 1) an attitudinal inoculation intervention addressing anti-vaccine misinformation, 2) a cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT)-informed intervention focused on addressing barriers to vaccination, or 3) a conventional public health messaging intervention without attitudinal inoculation or CBT content. The primary outcome is self-reported receipt of a COVID-19 vaccine dose within 4 weeks post-intervention.
