Secondary outcomes include vaccine hesitancy at different time points and self-reported vaccine receipt at 6 months post-intervention. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these interventions in increasing vaccine uptake among individuals with anxiety or depression, a population that may face unique barriers to vaccination.

This clinical trial aimed to examine the effects of binaural beat music on sleep quality, heart rate variability, and depression in older adults with poor sleep quality residing in a long-term care institution. The study had a randomized, parallel-group design with two arms: a binaural beat music group (BBM group) and a control group.

The BBM group listened to 15 minutes of Taiwanese Hokkien oldies (familiar music selected by the participant) with binaural beats embedded, while the control group listened to the same music without binaural beats. Both groups received the intervention for 20 minutes, three times a week (Monday, Wednesday, and Friday) for two weeks, totaling 12 sessions.

The primary outcomes measured were sleep quality (using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, PSQI) and heart rate variability (using an HRV analyzer). The secondary outcome was depression (using the Geriatric Depression Scale, GDS). Assessments were conducted at baseline and on Day 14 after the intervention.

The study included older adults aged 75-90 years with poor sleep quality (PSQI score > 7) residing in a long-

This is a mixed methods implementation science study aimed at evaluating the implementation of a Personalized Follow-up (PFU) pathway for patients with head and neck cancer. The study aims to understand the barriers and facilitators to achieving high fidelity and sustainability of the PFU pathway for patients and healthcare providers. The key aspects of the study are:

1. Eligibility: Patients referred to the Head and Neck Cancer Personalized Follow-Up clinic, treated with curative intent for head and neck cancer, disease-free for at least 2 years post-treatment, and healthcare providers involved in their care.

2. Intervention: Discharge from routine oncology follow-up 2 years after radical treatment for head and neck cancer.

3. Primary Outcomes: Acceptability of the PFU pathway to patients and service providers, safety of the PFU pathway in terms of timely detection of recurrent cancers.

4. Secondary Outcomes: Patient and service provider experience with the PFU pathway, sustainability of the PFU pathway.

5. Methods: Semi-structured interviews with patients and healthcare providers, cross-sectional patient surveys, analysis of clinical data on rec

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial comparing the effects of intrathecal bupivacaine-dexmedetomidine and intrathecal bupivacaine-neostigmine in elective cesarean sections. The study aims to evaluate the time taken to achieve a bilateral sensory block at T10 level after intrathecal injection.

The study involves three groups:

1. Group 1 (18 patients) received 10 mg hyperbaric bupivacaine, 10 μg dexmedetomidine, and 0.1 ml normal saline.
2. Group 2 (18 patients) received 10 mg hyperbaric bupivacaine, 50 μg neostigmine, and 0.1 ml normal saline.
3. Group 3 (18 patients) received 10 mg hyperbaric bupivacaine and 0.2 ml normal saline (control group).

The primary outcome measure is the time started from the end of intrathecal injection until the achievement of a bilateral sensory block at

This is a randomized, single-center, examiner-masked, parallel-group clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of an air-polishing device with erythritol powder (Air-Flow Prophylaxis Master) compared to a conventional ultrasonic scaler in preventing white spot lesions (WSLs) and gingivitis among patients undergoing fixed orthodontic treatment for 2 years. The primary outcomes are the appearance of WSLs and inflammatory lesions, and changes in clinical parameters like plaque accumulation, gingival inflammation, and bleeding on probing. Secondary outcomes include patient acceptance, tooth sensitivity, microbial counts, inflammatory markers in gingival crevicular fluid, and total treatment time. Participants aged 12-16 years will be randomly assigned to receive either monthly air-polishing or ultrasonic scaling every 6 months during their orthodontic treatment. Clinical examinations and sample collections will be performed at regular intervals to assess the outcomes.

This is a pilot study aimed at analyzing tissue samples from patients undergoing cardiothoracic surgery at the University Hospital Southampton NHS Foundation Trust. The study will recruit up to 10 patients, including thoracic surgical patients with or without a history of atrial fibrillation (AF) undergoing lung resection, and cardiac surgical patients with a history of AF undergoing left atrial appendage (LAA) exclusion.

The primary objectives are to perform histological analysis (immunohistochemistry, in situ hybridization, electron microscopy, collagen cross-linking) and molecular analysis (genome sequencing, miRNA and RNA sequencing, culture, RT-PCR, flow cytometry, and immunocytochemistry) on the excised tissue samples, which would normally be discarded. These analyses aim to investigate the role of tissue fibrosis and other factors in promoting and sustaining AF.

The study will include patients of both sexes, aged between 18 and 100 years, who are able to provide informed consent. Patients who are not undergoing ostial pulmonary vein or LAA tissue excision as part of their routine clinical care will be excluded.

The provided clinical trial document aims to compare the effects of integrated and isolated resisted exercise on strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners. The study involves two groups: Group 1 will undergo an integrated resisted training (INT) program involving exercises targeting core stability, power, and strength, while Group 2 will undergo an isolated resisted training (ISO) program with exercises like leg press, bench press, and back squats. The primary outcome measures include endurance (measured by a sit-up test), power (measured by a vertical jump test), and strength (measured by a 1RM maximum test). The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment clinical trial with a single-blind approach. Participants will be male gym beginners aged 18-30 years, with no history of regular exercise, lower limb injuries, or chronic diseases affecting physical function. The study aims to help coaches and trainers identify the most effective training methods for improving strength, power, and endurance in gym beginners.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of two interventions, Play Based Therapy and Functional Communication Training, in children aged 2 to 6 years with speech and language developmental delays due to hearing loss. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-group trial with two active comparator arms. Participants in Group A will receive Play Based Therapy, while those in Group B will receive Functional Communication Training. Both interventions will be delivered through 20-30 minute sessions, 5 days a week, for 3 months. The primary outcome measure is the change in functional language ability assessed by the Speech Questionnaire, measured at baseline and after 3 months of intervention. The study aims to determine which of the two therapies is more effective in improving speech and language skills in children with developmental delays.

This is a study evaluating the implementation and integration of Horyzons, a digital intervention platform, in outpatient mental health clinics in North Carolina that provide care for individuals with schizophrenia spectrum and other psychotic disorders. The primary aim is to assess barriers and facilitators of integrating Horyzons into first episode psychosis (FEP) clinics as part of standard care, using distinct implementation strategies for each clinic. Secondary aims include evaluating client engagement with Horyzons, attrition, changes in psychological measures, and use of state-funded services over 12 months. Around 20 clinicians/peer specialists will provide feedback on implementation barriers/facilitators through surveys and interviews. Approximately 50 FEP clients aged 16-35 will be recruited to use Horyzons for 12 months as part of clinical care, with assessments at baseline, 6 months, 12 months, and 3-month follow-up. Horyzons provides tailored therapeutic content and a moderated online community. Primary outcomes are qualitative and quantitative feedback from providers on implementation barriers/facilitators. Secondary outcomes include client engagement with Horyzons,

This clinical trial aims to investigate the expression levels of inflammatory and anti-inflammatory genes in liver transplant patients before and after the operation. The study involves two groups: a control group of healthy individuals and a group of liver transplant patients. The primary outcome measures include biochemical parameters (ALT, AST, PLT, AFP, bilirubin, and CRP levels) and gene expression levels of inflammatory cytokines (IL-2, IL-6, IFN-γ, TNF-α), anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-4, IL-10), TREM-1, HLA-G5, FOXP3, and CD14 in peripheral blood samples before the surgery. Secondary outcome measures include the same gene expression parameters at 2-3 months and 4-6 months after the surgery. The study aims to identify potential biomarkers with high predictive value for rejection and infection after liver transplantation by analyzing the gene expression patterns and biochemical parameters in liver transplant patients compared to healthy controls.

This is a phase 1, open-label, non-randomized clinical trial to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of intravitreal injections of BI 771716 in patients with geographic atrophy secondary to age-related macular degeneration. The trial has two parts:

1. Single Rising Dose (SRD) part: Patients receive a single intravitreal injection of BI 771716 at low, medium, or high doses to assess dose-limiting events, adverse events, and pharmacokinetic parameters like maximum serum concentration and area under the curve.

2. Multiple Dose (MD) part: Patients receive multiple intravitreal injections of BI 771716 to evaluate drug-related adverse events and trough serum concentrations. 

Key eligibility criteria include age ≥50 years, geographic atrophy lesion ≥1 disc diameter in the study eye, and better visual acuity in the non-study eye. The primary outcomes are occurrence of dose-limiting events (SRD part) and drug-related adverse events (MD part). Secondary outcomes include ocular adverse events

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial comparing furosemide-induced diuresis with matched dehydration using the RenalGuard device to standard furosemide diuretic therapy in patients with acute decompensated heart failure and overt fluid overload. The primary outcome is the occurrence of acute kidney injury, measured by daily serum creatinine levels up to 72 hours. The secondary outcome is daily weight decrease during the study treatment period of up to 72 hours. Eligible participants are adults over 18 years old with New York Heart Association class III or IV heart failure, significant fluid overload, and elevated B-type natriuretic peptide levels. The control group receives standard furosemide infusion, while the experimental group receives furosemide infusion with matched dehydration using the RenalGuard device to replace urine output with intravenous fluids.

This is a pilot study aimed at determining the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of a self-guided mindfulness-based intervention for pediatric patients aged 12-18 years with idiopathic (unexplained) chest pain. The study has two arms: a standard of care control group and an experimental group receiving a 30-day mindfulness intervention through the Headspace mobile app. The mindfulness intervention involves completing three 10-day courses (Basics, Basics 2, and Basics 3) with daily audio sessions ranging from 3 to 20 minutes, focusing on body awareness, breathing, and non-judgmental awareness of thoughts and emotions.

The primary outcomes measure feasibility through participant recruitment, retention, adherence to the mindfulness program, and survey response rates. Acceptability is assessed through a program evaluation survey. Secondary outcomes include pain coping strategies, perceived stress, quality of life, and frequency and intensity of chest pain episodes.

The study aims to evaluate if a self-guided mindfulness intervention is feasible, acceptable, and effective in improving pain coping, reducing stress, enhancing quality of life, and decreasing chest pain frequency and intensity in pediatric patients with id

This is a randomized, triple-blind, parallel-group, non-inferiority trial investigating the safety and immunogenicity of concomitant administration of the Novavax COVID-19 vaccine (NVX) and a 20-valent pneumococcal conjugate vaccine (PCV20) in adults aged 60 years or older. The study has four arms: NVX plus placebo, PCV20 plus placebo, NVX plus PCV20, and placebo plus placebo. The primary outcome measure is antibody levels at day 28. Eligible participants are adults aged 60 or above who have received three prior COVID-19 vaccine doses, with the third dose being an mRNA vaccine at least 16 weeks prior. Key exclusion criteria include immunosuppression, immunodeficiency, recent COVID-19 infection, and previous pneumococcal vaccination.

This is a phase I/II, open-label, single-center study evaluating the combination of the anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint inhibitor durvalumab and the TLR-3 agonist rintatolimod in patients with metastatic pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma. The primary objectives are to determine the safety and recommended phase II dose (RP2D) of the combination in phase Ib, and to evaluate the clinical benefit rate in phase II. Key secondary objectives include assessing survival outcomes, exploring immunogenic effects on circulating and tumor-infiltrating immune profiles, and evaluating quality of life. Eligible patients have metastatic pancreatic cancer with stable disease after FOLFIRINOX chemotherapy. In the treatment regimen, rintatolimod is given first via IV twice weekly for 6 weeks, followed by the addition of durvalumab IV every 4 weeks for up to 48 weeks. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility, efficacy and immunomodulatory effects of this novel combination immunotherapy approach in pancreatic cancer.

This is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, single-center clinical trial aimed at evaluating the prophylactic effects of the flavonoid diosmin on delayed-onset muscle soreness (DOMS) in humans. The study will recruit approximately 40 female athletes aged 16-35 years from the women's five-a-side soccer team in Londrina, Brazil. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group receiving 750 mg diosmin tablets or the placebo group receiving corn starch tablets. The treatment will be administered orally once daily for two days before and immediately before an intense dynamic exercise protocol involving leg press repetitions until fatigue. The primary outcome is muscle soreness, measured by digital algometer and visual analogue scale at baseline, 24 hours, and 48 hours after the exercise protocol. Secondary outcomes include muscle damage (creatine phosphokinase levels), oxidative stress (lipid peroxidation and antioxidant capacity), muscle function (knee extension torque and vertical jump height), and postural balance. The study aims to investigate whether diosmin supplementation can reduce DOMS, muscle damage, oxidative

This is a prospective observational study aimed at evaluating the short-term (3 months), medium-term (1 year), and long-term (2 years) effects of intrathecal baclofen (ITB) therapy on personal treatment goals in children with cerebral palsy (CP). The study will be conducted at the Amsterdam University Medical Center and Maastricht University Medical Center in the Netherlands, utilizing data from the Netherlands CP register.

The primary outcome measure is goal attainment scaling (GAS), which quantifies the achievement of individual treatment goals. Secondary outcomes include range of motion, spasticity, dystonia, scoliosis, selective motor control, functional strength, gait analysis, activities and participation questionnaires, and ITB treatment characteristics (dosage, complications).

The study aims to include 67 to 90 children and adolescents with CP under the age of 16 who are starting ITB treatment. Data will be collected before ITB initiation, at 3 months, 1 year, and 2 years.

The study objectives are:
1. Evaluate the short-, medium-, and long-term effects of ITB on

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the impact of vitamin D supplementation on the risk of developing gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) in pregnant women at high risk for GDM with low vitamin D levels (<30 ng/mL) at 7-11 weeks of gestation. The study aims to recruit pregnant women aged 21-40 years who meet the inclusion criteria, such as having a history of GDM, first-degree relatives with diabetes, overweight/obesity, or polycystic ovarian syndrome. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either vitamin D3 supplementation (200,000 IU/week) for 4-6 weeks or a placebo. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of GDM based on the International Association of Diabetes and Pregnancy Study Groups Criteria after a 75g oral glucose tolerance test at 28 weeks of gestation. The study findings may contribute to understanding the relationship between vitamin D and GDM risk and inform clinical practice and public health recommendations for vitamin D supplementation during pregnancy.

This is a prospective, multicenter, single-arm, open-label study evaluating the safety and effectiveness of the Neuroguard IEP Direct System for treating carotid artery stenosis in patients at high risk for adverse events after carotid endarterectomy. The Neuroguard IEP Direct System is a 3-in-1 carotid stent delivery system consisting of an angioplasty balloon, integrated embolic protection device, and a self-expanding nitinol stent. Eligible patients aged 20-80 years with symptomatic ≥50% or asymptomatic ≥70% carotid stenosis will receive the Neuroguard IEP Direct System. The primary outcome is the 30-day composite rate of major adverse events (stroke, myocardial infarction, and death). Patients will be followed for 30 days post-procedure, with additional follow-up for those experiencing stroke or cranial nerve injury.

This is a pilot study aimed at testing the feasibility, safety, and potential effectiveness of a 10-week Nordic Walking (NW) intervention for community-dwelling older adults at risk of falling or experiencing fear of falling (FOF). The study will be conducted in two stages.

Stage One is a two-arm, parallel, single-blind, randomized controlled trial. Forty older adults (aged 60+) at risk of falling will be recruited and randomly assigned to either the NW intervention group or a control group. The intervention group will receive supervised NW training sessions and coaching to practice independently, while the control group will receive regular phone calls discussing healthy lifestyle habits.

The primary outcomes include estimating the effect size of the intervention, evaluating adherence rates (as a measure of feasibility), and assessing the safety of the intervention by monitoring adverse events. Secondary outcomes will be assessed using measures such as the Timed Up and Go (TUG) test, Falls Efficacy Scale-International (FES-I), and the Four-Square Step Test (FSST) to evaluate fall risk, fear of falling, and balance, respectively.

Stage Two involves qualitative interviews with participants in the intervention group to

This clinical trial aims to develop and test online interventions to increase help-seeking for anxiety and depression among sexual and gender minority youth (SGMY). The study will use a user-informed approach to design and evaluate four intervention principles (IPs) focused on different aspects like intersectionality, confidentiality, educating communities, and finding affirming care providers. 

The trial will randomly assign 96 SGMY participants aged 14-19 with mild or higher anxiety/depression symptoms to one of 16 combinations of the four IPs or a control group. Over one month, feasibility (usage), usability, acceptability, and impact on help-seeking intentions will be measured for each IP combination. 

The goal is to identify promising IPs and components to inform the development of a comprehensive online intervention tailored to address unique barriers to mental health treatment faced by SGMY. This user-centered approach aims to create an engaging, affirming intervention to motivate SGMY to seek professional help for their mental health needs.

This is a randomized, parallel-assignment clinical trial investigating the application of propofol mixed with remifentanil for controlled sedation and analgesia during fiber colonoscopy procedures. The study aims to compare two methods of anesthesia administration:

1. Controlled analgesia/sedation (PCAS) group: Patients self-administer a mixture of propofol and remifentanil using a patient-controlled analgesia pump during the colonoscopy procedure.

2. Intravenous combined anesthesia group: Patients receive intravenous fentanyl, midazolam, and propofol administered by an anesthesiologist to induce unconsciousness before the colonoscopy.

The primary outcome measure is the auditory evoked potential index (AEPI), which reflects brain electrical activity in response to auditory stimuli. AEPI values are recorded at various time points before, during, and after the colonoscopy procedure.

The secondary outcome measure is the time taken for patients to reach specific recovery scores (OAA/S score of 5 and Aldrete score of 9) after the procedure.

This is a prospective, observational, confirmatory, single-center study aimed at predicting the chronicization of radiation-induced acute intestinal injury (RAII) based on the expression level of immune factors. The study will enroll 200 patients aged 18-75 years with locally advanced rectal cancer (T3-4/N+M0) who undergo neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy (NCRT) and total mesorectal excision (TME) and develop RAII during NCRT or within 1 month. The primary outcome is the area under the curve (AUC) of the prediction model for chronicization of RAII. Secondary outcomes include accuracy, precision, specificity, and sensitivity of the prediction model. Patients will undergo NCRT and TME according to treatment guidelines, and the expression levels of immune factors will be detected in pathological tissue after TME and applied to the prediction model. The study aims to develop a prediction model for chronicization of RAII based on immune factor expression levels, which could aid in the management and treatment of radiation-induced intestinal injury.

This is a Phase I randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and immunogenicity of an Omicron BA.4/5-Delta strain recombinant novel coronavirus protein vaccine (produced in CHO cells) in individuals aged 18 years and above. The trial aims to enroll 100 participants who are at least 6 months post-COVID-19 infection or vaccination. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the experimental vaccine or a placebo via intramuscular injection. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of adverse events (AEs), serious adverse events (SAEs), and adverse events of special interest (AESIs) within 12 months after vaccination. The secondary outcome measure is the geometric mean titer (GMT) of SARS-CoV-2 neutralizing antibodies against the prototype strain, Delta strain, and Omicron strains (BA.4/5, XBB) at 14 days after vaccination. Safety assessments include solicited and unsolicited AEs, as well as monitoring for specific events such as myocarditis, thrombosis, and immune-

This is a clinical trial evaluating the safety and performance of the ENDOMATIC SEPIOLA Left Atrial Appendage (LAA) Closure Device in patients with atrial fibrillation. The trial is an open-label, single-arm study with the primary outcome measure being device and procedure-related serious adverse events at 7 days, 45 days, and 6 months post-procedure. The secondary outcome measure is confirmation of functional LAA closure at 45 days. Eligible participants are adults with non-valvular atrial fibrillation, a CHA2DS2-VASc score of 2 or higher, and suitable LAA anatomy for the device. The intervention involves implantation of the SEPIOLA device into the left atrial appendage.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of motivational interviewing for patients with acute psychosis. The study aims to evaluate the impact of motivational interviewing on therapeutic alliance, treatment adherence, symptom severity, motivation for psychotherapy, and self-efficacy in patients with psychosis (ICD-10 diagnosis F2.x) admitted to inpatient units at the Psychiatric University Hospital of Zurich.

Participants aged 18-65 years will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving four sessions of motivational interviewing within two weeks or the active control group receiving four sessions of supportive conversations within the same timeframe. The primary outcomes are changes in therapeutic alliance (measured by the Scale to Assess Therapeutic Relationship) and treatment adherence (measured by the Brief Adherence Rating Scale) from baseline to week 3 or after the four sessions. Secondary outcomes include changes in symptom severity (Positive and Negative Syndrome Scale), motivation for psychotherapy (Questionnaire to measure the motivation for psychotherapy), and self-efficacy (General Self-Efficacy Scale).

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of motivational interviewing

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the application of chromosomal instability (CIN) detection in bile samples for the early diagnosis of biliary tract carcinoma. The study involves analyzing bile samples from patients with gallbladder cancer and cholangiocarcinoma, as well as control groups without any tumors in the bile duct, gallbladder, or other organs. The extracted DNA from the bile samples will be analyzed using a method called BileCAD, which detects CIN through low-coverage whole-genome sequencing and bioinformatics techniques.

The primary objectives are to determine the sensitivity and specificity of the BileCAD test in diagnosing biliary tract carcinoma by comparing it with pathological diagnosis. The secondary objectives include assessing the consistency of BileCAD microbial analysis results with clinical microbial culture results and evaluating the sensitivity of BileCAD in detecting different types and locations of malignant tumors.

The study will enroll participants aged 18 years or older who have not undergone systemic therapy or biliary tract surgery before the trial. Participants will be divided into two groups: biliary tract carcinoma patients (experimental group)

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the success of lumbar plexus block for lower extremity orthopedic surgeries using Near Infrared Spectroscopy (NIRS). NIRS is used to measure tissue oxygenation. The study involves attaching two NIRS probes, one on the extremity to be operated on and the other on the opposite lower extremity, at the level of the quadriceps femoris muscle. The primary outcome measure is the regional oxygen saturation (rSO2) measured by NIRS. Secondary outcomes include sensory block level, blood pressure values, and fingertip oxygen saturation (SO2). The study is a single-group, open-label design with participants aged 18-90 years undergoing lower extremity orthopedic surgeries requiring lumbar plexus block. Patients with conditions like BMI >40 kg/m2, infection at the block site, peripheral neuropathy, hemoglobinopathy, peripheral vascular disease, or allergy to local anesthetics are excluded.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the use of a digital platform (mindLAMP mobile application) to support the clinical effectiveness and integration of a task-shared, evidence-based psychosocial rehabilitation intervention (COPSI) for people with schizophrenia in primary care settings in India. The study aims to assess whether the mindLAMP app can enhance the clinical effectiveness (Aim 1) and integration (Aim 2) of the COPSI intervention.

The study has two arms: 1) Experimental arm receiving COPSI plus mindLAMP app, and 2) Active comparator arm receiving COPSI alone. COPSI is a collaborative, individualized intervention delivered in three phases by Community Health Officers. The mindLAMP app provides on-demand materials and scheduled content to promote engagement.

The primary outcome is disability measured by the Indian Disability Evaluation and Assessment Scale (IDEAS). Secondary outcomes include positive and negative symptoms (PANSS), anxiety (GAD-7), depression (PHQ-9), schizophrenia severity (CGI-SCH), and cognition (BACS). Assessments are done at baseline, 6

This is a prospective, interventional study investigating the characteristics of cytokine response in patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) treated with occlusal splint therapy. The study aims to analyze changes in the levels of pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-1β, IL-6, IL-7, IL-8, IL-13, and TNF-α) in circulating blood and gingival crevicular fluid (GCF) of TMD patients before and after treatment with stabilization occlusal splints. The primary outcomes are changes in cytokine levels in blood and GCF at baseline, one month, and three months after splint therapy. Secondary outcomes include changes in pain intensity, pain-related disability, oral health-related quality of life, perceived stress levels, jaw function limitation, depressed mood, anxiety, physical symptoms, and presence of parafunctional behaviors. The study involves participants aged 18-65 years diagnosed with myalgia, arthralgia, headache attributed to TMD, and/or painful disc displacement according to the Diagnostic Criteria for Temporomandibular Disorders (DC/TMD). Participants will be treated with

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of three different levels of digital training for addiction professionals on delivering the Community Reinforcement and Family Training (CRAFT) intervention for opioid use disorder (OUD) in families. The three arms are:

1. Digital tutorial overview only (T)
2. Digital tutorial plus weekly training materials (TM)  
3. Digital tutorial, training materials, plus feedback and coaching (TMC)

The primary outcome is CRAFT procedure fidelity measured through coded audio recordings of sessions with standardized patients. Secondary outcomes include CRAFT knowledge, program implementation potential, and new treatment entry rates for identified patients. 

Eligible participants are addiction counselors over 19 years old who have not been previously trained in CRAFT. The study aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of the different digital training approaches in improving CRAFT delivery and increasing treatment admission and retention for OUD among family members of the counselors' clients.

This is a prospective multi-center observational study aimed at describing the pattern of regional myocardial distribution of 3,3-diphosphono-1,2-propanedicarboxylic acid (DPD) SPECT uptake among patients with wild-type (ATTRwt) and hereditary (ATTRm) cardiac transthyretin amyloidosis. The study will enroll consecutive patients with Grade 1-3 cardiac DPD retention on scintigraphy and first-degree relatives of patients with ATTRm. Participants will undergo 99mTc-DPD scintigraphy, SPECT imaging, echocardiography, and TTR gene sequencing. The primary outcome is to compare the regional left ventricular 99mTc-DPD uptake between ATTRwt and ATTRm patients. Secondary outcomes include assessing right ventricular DPD accumulation and evaluating cardiac DPD uptake in asymptomatic ATTRm carriers. The study aims to investigate the clinical, biochemical, and echocardiographic features, including left ven

This clinical trial aims to study the long-COVID-19 syndrome in children aged 6 to 18 years. The primary objective is to diagnose, predict, and prevent post-COVID syndrome in children during the COVID-19 pandemic. The study involves conducting laboratory tests, questionnaires, and physical examinations on children who have recovered from COVID-19 or had asymptomatic infections. The primary outcome measure is the number of participants diagnosed with post-COVID syndrome within one year. The trial is designed as a single-group, open-label, interventional study with a prevention purpose. The intervention involves using devices for research on long-COVID-19 in children. The study highlights the need to investigate long-term and chronic symptoms of COVID-19 in children, as many cases may have gone unaccounted for during the pandemic.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of treadmill perturbation training for fall prevention after total knee replacement surgery. The study aims to recruit 378 participants scheduled for unilateral total knee arthroplasty (TKA). Participants will be randomly assigned to either the treadmill perturbation training group or the education control group.

The treadmill perturbation training group will undergo four sessions of training over two weeks before their surgery. During the training, participants will stand on a split-belt treadmill and experience controlled disturbances that simulate tripping or being perturbed to the side. They will be instructed to recover their balance and continue walking after each perturbation. The training aims to improve participants' ability to control their trunk motion and avoid falls.

The education control group will receive written educational materials related to fall prevention in older adults but will not undergo any additional training.

The primary outcomes measured are post-training trunk angle and angular velocity at the recovery step completion, and the fall rate during the first year after surgery. Secondary outcomes include fall status immediately after the training program.

The study will assess various demographic and functional risk factors for falls at baseline, including age, body mass

This is a single-arm, open-label, multicenter phase II study evaluating the efficacy and safety of the combination of cadonilimab (an anti-PD-1 antibody) plus nab-paclitaxel in patients with persistent, recurrent, or metastatic cervical cancer who have previously been treated with immune checkpoint inhibitors.

The primary objective is to assess the objective response rate (ORR) of this combination therapy. Secondary objectives include evaluating duration of response (DoR), disease control rate (DCR), time to response (TTR), progression-free survival (PFS), overall survival (OS), and safety/tolerability.

Key eligibility criteria include histologically confirmed cervical cancer, prior treatment failure with PD-1/PD-L1/CTLA-4 inhibitors, measurable disease per RECIST v1.1, adequate organ function, and provision of tumor tissue samples. The study excludes patients with active autoimmune diseases, immunodeficiency, significant cardiovascular/cerebrovascular disease, and other malignancies.

Patients will receive cadonilimab 10 mg/kg plus nab

This is a single-center, prospective, randomized, unblinded, controlled study conducted in Germany to assess the visual performance of the trifocal Hanita Lenses Intensity SL intraocular lens (IOL) compared to the trifocal Alcon PanOptix IOL in patients undergoing bilateral cataract surgery. The study aims to enroll approximately 58 patients, with 29 patients receiving bilateral implantation of the Intensity SL IOL and 29 patients receiving bilateral implantation of the PanOptix IOL. The primary outcome measure is to investigate whether the binocular distance-corrected visual acuity achieved with the Intensity SL IOL for distance, intermediate, and near ranges is not statistically significantly inferior to the parameters achieved with the PanOptix IOL. Secondary outcomes include defocus curve, contrast sensitivity, and patient satisfaction. Patients will undergo up to 10 study visits over 3-7 months, including preoperative, operative, and postoperative visits. The study follows relevant regulations and guidelines for clinical investigations of medical devices.

This is a retrospective, observational, single-center cohort study analyzing the hemodynamic effects of low-dose spinal anesthesia (1.3 mL 0.5% hyperbaric bupivacaine) for hip fracture surgery. The study includes adults over 18 years old who underwent hip fracture surgery with this low-dose spinal anesthesia technique between March 2017 and January 2020 at a specific hospital. The primary outcome measure is the cohort mean (SD) mean non-invasive blood pressure (MAP) taken at 2-minute intervals perioperatively. Secondary outcomes include the prevalence of hypotension defined by various blood pressure thresholds, mean depth x duration area under the curve for hypotension, blood pressure changes before spinal administration, effective duration of spinal anesthesia, and correlations between individual hypotension parameters and 30-day mortality/length of hospital stay. The study aims to determine if lower spinal doses are associated with reduced intraoperative hypotension compared to published data, and if hypotension correlates with postoperative outcomes in this patient population.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of malaria and intestinal parasitic diseases on COVID-19 transmission, morbidity, and immune responses in Malawi. The study will enroll up to 200 symptomatic COVID-19 cases (index cases), their household contacts (anticipated 700), and up to 600 vaccinees. The primary objectives are to assess the risk of asymptomatic infection among household contacts, the duration of neutralizing antibody responses, and changes in innate immune responses. Secondary objectives include evaluating the probability of household transmission, duration of COVID-19 symptoms, reinfection rates, breakthrough infection rates, antibody responses, and cellular immune responses. The study will follow participants for up to 1.5 years and collect blood and stool samples at various time points to measure immune parameters, antibody levels, and viral load. The findings may provide insights into how malaria and parasitic infections influence COVID-19 susceptibility, severity, and immune responses in this population.

This is a summary of the provided clinical trial document:

The study aims to investigate the effect of hot-cold application to the bladder on postoperative urinary retention (PUR) in patients undergoing orthopedic surgery. PUR is a common complication after orthopedic surgeries, leading to increased hospital stay, infection risk, and costs. The study is designed as a single-blind, randomized controlled trial with two parallel groups.

The experimental group will receive hot and cold application to the bladder using a thermophor device, while the control group will receive routine clinical care. The primary outcome measure is the prevention of PUR by applying hot and cold to the bladder, assessed through physiological parameters and questionnaires during the first 6 hours of the postoperative period.

Eligibility criteria include being 18 years or older, no urinary catheter inserted during the perioperative process, conscious and oriented, no renal disease, and voluntary acceptance to participate. Patients with intellectual disability, communication disability, or renal diseases will be excluded.

The study aims to contribute to the effective management of PUR in orthopedic surgery patients, minimize the need for invasive intervent

This is a prospective, multicenter study aimed at evaluating the sensitivity and specificity of a deep-learning integrated model that combines relevant clinical factors and radiomic features extracted from high-concentration (370 mgI/ml) Iopromide-enhanced pancreatic CT images obtained within 14 days after symptom onset, in predicting one-year recurrence risk of acute pancreatitis.

The primary objective is to assess the sensitivity and specificity of the model in predicting the first recurrence of acute pancreatitis within a 12-month follow-up period. Secondary objectives include evaluating the model's performance in predicting recurrence at 3 and 6 months, assessing the image quality of the CT scans, and analyzing the model's performance based on different types and severities of acute pancreatitis.

The study plans to enroll 694 eligible patients with a first episode of acute pancreatitis across 10 sites. Patients will undergo the enhanced CT scan, and relevant clinical information will be collected. Radiomics features will be extracted from the CT images, and patients will be followed up for 12 months to determine recurrence status. The

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effect of continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment on polycythemia (increased red blood cell count) in patients with obstructive sleep apnea. The study aims to compare changes in hematocrit (primary outcome) and hemoglobin levels between patients receiving CPAP plus conventional treatment and those receiving only conventional treatment over 12 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in quality of life, sleepiness, and the relationship between hypoxic burden, oxygen desaturation indices, and hematocrit/hemoglobin levels. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-80 years with polycythemia, moderate to severe obstructive sleep apnea, and without certain comorbidities like COPD, central sleep apnea, severe heart failure, or chronic kidney disease.

The study aims to compare the vaginal axis on MRI in patients undergoing different apical prolapse surgeries, including laparoscopic lateral suspension, laparoscopic pectopexy, and sacrospinous ligament fixation. The primary outcomes are vaginal axis and vaginal distances measured on MRI at 4 months post-operation. Secondary outcomes include prolapse symptoms, urinary symptoms, sexual function, quality of life measures, and patient global impression of improvement. The study involves female participants aged 18-80 years with genital prolapse, excluding those with certain conditions. It is a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with three intervention arms (lateral suspension, pectopexy, sacrospinous ligament fixation) and two control arms (hysterectomized patients without prolapse, nulliparous women). The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these surgical approaches in restoring normal vaginal axis and improving patient outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of simulation teaching method compared to traditional theory teaching in electronic fetal monitoring management for midwifery students. The study has two parallel arms: an experimental group receiving simulation training and a control group receiving theory training. The primary outcomes measured are students' knowledge through an information evaluation form, satisfaction and self-confidence through a scale, and self-efficacy in electronic fetal monitoring management through a self-efficacy scale. Secondary outcomes include evaluation of the simulation design through a simulation design scale. The study involves 68 midwifery students aged 18-45 years, randomly allocated to the experimental or control group. Data is collected before, immediately after, and 5 weeks after the interventions. The trial aims to assess if simulation training is more effective than theory training in improving knowledge, satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy in electronic fetal monitoring management among midwifery students.

This is a retrospective cohort study that aims to investigate the outcomes and predictors of mortality among critically ill patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation at Dessie Comprehensive Specialized Hospital in Ethiopia. The study will be conducted from August 2023 to January 2024, analyzing data from patient charts. The primary outcome measure is the clinical outcome (survival or death) of patients undergoing prolonged mechanical ventilation, defined as successful extubation after more than three spontaneous breathing trials or taking more than 14 days. The study will use descriptive statistics, bivariate, and multivariate analyses to examine the association between various factors and mortality. The study population includes all critically ill patients on prolonged mechanical ventilation during the study period, excluding those with incomplete or missing data. The study aims to provide insights into the outcomes and predictors of mortality for patients requiring prolonged mechanical ventilation, which could guide efforts to improve their care.

This clinical trial aims to compare two bleeding reduction strategies in patients who have undergone percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) and have been on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) with aspirin and a potent P2Y12 inhibitor (prasugrel or ticagrelor) for at least 30 days (chronic coronary syndrome) or 90 days (acute coronary syndrome). The two strategies being compared are:

1. DAPT de-escalation: Patients will continue aspirin and switch from prasugrel or ticagrelor to clopidogrel.

2. Potent P2Y12 inhibitor monotherapy: Patients will discontinue aspirin and continue with either prasugrel or ticagrelor.

The primary outcome measure is thrombus formation, defined as the area under the curve (AUC) measured by the Total Thrombus formation Analysis System (T-TAS), at 30 days. This will compare the trough effect (lowest level of antiplatelet activity) between the two strategies.

The study is a prospective, randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the age-dependent effects of egg intake on high-density lipoprotein (HDL) and immune profiles. The study involves three intervention groups: one consuming whole eggs, one consuming egg yolks, and one consuming egg whites, with each group consuming the equivalent of three large eggs per day for four weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in serum concentration of large HDL particles between the egg-free run-in period and the end of each intervention arm. The study is designed as a randomized, open-label, crossover trial with three arms. Participants will be healthy adults aged 18-30 or 60-70 years old with a body mass index (BMI) less than 30 kg/m2. The study aims to provide insights into the effects of different egg components on HDL and immune profiles, and how these effects may vary with age.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a patient-driven augmented reality-based rehabilitation system called MyoTrain AR in improving upper limb amputee outcomes. The study involves two parallel groups: an experimental group that will undergo functional task training using the MyoTrain AR system, and a control group that will receive motor imagery exercises.

The MyoTrain AR system consists of an augmented reality head-mounted display, kinematic trackers, surface EMG electrodes, and a desktop computer. Participants in the experimental group will use a pattern recognition-based myoelectric controller to operate a virtual prosthesis and complete a simulated functional task called the GaMA Cup Transfer Task.

The primary outcome measures are the mean completion time and mean relative grasp duration for the GaMA Cup Transfer Task. Secondary outcome measures include the Assessment of Capacity for Myoelectric Controls (ACMC), the GaMA Cup Transfer Task completion rate, and the GaMA Cup Transfer Task wrist activation.

The study targets unilateral trans-radial upper limb amputees who are candidates for a myoelectric pattern recognition prosthesis and meet other eligibility criteria. The trial aims to evaluate

This is a prospective, double-blinded, randomized controlled trial investigating the use of a gastric electric pacemaker as a treatment for postoperative ileus following extensive surgery. The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving active gastric electrical stimulation and a control group receiving sham stimulation. The primary outcome measure is the time from surgery to the first stool, with secondary outcomes including whole gut and regional transit times, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, need for interventions, re-hospitalization within 30 days, time to initiation of adjuvant chemotherapy, and 90-day mortality. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of gastric electrical stimulation in reducing postoperative ileus and improving recovery after extensive abdominal surgeries.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of aromatherapy and music therapy on pain, anxiety, and vital parameters in palliative care patients with cancer. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with four groups: music group, aromatherapy group, combined aromatherapy and music group, and a control group.

In the music group, patients listen to specially composed MusiCure® compositions with soft rhythms, melodies with harp, cello, strings, and natural sounds for 20 minutes per day for three consecutive days using headphones.

The aromatherapy group receives 5% lavender oil through a diffuser placed 30 cm away for 15-20 minutes, following the Aromatherapy-Clinical Guideline For Midwives.

The combined group receives both music therapy with headphones and aromatherapy inhalation for three consecutive days.

The control group does not receive any intervention.

The primary outcome measures include the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain assessment, Facial Anxiety Scale (FAS) for anxiety levels, Distress Thermometer for stress levels, Edmonton Symptom Assessment Scale (

This is a crossover study evaluating the effectiveness of a Somatosensation Device (SD) in enhancing feedback and improving functional mobility in individuals with lower limb amputation or neuropathy. The study involves two groups: one performing outcome measures without the SD (baseline) and the other wearing the SD during the assessments. 

The primary outcome measure is the Functional Gait Assessment (FGA), which evaluates postural stability and ability to perform various walking tasks. Secondary outcomes include the 10 Meter Walk Test (assessing walking speed), Mini-BESTest (multi-task balance assessment), Activities Specific Balance Confidence Scale (self-reported balance confidence), and Vestibular Disorders Activities of Daily Living Scale (self-reported independence in daily activities).

Participants aged 18-65 years with below-knee amputation (unilateral or bilateral) or neuropathy in their lower limbs are eligible. Exclusion criteria include recent severe back or knee pain, inability to walk for 3 minutes, and poor skin integrity that could be exacerbated by wearing the device.

The study aims to determine if the Somatosensation Device can improve functional

This is a decentralized, randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of the OtoBand device in providing temporary relief from vertigo symptoms in participants with various vestibular disorders. The study aims to enroll 36 participants in the Moderate or Worse (MoW) arm and 72 participants in the Quality of Life (QoL) arm. Participants will be randomized to receive either the active OtoBand device or a sham device during the treatment phase. The primary outcomes are changes in vertigo severity for the MoW arm and changes in the Vertigo Symptom Scale scores for the QoL arm, compared to baseline. The secondary outcome is the percent change in mean severity of vertigo episodes during the treatment phase compared to baseline. The study involves virtual meetings and data collection over approximately 49 days for the QoL arm and 42 days for the MoW arm.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial investigating the effect of a multistrain probiotic supplement called OMNi-BiOTiC® Active on the incidence and duration of upper respiratory tract infections (URTIs) in older adults aged 65 and above. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of acute URTIs over a 12-week supplementation period. Secondary outcomes include the duration of URTIs, changes in blood levels of various immune cells (leukocytes, neutrophils, lymphocytes, monocytes, eosinophils, basophils), and changes in serum immunoglobulin A (IgA) levels. Participants in the experimental group receive the probiotic supplement containing 11 strains of probiotic bacteria, while the placebo group receives an inactive supplement. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of the probiotic supplement in preventing and reducing the severity of URTIs in older adults.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of Gong's mobilization and Kaltenborn's mobilization techniques in treating adhesive capsulitis (frozen shoulder). The study involves randomly assigning participants with adhesive capsulitis to two groups: Group A receiving Gong's mobilization and Group B receiving Kaltenborn's mobilization. Both groups will also receive routine physical therapy, including electrical muscle stimulation and heat therapy. The primary outcomes measured are shoulder pain and disability (using the Shoulder Pain & Disability Index), pain intensity (using the Numeric Pain Rating Scale), and range of motion (using a universal goniometer). Assessments will be conducted at baseline, after 1.5 weeks, and after 3 weeks. The study aims to provide evidence-based insights into the relative effectiveness of these two mobilization techniques in improving pain, range of motion, and functional outcomes for patients with adhesive capsulitis.

This is a Phase 3, open-label, randomized, controlled clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin (an antibody-drug conjugate targeting HER2) in combination with pembrolizumab (an anti-PD-1 immunotherapy) compared to standard chemotherapy (gemcitabine plus cisplatin or carboplatin) in patients with previously untreated locally advanced or metastatic urothelial carcinoma (bladder cancer) that expresses HER2 (IHC 1+ or greater).

The primary outcomes are progression-free survival and overall survival. Secondary outcomes include objective response rate, duration of response, disease control rate, adverse events, quality of life measures, and time to pain progression.

Eligible patients must have histologically confirmed locally advanced unresectable or metastatic urothelial carcinoma, measurable disease, no prior systemic therapy for advanced disease, and be eligible for cisplatin- or carboplatin-based chemotherapy. Patients will be randomized to receive either the disitamab vedotin plus pembrolizumab combination or standard chemotherapy.

The

This is a double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of lactoferrin compared to placebo in improving clinical outcomes in intensive care unit (ICU) patients.

The study will enroll 650 patients admitted to the ICU departments of Mansoura University Hospital. Patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either:

1) Lactoferrin group: 200 mg lactoferrin orally twice daily (400 mg/day) for 28 days plus standard of care 
2) Placebo group: Standard of care only

The primary outcomes are 28-day all-cause mortality rate and incidence of hypersensitivity reactions. Secondary outcomes include day of death, need for invasive mechanical ventilation, oxygen support duration, ICU stay duration, and various laboratory parameters like white blood cell counts, hemoglobin, hematocrit, platelets, C-reactive protein, lactate dehydrogenase, ferritin, D-dimer, SOFA score, liver and kidney function tests.

The study aims to evaluate if lactoferrin, with its antioxidant,

This is a 10-week randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover trial investigating the effects of a chitin-glucan based formulation (BK003) versus placebo in patients with Crohn's disease in remission and experiencing irritable bowel syndrome (IBS)-like symptoms. The primary outcome is the subject's global assessment of relief responder rate measured at weeks 4 and 10. Secondary outcomes include changes in individual IBS symptoms (abdominal pain, bloating, flatulence), stool consistency, stool frequency, IBS-related quality of life, anxiety and depression scores, inflammatory markers (CRP, calprotectin), gut microbiome composition, and adverse events. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-75 with Crohn's disease in steroid-free remission for at least 3 months, presence of IBS-like symptoms, and meeting other criteria. The study involves a 2-3 week run-in period, followed by two 4-week treatment periods with BK003 or placebo separated by a 2-3 week washout, with a total of 5 study visits.

This clinical trial aims to develop a novel biomarker called virus-host chimera DNA (vh-DNA) for predicting response and prognosis in hepatitis B virus (HBV)-related hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) patients undergoing radiotherapy (RT). The key aspects of the trial are:

1. vh-DNA is a cell-free tumor-specific DNA present in 90% of HBV-related HCC patients and can be differentiated from normal cell DNA through HBV probe capture.

2. The study hypothesizes that vh-DNA could accurately diagnose residual tumors and predict early recurrence/metastasis earlier than contemporary imaging, allowing for timely salvage therapies.

3. Retrospectively, the study will analyze pre- and post-RT serum samples and tissues from HBV-related HCC patients to identify HBV integrations by Capture NGS and quantify vh-DNA by ddPCR, correlating with RT response and disease control.

4. Prospectively, the study will collect plasma samples from HBV-related HCC patients before/after RT, at specific time points, and at rec

This clinical trial aimed to develop and test the effectiveness of an online individual intervention program called the Meaning-Centered Coping Program (MCCP) for women diagnosed with breast cancer. The MCCP was based on the Meaning-Making Model and principles of Meaning Therapy, with the goal of not only reducing psychological distress but also facilitating the discovery of new positive meanings in life after a breast cancer diagnosis.

The study involved 44 women with stage I, II, or III breast cancer, diagnosed between 6 months and 3 years prior, who were randomly assigned to either the MCCP intervention group or a waitlist control group. The MCCP group received eight weekly 60-minute online individual sessions covering topics such as psychoeducation, accepting emotions, cognitive reframing, exploring personal strengths and values, finding meaning in cancer and life, and future planning.

The primary outcomes measured included meaning in life, posttraumatic growth, stress appraisal, global meaning violations, and automatic meaning-making efforts (intrusion and avoidance). Secondary outcomes included psychological flexibility and anxiety and depression levels. Assessments were conducted at baseline, post-intervention (8 weeks),

This clinical trial aims to investigate the nutritional intake, nutritional status, and physical activity level in people who have undergone a major dysvascular lower limb amputation (LLA), and their association with clinical outcomes. The study involves no intervention and will assess participants at multiple time points: during hospital admission 2 to 10 days post-LLA, at 5 weeks post-LLA, and at 6 and 9 months post-LLA.

The primary outcome measures include nutritional intake (energy, protein, carbohydrates, fat), diet quality (Dutch Healthy Diet Index), nutritional status (Patient-Generated Subjective Global Assessment), muscle mass (mid-upper arm circumference, triceps skinfold), muscle strength (handgrip strength), body mass index, and physical activity level (Activ8 accelerometer, adapted Short QUestionnaire to ASsess Health-enhancing physical activity).

Secondary outcome measures include mortality, wound healing, quality of life (World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaire - BREF), potential level of functioning (K-level), and physical functioning (6-minute walk test).

The study aims to provide insights

This is a single-center, prospective, open-label, decentralized, crossover pilot study aimed at determining the feasibility and advantages of conducting a remote clinical trial with multiple medications in patients with type 2 diabetes and elevated albuminuria. The primary objectives are to assess the feasibility of remote participation using digital technologies, remote data collection, and treatment adherence. The secondary objectives are to determine individual responses to the SGLT2 inhibitor empagliflozin on albuminuria, blood pressure, body weight, eGFR, and glucose, and whether suboptimal responses can be overcome by adding or switching to the mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist finerenone.

Eligible participants with type 2 diabetes, albuminuria, and CKD will receive empagliflozin for 3 weeks. Based on their albuminuria response, they will either continue empagliflozin, add finerenone, or switch to finerenone for 4 more weeks. Participants will collect urine, capillary blood samples, blood pressure, and body weight data remotely using digital devices and mail samples to the laboratory. The study aims to

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effects of a 12-week high-intensity interval training program on physical fitness, skills, and tactical performance among college male ice hockey players in China. The study involved 40 participants, randomly assigned to an experimental group (n=20) and a control group (n=20).

The experimental group underwent a high-intensity interval training program on ice, including repeated sprint training, sprint interval training, long-pass tracking drills, and chase-the-rabbit tracking drills. The intensity of training was gradually increased over three phases (weeks 1-4, 5-8, and 9-12).

The control group performed traditional on-ice training, including varied-pace skating, dribbling and shooting drills, passing and catching drills, and 2-on-1 offensive drills. The intensity was also increased gradually over the three phases.

The primary outcomes measured were maximal oxygen uptake, endurance, power, agility, skills (skating speed, dribbling speed), passing and shooting performance, and tactical performance (offensive tactics, coordination, and passing success rate). These outcomes were assessed before the experiment and at the 6-week mark.

The

This is a double-blind, randomized, crossover trial investigating the effect of chlorhexidine (CHX) mouthwash on the oral microbiome, salivary pellicle proteins, and vascular function in individuals with dental erosion and healthy controls.

The study involves two groups: a healthy group (n=12) and a dental erosion group (n=12). Within each group, participants are randomly assigned to receive either a placebo CHX mouthwash (ultrapure mint-flavored water) or an antibacterial 0.2% CHX mouthwash (Corsodyl Mint) for 7 days, rinsing twice daily. After a washout period of 12 weeks, the groups cross over to receive the opposite treatment for another 7 days.

The primary outcomes include identifying salivary proteins via SDS-PAGE and proteomics, and assessing oral microbiome diversity using 16S rRNA analysis. Secondary outcomes involve measuring blood pressure, endothelial function (iontophoresis and flow-mediated dilation), nitric oxide metabolites (nitrate and nitrite) in saliva and

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of a Pain and Coordination Plan (PAC-plan) in reducing opioid use and improving quality of life for patients after accidental injuries. The PAC-plan involves an opioid management plan upon hospital discharge, an appointment with the patient's general practitioner (GP) within 2-4 weeks, and increased collaboration between the GP and hospital specialists.

The primary outcome is oral morphine equivalent (OMEQ) consumption 6 weeks after discharge, and secondary outcomes include OMEQ at 52 weeks, registry-based OMEQ data, pain intensity, health-related quality of life, perceived injustice, optimism, depression symptoms, physical activity, and insomnia severity at 6 and 52 weeks.

Participants will be recruited from the Division of Orthopaedic Surgery at Oslo University Hospital in Norway and randomly assigned to either the PAC-plan intervention group or the control group receiving usual care. Data will be collected through self-reported questionnaires and registries.

The study aims to explore if the PAC-plan can reduce opioid use and improve quality of life for patients after

This is a cluster randomized controlled cohort study investigating guided versus standard antiplatelet therapy in interventional treatment of intracranial aneurysms with stents. The study aims to prevent ischemic events such as ischemic stroke, transient ischemic attack (TIA), and stent thrombosis within 30 days after stent implantation.

Participants are patients aged 18-80 years with unruptured intracranial aneurysms undergoing intracranial stenting, who have been on standard dual antiplatelet therapy for at least 5 days before the procedure.

The control group continues with the center's original antiplatelet regimen of aspirin 100 mg and clopidogrel 75 mg daily. The experimental group receives a guided antiplatelet regimen based on light transmission aggregometry (LTA) testing, with adjustments made to aspirin and/or ticagrelor dosages according to the maximum platelet aggregation rates induced by arachidonic acid and adenosine diphosphate.

The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of ischemic events, including ischemic stroke, transient isch

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between bone mineral density, gross motor function, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy (CP). The study involves two groups: Group 1 (Ambulant) consisting of 37 children with CP classified as levels I, II, and III according to the Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS), and Group 2 (Non-Ambulant) consisting of 38 children with CP classified as levels IV and V according to the GMFCS.

The study measures the following outcomes:

1. Bone mineral density (BMD) assessed using dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry (DXA) scans.
2. Gross motor function assessed using the Gross Motor Function Measure (GMFM).
3. Quality of life (QOL) assessed using the Quality of Life Questionnaire for Children (CP QOL-Child).

The study includes children with CP aged 7 to 10 years, with normal body mass index (BMI), and excludes those with conditions or treatments that may affect bone density or motor function.

The primary objective is to examine the relationship between

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, crossover study investigating the effects of the dopamine D2 receptor antagonist sulpiride on cognitive processes related to working memory gating, learning, and motivation. The study involves healthy volunteers between 18 and 45 years old who will receive either a single dose of 400mg sulpiride or placebo on two separate intervention days, with fMRI data acquisition occurring around the time of maximal drug effects.

The primary outcomes include reaction time, accuracy, and BOLD response during a working memory gating task, as well as accuracy and reaction time during a Simon task and a perceptual decision-making task, all measured under sulpiride and placebo conditions. These tasks are designed to assess the ability to selectively gate information into and out of working memory, cognitive effort investment, and the interaction between reward rate and evidence accumulation.

Secondary outcomes include baseline measures of eye-blink rate, working memory capacity, depression, impulsivity, anxiety, burnout, and COVID-related stress. The study aims to elucidate the dopaminergic mechanisms underlying working memory gating, learning, and motivation by examining the effects of sul

This clinical trial aims to investigate the prevalence of obesity and hypertension in Italian high school students aged 13-19 years, and explore the genetic and environmental factors associated with hypertension in this population. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Determine the prevalence of obesity and hypertension among adolescents in Italy.

2. Perform genetic analyses to identify associations between specific gene polymorphisms (e.g., Adducin genes, Endogenous Ouabain) and hypertension.

3. Explore the relationship between urinary markers of sodium/potassium excretion, inflammation, and oxidative stress with hypertension and cardiovascular risk in participants with specific genotypes.

The study involves enrolling adolescents from high schools in different regions of Italy. During the visit, investigators will collect data on eating habits, lifestyle, family history, blood pressure measurements, anthropometric measurements, urine samples, and saliva samples for DNA extraction and genotyping.

The primary outcome measure is to establish a link between specific polymorphisms of Adducin and Endogenous Ouabain-related genes with hypertension, sodium, and pot

The EPigenetic Consequences in Children of Intravenous vs Volatile Anaesthesia for Surgery (EPIVA) is a randomized, feasibility trial investigating the potential epigenetic effects of different types of anesthesia maintenance (intravenous vs. inhalational) on children undergoing hypospadias surgery. The primary objectives are to assess the feasibility of conducting such a trial, including measures like recruitment rate, retention rate, protocol compliance, and acceptability for participants and clinical staff. The secondary objectives are to explore whether anesthesia and surgery are associated with epigenetic changes in whole blood, and whether the type of anesthesia maintenance impacts these changes.

Male children aged 6 months to 3 years undergoing hypospadias surgery with an estimated anesthesia duration of at least 1 hour will be randomized to receive either intravenous (total intravenous anesthesia, TIVA) or inhalational (volatile agents) anesthesia maintenance after inhalational induction. Blood samples will be collected before induction and after surgery for epigenetic analysis using the Illumina Infinium MethylationEPIC BeadCh

This is a cross-sectional study aimed at investigating whether various additional markers can improve laboratory diagnostics in hypothyroid patients receiving levothyroxine (L-T4) treatment, particularly in cases where thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) cannot be used as a reflection of thyroid hormone status (e.g., central hypothyroidism). The study involves 400 participants divided into four groups of 100 patients each with different types of hypothyroidism (Hashimoto's hypothyroidism, hypothyroidism after thyroidectomy for thyroid cancer, central hypothyroidism, and hypothyroidism during treatment for Graves' disease) and 100 healthy controls. Participants will undergo a single blood draw and complete a questionnaire. The primary outcomes measured are TSH, free T4 (fT4), free T3 (fT3), and the fT3/fT4 ratio. Secondary outcomes include total T4, total T3, reverse T3, sex hormone-binding globulin, acylcarnitines, and amino acids. The study hypothesizes that treated hypothyroid participants with fT4 levels above the reference

This is a study aimed at implementing palliative non-operative management (PNOM) for selected frail elderly patients with a limited life expectancy who sustain a hip fracture. The key aspects are:

- The target population is frail institutionalized elderly (≥70 years old) with limited life expectancy who fracture their hip, and meet criteria such as malnutrition, mobility issues, or severe comorbidities.

- The primary aim is to implement PNOM in all hospitals in the Netherlands, so that these patients receive care that best meets their needs in the last phase of life, through shared decision-making.

- Secondary aims include enriching the PNOM protocol, developing educational modules, creating awareness, improving the protocol through smaller-scale implementation, and facilitating nationwide implementation.

- It is a multicenter prospective cohort study with mixed methods, involving interviews with healthcare professionals and patient representatives, development of educational materials, and implementation of the PNOM protocol in selected hospitals.

- Data will be collected through interviews, automated data extraction from the national hip fracture audit, and patient/proxy interviews about the implementation.

- The study compares non-operative treatment (P

This clinical trial aims to generate proof-of-concept for using a physiological clinical target volume (CTV) for radiotherapy treatment planning in patients with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma (a type of brain tumor). The study will extend the standard MRI scan used for radiotherapy planning with advanced MRI techniques that assess tumor oxygenation status and cell proliferation. This will allow the creation of a physiological CTV that includes information about microscale tumor invasion, in addition to the standard CTV.

The study will involve 10 patients diagnosed with IDH-wildtype glioblastoma. Each patient will undergo an extended MRI scan (60 minutes) during their standard radiotherapy planning. The physiological CTV and standard CTV will be compared in terms of volume and location. Patients will receive standard radiotherapy treatment based on the standard CTV.

The primary outcome measure is the volume and location analysis of the physiological and standard CTVs, with the hypothesis that the physiological CTV will be smaller in volume and better match microscale tumor invasion. The secondary outcome measure is the pattern-of-failure analysis, comparing the overlap of tumor recurrence with the physiological and standard CTV

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the acceptance and effectiveness of SARS-CoV-2 vaccination in systemic sclerosis (SSc) patients treated with autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (AHSCT) compared to non-transplanted SSc patients. The primary outcome measure is the cumulative incidence of asymptomatic or symptomatic COVID-19 infection after AHSCT versus non-AHSCT SSc patients within 18 months. Secondary outcomes include the proportion of patients refusing vaccination, the incidence of symptomatic COVID-19, time to first infection after vaccination, severity of symptomatic COVID-19, adverse events after vaccination, and humoral response to mRNA vaccines. The study involves two arms: SSc patients previously treated with AHSCT (cases) and SSc patients without AHSCT (controls). Eligible participants are adults with SSc followed at designated centers in France between January 2021 and June 2022, who received SARS-CoV-2 vaccination as per French guidelines.

This is a randomized controlled trial examining the effectiveness and implementation of an eHealth intervention called CNH+ (Connecting Families to Improve Parental Self-efficacy and Parent Psychosocial and Infant Health Outcomes in the NICU) compared to usual care in improving parental self-efficacy, psychosocial outcomes, and infant health outcomes in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) setting. The key aspects of the trial are:

- Design: Unblinded multicentre stepped wedge cluster randomized controlled trial across 4 Canadian NICUs
- Intervention: CNH+ is a bundled intervention targeting factors associated with improved parental self-efficacy through evidence-based education, peer videos, virtual communication with providers, and text message support
- Primary Outcomes: Change in parental self-efficacy measured at infant discharge, 21 days, and 6 months post-discharge using the Perceived Maternal Parenting Self-Efficacy tool
- Secondary Outcomes: Parental stress, depression, quality of life, family-centered care, infant growth, length of stay, breastfeeding, morbidities,

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effects of physical activity on physical fitness parameters, functional fitness age, and quality of life in postmenopausal women at risk of osteoporosis. The study had two groups: an experimental group that participated in the Otago Exercise Program (strengthening and balance exercises) and moderate-intensity walking for 12 weeks, and a control group that received no intervention.

The primary outcomes measured were lower and upper extremity strength, aerobic endurance, upper extremity flexibility, agility, quality of life, and dynamic balance. Assessments were conducted before and after the 12-week intervention period.

The study included postmenopausal women aged 54-75 years who were at medium or high risk of osteoporosis based on the Osteoporosis Self-Assessment Tool for Women (OST). Women with a history of fractures, recent surgery, cognitive or physical limitations preventing exercise, or those already exercising regularly were excluded.

The trial had a randomized, parallel-group design with an open-label approach. The experimental group received the Otago Exercise Program and walking intervention, while the control group did not receive any intervention.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the feasibility and preliminary effectiveness of a digital-based diet quality intervention for adolescents (aged 14-17 years) with overweight or obesity. The study aims to assess whether the intervention can improve diet quality, measured by the Healthy Eating Index (HEI) 2020 score from 24-hour dietary recalls, and meal timing traits, assessed by urinary sodium and potassium concentrations. Participants will be randomized to either a control group receiving usual care or an intervention group receiving a 4-week text message-based intervention targeting personalized goals, meal timing, nutrition skills, home food environment, and engagement strategies. The primary outcome is the change in HEI-2020 score, and secondary outcomes include changes in urinary sodium and potassium concentrations. The study will provide insights into the feasibility and potential effectiveness of a digital-based approach to improve diet quality and meal timing in adolescents with overweight or obesity.

This is a controlled clinical study aimed at predicting cerebral hyperperfusion syndrome (CHS) after carotid artery stenting by using multi-parameter characteristics based on cerebral autoregulation. The study plans to enroll 400 patients with carotid artery stenosis who will undergo carotid artery stenting. The primary outcome measure is cerebral hyperperfusion, defined as an increase in middle cerebral artery mean velocity by more than 100% within 7 days after the procedure. The secondary outcome measures include CHS, defined as ipsilateral headache, seizures, and neurological deficits within 1 month after stenting, and major stroke within 7 days after stenting. The study will use transcranial Doppler ultrasonography to measure cerebral blood flow parameters before, during, and after the stenting procedure. The study aims to analyze the incidence of postoperative complications like CHS and identify risk factors for cerebral hyperperfusion.
