This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of a group-based, videoconference-delivered expressive writing intervention on the emotional, social, and physical well-being of informal caregivers of persons diagnosed with cancer. The study involves randomly assigning caregivers to either an active intervention group or a waitlist control group. The active intervention group will attend four weekly videoconference sessions, each lasting up to 60 minutes, where participants will engage in expressive writing for 15-20 minutes, followed by group discussion and debriefing. The primary outcomes measured include psychological distress, general quality of life, and caregiver-specific quality of life, assessed at baseline and 6 weeks. Secondary outcomes include depression and perceived stress. The study seeks to identify potential mechanisms and moderators of the intervention's effectiveness, such as social and linguistic factors, age, gender identity, relationship to the patient, and baseline social constraints.

This is a prospective, randomized, controlled, single-surgeon trial investigating the use of intravenous tranexamic acid (IV TXA) in patients undergoing gender-affirming mastectomy (GAM) at the University of California San Francisco. The study aims to evaluate the effect of IV TXA on postoperative bleeding, hematoma, seroma, drain output, and time to drain removal.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving IV TXA or the control group without IV TXA. The experimental group will receive a loading dose of 1g TXA over 10 minutes immediately after anesthesia induction, while the control group will undergo a traditional GAM without TXA.

The primary outcomes include the number of participants with clinically significant hematomas, seromas, total patient drain output, and time to drain removal. Secondary outcomes consist of thromboembolic events and wound complications.

Eligible participants are individuals aged 18 years or older, undergoing GAM at UCSF, meeting WPATH guidelines for GAM, and with an ASA physical status classification of I-III. Exclusion criteria include

This is a randomized, controlled trial investigating the efficacy of smell training (ST) and trigeminal nerve stimulation (TNS) for treating persistent smell loss related to COVID-19. The study has three arms: 1) Active ST, 2) Placebo ST, and 3) Active TNS plus Active ST. The primary objectives are to determine the efficacy of ST versus natural recovery, the TNS-enhanced effects on smell loss, and whether TNS+ST is more effective than ST alone in treating other long COVID symptoms. The study will enroll 180 adults aged 18-65 with confirmed COVID-19 and persistent smell dysfunction. The primary outcomes measure changes in psychophysical olfactory function, perceived intensity/hedonics of odorants, and olfactory-related quality of life from baseline to 4 and 12 weeks. Secondary outcomes include changes in long COVID symptoms, cognitive function, mood, sleep quality, and symptoms of depression and anxiety. The interventions involve 12 weeks of twice-daily ST sessions and/or once-daily 30-minute TNS sessions. This trial aims to evaluate ST and the potential additive benefits of TNS for treating

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating the clinical effect of acupuncture therapy for primary insomnia. The study has two parallel arms: an acupuncture group receiving the Tiaoshen acupuncture treatment, and a placebo acupuncture group receiving non-insertive sham acupuncture. The primary outcome measure is the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI) score, assessed before treatment, at the 4th week of treatment, and 4 weeks after treatment completion. Secondary outcomes include the Fatigue Scale-14, Epworth Sleepiness Scale, Self-Rating Anxiety Scale, Self-Rating Depression Scale, polysomnography, and heart rate variability. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of acupuncture therapy compared to placebo in improving sleep quality and related symptoms in patients with primary insomnia aged 18-70 years. Key eligibility criteria include meeting the diagnostic criteria for chronic insomnia, a PSQI score >7, and no major physical or mental illnesses.

This is a randomized phase III clinical trial comparing two neoadjuvant (pre-surgical) chemo-immunotherapy regimens for early-stage triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). The primary objective is to assess if an anthracycline-free regimen of taxane-platinum chemotherapy plus pembrolizumab has non-inferior breast cancer event-free survival compared to a taxane-platinum-anthracycline regimen plus pembrolizumab.

Key aspects:

- Patients with early-stage TNBC are randomized to two treatment arms:
    Arm I: Paclitaxel, carboplatin, pembrolizumab followed by doxorubicin, cyclophosphamide, pembrolizumab
    Arm II: Docetaxel, carboplatin, pembrolizumab (anthracycline-free)

- Primary endpoint is breast cancer event-free survival 
- Secondary endpoints include pathological complete response rates, residual cancer burden, distant relapse-free survival, overall survival, safety/tolerability
- Exploratory endpoints assess patient-reported outcomes like fatigue, physical

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a one-year version of the Parent-Child Assistance Program (PCAP-1) in preventing the need for foster care and promoting reunification, helping parents achieve and maintain recovery, access comprehensive services, and prevent subsequent substance-exposed pregnancies. The study will recruit 40 eligible pregnant or parenting individuals who have used substances during pregnancy to receive PCAP-1 services, and compare their outcomes to a control group of approximately 40 individuals from the original PCAP trial. The primary outcomes include the proportion of children not placed in foster care, mothers acquiring or maintaining child custody, abstinence from drugs and alcohol, use of reliable birth control methods, and reduction in costs to state agencies. Secondary outcomes include stable housing, employment, educational enrollment or completion, receipt of public benefits, and criminal justice involvement. Data will be collected through interviews, surveys, case manager reports, and child welfare administrative data. The study aims to establish causal evidence of PCAP-1's effectiveness, estimate cost savings, and lay the groundwork for its inclusion in relevant federal registries.

This is a comparative study evaluating the agreement, precision, and safety of two test devices (Tomey OA-2000 and Tomey CASIA2) against a predicate device (LenStar LS900) for optical measurements in three subject populations: normal eyes, eyes with cataracts, and special eyes without a natural lens or containing artificial materials.

The study involves optical measurements using the test and predicate devices on eligible subjects aged 22 years or older. The primary outcomes include assessing the agreement between the test devices and predicate device, evaluating the precision (repeatability and reproducibility) of the test devices, and monitoring for any adverse events related to the safety of the devices.

The study design includes three arms corresponding to the subject populations (normal, cataract, and special eyes), with all groups undergoing optical measurements by the test and predicate devices. Data analysis will involve comparing the measurements from the test devices against the predicate device using statistical methods such as mean differences, limits of agreement, Bland-Altman plots, and regression analysis. Additionally, precision will be evaluated using analysis of variance models to estimate repeatability and reproducibility limits for each device and subject population.

This is a Phase 3, multicenter, open-label, randomized study comparing rituximab plus zanubrutinib versus rituximab monotherapy in previously untreated, symptomatic splenic marginal zone lymphoma (SMZL) patients. The study aims to evaluate whether adding zanubrutinib to rituximab improves progression-free survival (PFS) compared to rituximab alone.

Approximately 120 patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either:

Arm A: Rituximab + Zanubrutinib 
- Zanubrutinib 160 mg twice daily orally 
- Rituximab 375 mg/m2 IV on specific cycles

Arm B: Rituximab monotherapy
- Rituximab 375 mg/m2 IV on specific cycles

The primary outcome is the PFS rate at 3 years. Secondary outcomes include complete remission rates, best response, time to next treatment, duration of response, overall survival, and safety/adverse events.

Key eligibility criteria include untreated SMZL, measurable disease, adequate organ function

This is a randomized, double-blinded, comparative study evaluating the efficacy of continuous ultrasound-guided serratus anterior plane block versus thoracic epidural for pain management in adult patients undergoing thoracotomy for lung cancer surgery. The primary outcome is postoperative total morphine requirement over 24 hours. Secondary outcomes include intraoperative fentanyl requirement, time to first analgesia request, postoperative pain scores, length of hospital stay, and patient satisfaction. 

The study plans to enroll 74 patients aged 18-65 years, with 37 patients randomized to each group. In the serratus plane block group, patients will receive a bolus of 0.25% bupivacaine followed by a continuous infusion of 0.125% bupivacaine through a catheter placed superficial to the serratus anterior muscle under ultrasound guidance. In the thoracic epidural group, patients will receive intermittent boluses of 0.25% bupivacaine through an epidural catheter after a test dose of lidocaine with epinephrine. Both groups will receive general anesth

This is a pilot study investigating the use of a PICU (Pediatric Intensive Care Unit) Journal intervention to enhance parent/caregiver engagement and reduce stress during their child's PICU admission at Monroe Carell Jr. Children's Hospital at Vanderbilt. The study involves providing parents/caregivers with a customizable journal to document their child's PICU experiences and outcomes. Data will be collected at three time points: within 24-72 hours of admission, around discharge, and 3 months post-discharge. The primary outcomes measured include parent/caregiver stress levels, care engagement, anxiety/depression symptoms, impact of events, and satisfaction with the journal. Child participants will also report on their impact of events. PICU staff perceptions of the intervention will be assessed. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and utility of the PICU Journal in supporting parents/caregivers and potentially reducing post-intensive care syndrome in pediatric patients and their families.

This clinical trial aims to compare two stakeholder engagement methods, Design Thinking (DT) and Focus Groups (FG), to determine which is more effective in obtaining input from Hispanic and Latino families on the facilitators and barriers to accessing therapy services for autistic children. The study focuses on this population as it is the largest minority group in the US with a rapidly growing number of autistic children.

The trial has two phases:

1. Participants (autistic adults, parents/caregivers, occupational therapists, teachers, and cultural experts) are randomized to either the DT or FG group. Stakeholder engagement is evaluated using the Stakeholder-Centric Engagement Evaluation measure based on PCORI principles.

2. Data from phase 1 is used to culturally adapt an occupational therapy intervention manual (Ayres Sensory Integration) for Hispanic/Latino autistic children, with separate manuals adapted based on DT and FG data. Stakeholders provide input on the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the adapted manuals using standardized measures.

The primary aim is to compare the effectiveness of DT and FG in engaging stakeholders, while the

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study evaluating harm reduction products as a second-line intervention for adult smokers aged 22-65 who do not quit smoking with nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) after 4 weeks. The study has the following key aspects:

1. Participants who successfully quit smoking with NRT in the first 4 weeks can continue with NRT or switch to an e-cigarette or nicotine pouch for the next 5 weeks.

2. Participants who do not quit smoking with NRT in the first 4 weeks are randomized into the following groups for the next 5 weeks:
   a. Switch to a nicotine pouch (intervention) or remain on NRT (control)
   b. Switch to an e-cigarette (intervention) or remain on NRT (control)

3. The primary outcome is the change in expired air carbon monoxide (CO) levels at week 10 compared to baseline for NRT non-responders.

4. Secondary outcomes include smoking abstinence rates (self-reported and CO-verified) for NRT non-responders from week 7

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of the flipped classroom model on nursing students' knowledge of asepsis principles and learning skills. The study involves first-year nursing students at Bilecik Şeyh Edebali University. The experimental group will receive flipped training, where they will access videos and materials on asepsis principles two weeks before the infection control course. During the course period (11/11/2023-12/12/2023), the experimental group will reinforce the learned information through classroom activities, while the control group will receive traditional lectures. The primary outcome measure is the effect of the flipped education model on the course success of nursing students, assessed through knowledge tests administered at the end of the study period and two weeks later. The study is designed as a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and an open-label approach. The study period will last until 20/12/2023.

This is a prospective, open-label, single-arm study to evaluate the ability of Epitel's Remote EEG Monitoring System (REMI) to capture ictal events (seizures) in an ambulatory setting for an extended period of 14-28 days. The study aims to demonstrate that the REMI system can record EEG data that clinicians can use to identify seizure events over an extended period, and that extended clinical EEG data is valuable in the diagnosis and treatment of seizure-related symptoms.

The study will enroll patients aged 18-70 years with a reported history of seizures (epileptic, non-epileptic, or unknown) and a minimum reported seizure rate of one every two weeks. Patients will be prescribed the REMI system and instructed to use it for a prolonged period (up to 30 days) for a minimum of 20 hours per day.

The primary outcome measure is the number of ictal events identified by three independent board-certified epileptologists assessing the REMI data over the first 14 days. The secondary outcome measure is the number of ictal events identified over the full

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of two different exercise training programs on blood pressure and other health markers in adults with hypertension. The study aims to recruit 75 adults aged 40-65 years with controlled hypertension who are sedentary. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups:

1. Multicomponent training group: This group will perform 60-minute sessions twice a week for 12 weeks. Each session includes 20 minutes of strength training (bench press and squats) and 20 minutes of cardiovascular exercise, with intensity progressively increasing over the 12 weeks.

2. Continuous cardiovascular training group: This group will perform 60 minutes of continuous cardiovascular exercise twice a week for 12 weeks, with intensity progressively increasing over time. 

3. Control group: This group will not participate in any exercise program.

The primary outcome is changes in blood pressure from baseline to 12 weeks. Secondary outcomes include changes in mean arterial pressure, pulse pressure, double product, resting heart rate, body composition (weight, muscle mass, fat mass, visceral fat), waist circumference, blood lipids, glucose

This is a before-and-after study evaluating the impact of a sensitization campaign on preoperative fasting guidelines. The primary outcome measure is the fasting time (liquid and solid) before surgery. Secondary outcomes include rates of preoperative oral carbohydrate loading, prolonged fasting exceeding 12 hours, preoperative anxiety and discomfort levels, thirst and hunger feelings, preoperative nausea or vomiting, postoperative nausea or vomiting, patient satisfaction with communication about fasting, postoperative quality of recovery score, length of hospital stay, and postoperative surgical complications. The study involves two groups: a "before" group undergoing standard preoperative fasting, and an "after" group exposed to the sensitization campaign about fasting rules, including lectures, reminders, individualized fasting cards, and clear medical prescriptions. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the campaign in improving adherence to fasting guidelines and associated outcomes.

This is a randomized controlled trial aimed at evaluating the effects of the "Mentoring to be Active + Family" (MPBA+F) intervention on physical activity outcomes and health outcomes among rural Appalachian 7th/8th grade children with overweight or obesity. The study will recruit 288 children, with half receiving the MPBA+F intervention and the other half receiving a self-guided comparison program. The MPBA+F intervention consists of 10 weekly peer-mentoring sessions delivered virtually, followed by a 6-month family reinforcement program. The primary outcome is change in daily physical activity measured by accelerometry, and secondary outcomes include changes in body composition (BMI, body fat, weight). The study aims to improve self-regulation, self-efficacy, and social support to increase intentional exercise and physical activity among underserved youth with overweight or obesity, ultimately reducing the high rates of obesity and type 2 diabetes in Appalachian youth.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of virtual reality animation and ice massage on the hoku point (LI4 area) on labor pain, duration of labor, and birth satisfaction. The study involves three parallel groups: an ice massage group receiving ice massage on the hoku point for 20 minutes during active labor, a virtual reality animation group watching a 20-minute virtual reality animation during active labor, and a control group receiving standard care. The primary outcomes measured include labor pain assessed by the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), duration of labor phases (latent, active, and placental expulsion), and birth satisfaction assessed by the Birth Satisfaction Scale-Revised (BSS-R). The study includes term primiparous women with singleton pregnancies, aged 18-35 years, with a BMI below 30 and cervical dilation of 0-3 cm at enrollment. The study has a randomized, parallel-group design with no masking.

This is a study investigating the epidemiology of cytomegalovirus (CMV) disease in pediatric and adult liver transplant recipients in China. The study includes two groups: children aged ≤18 years and adults aged >18 years, who have received their first orthotopic liver transplant within 10 days prior. The primary outcome measures are clinically significant CMV reactivation or CMV disease observed within 12 months of transplantation, end of follow-up survey at 22 months if no CMV reactivation occurred, and death within 22 months. Secondary outcomes include loss to follow-up and participants asked to withdraw during the 22-month follow-up period. The study aims to understand the incidence and patterns of CMV disease in liver transplant recipients in China.

This clinical trial aims to develop and validate brain imaging biomarkers that can predict the presence of "Aiming Spatial Neglect" (Aiming SN) in veterans with right brain stroke. Aiming SN, which affects movement, intention, and action, has been shown to respond well to Prism Adaptation Therapy (PAT). The study will enroll 180 veterans, including 120 with spatial neglect and 60 without, to achieve the following objectives:

1. Define and validate brain imaging biomarkers that predict the presence of Aiming SN, which is a strong predictor of functional recovery after receiving PAT.

2. Examine the correlation between the brain imaging biomarkers predicting Aiming SN and improvements in daily life function after PAT.

3. Determine if adding behavioral predictors to biomarker predictors can account for additional variance in the trajectory of functional recovery.

The primary outcome measures are the identification of spatial neglect type (Aiming SN versus Where SN) and the improvement trajectory of functional independence as measured by the Functional Independence Measure (FIM). Secondary outcomes include the severity of spatial neglect assessed by

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of liquid biopsy as a diagnostic tool for gliomas by analyzing circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) in blood samples of patients with suspected glioma. The study will correlate the results of ctDNA analysis with tissue biopsies and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) findings. The primary outcome measure is the detection of circulating free DNA in blood samples using droplet digital PCR (ddPCR). The study is designed as a single-arm, open-label trial with adult participants (≥18 years) who have a de novo primary brain lesion compatible with glioma on MRI and are scheduled for surgical resection. The study aims to assess the feasibility, accuracy, and potential benefits of liquid biopsy compared to conventional tissue biopsy for glioma diagnosis, including factors such as time, cost, and patient impact.

This is a pilot study evaluating the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of combining zimberelimab (an anti-PD-1 antibody), quemliclustat (a CD73 inhibitor), and modified FOLFIRINOX chemotherapy in patients with borderline resectable or locally advanced pancreatic adenocarcinoma. 

The primary objectives are to assess safety/tolerability, resection rate (for borderline resectable cohort), progression-free survival (for locally advanced cohort), and incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula after neoadjuvant treatment (for borderline resectable cohort). 

Secondary objectives include evaluating efficacy measures like changes in CA19-9 levels, objective response rate, pathologic complete response rate (borderline resectable cohort), and overall survival.

Exploratory objectives involve analyzing the effects of the treatment combination on the tumor microenvironment and identifying potential biomarkers predictive of response.

Patients receive zimberelimab, quemliclustat, oxaliplatin, leucovorin, and irinotecan intravenously, with computed tomography scans,

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effect of probiotics on depression and cardiovascular disease risk factors in hemodialysis patients. The study involves two groups: an intervention group receiving a probiotic supplement (MIYAIRI 588, 3g/day) for 3 months, and a control group receiving no intervention. The primary outcome measure is the change in depression score, assessed using the Beck Depression Inventory (Chinese version 2.0), from baseline to 3 months. The study includes adults aged 20 years or older undergoing hemodialysis for at least 3 months, with specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to medical conditions, medication use, and depression severity. The trial aims to evaluate the potential benefits of probiotic supplementation on mental health and cardiovascular risk factors in this patient population.

This is a study aimed at increasing alcohol abstinence in young adults aged 18-24 years with alcohol use disorder (AUD). The study has two phases:

1. K99 Phase (Formative): A single-arm pre/post study to test the feasibility and acceptability of an integrated Contingency Management and Problem-Solving Therapy (CM-PST) intervention. 20 participants will receive 8 sessions of CM-PST delivered remotely via videoconferencing over 12 weeks.

2. R00 Phase (Preliminary Efficacy Trial): A two-arm randomized controlled trial. 84 participants will be randomized to either the CM-PST intervention group (42 participants) or the CM-only control group (42 participants). The CM-PST group will receive the same 8-session intervention as in the K99 phase, while the control group will receive contingency management (CM) only, which involves rewards for alcohol abstinence.

The primary outcome measure is alcohol abstinence, monitored for up to 6 months by blood alcohol content. Secondary outcomes include changes in AUD severity, alcohol-related negative

This is a Phase 2, randomized, open-label study comparing the efficacy of a triplet therapy (encorafenib, binimetinib, and pembrolizumab) versus a doublet/control therapy (nivolumab and ipilimumab) in patients with metastatic or unresectable locally advanced BRAF V600E/K-mutant melanoma. The study aims to enroll approximately 150 participants who have progressed during or after prior treatment with an approved anti-PD-1 monotherapy (pembrolizumab or nivolumab) in the adjuvant or first-line metastatic setting. Participants will be randomized in a 1:1 ratio to receive either the triplet therapy or the doublet/control therapy. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate, defined as the proportion of participants with a confirmed complete or partial response. Secondary outcomes include progression-free survival, overall survival, duration of response, disease control rate, time to response, incidence of adverse events, and patient-reported outcomes. The study will assess the efficacy and safety of the triplet therapy compared to the doublet/control therapy in

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This is a randomized parallel-group study investigating the effects of high-fidelity simulation and virtual reality-based simulation on nursing students' simulation-based learning, reflective thinking skills, and therapeutic communication skills. 

The study will be conducted at Hacettepe University Faculty of Nursing with second-year undergraduate nursing students in the 2023-2024 academic year. The target sample size is 76 students, randomized into two groups:

1) High-fidelity simulation group (n=38) 
2) High-fidelity simulation + virtual reality group (n=38)

The high-fidelity simulations will focus on diabetes mellitus scenarios in the nursing simulation lab. The virtual reality component will involve online modular training and an interactive virtual simulation on diabetes patient education.

Primary outcomes are scores on the Simulation Based Learning Scale, Reflective Thinking Skills for Problem Solving Scale, and Therapeutic Communication Skills Scale, measured before and after the 60-minute simulation sessions.

The study aims to evaluate if adding virtual reality enhances simulation-based learning, reflective thinking, and therapeutic

This is a randomized, open-label, crossover clinical trial aimed at evaluating the efficacy of a newly developed air trap called "Emboless" in reducing microemboli of air during hemodialysis, compared to a standard air trap (Fresenius 4008/5008). The study involves chronic hemodialysis patients aged 18 years or older, who will undergo two paired series of hemodialysis sessions, one with the Emboless air trap and one with the standard air trap, in a randomized order. The primary outcome measure is the reduction of air microemboli contamination, assessed by counting the number and size of microbubbles at the inlet and outlet of the air trap using an ultrasound device during a 30-minute period of hemodialysis. Secondary outcomes include comparing air contamination between hemodialysis and hemodiafiltration, and monitoring adverse events. The study aims to enroll a maximum of 30 patients, with a total of 120 dialysis sessions. A safety committee will evaluate any significantly worse outcomes, particularly with the Emboless air trap.

This is a single-blinded crossover study investigating the effects of repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (theta burst stimulation) on movement and injury risk biomechanics among individuals with and without a concussion history. The study involves two testing sessions separated by at least 7 days. During the first session, participants will complete single-task serial subtraction, single- and dual-task jump landing, and receive theta burst stimulation intervention. Jump landing will be performed before and after stimulation under single- and dual-task conditions. In the second session, participants will repeat the jump landing before and after stimulation under single- and dual-task conditions. Symptom checklist, Tampa Scale of Kinesiophobia 11, Godin Leisure Activity Questionnaire, and NASA Task Load Index will be administered at various points. The study aims to determine how theta burst stimulation to the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (experimental condition) and vertex (control condition) influences movement and injury risk biomechanics, such as reaction time, knee and hip angles, and trunk angles, among individuals with and without a concussion history.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial comparing extended pancreatic neck transection versus conventional pancreatic neck transection during laparoscopic pancreaticoduodenectomy (LPD) for patients with benign or resectable malignant tumors of the lower common bile duct, ampulla of Vater, head or uncinate process of the pancreas. The primary outcome is the incidence of clinically relevant pancreatic fistula within 3 months postoperatively. Secondary outcomes include location of the pancreatic duct in the transverse section, duration of pancreaticojejunostomy, postoperative morbidity, and mortality within 3 months. Patients in the experimental arm undergo extended pancreatic neck transection at 5-10mm beyond the left side of the portal vein during LPD, while those in the control arm undergo conventional neck transection. The study aims to evaluate if extended transection can reduce the rate of pancreatic fistula formation after LPD.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial investigating the effects of two types of concurrent training (traditional concurrent training and concurrent training combined with dance classes) on functional performance, cognitive function, and quality of life in older adults aged 65-75 years.

The study has three arms: 
1) Traditional concurrent training group performing strength training and aerobic exercise (walking/treadmill) twice a week for 12 weeks. 
2) Concurrent training with dance classes group performing strength training combined with dance classes twice a week for 12 weeks.
3) Control group maintaining their usual routine.

The primary outcomes measured are changes in dynamic balance, cognitive function, self-reported quality of life, static balance, seat-to-stand capacity, stair climb capacity, leg strength, leg power, hand grip strength, and cardiorespiratory capacity at baseline, 8 weeks, and 12 weeks.

Secondary outcomes include changes in quadriceps muscle thickness, affectivity with the intervention, lipid profile, specific tension of quadriceps, and depressive symptoms at baseline and 12 weeks.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of these two concurrent training approaches on various functional, cognitive, and

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of a virtual reality (VR)-based sensory stimulation intervention in preventing delirium in intensive care unit (ICU) patients. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the VR intervention on delirium incidence, duration, and severity as the primary outcomes. Secondary outcomes include patients' psychological well-being (post-traumatic stress disorder, sleep quality, and ICU memory), clinical outcomes, quality of life, independence, and cognitive function.

Participants aged 18-90 years, admitted to the ICU for the first time with a Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale score ≥-3, and without conditions like dementia, delirium, acute psychiatric illness, end-stage cancer, severe hearing impairment, or radioactive material exposure, will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving the VR-based sensory stimulation intervention or the control group receiving usual care.

The VR intervention will be administered for up to 14 days by a research team. Outcomes will be assessed during the intervention period, at discharge from the ICU, and through a 6-month follow-up using various validated scales and measures

This is a randomized, parallel-group, open-label clinical trial investigating the outcome of surgical fixation of multiple fractured ribs at Sohag University Hospital. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of surgical rib fixation (open reduction and internal fixation) compared to conservative treatment in patients with multiple rib fractures. The primary outcomes measured are the need and duration of mechanical ventilation, and the severity of thoracic pain assessed using a pain scale from 0 to 10, over a one-year follow-up period. Eligible participants include patients with multiple fractured ribs requiring pre-ventilation, regardless of gender. The study randomly assigns participants to either the intervention group receiving surgical rib fixation or the control group receiving conservative treatment.

This is a randomized, parallel-group study comparing the acute psychobiological responses to two different laboratory stress tests: the Mannheim Multicomponent Stress Test (MMST) and the Trier Social Stress Test (TSST). The study aims to assess changes in salivary cortisol levels, state anxiety, heart rate, and salivary alpha-amylase in response to these stress tests.

Participants will be healthy, recreationally active men and women aged 18-35 years, randomly assigned to either the MMST or TSST group. The MMST involves a computer-based paced auditory serial addition task with distractions like emotionally evocative images and white noise. The TSST involves a mock job interview and mental arithmetic task in front of observers and a video camera.

The primary outcome is the change in salivary cortisol levels from pre-stress to peak post-stress. Secondary outcomes include changes in state anxiety (measured by STAI-S), heart rate, and salivary alpha-amylase levels.

The study aims to compare the psychobiological stress responses elicited by these two different laboratory stress

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of a probiotic lysate (postbiotic and metabiotic) supplement in adults with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study aims to assess the effects of the supplement on hepatic fat content measured by MRI-PDFF and ultrasound, liver enzymes, biochemical indices of hepatic steatosis, and chronic systemic inflammatory markers in NAFLD patients.

The study involves two parallel groups: an active group receiving the probiotic lysate supplement (containing cell lysate and DNA fragments of L. rhamnosus DV - NRRLB-68023) at a dose of 100mg twice daily for 3 months, and a placebo group receiving an identical placebo capsule. The study has a screening period of up to 1 week, a 3-month treatment period, and a 3-month follow-up period.

The primary outcomes include changes in hepatic fat content measured by MRI-PDFF and ultrasound attenuation coefficient, and changes in the fatty liver index (FLI). Secondary outcomes include changes

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of using virtual reality (VR) as an adjuvant therapy for sickle cell vaso-occlusive crisis (VOC) in the pediatric emergency department. The study has two arms: a control arm involving a retrospective chart review of patients aged 6-21 years with sickle cell VOC, and a trial arm where patients aged 6-21 years presenting with VOC will receive VR therapy in addition to standard medical care.

The primary objectives are to assess the impact of VR therapy on reducing pain severity and hospital admission rates compared to standard care alone. Secondary objectives include evaluating the effect of VR therapy on reducing the length of stay in the emergency department and time to disposition.

In the trial arm, patients will be offered VR goggles with guided meditation software simultaneously with standard medication therapy (NSAIDs and opioids). Pain scores, patient disposition (admitted or discharged), length of stay, and time to disposition will be measured.

The study aims to enroll 100 patients in each arm and will compare the outcomes between the VR therapy group and the historical control group receiving standard care alone.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study aimed at evaluating the efficacy of a web-based empowerment program for secondary cardiovascular prevention in patients after an acute myocardial infarction (AMI). The experimental intervention consists of educational, motivational, and coaching actions delivered through a web platform, including periodic emails with educational materials, a message box for questions and answers, and video calls with the prevention team. The intervention is personalized based on the patient's risk factor profile and agreed upon through shared decision-making.

The primary outcomes are changes in measurable risk factors such as BMI, blood pressure, LDL cholesterol, glycemia levels, glycosylated hemoglobin in diabetic patients, and expired carbon monoxide in smokers, measured at 12 months. Secondary outcomes include lifestyle changes (physical activity, diet adherence, smoking cessation/reduction, self-efficacy, health locus of control), treatment adherence, and glucose control in diabetic patients. Long-term maintenance of controlled risk factors and the incidence of symptomatic coronary events will be evaluated at 48 months.

The study includes patients aged 18-75 years who

This clinical trial aims to investigate the accuracy of pocket-sized ultrasound (PsUS) in diagnosing pediatric elbow fractures. The study consists of two parts: a feasibility phase and an active study phase.

In the feasibility phase, the study providers will receive training on performing elbow PsUS exams. They will then obtain three elbow ultrasound exams from participants aged 1-16 years to demonstrate their ability to capture adequate images.

In the active study phase, children aged 1-16 years with isolated acute elbow pain will be recruited from the emergency department. After obtaining consent, participants will undergo bilateral standardized elbow PsUS exams. The ultrasound provider will assess the images for signs of fracture before reviewing any radiographic imaging. Participants will then receive standard clinical care, which may include X-ray or bedside nursemaid reduction. The study investigators will review the final radiology readings and follow up with participants to determine if any additional imaging or care was required.

The primary aim of the feasibility phase is to determine the acceptability of the PsUS study training for obtaining adequate elbow images. The primary aim of the active study is to

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of two different orthoses, a toe separator orthosis and a dynamic orthosis, on individuals with mild to moderate hallux valgus deformity. The study will evaluate the changes in hallux valgus angle, plantar pressure distribution, and patient-reported outcomes after using each orthosis for one month.

The primary outcomes measured are the hallux valgus angle, assessed using a goniometer, and plantar pressure distribution, measured using a plantar pressure analysis system. Secondary outcomes include the Manchester-Oxford Foot Questionnaire, which evaluates foot pain, walking, standing, and social interaction, and a satisfaction evaluation for the orthoses used.

Participants aged 18-65 years with mild to moderate hallux valgus deformity will be randomly assigned to either the toe separator orthosis group or the dynamic orthosis group. They will be asked to wear the assigned orthosis for an average of 8 hours per day for one month. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, immediately after wearing the orthosis, and after one month of use. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of these two orthotic interventions in improving hallux valgus angle

This is a prospective study evaluating speech function through patient- and parent-reported outcome measures in children with isolated or combined cleft palate undergoing pharyngeal flap surgery for velopharyngeal insufficiency. The study includes children under 18 years of age from six specialized cleft centers in Sweden. The primary outcomes are speech function assessed using the CLEFT-Q questionnaire for patients and the Intelligibility in Context Scale for parents, measured preoperatively and one year postoperatively. Higher scores on these measures indicate better speech outcomes. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of pharyngeal flap surgery in improving speech function from the patient's and parent's perspectives.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of probiotics compared to placebo and acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) for the treatment of alcohol use disorder among adult males. The study will be conducted at two sites in China and Malaysia. The primary objective is to determine differences in the severity of alcohol dependence, withdrawal, and craving among the three intervention groups (probiotics, placebo, ACT) across four time points (baseline, 8 weeks, 12 weeks, 24 weeks). Secondary objectives include assessing differences in depression, anxiety, EEG characteristics, pro-inflammatory cytokine levels, and gut microbiota profiles. Male participants aged 18-55 years with alcohol use disorder will be recruited and randomized to receive either probiotics, placebo, or ACT in addition to conventional drug therapy for alcohol detoxification. Assessments will be conducted at multiple time points using various scales and biological samples. The study aims to evaluate the potential therapeutic effects of probiotics and compare them with placebo and ACT in treating alcohol use disorder.

This is a multicenter, parallel-arm, open-label, randomized controlled trial comparing the use of barbed absorbable sutures (V-Loc, Covidien, Medtronic) versus standard absorbable sutures (Vicryl, Ethicon Inc) for vaginal cuff closure after total laparoscopic hysterectomy. The primary outcomes are vaginal cuff dehiscence at 30 and 90 days post-surgery. Secondary outcomes include vaginal cuff complications, hospital stay, operative time, intraoperative blood loss, 30-day post-surgical morbidity, quality of life, and sexual function at 90 days. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of barbed sutures compared to standard sutures for vaginal cuff closure in patients undergoing elective total laparoscopic hysterectomy for benign conditions.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the neurobiological mechanisms underlying gambling addiction by examining the interplay between reward processing, emotional processing, and gambling behavior. The primary objective is to test the hypothesis that there are two distinct brain phenotypes in gambling addiction: 1) striatal hyper-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hypo-reactivity to emotional stimuli, and 2) striatal hypo-reactivity to reward combined with amygdala hyper-reactivity to emotional stimuli. These phenotypes are hypothesized to characterize two subpopulations of gamblers, referred to as "impulsive" and "emotional," respectively.

The study will recruit 60 individuals with gambling problems (including those meeting DSM-5 criteria for gambling disorder and those with problem gambling) and 60 healthy controls. Participants will undergo functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) while performing tasks involving reward processing and emotional processing. The striatal BOLD response to reward outcomes and the amygdala BOLD response to emotional stimuli will be measured.

The secondary objective is to determine whether the proposed brain phenotypes can predict gambling behavior in real-life situations. This will be assessed using

This is a randomized controlled prospective trial comparing the use of 2D 4K and 3D HD laparoscopic imaging systems in bariatric (gastric bypass) surgery. The study aims to evaluate the impact of these imaging systems on various outcomes, including operation time, intraoperative and postoperative complications, surgeon workload, and patient recovery.

Participants are patients aged 18 and above with a BMI > 35 who meet the criteria for gastric bypass surgery according to SMOB guidelines. They are randomly assigned to undergo the surgery using either a 2D 4K or a 3D HD laparoscopic imaging system.

The primary outcome measure is the operation time, defined as the duration from the initial incision to the completion of skin suturing. Secondary outcomes include intraoperative complications (assessed by blood loss and hemoglobin decrease), surgeon workload (measured by the Surg-TLX questionnaire), and postoperative complications (classified using the Clavien-Dindo scale and duration of hospitalization).

The study aims to provide insights into the potential advantages and disadvantages of using advanced imaging technologies in bariatric surgery,

This is a single-arm, open-label, prospective study evaluating the efficacy and safety of Huaier granule in patients with stage I primary ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer after surgery. The primary objective is to assess the 1-year progression-free survival rate. Secondary objectives include evaluating overall survival, quality of life, pain scores, and adverse events. Eligible patients are females aged ≥18 years with histologically confirmed stage I ovarian, fallopian tube, or peritoneal cancer who underwent surgery but are not suitable or unwilling to receive chemotherapy. Patients will receive oral Huaier granule 20g three times daily for 28-day cycles until disease progression, intolerable toxicity, or up to 24 months. The study will assess progression-free survival, overall survival, quality of life, pain scores, and safety over a 2-year period.

This is a non-invasive observational study investigating the prevalence and effects of small intestinal bacterial overgrowth (SIBO) in critically ill, mechanically ventilated patients in the intensive care unit (ICU). The study employs a modified hydrogen breath test technique to diagnose SIBO by measuring expired hydrogen levels from the ventilator tubes after administering lactulose. The primary objective is to assess the prevalence of SIBO in this patient population. Secondary outcomes include examining the effects of SIBO on ventilator-associated pneumonia, ICU length of stay, and all-cause in-hospital mortality. Eligible participants are adult ICU patients requiring mechanical ventilation for more than 48 hours, with no recent antimicrobial therapy, gastroprotective medication, probiotics, or prokinetics use, and no known gastrointestinal disease or recent abdominal surgery. The hydrogen breath test is performed on the day of ICU admission, and then on days 3, 5, and 7 of the ICU stay for enrolled patients.

This study aimed to investigate the presence of exercise-induced hypoalgesia (EIH) following exercise in patients after total knee arthroplasty (TKA) and whether it changes with exercise intensity. It was a repeated measures and single-blinded randomized study involving 38 patients 24 hours after TKA. Participants were randomly assigned to either a low-intensity exercise (LIE) group or a high-intensity exercise (HIE) group. The exercise programs lasted for five days during hospitalization. Pain severity was assessed using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), and pressure pain thresholds (PPTs) were measured over the quadriceps and biceps brachii muscles immediately before and after exercise. The primary outcomes were changes in pain severity and PPTs. The HIE program consisted of ankle pump exercise, quadriceps isometric exercise, terminal extension exercise, passive-active assistive-active range of motion exercise, heel sliding exercise, and straight leg raise exercise, performed for 3 sets of 15 repetitions. The LIE program was similar but with 2 sets of 8 repetitions and included continuous passive motion sessions.

The Nigerian Breast Cancer Risk-Reduction Study is a randomized, parallel-assignment, double-blind clinical trial aimed at evaluating the effects of individualized breast cancer risk assessment and counseling on adherence to risk reduction recommendations among first-degree female relatives of breast cancer patients in Southwestern Nigeria.

The study involves two arms: the standard care arm, where participants receive breast cancer awareness education, monthly Breast Self-Examination (BSE) training, general breast cancer screening recommendations, and general lifestyle modification recommendations; and the experimental arm, where participants receive the same standard care plus individualized breast cancer risk assessment, individualized breast cancer risk counseling, and lifestyle risk reduction recommendations.

The primary outcomes measured include adherence to breast screening recommendations, adherence to lifestyle risk reduction recommendations, predictors of BSE, and predictors of time to first breast cancer screening post-intervention. Secondary outcomes include perception of familial breast cancer risk, knowledge of familial breast cancer risk, and knowledge, attitude, and perception towards genetic testing and breast cancer etiology.

The study targets first-degree female relatives of histologically diagnosed breast cancer patients, aged between 20 and 75 years, with no personal history of breast cancer, no previous exposure

This is an open-label, two-period, fixed-sequence study investigating the effects of CYP2B6 genotype and efavirenz on the pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics of methadone and tizanidine in healthy volunteers. The study has three phases:

1. Control phase: Participants receive a single oral dose of methadone (10 mg) and tizanidine (4 mg) at baseline. Pharmacokinetic sampling and pharmacodynamic assessments are performed over 72 hours. 

2. Efavirenz treatment phase: Participants take efavirenz (600 mg/day) orally for 16 days to achieve steady-state concentrations.

3. Steady-state phase: After 16 days of efavirenz treatment, participants receive a single oral dose of methadone (10 mg), tizanidine (4 mg), and efavirenz (600 mg). Pharmacokinetic sampling and pharmacodynamic assessments are repeated over 72 hours. 

The primary outcome is the magnitude of the effect of CYP2B6 gen

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate serum magnesium levels in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study included two groups: a cases group of type 2 diabetes patients and a control group. The primary outcome measure was the percentage of magnesium levels, which was evaluated over a one-year period. The study excluded patients with renal failure, type 1 diabetes, acute pancreatitis, hyperthyroidism, hyperparathyroidism, malignancies, and those taking loop/thiazide diuretics, magnesium supplements, or magnesium-containing antacids. The eligibility criteria specified a minimum age of 30 years and included only female participants.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of Ophiochepalus striatus extract on serum levels of IGF-1 and IL-6 in elderly patients with sarcopenia. It is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either Ophiochepalus striatus extract (2x5 grams per day) or placebo (maltodextrin, 2x5 grams per day) for 14 days. The primary outcomes are serum levels of IGF-1 and IL-6 after 2 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcomes include SARC-F score, muscle mass, muscle strength, and physical performance. The study includes elderly patients aged 60 years or older with sarcopenia diagnosed based on the AWGS criteria, excluding those with certain medical conditions or unwillingness to participate.

This is a randomized controlled feasibility study evaluating a digital therapeutic mobile app called the 2Morrow Chronic Pain Self-Management Program for improving pain self-management and function in patients with chronic pain. The study has two arms: an intervention arm receiving the mobile app in addition to usual care, and a control arm receiving usual care alone. The primary outcome is the PROMIS Pain Interference Scale, measuring perceived pain interference in daily functioning. Secondary outcomes include depression (PHQ-9) and anxiety (GAD-7) symptom measures. The study aims to assess the feasibility of using the mobile app and conducting a larger trial, as well as estimate effect sizes for planning an efficacy trial. Participants must be aged 18 or older, have a documented pain-related diagnosis, recent primary care visits, moderate-to-severe pain interference, and access to a smartphone. The mobile app provides evidence-based psychotherapy, activity tracking, screening, provider communication, and coaching support for chronic pain self-management.

This is a summary of the clinical trial document:

The study is a randomized, parallel-group trial comparing two surgical techniques for robot-assisted radical cystectomy with intracorporeal neobladder reconstruction (FloRIN) in patients with bladder cancer. 

The experimental arm involves performing the FloRIN procedure without using ureteral stents (stentless FloRIN). The active comparator arm involves performing the FloRIN procedure with the use of ureteral stents (stented FloRIN).

The primary outcome is the rate of mid-term complications at 6 months after surgery. The secondary outcome is the rate of perioperative complications within 7 days after surgery. 

Eligible participants are patients diagnosed with non-metastatic bladder cancer (stages T1-T4N0-N1M0) who are candidates for radical cystectomy with curative intent and neobladder reconstruction. Patients with metastatic disease, tumor involvement of the prostatic urethra, or urethral stricture are excluded.

The study aims to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the stentless FloRIN technique compared to the stented approach

This is a randomized crossover clinical trial investigating the effects of different storage conditions (wet vs. dry) on removable orthodontic retainers. The primary objective is to compare the microbial colony counts on retainers stored in wet and dry conditions. Secondary objectives include comparing the surface roughness, color stability, compressive strength, and impact on oral health-related quality of life between the two storage conditions.

The study involves 24 participants aged 18 and above who have completed fixed orthodontic treatment and are ready for retainers. They will be randomly assigned to start with either wet or dry storage for their Hawley or vacuum-formed retainers. After 3 months, they will switch to the opposite storage condition for another 3 months.

Retainers will be analyzed for microbial counts, surface roughness, color changes, and compressive strength at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. Participants will also complete a questionnaire assessing the impact on their oral health-related quality of life.

The study aims to provide evidence-based guidelines for the optimal storage method for removable orthodontic retainers, considering factors like microbial

This is a study investigating the impact of enhanced continuity of nutrition care between acute care hospital settings and community meal provision organizations on malnutrition outcomes in older adults aged 60 and above. The key aspects are:

- It tests a new model of cross-referrals, data transfer, and nutrition care across hospital and community settings to improve food security, quality of life, and reduce determinants of malnutrition in malnourished older adults after hospital discharge.

- It uses a stepped wedge cluster-randomized trial design across 8 sites in the US, with a focus on recruiting Black, Latino, Indigenous, Native American, and rural populations. 

- The intervention involves registered dietitian nutritionists (RDNs) providing medical nutrition therapy (MNT) and medically tailored meals (MTM) for 3 months post-discharge through community meal provision organizations.

- Primary outcomes are quality of life and program sustainability. Secondary outcomes include rates of nutrition care receipt, food security, malnutrition risk/diagnosis, and implementation barriers/facilitators.

- The study aims to evaluate the feasibility, sustainability, and impact of the new model of continuity of nutrition care across

This is a randomized, single-blind, crossover study investigating the hemodynamic effects of modulating circulating ketone bodies with 1,3-butanediol in patients with chronic heart failure (NYHA class II-III, LVEF <40%). The study involves two arms: an experimental arm receiving 1,3-butanediol dietary supplement and a placebo comparator arm receiving an isovolumic placebo. The primary outcome measure is cardiac output, measured by LVOT VTI and HR, at 6 hours. Secondary outcome measures include stroke volume, heart rate, LVEF, changes in circulating 3-OHB, and changes in FFA, also measured at 6 hours. The study aims to assess the potential therapeutic effects of ketone body modulation on cardiac function in heart failure patients.

This is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-blinded clinical trial investigating the use of subpectoral bupivacaine for pain management in adolescent reduction mammaplasty. The study aims to assess the efficacy of injecting 20cc of 0.25% bupivacaine solution or saline into the pectoralis fascia in reducing post-operative pain, narcotic use, and length of stay in the post-anesthesia care unit. Participants will be female adolescents aged 13-25 undergoing bilateral reduction mammaplasty. The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain score, measured by patient self-report on a 1-10 scale in the post-anesthesia care unit and daily until the 1-week follow-up visit. Secondary outcomes include narcotic use, length of post-anesthesia care unit stay, return to full activity, and demographics. Patients will be randomized to receive either bupivacaine or saline injections, with block randomization used to ensure equal group sizes. The study aims to enroll patients from 2022 to 2025, with an interim analysis planned after 60 patients

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the Spot Delete technique in pencil beam scanning proton therapy for reducing radiation dermatitis (skin redness) in breast cancer patients compared to historical data from regular proton therapy without this technique. The study will enroll breast cancer patients (stages 0-III) undergoing proton therapy after lumpectomy or mastectomy. Digital photographs, patient self-reports, and medical staff assessments will be used to measure and document the degree of skin reactions during and after proton therapy with the Spot Delete technique. The primary outcome is the reduction in radiation dermatitis compared to historical rates, assessed using the Common Terminology Criteria for Adverse Events (CTCAE) and Radiation Dermatitis Severity (RDS) scoring systems. A secondary objective is to investigate the relationship between the linear energy transfer (LET) of the proton beam and the location and severity of skin reactions. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefit of the Spot Delete technique in mitigating skin toxicities during proton therapy for breast cancer patients.

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, non-inferiority trial comparing the effectiveness of generic cetrorelix acetate versus reference cetrorelix acetate for ovarian stimulation using a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) antagonist protocol in women undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF). The study aims to evaluate the cumulative live birth rate, defined as the first live birth (gestation ≥ 24 weeks) in one IVF/intracytoplasmic sperm injection egg retrieval cycle (fresh and frozen-thawed embryo transfer cycle), as the primary outcome measure. Eligible participants are infertile women aged 20-42 years undergoing IVF treatment with a flexible GnRH antagonist protocol. The study has two parallel arms: one receiving generic cetrorelix acetate (0.25 mg subcutaneously) and the other receiving reference cetrorelix acetate (0.25 mg subcutaneously). The study is designed as a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, non-inferiority trial.

This is a Phase 1 clinical trial evaluating the safety, tolerability, and preliminary efficacy of the combination of peposertib (an investigational anti-cancer drug) and low-dose pegylated liposomal doxorubicin (a chemotherapy drug) in patients with metastatic or unresectable leiomyosarcoma and other soft tissue sarcomas.

The trial has two parts:

1. Dose Escalation: To determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the drug combination by evaluating dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs).

2. Dose Expansion: To further evaluate the safety and estimate the objective response rate (ORR) and progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with leiomyosarcoma treated at the RP2D.

Key secondary objectives include assessing the pharmacokinetics of the drug combination and correlative studies exploring potential biomarkers of response. Patients receive oral peposertib twice daily and intravenous liposomal doxorubicin once daily in 28-day cycles

This is a prospective, randomized controlled trial examining the feasibility and potential benefits of a free online Zoom t'ai chi and qigong gentle movement and meditation program for reducing back pain and improving sleep and quality of life among individuals with chronic back pain. The study aims to assess whether the 12-week, twice-weekly program can improve pain levels, sleep, and quality of life compared to a waitlist control group. The primary outcome is change in Oswestry Disability Index (ODI) scores for low back pain. Secondary outcomes include changes in visual analog scale (VAS) scores for back and leg pain, SF-36 health survey scores for quality of life, and Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index scores. The study plans to recruit 300 participants with chronic low back pain, randomized to either the t'ai chi/qigong intervention group or the waitlist control group. Data will be collected through surveys at baseline, mid-intervention, post-intervention, and follow-up. Statistical analyses will compare outcomes between groups and explore potential differences based on smoking status and BMI.

The EMBOL-AF is a multicenter, international, observational, retrospective registry study investigating the characteristics, management, and outcomes of systemic arterial embolic events, particularly stroke and transient ischemic attack (TIA), after catheter ablation for atrial fibrillation or left atrial macroreentrant arrhythmias. The primary objectives are to study the acute clinical profile, imaging findings, therapeutic management, and 3-month sequelae of stroke/TIA associated with these ablation procedures. Secondary objectives include assessing the association between the risk and severity of stroke/TIA with specific ablation techniques (e.g., radiofrequency, cryoablation, laser, pulsed-field ablation) and other procedural factors like anticoagulation management, transesophageal echocardiography, and anesthesia. The study will retrospectively collect data on all cases of arterial embolism that occurred between January 1, 2017, and July 31, 2023, at participating centers worldwide. The study aims to provide insights into the incidence, management, and outcomes of this clinically relevant complication of atrial

This clinical trial aims to evaluate patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) during the acceleration of en-masse retraction of upper anterior teeth using a low-intensity direct electrical current. The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving electrical stimulation to accelerate tooth movement, and an active comparator group undergoing traditional retraction without acceleration.

The trial will recruit adult patients aged 17-25 years with Class II Division 1 malocclusion, meeting specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. Participants in both groups will undergo orthodontic treatment with fixed appliances and extraction of maxillary first premolars. The experimental group will use a removable intraoral device to apply electrical stimulation for 5 hours daily, while the comparator group will undergo traditional retraction without acceleration.

The primary outcome measures are changes in the perception of pain and discomfort, assessed using visual analog scales (VAS) at specific time points during the treatment. Secondary outcomes include changes in the perception of burning, swelling, chewing ability, speech ability, analgesic consumption, patient satisfaction, ease of the procedure, possibility of repeating the procedure, and recommendation to a friend.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness

This is a single-site, non-randomized prospective observational study of men with prostate cancer. The primary objective is to evaluate whether baseline plasma Amyloid-beta 42/40 (Aβ42/40) ratio is associated with cognitive decline in men upon starting androgen deprivation therapy (ADT). The study has two cohorts: 1) Participants with prostate cancer starting ADT (ADT Cohort), and 2) Participants in remission from prostate cancer who have never received ADT (Prostate Cancer Control (PC) Cohort). The study involves blood-based assays, cognitive assessments, and quality of life surveys for both cohorts. The primary outcome measures are the proportion of participants with cognitive decline, mean cognitive decline, and proportion of participants with cognitive impairment after ADT in the ADT cohort. Secondary outcome measures include change in mean plasma Aβ42/40 ratio, mean cognition score, and mean study partner-reported cognition score. The study aims to evaluate the association between ADT and cognitive decline, as well as the potential role of plasma Aβ42/40 ratio in predicting

This is a multicenter, parallel-arm, double-blind, individually randomized superiority trial comparing high-dose (1000 mg QID) cephalexin to standard-dose (500 mg QID) cephalexin for the treatment of non-purulent cellulitis in adults presenting to the emergency department. The primary outcome is oral antibiotic treatment failure, defined as a change in antibiotic or step up to IV therapy within 7 days due to worsening infection. Secondary outcomes include clinical cure, clinical response, unplanned healthcare visits, hospitalization, adverse events, antibiotic intolerance, antibiotic allergy, medication adherence, and health-related quality of life. The study aims to enroll 446 patients across 8 Canadian emergency departments. If high-dose cephalexin is found superior, it could change practice by reducing unnecessary IV antibiotic use, hospitalization, and costs for cellulitis management.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the validity and reliability of the Health Literacy Scale for Acute Complications of Type 1 Diabetes for Children (8-12 Years) in Turkish, and to assess the effect of an educational board game on diabetes acute complications and health literacy in children aged 8-12 years with type 1 diabetes.

The study involves two stages: 
1) A general screening to determine the current health literacy levels using the Health Literacy Scale.
2) A randomized controlled trial with an intervention group receiving the educational board game and a control group. 

The intervention group will play the diabetes health literacy board game (DISOY) in the clinic and at home, while the control group will not receive any intervention initially. The primary outcomes are the validity and reliability of the Turkish Health Literacy Scale, and the evaluation of health literacy levels using the scale at baseline, 4 weeks, and 12 weeks after randomization.

The study aims to provide an educational tool to improve diabetes health literacy and acute complications management in children with type 1 diabetes.

This is a randomized controlled pilot clinical trial comparing biofilm accumulation on the surface of zirconia versus titanium dental implants. The study aims to evaluate the total amount of biofilm and specific bacterial species present on the implants before crown placement, at 6 months, and 1 year after crown placement. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either a zirconia or titanium two-piece dental implant to replace a single missing tooth. The primary outcome measure is the total amount of biofilm and the amount of various bacterial species, including A. actinomyces, P. gingivalis, P. intermedia, T. forsythia, P. micra, F. nucleatum, C. rectus, E. corrodens, Capnocytophaga sp., A. odontolyticus, S. mutans, and Candidae sp., which will be assessed by culturing samples taken from the peri-implant sulcus. Secondary outcomes include implant survival, probing depth, bleeding on probing, plaque index, amount of keratinized gingiva, and marginal bone loss evaluated radiographically. The study will be conducted at the

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of aromatherapy using rosemary and lemongrass essential oils on alleviating dental anxiety in children aged 6 to 9 years old undergoing primary molar extraction. The study has three parallel groups: a control group with no intervention, a rosemary group where children inhale two drops of rosemary oil for 3 minutes before the procedure, and a lemongrass group where children inhale two drops of lemongrass oil for 3 minutes before the procedure. The primary outcome measures include pulse rate, oxygen saturation, blood pressure, and pain level, which will be assessed at baseline, during the procedure, and immediately after the procedure. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with single masking.

The study aims to investigate the effect of using puzzles as an active learning tool on concept learning related to vital signs in first-year nursing students. It is a randomized controlled trial with two parallel groups: an experimental group and a control group. The experimental group will receive education on vital signs concepts (respiration, pulse, and blood pressure) through puzzles for two weeks, while the control group will receive regular classroom instruction. Pre-tests and post-tests will be administered to both groups to assess their knowledge levels. The primary outcome measure is the students' scores on the knowledge tests, which will be evaluated after five weeks. The study hypothesizes that the use of puzzles will positively contribute to the knowledge level and motivation of nursing students in learning complex concepts related to vital signs.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, open-label study aimed at evaluating the effect of a motivational interviewing program based on the transtheoretical model on smartphone addiction and sleep quality among nursing students.

The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving the motivational interviewing intervention and a control group without intervention. Nursing students at Aksaray University who meet the eligibility criteria, including scoring above the cut-off for smartphone addiction on the Smartphone Addiction Scale-Short Form (SAS-SF), will be randomly assigned to either group.

The experimental group will undergo a motivational interviewing program tailored to their stage of change according to the transtheoretical model, with a maximum of six motivational interviews. Those in the preparation phase will also receive training on smartphone addiction.

The primary outcomes measured are smartphone addiction (SAS-SF), sleep quality (Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index), and stage of change (Classification of Stages of Change Scale). These will be assessed at baseline (week 1) and post-intervention (week 16) for both groups.

The study aims to determine the effectiveness of the motivational interviewing program in reducing smartphone addiction and improving sleep quality among nursing students, who

This is a randomized, split-face trial comparing the efficacy of potassium-titanyl phosphate (KTP) laser alone versus KTP laser combined with ivermectin 1% cream for the treatment of facial rosacea. The study involves participants with Fitzpatrick skin types I-IV and facial erythematous or mild papulopustular rosacea. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive KTP laser treatment on one side of the face and KTP laser plus ivermectin 1% cream on the other side. The primary outcome measure is the reduction in erythema assessed by the Normalized Erythema Index (NEI) at 16 weeks. Secondary outcomes include erythema reduction assessed by Skin Redness Index (SRI) and Clinical Erythema Assessment (CEA), clinical improvement of skin lesions assessed by Physician Global Assessment (PGA), patient satisfaction assessed by Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), reduction in telangiectasia severity assessed by Telangiectasia Grading Scale (TGS), and changes in the number of papules, papulopustules, and patient-reported days of sw

This is a retrospective study analyzing cerebral glucose metabolism using FDG PET imaging data from a large cohort of patients with neurodegenerative diseases and head trauma. The primary aim is to characterize the patterns of regional hypo- or hypermetabolism associated with different neurodegenerative pathologies by examining individual subjects and brain circuits over a 4-year period. The study includes patients aged 18 years and older diagnosed with neurodegenerative diseases, with no other specific inclusion or exclusion criteria mentioned. The key intervention is the diagnostic FDG PET scan, which will be used to identify regions of altered brain function specific to each clinical condition.

This is a prospective, longitudinal cohort study investigating SARS-CoV-2 antibody responses and clinical outcomes in people with cystic fibrosis (pwCF) over a 3-year period. The study aims to determine the seroprevalence of SARS-CoV-2 antibodies in pwCF, the association between seropositivity and clinical symptoms/outcomes, and the longitudinal comparison of antibody levels following natural infection and vaccination. Participants will be enrolled from participating CF centers, and blood samples will be collected at routine clinic visits for up to 24 months to measure antibody levels. Clinical data, including demographics, medical history, medications, exacerbations, microbiology, and lung function, will also be collected. The primary outcomes include SARS-CoV-2 seroprevalence, the association between seropositivity and clinical outcomes, and the longitudinal comparison of antibody levels following natural infection and vaccination. Secondary outcomes involve investigating serum proteomic and genomic responses in seropositive and seronegative pwCF. The study aims to provide insights into the impact of COVID-19 on pwC

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use and reproducibility of duplex ultrasound in measuring the diameter of the left common iliac vein (CIV) to aid in the diagnosis of May-Thurner Syndrome (MTS) in patients presenting with unexplained left leg swelling. The study involves two groups: a symptomatic group with unexplained left leg swelling and an asymptomatic group without left leg swelling. Both groups will undergo a vascular ultrasound scan of the left CIV. The primary outcome measure is the diameter measurement of the left CIV, while the secondary outcome measure is the inter- and intra-operator variation of the diameter measurement. The study is designed as a non-randomized, open-label, single-group assignment study with a diagnostic purpose. Participants must be 18 years or older, have the capacity to consent, and require a vascular ultrasound scan as part of their routine care. The study aims to assess the reliability and reproducibility of duplex ultrasound in measuring CIV diameter, which can aid in the diagnosis of MTS, a condition characterized by compression of the left iliac vein.

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate the health-related quality of life of patients with symptomatic convergence insufficiency, a condition characterized by difficulty converging the eyes during near work. The study included two groups: a training group that received visual training in the hospital, and a non-training group. The primary outcome measures were changes in the EuroQol five dimensions questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) score and the shortForm 6D (SF-6D) questionnaire score, which assess health-related quality of life. The scores range from 0 (death) to 1 (complete health), and the changes were measured between baseline and 3 months. The study included participants aged 8 to 15 years old with specific criteria related to visual acuity, eye alignment, and convergence ability.

This is a pilot study investigating the use of indocyanine green (ICG) dye and a Spy-Phi handheld camera for sentinel lymph node mapping in early-stage vulvar cancer patients undergoing surgery. The primary objectives are to evaluate the detection rate of sentinel lymph nodes (SLNs) using ICG dye compared to the standard blue dye, and to assess the difference in SLN detection between the two dyes at the patient and hemi-pelvis levels. Secondary objectives include determining the sensitivity, specificity, and negative predictive value of ICG dye versus blue dye for SLN detection. Eligible participants are women aged 18 or older with early-stage squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva, tumor diameter less than 4 cm, and clinically negative inguinofemoral lymph nodes. The study aims to simplify the process of SLN mapping during vulvar cancer surgery by potentially replacing the radioactive tracer with the fluorescent ICG dye and specialized camera imaging.

This is a crossover, randomized, double-blind trial investigating the effects of different neuromuscular electrical stimulation (NMES) protocols on the triceps surae muscle. The study aims to compare the effects of four NMES protocols: Russian current at 2500 Hz with 10% duty cycle, Aussie current at 1000 Hz with 10% duty cycle, pulsed current at 50 Hz with 500 μs phase, and pulsed current at 50 Hz with 200 μs phase. The primary outcomes measured include evoked torque, muscle fatigue, sensory discomfort, and peripheral oxygen extraction. The study involves five sessions, with the first session determining the maximum intensity level for each protocol and randomizing the sequence of interventions. The subsequent four sessions involve evaluating the outcomes before, during, and after applying the NMES protocols. The study includes healthy, physically active participants aged 18-45 years.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study investigating the metabolic effects of a four-week lactate-ketone ester supplementation in obese individuals aged 30-60 years. The primary outcome measure is insulin sensitivity, assessed through a hyperinsulinemic-euglycemic clamp.
