Secondary outcomes include changes in lipolysis rate, body weight and composition, gastric emptying rate, cardiac function parameters, blood concentrations of various metabolites and hormones, liver function, inflammation markers, mood and anxiety scores, supplement tolerability, and appetite regulation. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either the lactate-ketone ester supplement or a placebo for 28 days, followed by a washout period and crossover to the other treatment arm. The study aims to evaluate the potential metabolic benefits of lactate-ketone ester supplementation in individuals with obesity.

This is a 6-week study exploring the impact of FitnessGenes' personalized recommendations platform, which uses genetic and lifestyle data, on improving the wellbeing of healthcare staff from multiple NHS trusts. Participants will provide a saliva sample for DNA testing, complete questionnaires on wellbeing (WHO-5 index), perceptions of DNA testing, and sustainability of recommendations at baseline, 3 weeks after receiving personalized recommendations, and a 3-month follow-up. The primary outcome is change in physical and psychological wellbeing measured by the WHO-5 index. Secondary outcomes include perceptions of DNA testing and how sustainable the personalized recommendations were. The study aims to assess if providing personalized recommendations based on genetic and lifestyle data can improve employee health and wellbeing.

This is a prospective longitudinal cohort study that aims to identify volatile organic compound (VOC) profiles in breath samples that are predictive of invasive pulmonary aspergillosis (IPA) in patients with acute myeloid leukemia (AML) or undergoing hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (HCT). The study will enroll patients newly diagnosed with AML or planned for HCT at Rambam Medical Center. Breath samples will be collected at baseline, upon clinical suspicion of IPA, and after treatment discontinuation. VOC profiles will be analyzed using gas chromatography-mass spectrometry and compared between patients who develop IPA and those who do not. The primary outcome is the diagnosis of IPA according to the EORTC criteria. The study aims to develop a non-invasive diagnostic tool for IPA using breath VOC analysis.

This is a single-arm interventional study evaluating the efficacy and safety of ultrasound-guided psoas tenotomy in patients with iliopsoas impingement after total hip replacement. The primary outcome is the success rate of the procedure, assessed by the disappearance of iliopsoas impingement at 3 weeks post-operatively. Secondary outcomes include pain scores, hip function scores (Oxford Hip Score, Harris Hip Score, Postel and Merle Aubigne score), technical difficulty, operative time, blood loss, length of hospital stay, scarring, quality of life, patient satisfaction, subjective hip value, forgotten hip sensation, complications, and rehabilitation needs. Assessments are performed pre-operatively, intra-operatively, and at various time points up to 6 months post-operatively. The study aims to evaluate this new ultrasound-guided technique compared to standard practice for psoas tenotomy in patients with iliopsoas impingement after hip replacement.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial comparing the effects of different volumes (20 ml, 25 ml, and 30 ml) of 0.25% bupivacaine for thoracic paravertebral block (TPVB) in providing post-thoracotomy analgesia. The primary outcomes are pain scores at rest and during coughing, measured using a visual analog scale at 1, 2, 4, 12, 24, and 48 hours after surgery. The secondary outcome is 24-hour morphine consumption. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-80 years, with an ASA physical status of I-III and a BMI of 18-40 kg/m2, undergoing elective thoracotomy surgery. The study aims to determine the optimal volume of local anesthetic for TPVB in managing post-thoracotomy pain.

This is a non-randomized, parallel-group, open-label interventional study investigating the effects of muscle vibration therapy using the "Vibra Plus" device in addition to standard rehabilitation on mobility, postural control, fatigue, and quality of life in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS).

The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving standard rehabilitation plus vibration therapy with the Vibra Plus device applied to their lower limbs, and a control group receiving standard rehabilitation alone.

The primary outcomes are changes in mobility (measured by motricity index), postural control (measured by Tinetti's scale and Berg's scale) over 12 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in fatigue (measured by Fatigue Severity Scale, Modified Fatigue Impact Scale, Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Functions, Borg Scale, and Medical Research Council Scale), and quality of life (measured by Multiple Sclerosis Quality of Life-54 scale and Coping Orientation to Problems Experienced questionnaire) over 12 months.

The study aims to enroll 40 patients with MS (20 in each group) aged between 20 and 60 years

This is a Phase I dose-escalation and dose-expansion study evaluating the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and safety of the combination of osimertinib, cetuximab, and tucatinib in patients with EGFR-mutant stage IV or recurrent non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) who have acquired resistance to EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs). The primary objective is to estimate the MTD of this triple combination. Secondary objectives include evaluating toxicities, preliminary anti-tumor activity, and progression-free survival. Patients receive osimertinib 80mg daily, tucatinib 200mg twice daily, and cetuximab 250mg/m2 intravenously every 2 weeks in 28-day cycles until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. The study has specific inclusion/exclusion criteria related to EGFR mutation status, prior treatments, organ function, and other factors. Key outcomes measured are dose-limiting toxicities, adverse events, objective response rate, and progression-free survival.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study comparing transbronchial cryobiopsy with a 1.1 mm flexible cryoprobe to traditional transbronchial lung biopsy with biopsy forceps in patients aged 18-65 years who have undergone lung transplantation and require monitoring for complications such as rejection. The primary outcome is the diagnostic efficacy of the two biopsy methods for detecting lung transplant rejection, evaluated against a multidisciplinary treatment reference standard. Secondary outcomes include incidence of complications, sample size, number of alveoli and blood vessels in the sample, percentage of artifact-free lung parenchyma, and number of attempts needed to obtain five samples. The study aims to assess the utility of transbronchial cryobiopsy as a diagnostic tool for monitoring lung transplant complications.

This is a study investigating selective fetal growth restriction (sFGR) in monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancies. The key aspects are:

- It aims to improve outcome prediction at the time of sFGR diagnosis by testing several predictors, including additional ultrasound parameters.
- It will examine placental histology to understand the underlying pathophysiology of sFGR.
- It will evaluate the neurodevelopment of sFGR twins at two years of age.
- It will assess the impact of sFGR pregnancy on parental mental health and parent-to-infant attachment.
- The primary outcome measure is a composite of fetal demise, selective fetal reduction, or iatrogenic preterm birth before 32 weeks due to fetal distress.
- Secondary outcomes include ultrasound parameters, prenatal and postnatal attachment, post-traumatic stress, and PARCA-R evaluation.
- Inclusion criteria include monochorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy, sFGR diagnosis before 28 weeks, and parental consent.
- Exclusions include lethal fetal anomalies, higher-order multiples,

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of an interactive educational digital platform (called THE GUIDE) for improving mental health outcomes in transgender and gender-diverse (TGD) youth aged 15-25 years and their caregivers. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an immediate access group that receives the digital platform plus usual care, or a deferred access group that receives usual care initially and gains access to the platform after 6 months. The primary outcome is suicidal ideation measured by the Columbia-Suicide Severity Rating Scale (C-SSRS) at baseline and every 3 months up to 12 months post-intervention. Secondary outcomes include depression (PHQ-9), anxiety (GAD-7), perceived family acceptance (TransFATE and FACES IV scales), and self-harm (NSSI). The study aims to detect a reduction in suicidal ideation from 40% at baseline to 26.3% or lower at 12 months in the immediate access group compared to the deferred access group. Data will be analyzed according to intention-to-treat principles.

This is a non-randomized, open-label, single-group study aimed at treating individuals with alcohol use disorder (AUD) or cannabis use disorder (CUD). Participants with AUD will receive 12 weeks of group cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) for AUD, with the option of evidence-based pharmacotherapy guided by an algorithm. Participants with CUD will receive 12 weeks of group CBT combined with motivational enhancement therapy for CUD. The primary outcomes include changes in binge drinking days, cannabis use frequency, average drinks per day, amount of cannabis used per week, alcohol craving, and cannabis craving during the 12-week treatment period. Secondary outcomes include treatment retention, changes in depressive symptoms, anxiety symptoms, and quality of life. The study aims to phenotype patients with AUD and CUD using the Addictions Neuroclinical Assessment.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the impact of positive, neutral, and negative expectation speech on the effects of spinal manipulative therapy for chronic low back pain. The study has three parallel arms:

1. Positive Expectation Group: Participants will watch a video delivering positive messages about spinal manipulative therapy before receiving one session of the therapy. 

2. Neutral Expectation Group: Participants will watch a video with neutral messages about the therapy before receiving one session.

3. Negative Expectation Group: Participants will watch a video with negative messages about the therapy before receiving one session.

The primary outcome is pain intensity measured by the Numeric Pain Rating Scale immediately after the therapy session. Secondary outcomes include global perceived effect of improvement, expectations regarding the therapy (measured by the Low Back Pain Expectation Scale and Treatment Expectations in Chronic Pain Scale), and perception of empathy in the therapeutic encounter (measured by the Consultation and Relational Empathy Scale).

The study aims to determine if inducing positive expectations through speech can enhance the effects of spinal manipulative therapy for chronic low back pain compared to neutral or negative expectation speech. Participants aged 18-60 years with

This is a randomized, sham-controlled study investigating the effects of transcranial focused ultrasound (tFUS) on resting-state functional connectivity in the brain's reward network in healthy individuals. The primary outcome measure is changes in resting-state functional connectivity between the nucleus accumbens (the stimulation target) and connected brain regions like the prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, amygdala, and sensory areas, before and after tFUS stimulation. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either active tFUS targeting the nucleus accumbens or sham tFUS stimulation during fMRI scanning. The study aims to evaluate the potential of tFUS as a non-invasive brain stimulation technique for modulating functional connectivity in specific neural circuits.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study investigating the effects of semaglutide, a glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist, on intracranial blood flow and blood-brain barrier permeability in patients with type 2 diabetes. The study aims to understand the biological basis of the observed stroke reduction with semaglutide treatment in type 2 diabetes patients.

The study will enroll men and women aged 40-65 years with type 2 diabetes for at least 3 years and HbA1c levels between 7-10%. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either semaglutide or placebo for one year. The primary outcomes are intracranial blood flow, measured as total length and number of distal vessels, and blood-brain barrier permeability, measured by dynamic contrast-enhanced MRI. Secondary outcomes include inflammatory markers like hsCRP, interleukin-6, and tumor necrosis factor-alpha.

The study hypothesizes that semaglutide improves endothelial function, leading to better cerebral blood flow and reduced blood-brain barrier perme

This is a retrospective cross-sectional study investigating the potential association between esophagogastric histopathology and the presence of colorectal neoplasms in patients younger than 50 years old who underwent simultaneous gastroscopy and colonoscopy. The study included patients aged 18-50 years who had complete gastroscopy and colonoscopy examinations, with adequate bowel preparation, and no history of gastrointestinal cancer, hereditary polyposis, or inflammatory bowel diseases. The participants were divided into two groups: the normal colonoscopy group and the colorectal polyps group. The primary outcome measure was the prevalence or occurrence of upper gastrointestinal diseases, including Helicobacter pylori, atrophic gastritis/intestinal metaplasia, reflux esophagitis, Barrett's esophagus, peptic ulcer, gastric polyps, low-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (LGIN), and high-grade intraepithelial neoplasia (HGIN), within a one-year time frame.

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing two surgical techniques for augmenting atrophic anterior maxilla: the screw tent pole technique and autogenous bone block technique. The primary objective is to assess the amount of bone gain, while the secondary objective is to evaluate bone quality through histomorphometric analysis. The study involves systemically healthy patients over 18 years old with atrophic anterior maxilla (initial ridge width ≤5mm and moderate bone height). Participants will be randomly assigned to either the tent pole group or the autogenous bone block group in a 1:1 allocation ratio. The surgical procedures for both techniques are described in detail. Post-operative care instructions and follow-up evaluations, including CBCT scans and bone core biopsies, are outlined. The primary outcome is bone gain measured at 6 months post-surgery, and the secondary outcome is bone quality evaluation through histomorphometric analysis of the bone core biopsy samples taken at 6 months.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the performance of a CD4/CD8+ interferon gamma release assay (IGRA) for monitoring the response to anti-tuberculosis treatment. The study involves two groups: a control group of healthy subjects and a group of patients with pulmonary tuberculosis (PTB). The primary outcome measure is to assess the correlation between changes in IFN-γ response in the IGRA assay and culture conversion, which is the reference standard for treatment response. Measurements will be taken at the time of diagnosis, 30-34 days after treatment initiation, 2 months after treatment initiation, and at the end of anti-TB therapy (6-9 months). The study will include participants aged 18 years or older, excluding those with immunosuppression or who have already received more than 72 hours of anti-TB treatment.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the accuracy and reliability of using radiofrequency (RF) and pinprick stimuli to evoke brain responses, measured through electroencephalography (EEG), as an objective alternative to subjective quantitative sensory testing (QST) for assessing the nociceptive system. The study involves two experimental settings:

1. Radiofrequency-evoked potentials (RFEPs): RF stimuli will be applied at pain threshold intensity to the arm and leg using an adapted electrocoagulation device. The latency and amplitude of the evoked brain responses will be measured.

2. Pinprick evoked potentials: An automated stimulator with a blunt tip will be used to apply pinprick stimuli at varying speeds and forces. The resulting brain responses will be recorded.

The primary outcome measure is the latency and amplitude of the evoked potentials (EPs) from RF and pinprick stimuli. Secondary outcomes include changes in pinprick sensation ratings, and the conduction velocity of the RF stimuli to estimate the type of nerve fibers involved.

The study aims to assess the effect of stimulation intensity on the signal parameters

This clinical trial aims to characterize the biomechanical coupling of the brain to the skull in human volunteers with and without a history of traumatic brain injury (TBI) using magnetic resonance elastography (MRE). The study will involve three groups: 25 mild TBI patients with a history of traumatic meningeal enhancement (TME+), 25 TBI patients without TME (TME-), and 25 healthy controls. Additionally, up to 10 more healthy controls may be recruited for technical development of imaging protocols.

The primary objective is to apply MRE to measure the relative motion of the brain and skull while the head is vibrated at specified frequencies, and to determine whether local shear strain measures within the cortex during MRE are altered in TME+ subjects. The study endpoints are the completion of the MRE visit for each volunteer, and the MRE data will be used to characterize the skull-brain interface using the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation across the interface.

The study will measure the primary outcome of obtaining MRE images, which will be processed to estimate global differences in the amplitudes and temporal delays of translation and rotation between the

This is a randomized controlled crossover trial investigating the effect of pharmacist-initiated home blood pressure monitoring on blood pressure control in women. The study aims to determine if providing women with home blood pressure monitors, along with enhanced pharmacist care involving review of home readings and recommendations to physicians, leads to better blood pressure control compared to usual care.

Key aspects:

- Population: Women aged ≥18 years with uncontrolled hypertension
- Intervention group: Provided home blood pressure monitor, measure BP at home every 4 weeks, pharmacist reviews readings monthly and makes recommendations to physician
- Control group: Usual pharmacist care without home monitoring, BP measured at pharmacy visits only
- Primary outcome: Difference in change in systolic blood pressure between groups at 24 weeks  
- Secondary outcomes: Proportion at BP target, medication adherence, medication changes, lifestyle changes, patient satisfaction
- Study design: Randomized controlled trial with crossover opportunity for control group after 24 weeks
- Setting: Community pharmacies in Ontario, Canada
- Target sample size: 368 participants
- Study duration: 24 weeks for primary outcome, follow-up at 52 weeks

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of moderate alcohol consumption on heart function in patients who recently had a myocardial infarction (heart attack). The study involves 220 participants who will be randomly assigned to either consume one standard alcoholic drink per day for 12 months or abstain from alcohol completely for 12 months. The primary outcome measure is the change in left ventricular ejection fraction (a measure of heart pumping ability) between baseline and 12 months. The study aims to determine if moderate alcohol consumption after a heart attack impacts cardiac function compared to abstinence. Participants must meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to their recent heart attack, alcohol consumption habits, and overall health status.

This is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of lactulose for bowel preparation in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) compared to polyethylene glycol (PEG). The study includes patients aged 16-75 years with confirmed or suspected IBD requiring a colonoscopy. The primary outcomes are the effective preparation rate measured by the Boston Bowel Preparation Scale, incidence of adverse events, and patient-evaluated taste score. Secondary outcomes include effects on liver function and serum electrolytes. Patients in the experimental arm will receive 3 bottles of lactulose oral solution, while the active comparator arm will receive 3L of PEG for bowel preparation before colonoscopy. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of lactulose as an alternative bowel preparation option for IBD patients undergoing colonoscopy.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of aromatherapy on sleep quality and quality of life for older adults at risk of metabolic syndrome in the community. The study aims to understand the sleep status and quality of life of these older adults and explore whether aromatherapy using lavender essential oil can improve their sleep quality and quality of life compared to a placebo (sweet almond oil). A total of 64 elderly participants from two community bases in Hsinchu City, Taiwan will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving aromatherapy or the control group receiving the placebo. The primary outcomes measured are sleep quality assessed by the Chinese version of the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (CPSQI) and quality of life assessed by the World Health Organization Quality of Life Questionnaires, evaluated one month after the intervention. The study hypothesizes that older adults in the aromatherapy group will have better sleep and quality of life compared to those using the placebo.

This is a 6-month prospective randomized controlled clinical trial comparing the effectiveness of two methods for soft tissue augmentation around dental implants: using a connective tissue graft (CTG) from the patient's own tissue or using a collagen matrix (CM) called Fibro-Gide.

The study involved 32 patients aged 25-59 years who required soft tissue augmentation prior to dental implant placement in the distal mandible. Patients were randomly assigned to receive either a CTG (n=16) or the collagen matrix (n=16) during the implant surgery.

The primary outcome was the amount of soft tissue thickness gain at 90 days post-surgery measured using intraoral scanning and software analysis. Secondary outcomes included soft tissue thickness gain at 180 days, pain levels, edema, analgesic consumption, quality of life (OHIP-14 questionnaire), attached mucosa width, and soft tissue aesthetics (PES score).

The key aspects evaluated were the clinical effectiveness, patient-reported outcomes, and aesthetic results of the two soft tissue augmentation methods over the 6-month follow-up period after implant surgery.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the effectiveness of intraoral and transcutaneous injection of botulinum toxin (Botox) for the treatment of myofascial pain in the masseter muscle. The study includes two intervention groups: one receiving intraoral injection of Botox into trigger points of the masseter muscle, and the other receiving transcutaneous injection of Botox into the masseter muscle. The primary outcome measure is pain score assessed using a 10-point visual analogue scale (VAS) at 6 weeks post-injection. The secondary outcome measure is the Oral Health Impact Profile (OHIP-14) scale, which evaluates self-reported discomfort, disability, and functional limitation due to oral conditions, also measured at 6 weeks. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these two injection methods in reducing myofascial pain and improving oral health-related quality of life.

The OptimizeD study aims to determine whether different patients with moderate to severe depression respond differentially to brief psychological treatment (Healthy Activity Program based on behavioral activation) or antidepressant medication (fluoxetine), and if so, whether one can optimize outcomes in a cost-effective manner for primary care patients. The study has two specific aims: 1) To evaluate the effectiveness of optimization via generating a precision treatment rule on clinical and functional outcomes, and 2) To assess the costs of optimal vs. non-optimal treatments and conduct a cost-effectiveness analysis. It also has two exploratory aims: 1) To explore whether the precision treatment rule can make tests of mediation more precise, and 2) To explore whether polygenic risk scores and other biomarkers can enhance the prediction of treatment response.

The study is a randomized, parallel-group trial with two intervention arms: Healthy Activity Program (HAP) and fluoxetine. Participants are adults aged 18 or over with moderate to severe depression attending primary health care centers. The primary outcome is depression severity measured by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9) at 3 months post-recruitment. Secondary outcomes

This is a study investigating the interactions between pulmonary immune cells and the microbiome in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The study will enroll 20 patients with none-to-mild ARDS and 20 patients with moderate-to-severe non-COVID-19 ARDS. Bronchoalveolar lavage fluid (BALF), endotracheal aspirate, oral and nasal swabs, and blood samples will be collected from the patients within 72 hours of intubation and again after 7-10 days if still intubated. The primary outcomes are the lung microbiome composition assessed by 16S rRNA sequencing and lymphocyte populations evaluated by flow cytometry in BALF and blood. Secondary outcomes include cell differential counts, cytokine levels, respiratory pathogens, and microorganism growth in body fluids. The study aims to understand the role of immune cell-microbiome interactions in ARDS severity and progression.

This is a randomized controlled study comparing the effects of 3D printed foot orthoses with prefabricated foot orthoses in subjects with flexible flatfoot. The study aims to evaluate if 3D printed orthoses can reduce self-reported pain more effectively than prefabricated orthoses.

The study will recruit healthy adults aged 18-65 years with flexible flatfoot but no other physical or neurological disabilities. Participants will be randomly assigned to either receive 3D printed foot orthoses or prefabricated foot orthoses.

The primary outcomes measured are pain levels using the Visual Analog Scale at baseline (week 0) and after 4 weeks of orthosis use. Additionally, user satisfaction with the orthoses will be assessed using the Quebec User Evaluation of Satisfaction with Assistive Technology questionnaire at week 4.

The study aims to determine if there is a significant difference in pain reduction and user satisfaction between the two groups, which could help identify the more effective orthosis option for flatfoot management.

This is a single-center cross-sectional study investigating the pulmonary ventilation function between patients with primary and recurrent incisional hernia. The study involved searching electronic medical records from January 2016 to March 2023 for patients diagnosed with abdominal incisional hernia, excluding those with other types of hernias or incomplete data. Patients were divided into two groups: primary and recurrent incisional hernia. Data collected included age, gender, ethnicity, BMI, abdominal CT images, maximum length of abdominal wall defect, comorbidities, and pulmonary function test reports. The primary outcome measure was recurrence after surgical repair. Pulmonary ventilation function, graded based on FEV1 percentage of expected value, was the main observation index. Statistical analyses were performed to compare the two groups. The study aimed to assess the differences in pulmonary ventilation function between patients with primary and recurrent incisional hernia.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate a strategy for detecting and monitoring unstable coronary plaques in patients presenting to the emergency department with chest pain suspected of coronary artery disease. The study involves categorizing patients into risk groups based on their coronary artery calcium score, which reflects the extent of atherosclerotic plaque burden. Patients in the intermediate and high-risk groups (groups III and IV) will undergo 18F-Na PET scans to identify and monitor unstable coronary plaques. The primary outcomes include measuring changes in calcium scores, plaque size, density, morphology, and stenosis diameter, as well as changes in 18F-Na PET binding to plaques over an 8-month period. Secondary outcomes include evaluating the effectiveness of initiating primary cardiovascular prevention strategies, comparing symptom evolution and cardiovascular event rates with a historical cohort, and assessing the impact of secondary prevention treatment on plaque stability. The study aims to provide insights into the frequency and evolution of unstable coronary plaques and inform prevention strategies for coronary artery disease.

This is a cross-sectional study aimed at investigating the association between white matter hyperintensity (WMH) shape and markers of cerebral small vessel disease (SVD), cognition, and glymphatic function in patients aged 65 and above with memory complaints or vascular brain abnormalities. The study involves 3T and 7T MRI scans, as well as neuropsychological assessments. The primary outcome measure is the association between WMH shape (assessed by parameters like convexity, solidity, concavity index, and fractal dimension) and structural and functional markers of cerebral SVD, such as lacunes and microbleeds. Secondary outcomes include the association of WMH shape with cognition, identification of WMH subtypes, and the association between novel glymphatic markers (e.g., perivascular space volume, CSF mobility) and SVD markers/cognition. The study aims to provide insights into the pathological mechanisms underlying WMH shape variations and their relationship with cognitive impairment and cerebrovascular pathology.

This is a single-center, case-control, diagnostic study investigating the role of an artificial intelligence (AI) system in the endoscopic diagnosis of esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma. The study aims to develop and validate an intelligent endoscopic diagnosis system based on deep learning algorithms. The primary outcomes measured include sensitivity, specificity, negative predictive value, positive predictive value, and accuracy of the AI system in diagnosing esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma. The performance of the AI system will be compared with endoscopists of different levels. The study includes endoscopic images of patients aged 18 to 75 years who underwent endoscopic examination or treatment, with pathologically confirmed esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma in the case group and benign findings in the control group. The study will evaluate the clinical utility of the AI system as an auxiliary tool for endoscopists in diagnosing esophagogastric junctional adenocarcinoma.

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the provided clinical trial document:

This is an open-label, single-arm, phase III study evaluating the efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics of FRSW107 (recombinant human coagulation factor VIII-Fc fusion protein) in pediatric patients aged 1-12 years with severe hemophilia A. The primary outcome is the annualized bleeding rate (ABR) over 1 year of treatment. Secondary outcomes include joint ABR, adverse events, incidence of FVIII inhibitor development, pharmacokinetic parameters like Cmax, Tmax, and FVIII activity levels over time. Patients will receive prophylactic FRSW107 every 3 days, with dose adjustments allowed based on response and FVIII trough levels. The study has a main treatment period requiring ≥50 exposure days and 26 weeks of treatment, followed by an extension period until 100 exposure days are reached while continuing the same prophylactic regimen. Key eligibility criteria include severe hemophilia A, previous FVIII exposure, and absence

This is a randomized crossover study investigating the acceptability and effects of live music therapy sessions compared to listening to a recording of the same music therapy session in palliative care patients with terminal cancer or severe illness. The primary outcome is intervention acceptability measured by a questionnaire. Secondary outcomes include symptom severity, quality of life, anxiety, depression, subjective experience, and objective measures of autonomic response such as heart rate, heart rate variability, electrodermal activity, and temperature. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either live music therapy first followed by the recording, or the recording first followed by live music therapy. The study aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and potential benefits of live versus recorded music therapy in improving symptoms and quality of life in palliative care patients, while also examining objective physiological responses. The findings may support the use of music therapy as an evidence-based complementary treatment in palliative care.

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effect of reusing operative supplies on the rate of postoperative endophthalmitis after cataract surgery, as well as the potential impact on financial costs and climate change. The study involved two groups: one where the surgeon changed gowns and gloves between cases, and another where only gloves were changed, with one gown used for all cases. Various operative supplies, such as keratomes, MVRs, IOL cartridges, OVDs, phaco tips, and cassettes, were reused and sterilized with alcohol between cases. Intracameral antibiotic prophylaxis was also reused and diluted. The primary outcome measure was the rate of postoperative complications, specifically infections, over a 6-month period. The trial sought to determine if reusing supplies could reduce costs and environmental waste without increasing the risk of endophthalmitis, particularly in developing countries.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled study investigating a new neuroregulatory technology called deep transcranial magnetic stimulation (dTMS) for the treatment of anorexia nervosa (AN) in adult females aged 18-35 years. The study is based on the hypothesis that overactivation of the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC) and its abnormal functional connectivity with other brain regions is the neuropathological mechanism underlying AN.

The study involves two parallel groups: an experimental group receiving real dTMS targeting the ACC (40 participants) and a sham comparator group receiving sham dTMS (40 participants). Both groups receive basic nutritional therapy as well. The dTMS/sham intervention is given 5 times per week for 6 weeks, totaling 30 treatments.

The primary outcome measure is the change in body mass index (BMI). Secondary outcomes include scores on various psychometric scales assessing eating disorder symptoms, depression, anxiety, and obsessive-compulsive symptoms related to eating disorders.

Assessments are conducted at baseline, during the 6-week treatment period (weeks 2, 4, and 6), and

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the acceptability of expanded newborn screening to parents in France, with or without the use of genetic testing as the first line of screening. The study involves four populations:

1. Parents or co-parents of a newborn child (less than a week old), who will complete an online questionnaire and may participate in a semi-structured interview.

2. Parents or co-parents whose youngest child is between 1 week and 3 years old, who will complete an online questionnaire.

3. Parents or co-parents whose child had a positive newborn screening result confirmed at diagnosis (except for hearing loss), who will participate in a semi-structured interview.

4. Parents or co-parents whose child was diagnosed later based on clinical signs for diseases not included in the current French newborn screening program but included in other countries' programs, who will participate in a semi-structured interview.

The primary outcome measure is a mixed matrix of parental acceptability dimensions of expanded newborn screening, combining quantitative and qualitative data. Secondary outcomes include parental acceptability scores, typology of acceptability scores, importance given to different modalities of information about newborn screening, opinions on screening for specific conditions

This is a randomized, parallel-group trial investigating the effectiveness of a 12-week remote Tai Chi and Qigong rehabilitation program for individuals with low back pain. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Oswestry Disability Index from baseline to 3 months after the intervention. Secondary outcomes include changes in visual analogue scales for low back and leg pain, the SF-36 health survey, and the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. Participants in the experimental group will receive the remote Tai Chi and Qigong program twice per week, while the control group will receive usual care as per their primary care physician or physical therapist. The study aims to assess the potential benefits of this mind-body exercise intervention for managing low back pain and associated disabilities.

This is an observational cohort study aimed at evaluating the safety and efficacy of CD19-directed chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T cell therapy in people living with HIV (PLWH) who have been treated for B-cell lymphoid malignancies such as acute lymphoblastic leukemia, diffuse large B-cell lymphoma, high-grade B-cell lymphoma, transformed follicular lymphoma, or primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma. The study will include PLWH aged 18 years or older who have received CD19-directed CAR T cell therapy outside of a clinical trial between August 30, 2017, and August 31, 2021. The primary outcome measure is the rate of toxicities related to CAR19 therapy, assessed using the Common Terminology for Adverse Events (CTCAE) criteria and the American Society for Transplantation and Cellular Therapy (ASTCT) criteria for cytokine release syndrome. Secondary outcome measures include changes in CD4 count, absolute lymphocyte count, HIV viral load, overall response rate, and complete remission rate at 3 and 6 months post

This is a prospective observational study in the UK that aims to discover novel predictive biomarkers to guide treatment decision-making and improve progression-free survival (PFS) and overall survival (OS) in patients with advanced triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC). Patients will undergo a mandatory biopsy or fine needle aspiration of the breast tumor or metastasis before starting their next line of therapy. The research sample will be processed and cultured in Pear Bio's organ-on-a-chip system, which provides a physiological 3D environment for drug dosing experiments. Approved therapies (monotherapy or combinations) will be tested on the cultured cells, and their responses will be monitored using confocal microscopy and other omics assays. For immunotherapies, tumor cells will be co-cultured with immune cells in a modified chip architecture. The study will evaluate the accuracy of Pear Bio's image-based biomarkers in predicting complete response rate, PFS, and OS. The primary outcome is to establish the functional dose of each commonly used FDA-approved therapeutic or combination in the Pear Bio system.

This is a health economic analysis study investigating the impact of delayed elective surgery on quality of life and associated costs in patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). The study involves two groups: 1) Patients with IBD who were on the waiting list for elective surgery between 2017-2021 at Sahlgrenska University Hospital, and 2) Patients with IBD who underwent elective surgery during the same period at the same hospital. The primary outcome measure is how health economy, including quality of life, is affected when surgery is delayed in IBD patients. Secondary outcomes include examining socioeconomic differences in delayed surgery and whether waiting for surgery affects the surgical outcome (complications, failures). The study aims to evaluate the economic and quality of life implications of delaying elective IBD surgery, which could inform healthcare resource allocation and surgical prioritization decisions.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of myeloid-derived suppressor cells (MDSCs) and cancer stem cells in non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The study will assess the non-immunological pro-tumor functions of MDSCs isolated from lung cancer patients. The primary outcome measure is the comparative analysis of the modifications in phenotype and functions of lung cancer cell lines when exposed to MDSCs extracted from patient tumor tissue. The study will involve collecting tumor samples from consecutive NSCLC patients undergoing surgical treatment. The study excludes patients receiving chemotherapy, radiotherapy, or immunotherapy in the neoadjuvant setting, and those with concomitant or previous cancer within the last 2 years. The study aims to better characterize the non-immunological functions of MDSCs and their role in tumor progression and resistance to immunotherapies in NSCLC.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of substituting unsweetened sparkling water for sugar-sweetened beverages (SSB) on sweetness perception and glycemic control in overweight/obese adolescents at risk for type 2 diabetes. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Participants: Overweight/obese adolescents (aged 10-21 years) who consume ≥2 servings of SSB per day and have a family history of diabetes or prediabetes.

2. Intervention: Participants will be provided with unsweetened flavored sparkling water and encouraged to substitute it for their regular SSB intake for 12 weeks.

3. Primary Outcomes: Changes in 2-hour glucose concentration, dietary consumption of SSB and sparkling water, insulin sensitivity, and glycemic variability.

4. Secondary Outcomes: Changes in flavor perception of beverage sweetness, blood pressure, blood triglycerides, and waist circumference.

5. Study Design: Prospective, before-and-after cohort study with a single intervention arm.

The trial aims to evaluate whether reducing added sugar intake by substituting uns

This is a randomized, double-blinded, prospective study comparing the early wound healing after using NOVOSYN® Quick versus MONOSYN® Quick suture material in resective periodontal surgery. The study involves adult patients undergoing resective periodontal surgery with specific incisions. The primary outcome measure is the early wound healing score (EHS), which evaluates clinical signs of re-epithelialization, hemostasis, and inflammation. Secondary outcomes include incidences of wound dehiscence, dentinal hypersensitivity, oral candidiasis, angular cheilitis, swelling, bleeding, infection, systemic complications, pain assessment, patient satisfaction, bacterial contamination of the suture thread, and assessment of suture material handling. Patients will be randomly assigned to receive either NOVOSYN® Quick or MONOSYN® Quick suture material during the resective periodontal surgery procedure.

This is a small sample, single-center, randomized, controlled clinical study investigating the use of Coenzyme I for injection in the treatment of sudden sensorineural hearing loss. The study recruited patients diagnosed with sudden sensorineural hearing loss within 72 hours, aged 18 years or older. Participants were randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving Coenzyme I for injection plus conventional treatment or the control group receiving conventional treatment alone for 14 days. The primary outcome measures were pure tone average (PTA) assessed at baseline, days 3, 7, 14, 30, and 90. Secondary outcomes included speech recognition rate, Tinnitus Handicap Inventory (THI), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) for tinnitus loudness, and VAS for severity of ear fullness, measured at the same time points. The study aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Coenzyme I for injection in improving hearing and tinnitus symptoms in patients with sudden sensorineural hearing loss.

This is a study aimed at establishing the scientific basis for newborn screening for cystinosis and primary hyperoxaluria (PH) using molecular genetic testing. The key aspects are:

- It is a pilot project to screen 200,000 newborns in Germany for two common mutations in the CTNS gene (causing cystinosis) and one mutation each in the AGXT gene (PH1) and HOGA1 gene (PH3) using real-time PCR on dried blood spots.

- For cystinosis, samples with heterozygous mutations will undergo next-generation sequencing to detect 175 additional CTNS mutations.

- Positive screening results will be confirmed by measuring white blood cell cystine levels for cystinosis, and urine/plasma testing for PH.

- The primary outcomes are the number of newborns with confirmed cystinosis diagnosis, heterozygous CTNS mutations, and PH1/PH3 cases identified.

- Secondary outcome is the urine analysis results in heterozygous PH1/PH3 cases.

- Diagnosed infants will be referred to

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of negative pressure drainage on reducing surgical site infections (SSIs) in clean-contaminated and contaminated surgical wounds of abdominal surgery. Patients undergoing intra-abdominal surgery will be randomly assigned to either receive negative pressure drainage (intervention group) or no drainage (control group) in their surgical wounds. The primary outcome is the rate of SSIs, measured at postoperative days 3, 5, 7, and 14. Secondary outcomes include length of hospital stay and quality of life scores at days 7 and 14 after discharge. The study aims to compare the rate of SSIs between the two groups and evaluate the potential benefits of negative pressure drainage in preventing SSIs and improving patient outcomes after abdominal surgery.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study comparing the immune modulation effects of three CDK4/6 inhibitors (ribociclib, palbociclib, and abemaciclib) in combination with letrozole, an endocrine therapy, in the neoadjuvant treatment of early-stage estrogen receptor-positive (ER+)/HER2-negative breast cancer.

The study aims to investigate the differences in immune modulation among these three CDK4/6 inhibitors, which have shown varying overall survival benefits in advanced ER+/HER2- breast cancer, potentially due to their differential effects on the tumor microenvironment and immune system.

Participants will be randomized to receive one of the following treatment combinations:
1. Palbociclib + Letrozole
2. Ribociclib + Letrozole
3. Abemaciclib + Letrozole

The primary outcome measure is the change in the expression of immune-related gene signatures, assessed through RNA sequencing of serial tumor biopsy samples collected before treatment, at 2 weeks after treatment, and after 12

This is a study aimed at developing and testing the feasibility of implementing a dementia care intervention called "Dementia Care Quality at Home" in two home-based primary care (HBPC) practices. The intervention involves: 1) a standardized assessment tool to evaluate the needs of people living with dementia (PLWD) and their caregivers, 2) seven educational modules to optimize well-being of PLWD and caregivers, and 3) regular team-based review and case conferences to address care challenges.

The primary objectives are to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and fidelity of implementing this intervention in HBPC practices for PLWD and their caregivers. Specific measures include feasibility of caregivers engaging with assessments and educational materials, practices identifying eligible patients/caregivers, and practices using the assessment tools. The study will survey caregivers to assess acceptability and impact on caregiver well-being.

Eligible participants include English-fluent adults living in the U.S., caregivers providing at least 4 hours of daily care for a PLWD and experiencing caregiver stress, and HBPC staff.

This is a randomized clinical trial investigating the comparative effects of resistance training and flexibility training on self-efficacy, symptoms of depression, and quality of life in postpartum women with depression. The study aims to recruit 36 postpartum women aged 20-40 years who are 6 weeks to 8 months postpartum. Participants will be randomly assigned to either a resistance training group or a flexibility training group. Both groups will receive 16 sessions of their respective training, twice per week for 8 weeks. The primary outcomes measured are exercise self-efficacy, depressive symptoms (using the Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale), and maternal postpartum quality of life (using the MAPP-QOL questionnaire). The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of these exercise interventions for improving self-efficacy, reducing depressive symptoms, and enhancing quality of life in postpartum women with depression.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate and compare the surface hardness and wear resistance of prefabricated and CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth used in complete dentures. The study involves a randomized, crossover design with two intervention groups. One group receives complete dentures with prefabricated artificial teeth, while the other group receives dentures with CAD/CAM milled artificial teeth. The primary outcomes measured are the wear resistance of the denture teeth, assessed through 2D, vertical, and 3D volumetric wear measurements using denture scanning and superimposition at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. Additionally, the surface hardness of the denture teeth is evaluated using Vickers's hardness test at baseline and after 6 months of use. The study includes completely edentulous participants aged between 55 and 65 years with Angle's class I maxillomandibular relations, excluding those with systemic diseases affecting bone and soft tissue health.

This is a randomized trial comparing trastuzumab deruxtecan (T-DXd) versus standard neoadjuvant treatment for HER2-positive breast cancer. The key aspects are:

- Patients with HER2-positive, locally advanced breast cancer are randomized to receive either T-DXd or standard chemotherapy (docetaxel/paclitaxel, carboplatin, trastuzumab, pertuzumab) for the first 3 cycles. 

- After 3 cycles, treatment for the next 3 cycles is determined by the molecular intrinsic subtype (PAM50) of the tumor.

- The primary outcome is the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate in the HER2-enriched subgroup.

- Secondary outcomes include pCR rates in other subtypes, event-free survival, overall survival, response rates, biomarkers, breast/axillary surgery rates, and quality of life measures.

- The study aims to evaluate if T-DXd improves pCR rates compared to standard treatment in the HER2-enriched subgroup, and if biology-driven

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of using intravenous anesthetics (propofol) versus inhaled anesthetics (sevoflurane) on the prognosis and survival outcomes of patients undergoing surgery for primary brain, liver, lung, and ovarian cancers. The study also investigates the potential mechanisms of action behind any observed differences.

The trial is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, triple-masked study. Participants are randomly assigned to receive either propofol (intravenous anesthesia) or sevoflurane (inhaled anesthesia) during their cancer surgery.

The primary outcomes measured are overall survival at 6 months, 1 year, and 3 years, as well as the presence of disease progression (recurrence or metastasis) within 36 months after surgery. Secondary outcomes include postoperative complications, Karnofsky performance status scores (a measure of functional impairment), and length of hospital stay.

Eligible participants are adults aged 20-80 years with primary brain, liver, lung, or ovarian cancer scheduled for elective surgery under general anesthesia. Patients with severe mental disorders, poor

This is a cluster-randomized controlled trial aimed at promoting physical activity-related health competence (PAHCO) among nursing students in vocational education in Bavaria, Germany. The study has four arms:

1. Cooperative Planning arm: Participatively developed intervention concept through cooperative planning to promote PAHCO, tailored to each school. 

2. Expert-Based Intervention delivered by External Specialists arm: An expert-developed intervention concept delivered by trained physical activity specialists.

3. Expert-Based Intervention delivered by Teachers arm: The same expert-developed intervention concept, but delivered by trained teachers from the participating schools.

4. Control arm: Regular education and health promotion without any systematic PAHCO intervention.

The primary outcomes are changes in PAHCO, psychological movement quality, and quality of physical activity, measured at post-intervention (1 year) and follow-up (2 years). Secondary outcomes include general health status, work ability, musculoskeletal complaints, and physical job stress in nursing.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of different approaches (participatory co-creation, expert-led by specialists, expert-led by teachers) in disseminating and implementing PAHCO curriculum content in

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial evaluating the effects of diosmin/hesperidin combination, alone or with metformin and/or combined oral contraceptive, on clinical outcomes in patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The study aims to assess the improvement in inflammation, glycemic index, PCOS status, and quality of life after 4 months of treatment. The primary outcomes are changes in inflammatory marker IL-6, fasting insulin, and HOMA-IR. Secondary outcomes include changes in PCOS signs, symptoms, hormone levels, and quality of life measured by the Women's Health Questionnaire. The study involves three intervention arms: 1) metformin + combined oral contraceptive, 2) diosmin/hesperidin + combined oral contraceptive, and 3) diosmin/hesperidin + metformin + combined oral contraceptive. Eligible participants are premenopausal women aged 18-40 years with a confirmed diagnosis of PCOS based on the Rotterdam criteria.

This is a Phase II clinical trial investigating the use of a near-infrared (NIR) fluorescent visualization system called Cetuximab-IRDye800 for the detection of non-visible lung cancer nodules during minimally invasive surgery. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of Cetuximab-IRDye800 in detecting lung nodules, lymph node metastases, and unexpected cancer localizations that are not visible to the naked eye or conventional imaging methods.

Key aspects of the trial:

- Participants: Patients with clinical Stage I non-small cell lung cancer eligible for minimally invasive surgical resection.
- Intervention: Patients will receive an intravenous infusion of 100 mg cetuximab followed by 50 mg Cetuximab-IRDye800 (a NIR fluorescent dye conjugated to cetuximab, an anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody) 2-5 days before surgery.
- Primary Outcome: Proportion of patients with detection of lung nodules during surgery by the NIR camera, compared to the pathology report.
- Secondary Outcomes:

This is a multicenter, randomized controlled trial comparing standard perioperative antibiotic prophylaxis versus prolonged antibiotic prophylaxis for 5 days after pancreatoduodenectomy (Whipple's procedure) in patients with a high risk of contaminated bile (those with preoperative biliary drainage or ampullary malignancy). The primary outcome is the rate of clinically relevant organ/space surgical site infections within 90 days requiring intervention. Secondary outcomes include rates of organ/space infections, isolated organ/space infections, wound infections, postoperative pancreatic fistula, bile/enteric leaks, post-pancreatectomy hemorrhage, delayed gastric emptying, bacteremia, Clostridium difficile infection, major morbidity, reinterventions, ICU admission, length of hospital stay, readmissions, and mortality. The trial aims to enroll 322 patients to achieve 304 evaluable patients, with 1:1 randomization to perioperative prophylaxis alone (control) or perioperative prophylaxis plus 5 days of cefuroxime and metronidazole (

This is a Phase 2, open-label, single-arm basket trial evaluating the combination of oral sotorasib (960 mg once daily) and intravenous panitumumab (6 mg/kg every 14 days) in patients with advanced solid tumors carrying the KRAS G12C mutation, excluding non-small cell lung cancer and colorectal cancer. The primary outcome measure is the objective response rate based on RECIST v1.1 criteria, assessed after the first cycle (14 days). Key eligibility criteria include locally advanced or metastatic solid tumors with KRAS G12C mutation, measurable disease, adequate organ function, and no prior treatment with sotorasib or anti-EGFR monoclonal antibodies. The trial aims to assess the efficacy of this combination therapy in patients with KRAS G12C-mutated advanced solid tumors.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-arm clinical trial investigating the use of a novel volume-stable collagen matrix (VCMX) in the treatment of single gingival recession associated with non-carious cervical lesions partially restored.

The study involves two treatment arms:

1. Active Comparator (PR+CAF): Participants will undergo a partial restoration procedure with the apical margin placed 1 mm beyond the cementoenamel junction, followed by a coronally advanced flap (CAF) procedure.

2. Experimental (PR+CAF+VCMX): Participants will undergo the same partial restoration and CAF procedures, but with the addition of a volume-stable collagen matrix (VCMX) placed at the cementoenamel junction level and stabilized by sutures.

The primary outcome measure is the recession reduction (RecRed) at 180 days, calculated as the difference between the final depth of gingival recession and the initial gingival margin position. Secondary outcomes include dentine hypersensitivity, patient-centered esthetic evaluation, Oral Health Impact Profile, patient discomfort, number of analges

This is a non-randomized, parallel-group study investigating the effects of different nutritional support modes based on nutritional risk screening on postoperative nutritional status of patients with gastrointestinal cancer. The study involves 302 patients with gastrointestinal tumors admitted to the First Hospital of Shanxi Medical University from July 2021 to June 2023.

Patients are divided into an intervention group (n=204) and a control group (n=98) based on nutritional risk screening results using NRS-2002 and PG-SGA scores. The intervention group receives a malnutrition five-step treatment model plus conventional nutritional intervention, while the control group receives conventional nutritional intervention alone.

The primary outcomes are changes in NRS-2002 and PG-SGA scores before and after propensity score matching between the two groups. Secondary outcomes include dietary energy and protein intake, nutrient energy and protein intake, anthropometric measures (BMI, fat-free weight), functional measures (grip strength, walking time), and laboratory parameters (prealbumin, albumin, hemoglobin).

The study aims to analyze the changes in various nutrit

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of the abutment-prosthesis connection on marginal bone loss and gingival sealing around dental implants. It is a randomized, parallel-assignment study with two arms: the experimental arm using the Connect® abutment and the active comparator arm using a conventional multi-unit abutment. The primary outcome measure is marginal bone level measured by standardized periapical radiography at 1 year. Secondary outcomes include peri-implant microbiome evaluated by next-generation sequencing methods and peri-implant inflammation assessed by measuring pro-inflammatory markers in the peri-implant sulcus, both at 1 year. The study includes partially edentulous patients aged 18-75 years requiring 2 implants for restoring at least 2 molars, 2 molars and 1 premolar, or 2 premolars and 1 molar in the mandible.

This is a clinical trial evaluating the feasibility of a wearable ultrasound patch for non-invasive monitoring of blood flow in the brain compared to a conventional transcranial Doppler probe. The study aims to recruit 60 participants aged 18 years or older, without serious medical conditions like heart attack, low blood pressure, aortic stenosis, carotid artery stenosis, glaucoma, or retinopathy. The primary outcome measure is the agreement between the measurements from the wearable ultrasound patch and the conventional transcranial Doppler probe in terms of peak systolic velocity, mean flow velocity, and end diastolic velocity of blood flow in various cerebral arteries, including the middle cerebral artery, anterior cerebral artery, posterior cerebral artery, vertebral artery, basal artery, internal carotid artery, and ophthalmic artery. The agreement will be evaluated using Bland-Altman plots over a study period of 1.5 years.

This is a single-arm, open-label study evaluating the clearance of uremic toxins in maintenance hemodialysis patients undergoing hemodiafiltration with endogenous reinfusion (HFR). The primary outcomes are the concentrations of β2-microglobulin, indoxyl sulfate, and λ-free light chain before and after HFR treatment. Secondary outcomes include single-compartment urea clearance index, urea reduction ratio, concentrations of other middle molecules and macromolecular uremic toxins, serum albumin, branched-chain amino acids, vitamins A, C, and E, and patient comfort during HFR treatment. The study includes adults aged 18-75 years on maintenance hemodialysis for at least 3 months, with adequate vascular access and dialysis adequacy. Key exclusion criteria are pregnancy, severe cardiovascular disease, active bleeding, unstable blood pressure, severe anemia or coagulation risk, severe infection, and drug addiction or severe mental disorders.

This is a randomized, controlled, open-label, multi-center clinical trial investigating the effect of combining multikinase inhibitors (sorafenib, lenvatinib, or donafenib) with bevacizumab as adjuvant therapy in patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) at high risk of recurrence after liver transplantation. The primary objective is to evaluate the one-year recurrence-free survival rate. Secondary outcomes include recurrence-free survival duration, overall survival, two-year and three-year recurrence-free survival rates, graft survival, quality of life, and safety (incidence of adverse events). Eligible participants are aged 18-75 years, have undergone liver transplantation within 4-8 weeks, and meet specific criteria for high-risk HCC recurrence. The intervention arm will receive a multikinase inhibitor plus bevacizumab for up to 12 months, while the control arm will not receive adjuvant therapy. The study aims to investigate the efficacy and safety of this combination therapy in preventing HCC recurrence after liver transplantation in high-risk patients.

This is a pragmatic trial evaluating the effectiveness of a supportive-expressive group therapy (SEGT) intervention for improving mental health outcomes in inpatients with limb loss at a rehabilitation hospital in Toronto, Canada. The trial will recruit 130 inpatients, with 65 randomly assigned to receive SEGT and 65 to receive treatment as usual (TAU). The SEGT intervention is a 6-module program delivered over 3 weeks, focusing on coping with limb loss, managing associated sequelae, goal setting, and strategies for community living. The primary outcomes are changes in depression (PHQ-9) and anxiety (GAD-7) scores, measured at baseline, post-intervention, and 3 months post-discharge. Secondary outcomes include changes in PTSD symptoms (PCL-5) and self-efficacy (GSE). The trial aims to determine if SEGT leads to better mental health outcomes compared to TAU for inpatients with limb loss.

This is a single-center, open-label, randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of 20% human albumin infusions on coagulation parameters in patients with decompensated cirrhosis of the liver. The study aims to enroll patients aged 18-70 years with decompensated cirrhosis of any cause and serum albumin ≤2.5 g/dl. Participants will be randomized to receive either 20% human albumin solution infusion to maintain serum albumin levels above 3.0 g/dl or standard of care treatment. The primary outcomes are changes in clotting time, clot formation time, and maximum clot formation measured by ROTEM over 1 week. Secondary outcomes include changes in inflammatory markers, endothelial dysfunction, pulmonary function, renal function, adverse effects of albumin, changes in the albuminome, duration of hospital stay, and 28-day mortality. The study will assess coagulation parameters, inflammatory markers, endothelial dysfunction markers, cardiac function, and other relevant tests at multiple timepoints over 1 week or until discharge. The expected duration of the study is 1

This is a prospective study evaluating the significance of minimal residual disease (MRD) monitoring in patients with potentially resectable stage III non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) without EGFR/ALK mutations. The study enrolled 65 patients and collected peripheral blood samples at multiple timepoints, including after neoadjuvant therapy, surgery (if any), adjuvant therapy, and during follow-up. The samples were analyzed using a tumor-informed personalized MRD test kit. Patients were followed up for 2 years, with a total of 9 follow-up visits every 3 months. The primary outcome measure was disease-free survival (RECIST), and secondary outcomes included overall survival, prediction of recurrence by positive MRD, pathological complete response (pCR) rate in MRD-negative patients, negative MRD rate in pCR patients, and 2-year disease-free survival in ctDNA-negative patients in the operable and inoperable groups. The study aimed to evaluate the significance of MRD monitoring in this patient population.

This is a single-center prospective cohort study comparing ciprofol and propofol for sedation in hypotensive intensive care unit (ICU) patients. The study aims to evaluate the proportion of patients meeting the Richmond Agitation-Sedation Scale (RASS) sedation target within 24 hours as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include dosages of ciprofol/propofol and norepinephrine, duration of mechanical ventilation, incidence of adverse events, length of ICU stay, and mortality rate up to 28 days. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 or older requiring vasopressors to maintain mean arterial pressure ≥65 mmHg and sedation in the ICU. The study has two arms: the ciprofol group receiving ciprofol for sedation and the propofol group receiving propofol. Key exclusion criteria include pregnancy, severe neurological disease, allergy to study drugs, long-term benzodiazepine or opioid use, and concomitant use of other sedatives.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial comparing laparoscopy plus laparotomy versus laparotomy alone for the treatment of premature infants with complicated necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) requiring surgery. The primary objective is to evaluate the inflammatory response on postoperative day 2 by measuring the change in C-reactive protein levels from baseline. Secondary objectives include assessing postoperative inflammatory markers, mortality, intestinal morbidity, reoperation rate, length of hospital stay, and neurological morbidity up to 3 months. The study also aims to evaluate the tolerance of laparoscopy by monitoring intraoperative cardiorespiratory parameters and the presence of local lesions related to trocar insertion. Premature infants diagnosed with NEC requiring surgery will be randomized to either laparotomy alone or laparoscopy followed by laparotomy.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing intense pulsed light and diode laser for hair removal in the axillary (underarm) region of women. The study involves 4 monthly treatment sessions followed by evaluations at 4-6 weeks and 6 months after the final session. The primary outcomes are hair count and the Global Aesthetic Improvement Scale assessed by blinded evaluators. Secondary outcomes include hair thickness, pain scores, quality of life, satisfaction level, and self-esteem. Eligible participants are women aged 18 and older with Fitzpatrick skin types I-IV who have not used certain medications or had previous hair removal treatments in the area. The study aims to evaluate and compare the efficacy, safety, and patient-reported outcomes of intense pulsed light versus diode laser for axillary hair removal.

This is a study investigating the evolution of plasma brain-derived tau (BD-tau) levels in patients with acute ischemic stroke due to large- or medium-vessel occlusion within 9 hours of symptom onset. The primary objective is to characterize the time course of BD-tau levels, including when they start to rise after stroke onset, the pattern of rise (linear, exponential, or logarithmic), and when they plateau, indicating no further infarct progression. The study will enroll 100 patients and measure BD-tau levels every hour from admission to 48 hours after stroke onset. Secondary outcomes include imaging measures like ASPECTS score, ischemic core volume, collateral score, final infarct volume, infarct progression, as well as functional outcomes at 90 days and 7 days assessed by the modified Rankin Scale. The study also aims to evaluate the association of BD-tau levels with early recurrent ischemic stroke, secondary intracerebral hemorrhage, and hemorrhagic transformation. The findings may provide insights into the responsiveness of BD-tau to brain injury after stroke onset and its potential utility in monitoring infarct evolution and guiding therapeutic decisions.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of artificial intelligence (AI) in accelerating the learning curve for mastering contrast-enhanced ultrasound (CEUS) of thyroid nodules. The study involves three groups of participants: a training set, an internal test set, and an external test set, all consisting of patients with thyroid nodules who underwent CEUS and fine-needle aspiration biopsy. The AI system assists radiologists in extracting ultrasound features of thyroid nodules. The primary outcome measures include the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve, the number of cases assessed by trainees, and the time taken for case assessment. These measures are evaluated at the end of the first, third, and sixth months of the trainees' rotation. The study aims to determine if AI can accelerate the learning process for interpreting CEUS of thyroid nodules.

This is a basic experimental study involving human subjects to quantify the perceptual experiences of retinal and cortical prosthesis patients. The study aims to test different stimulus encoding methods, including computer vision and machine learning techniques, to support simple perceptual and behavioral tasks such as object recognition and navigation. The study will produce visual percepts in patients either by directly stimulating electrodes or by displaying images on a computer or projector screen, which will be converted into pulse trains on the patients' electrodes. The primary outcome measures include assessing the effect of stimulation strategies on phosphene shape, pattern discrimination accuracy, and scene understanding performance. The study will involve perceptual tasks, such as signal detection and object recognition, as well as behavioral tasks, like walking towards a goal location. Patients' responses, reaction times, and eye positions will be recorded. The study will compare the performance of prosthesis patients across different stimulus encoding methods and with normally sighted control subjects viewing stimuli manipulated to match the expected perceptual experience of prosthesis patients.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of regular ultrasound surveillance in detecting nodal metastasis in patients with high-risk cutaneous squamous cell carcinoma (cSCC) of the head and neck. The study includes three arms based on the Brigham and Women's Hospital (BWH) staging of cSCC:

1. BWH stage T2a tumors in immunosuppressed patients: Participants will undergo ultrasound surveillance every 6 months and regular visits every 3 months for 2 years without any initial imaging or sentinel lymph node biopsy.

2. BWH stage T2b tumors: Participants will undergo CT imaging and sentinel lymph node biopsy (SLNB). If both are negative, they will be enrolled and undergo ultrasound surveillance every 6 months and regular visits every 3 months for 2 years.

3. BWH stage T3 tumors: Similar to the T2b arm, participants will undergo CT imaging and SLNB. If both are negative, they will be enrolled and undergo ultrasound surveillance every 6 months and regular visits every 3 months for 2

This clinical trial aims to investigate salivary biomarkers for the diagnosis of gastroesophageal reflux (GER) and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) in infants. The study involves two groups: an experimental group of infants aged 2 months to 1 year with GER or GERD symptoms undergoing 24-hour esophageal multichannel intraluminal impedance and pH monitoring (MII-pH), and a control group of healthy infants. Saliva samples will be collected from the experimental group at defined time points during the MII-pH procedure, and a single sample will be taken from the control group. The primary outcome measure is to identify the prevalence of GERD in infants with reflux symptoms. Secondary outcomes include identifying differences in the biochemical profile (pepsin, pepsinogen, electrolytes) of saliva samples between healthy, GER, and GERD infants, investigating circadian variations in the biochemical profile, and correlating symptom onset and nutrition with changes in the biochemical profile. The study aims to develop non-invasive diagnostic strategies and personalized therapeutic treatments for GER and

This is a prospective open-label observational study aimed at comparing the effect of Empagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor) and Dulaglutide (GLP-1 receptor agonist) on liver fat fraction in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus and non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD). The study will enroll patients aged 25-75 years with type 2 diabetes and NAFLD, and allocate them into three groups: Empagliflozin group (receiving Empagliflozin 10mg daily), Dulaglutide group (receiving Dulaglutide 1.5mg weekly), and a control group receiving optimal antidiabetic treatment excluding GLP-1 agonists or SGLT2 inhibitors. The primary outcomes are reduction in liver fat fraction measured by MRI-PDFF and the percentage of participants achieving >30% liver fat fraction reduction after 52 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcomes include changes in HbA1c, body mass index, fatty liver index, fibrosis scores (FIB-4, APRI, N

This is a randomized clinical trial assessing the feasibility of using surgical templates for the surgical exposure of palatally impacted upper canines with the open-eruption technique. The study compares this method with the conventional free-hand surgical exposure.

The study has two groups:
1. Test group: Surgical exposure using a surgical template designed with virtual planning.
2. Control group: Conventional free-hand surgical exposure.

Patients aged 11-18 years requiring surgical exposure and orthodontic eruption of palatally impacted canines are included. The primary outcomes measure the success of the intervention (attachment bonding) and the success of the open eruption technique. Secondary outcomes include costs, surgery duration, postoperative pain, and complications.

The study involves preoperative CBCT scans, virtual planning, and 3D printing of surgical templates for the test group. Surgeries are performed under local anesthesia, with postoperative instructions and medication prescribed. Measures are taken to manage participant bias and blinding.

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the CAVEAT clinical trial:

The CAVEAT (Clinician-Assisted Videofeedback Exposure-Approach Therapy) trial is an open-label feasibility study examining a brief manualized psychotherapy for violence-exposed mothers and their young children aged 1-5 years. The primary aim is to assess the feasibility of recruitment, treatment adherence, therapeutic alliance, patient/therapist satisfaction, and appropriateness of evaluation measures. A secondary aim is to evaluate the feasibility of administering the CAVEAT therapy manual and procedures in a clinic setting. 

The study involves 12 mother-child dyads where the mothers have experienced interpersonal violence and have concerns about their child's emotional/behavioral difficulties or relational disturbances. The CAVEAT therapy integrates components from existing evidence-based psychotherapies and uses clinician-assisted videofeedback exposure sessions to help mothers perceive their child's perspective and emotional communication more accurately.

Eligibility criteria include biological mothers aged 18-50 years with children aged 12-54 months who have lived together since birth. Mothers with active psychosis,

This is a randomized controlled trial aimed at reducing the risk of type 2 diabetes and pre-diabetes in Asian women with a history of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) in Singapore. The study involves a 1-year intervention period followed by a 3-year follow-up period. Eligible women will be randomized into two groups: 

Group 1 (Intervention): Participants will receive the LvL UP App, a smartphone-based conversational agent that delivers a holistic lifestyle intervention focusing on diet, physical activity, and mental well-being. They will also receive the HAPPY App for health promotion information and to display health data, as well as an Oura ring and app for activity and sleep tracking.

Group 2 (Control): Participants will receive the HAPPY App and Oura ring/app, but not the LvL UP App intervention.

The primary outcome is the incidence of type 2 diabetes confirmed by an oral glucose tolerance test over 4 years. Secondary outcomes include changes in cardiometabolic variables, body composition, mental well-being, children's health, and adverse events related to diabetes.

Assessments will be conducted

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effect of dry heat and dry cold application on pain, anxiety, and fear levels before blood sample collection in school-aged children (7-12 years old). The study had three parallel groups: a dry heat application group, a dry cold application group, and a control group.

In the dry heat application group, an electric heating pad set to 42°C was applied to the area where the blood sample would be collected for 5 minutes before the procedure.
