In the dry cold application group, a gel pad was used to apply dry cold to the same area for 3 minutes before the procedure. The control group received routine care without any heat or cold application.

The primary outcome measure was pain levels assessed using the Wong Baker Faces Pain Rating Scale one minute after blood sampling. Secondary outcome measures included fear levels assessed using the Child Fear Scale and the Medical Procedures Fear Inventory, as well as anxiety levels assessed using the Child Anxiety Scale, measured before and after blood sampling.

The study was a randomized controlled trial with parallel assignment and an open-label design. Eligible participants were school-aged children (7-12 years old) without physical, mental, auditory, visual, or

This is a phase I clinical trial assessing the safety and efficacy of using intra-arterial melphalan chemotherapy for chemoreduction of large choroidal melanomas (≥8 mm thickness), followed by ruthenium-106 (Ru-106) plaque brachytherapy. The primary aim is to determine the safety of this treatment approach through electroretinography (ERG) measurements at different time points up to 6 months post-treatment. Secondary outcomes include tumor size reduction, visual acuity changes, signs of intraocular inflammation, treatment-related adverse events, and globe salvage rate at 12 months. Eligible patients with choroidal melanoma ≥8 mm thick will receive a single intra-arterial injection of 7.5 mg melphalan, followed by Ru-106 plaque brachytherapy 4±1 weeks later, with a target tumor apex dose of around 80 Gy. Patients will undergo comprehensive ophthalmic examinations, including ERG, optical coherence tomography, ultrasonography, and fundus imaging at baseline and follow-up visits. This trial explores

This is a retrospective observational study aimed at establishing a trauma registry at a general hospital in Villavicencio, Colombia, during the first semester of 2023. The study will include patients aged 16-120 years admitted to the emergency ward due to trauma, categorized into blunt injury and penetrating injury groups. No therapeutic or diagnostic interventions will be provided as it is an observational study. The primary outcome measure is the number of patients who died within 28 days or upon discharge. Secondary outcome measures include hospital and ICU length of stay, need for ICU admission and mechanical ventilation, and duration of mechanical ventilation. The study aims to gather data on the incidence, mechanisms, severity, and outcomes of trauma cases to inform policies, resource allocation, and clinical practice guidelines for trauma management in the region.

This is a feasibility study investigating a non-invasive postural therapy (NIPT) for older adult veterans with lumbosacral spinal stenosis. The study aims to assess the change in mobility, measured by actigraph, after a 6-week trial of NIPT. The intervention involves providing durable medical equipment and training to help participants maintain a flexion posture continuously during the trial period. Participants will wear actigraphs and pedometers intermittently and complete questionnaires and mobility assessments. The study has specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to the diagnosis of spinal stenosis, symptom duration, prior treatments, and comorbidities. The target population is veterans aged 60-80 years receiving care at participating VA facilities.

This is a pilot study to assess the effects of self-administered nitrous oxide (SANO) on urodynamic study (UDS) parameters. The study involves participants undergoing two UDS runs, one with SANO and one with oxygen. The primary outcome measure is bladder capacity, measured in milliliters at the time of maximum fill during each UDS run. Secondary outcome measures include intra-UDS pain and anxiety levels, post-void residual, maximum flow rate, detrusor overactivity, and detrusor pressure at maximum flow.

The study is designed as a randomized, crossover trial with triple masking. Participants aged 21-85 years scheduled for a UDS will be randomly assigned to receive either SANO during the first UDS run and oxygen during the second, or vice versa. SANO will be administered at a concentration of 25-50% during catheter placement and the participant's preferred level during the UDS run. Oxygen will be given at 100% and 10 liters/minute.

The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of SANO in improving patient experience and urodynamic parameters during UDS procedures.

This clinical trial aims to study the impact of adverse childhood experiences (ACEs) on adaptation and quality of life in women who have had breast cancer and are in remission. The primary outcome measure is quality of life assessed using the SF-12 scale. Secondary outcomes include fear of cancer recurrence, fatigue, anxiety, depression, attachment styles, resilience, and biological measures such as heart rate variability and epigenetic markers related to stress response.

The study includes women over 18 years old who have had breast cancer, are in remission, and meet other eligibility criteria. Participants will complete questionnaires assessing ACEs, quality of life, psychological factors like anxiety and depression, attachment styles, and resilience. Additionally, there is an exploratory biological component measuring chronic stress levels and epigenetic markers.

The trial aims to understand how ACEs and related factors like attachment and resilience influence adaptation and quality of life in breast cancer survivors. The findings could inform supportive care and interventions for this population.

This is a single-center, blinded, controlled, prospective crossover trial aimed at evaluating the real-world effectiveness of an artificial intelligence (AI)-assisted polyp/adenoma detection system (DiscoveryTM AI, Pentax Medical) during screening colonoscopy. The study involves two groups of participants aged 45-89 years undergoing screening colonoscopy. One group will undergo a standard high-definition (HD) colonoscopy followed by an HD colonoscopy assisted by the AI system, while the other group will undergo the procedures in the reverse order. The procedures will be performed by expert and non-expert endoscopists, who will be blinded to the results of the previous procedure. The primary outcomes are the adenoma detection rate (ADR) and polyp detection rate (PDR), which will be compared between expert and non-expert endoscopists. The diagnostic performance of the AI system, including sensitivity, specificity, positive and negative predictive values, and observer agreement, will also be assessed. A secondary outcome is the adenoma miss rate (AMR), determined by the number of missed adenomas on the initial examination. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the AI-

This is a non-randomized, open-label, parallel-group study investigating the tolerability, efficacy, and potential mechanisms of a low glycemic index (LGI) diet in pregnant people with epilepsy. The study aims to enroll 21 participants, with a 1:2 ratio of intervention to control group. The intervention group will initiate an LGI diet with ongoing dietician support until pregnancy completion, while the control group will follow a standard diet. The primary outcome is the tolerability of the LGI diet, measured by the number of participants able to continue the diet during pregnancy. Secondary outcomes include seizure frequency, gut bacteria composition, and metabolic pathway alterations, assessed through stool and blood samples collected during pregnancy and up to 3 months postpartum. The study will provide insights into the potential benefits and mechanisms of the LGI diet as a non-pharmacological treatment for epilepsy during pregnancy.

This is a feasibility study investigating the use of mesothelin-targeted chimeric antigen receptor (CAR) T-cell therapy as a neoadjuvant treatment for patients with resectable pancreatic cancer. The primary objective is to evaluate the pathologic response rate on resected pancreatic tumor specimens after endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)-guided injection of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells. Secondary objectives include assessing radiological response, rate of R0 surgical resection, safety, disease-free survival, and overall survival. Eligible patients have histologically confirmed resectable pancreatic cancer and meet specific inclusion/exclusion criteria. In the experimental arm, participants will receive EUS-guided injection of mesothelin-targeted CAR-T cells prior to planned curative surgical resection. The study aims to determine the feasibility and potential efficacy of this novel immunotherapy approach in the neoadjuvant setting for pancreatic cancer.

This is a 3-month randomized controlled study evaluating the effectiveness of a web-based decision support system (DSS) called TREAT (TREatment Adherence SupporT) in promoting adherence to oral anticancer treatments among 100 metastatic breast cancer patients. The primary aim is to assess if TREAT can foster adherence to oral treatments over a 3-month period. Secondary aims include identifying clinical, psychological, and quality of life factors that predict adherence, and evaluating risk perception as a predictor of adherence.

Participants are randomized 1:1 to either receive TREAT for 3 months (intervention group) or standard medical advice (control group). TREAT comprises sections on metastatic breast cancer, treatment adherence, promoting adherence, and an adherence diary. Adherence is measured by calculating the ratio of pills taken to prescribed amount. Data is collected at baseline, 1 month, 2 months, and 3 months using validated questionnaires assessing adherence, clinical factors, psychological parameters like anxiety and depression, personality traits, coping self-efficacy, sense of coherence, quality of life, and risk perception.

This is a randomized, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effects of weight-bearing exercises with and without Jaffrey's core stability exercise training on dynamic balance and trunk muscle strength in children with Down syndrome aged 4 to 10 years. The study has two intervention arms: one group receives weight-bearing exercises, and the other group receives Jaffrey's core stability exercises. The primary outcome measures are the Pediatric Balance Scale, which assesses functional balance skills, and the Trunk Control Measurement Scale, which measures trunk control in children. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these exercise interventions in improving balance and trunk muscle strength in children with Down syndrome over a 4-week period.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial investigating the effects of melatonin supplementation on various cardiovascular, bone metabolism, and quality of life markers in peritoneal dialysis patients. The study involves two parallel groups: an active comparator group receiving 5 mg of melatonin tablets 30 minutes before bedtime, and a placebo comparator group receiving placebo tablets. The primary outcomes include serum levels of lipoprotein(a), malondialdehyde, high-sensitivity C-reactive protein, soluble intercellular adhesion molecule-1, glucose, pentosidine, carboxymethyl lysine, procollagen 1 intact N-terminal propeptide, osteoprotegerin, tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase 5b, receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa-Β ligand, blood pressure, triglycerides, cholesterol levels, and quality of life assessments. Secondary outcomes include serum levels of albumin, calcium, phosphorus, and intact parathyroid hormone. The study duration is 10 weeks, and eligible participants are peritoneal dialysis patients aged 18

This is a study investigating an optimization strategy to predict and individualize oxygen delivery during cardiac surgery under cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB). The study aims to measure the values of oxygen delivery (DO2) calculated using the CONNECT software from LivaNova, which utilizes CPB output and hemoglobin values. The primary outcome measure is the DO2 values calculated every 20-30 seconds during CPB and up to 28 days postoperatively. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of postoperative acute kidney injury (AKI) assessed by creatinine measurement, the incidence of postoperative delirium assessed by CAM-ICU, CPC, and mRS scores, and vital status up to 28 days postoperatively. The study intervention involves the use of CPB, with priming volume set at 1200-1500 mL, and patient blood and hemodynamic management left to the discretion of the anesthesiologist. The study includes adult patients aged 18-100 years scheduled for elective cardiac surgery under CPB at the University Hospital of Lille, France, who have provided written consent and are insured under the French social security system

This clinical trial aims to investigate the changes in lumbar region temperature during auricular acupressure at the kidney point in healthy volunteers. The study has a randomized, crossover design with two groups: one receiving auricular acupressure (AA) first followed by sham auricular acupressure (SA), and the other receiving SA first followed by AA. The primary outcomes are the changes in temperature of the left and right lumbar regions, measured using an infrared thermal imaging camera during the procedures. The secondary outcome is the proportion of auricular acupuncture side effects. The study involves healthy volunteers aged 18-30 years, with specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to body mass index, mental health status, medication use, and other factors that may affect body temperature. The interventions include auricular acupressure applied at the kidney point on the left and right ears using a tape with a Vaccaria seed, and sham auricular acupressure using a tape without a seed. The study aims to provide insights into the potential effects of auricular acupressure on lumbar region temperature.

This is a summary of the provided clinical trial document:

The trial aims to compare three different strategies for managing mean arterial pressure (MAP) during cardiopulmonary bypass (CPB) in cardiac surgery patients. The three treatment groups are:

1. Standard MAP: 50-60 mmHg (control group)
2. High MAP: 70-80 mmHg  
3. Patient-tailored MAP: Comparable to the patient's pre-operative MAP

The primary outcome is the peak serum lactate value (Lmax) detected during CPB, as an index of tissue hypoperfusion. Secondary outcomes include area under the lactate curve, cases with Lmax >3 mmol/l, cerebral/pulmonary perfusion, low cardiac output, postoperative cardiac/pulmonary/renal function, gastrointestinal ischemia, neurological dysfunction, and mortality.

It is a multicenter, randomized, open-label, parallel-group study planned to enroll 999 patients undergoing elective cardiac surgery across 4 centers in Italy and Spain. Extensive pre-, intra-, and post-operative data will be

This is a prospective observational study investigating the acute and subacute effects of intravenous furosemide (80 mg) on hemodynamics and pulmonary congestion in patients with acute decompensated heart failure. The primary outcome measure is the change in pulmonary fluid content, assessed using remote dielectric sensing (ReDS), from baseline to 30 minutes after furosemide administration. Secondary measures include blood pressure, peripheral oxygen saturation, ultrasound examination of the heart and lungs, and assessment of cardiac filling pressures using Doppler and strain analysis. Measurements are repeated at multiple time points up to 6 hours after furosemide administration. The study aims to evaluate the acute effects of furosemide on relieving pulmonary congestion and improving hemodynamics in patients with acute heart failure.

This is a national randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of a smartphone application for university students with binge drinking behavior. The study aims to evaluate the change in the number of standard drinks consumed per week and the change in phosphatidylethanol (PEth) concentration, a biomarker for alcohol consumption, over a period of 30 months.

The study involves two parallel groups: an experimental group receiving the smartphone application intervention and an active comparator group serving as a control. Both groups will undergo blood microsampling for the measurement of PEth at various time points throughout the study duration.

The primary outcome measure is the change in the number of standard drinks consumed per week over 30 months. Secondary outcome measures include the change in PEth concentration at 3, 6, 9, 12, 15, 18, 21, 24, 27, and 30 months.

Eligible participants are university students aged 18 to 25 years with binge drinking behavior, defined as having at least one occasion with six or more drinks in the last three months. Exclusion criteria include not having a compatible smartphone, previous use of the MyDéfi smartphone application, psychiatric

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial evaluating the potential benefit of nitazoxanide as an adjuvant therapy in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus. The study aims to assess the effect of nitazoxanide (500 mg twice daily) in addition to metformin and dipeptidyl peptidase-4 (DPP-4) inhibitors on glycemic control, insulin resistance, lipid profile, and serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1 and asprosin in patients with type 2 diabetes. The primary outcome measure is glycemic control, assessed by fasting blood glucose and glycated hemoglobin levels after 12 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcomes include insulin resistance (measured by fasting insulin level and HOMA-IR), lipid profile (total cholesterol, LDL, HDL, and triglycerides), and serum levels of A-kinase anchoring protein 1 and asprosin. The study involves 70 participants aged 18 years or older with type 2 diabetes, glycated hemoglobin between 7% and 9%, and

This clinical trial aims to investigate the clinical risk factors of autism and elucidate changes in the gut microbiome and metabolome in Egyptian autistic children aged 3-9 years. The study will examine prenatal, natal, and postnatal history to analyze autism clinical risk factors. Additionally, stool samples will be collected to investigate the intestinal microbiome and conduct metabolome analysis. The primary outcome measure is autism clinical risk factors, while the secondary outcome measures include intestinal microbiome and metabolome analysis. The study does not involve any intervention and aims to explore the potential correlation between gut microbiome, metabolome, and autism severity and clinical outcomes in Egyptian children with autism spectrum disorder.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of an internet-based self-help money management program for adults with severe mental illness. The study aims to assess if the 4-week online program can improve financial self-efficacy, financial behavior, financial attitude, and financial well-being compared to a waitlist control group. 

The primary outcomes measure changes in financial self-efficacy, financial behavior, financial attitude, and financial well-being from baseline to post-intervention and follow-up. Secondary outcomes include changes in psychological well-being, anxiety, depression, quality of life, as well as treatment adherence, satisfaction, and acceptability of the online program.

Participants with severe mental illness will be randomly assigned to either receive the 4-week online money management program immediately or to a waitlist control group. The program covers key money management concepts and skills based on the Model of Human Occupation theory. Assessments occur at baseline, post-intervention, and 4-week follow-up. The study utilizes self-report scales and a post-intervention interview.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Startle Adjuvant Rehabilitation Therapy (START) in enhancing arm function in individuals post-stroke. START involves applying a startling acoustic stimulus alongside traditional therapy to activate the brainstem and potentially enhance skill re-learning.

The study has two main aims:

1. Evaluate the capacity of START to enhance training outcomes in individuals with stroke during tasks of functional significance, such as a functional reaching task. This will be assessed through a randomized, single-blind, parallel, controlled trial comparing START with a control group (training without START).

2. Evaluate the generalizability of START training to untrained tasks, such as sorting and dressing tasks, to assess skill transfer.

The primary outcomes include changes in electromyography (EMG) onset and amplitude, movement onset and linearity, and functional reaching task scores during training and from baseline to post-training. Secondary outcomes include retention of functional reaching task scores, sorting task scores, and dressing task scores at one-month post-training.

The study aims to demonstrate that START can enhance functional tasks during therapy and that the training benefits can transfer to untrained tasks, potentially revolutionizing treatment for stroke survivors

This is a prospective, single-arm, open-label study evaluating the effects of endoscopic lung volume reduction (ELVR) using endobronchial valves on diaphragm function and conformation in patients with hyperinflated chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) without collateral ventilation. The primary outcomes are changes in transdiaphragmatic pressure, measured by magnetic phrenic stimulation at functional residual capacity (FRC), and diaphragm conformation, assessed by 3D modeling of diaphragm fibers length, length of the zone of apposition, and radius of curvature of the diaphragmatic domes, before and 3 months after unilateral ELVR. The study includes COPD patients aged 18 years or older who are eligible for valve insertion and have a total lung volume reduction (TLVR) of at least 50%.

This is a two-year randomized clinical trial evaluating the clinical performance of three bulk-fill resin composites (Fill-Up, QuiXfil, and Tetric N-Ceram Bulk Fill) in Class II restorations. The study included participants aged 21-50 years who required at least three Class II restorations due to primary carious lesions. Each participant received one restoration with each of the three composite materials. The primary outcome measures were the esthetic, functional, and biological properties of the restorations, evaluated using FDI criteria over the two-year follow-up period. The study aimed to assess the clinical performance and compare the three bulk-fill resin composites in terms of their esthetic, functional, and biological properties in Class II restorations.

This is a randomized phase II clinical trial comparing the efficacy and safety of retreatment with 177Lu-DOTATATE peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) versus everolimus in patients with metastatic or unresectable, well-differentiated midgut neuroendocrine tumors (NETs) who have progressed after previous PRRT treatment.

The primary objective is to evaluate the effect of 177Lu-DOTATATE versus everolimus on progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary objectives include evaluating toxicity, safety, overall response rate, overall survival, post-progression survival, time to second disease progression, and quality of life.

Patients are randomized to receive either:
- Arm 1: 177Lu-DOTATATE intravenously every 8 weeks for two cycles 
- Arm 2: Everolimus orally daily

Patients in Arm 2 whose cancer worsens can cross over to receive 177Lu-DOTATATE in Arm 1. Computed tomography scans and blood samples are collected during the study. The study aims to determine the

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of the Mulligan technique versus McKenzie extension exercises with manual traction in patients with chronic unilateral radicular low back pain. The study aims to evaluate the outcomes of these two interventions in terms of pain reduction, disability, and range of motion.

The study will recruit participants aged 28-50 years, of both genders, clinically diagnosed with lumbar radiculopathy. Patients with a history of spinal surgery, recent corticosteroid use, osteoporosis, fractures, lumbar instability, trauma, inflammatory disorders, or acute disc bulge will be excluded.

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two groups: Group A will receive Mulligan techniques with manual traction, and Group B will receive McKenzie extension exercises with manual traction. The interventions will be administered for four weeks, with two sessions per week.

The primary outcome measures are the Numeric Pain Rating Scale (NPRS), Oswestry Disability Index (ODI), and lumbar range of motion, which will be assessed at baseline and after the 4-week intervention period.

The study aims to determine the effectiveness of these two manual

This is a Phase 2, multicenter, long-term, open-label extension trial evaluating the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of weekly subcutaneous doses of TransCon CNP in children and adolescents aged 3-15 years with achondroplasia. The primary objectives are to assess the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events and changes in height Z-scores over an average of 10 years. Secondary objectives include measuring annualized growth velocity. Participants will receive 100 mcg of TransCon CNP, a lyophilized powder reconstituted with sterile water for injection, administered subcutaneously once weekly. Key eligibility criteria include having completed a prior clinical trial with TransCon CNP, willingness to administer weekly injections, and no known hypersensitivity to the investigational product or related products.

This is a prospective observational study exploring the impact of illness perceptions, coping strategies, self-efficacy, depression, and anxiety on the quality of life in patients with paroxysmal atrial fibrillation. The study aims to assess the mediating effects of these factors on the quality of life using correlation analysis and mediation analyses. The primary outcome measure is the 12-item Short Form Health Survey (SF-12), which evaluates the physical and mental components of health-related quality of life. The study includes patients aged 18-75 years with a diagnosis of paroxysmal atrial fibrillation, confirmed by ECG and cardiologist examination, and excludes those with severe complications, psychiatric conditions, cognitive impairment, or participation in other studies. The quality of life will be measured at the start of the study and up to 24 weeks.

This is a prospective registry study investigating the success rate of transanal local excision alone for organ preservation in early rectal cancer (cT1N0M0) with no adjuvant treatment. The primary outcome is the rate of patients who do not require total mesorectal excision (TME) after a follow-up of 36 months. Secondary outcomes include postoperative morbidity, radicality of resection, histological predictors of poor outcome, and quality of TME specimen if radical surgery is required. The study aims to enroll 145 patients aged 18 years or older with rectal cancer staged as cT1N0M0, with the inferior tumor edge within 2 cm of the anorectal ring. Patients will undergo transanal full-thickness local excision and be followed up for 36 months to assess the need for TME. The study will collect data on demographics, tumor characteristics, operative details, pathological findings, and follow-up outcomes. The study aims to determine if local excision alone is sufficient for organ preservation in at least 80% of patients with early rectal cancer in real-world clinical practice.

This is a prospective, multicenter study aimed at evaluating the outcomes of surgical repair for type A aortic dissection (TAAD). The study aims to investigate the impact of center volume on mortality, as well as identify predictors of outcomes, including clinical and perioperative variables. The study will enroll patients aged 18 years or older who require surgical repair for acute TAAD within 7 days of symptom onset.

The study has four intervention arms:

1. Conservative root-sparing aortic valve resuspension with or without hemiarch repair
2. Extensive ascending aorta replacement (AAR) with aortic root replacement (ARR)
3. Extensive AAR with total arch replacement (TARP)
4. Extensive root and ascending aorta replacement with TARP

The primary outcomes include operative mortality, rates of mesenteric ischemia, permanent neurologic deficit, major adverse events (including myocardial infarction, stroke, need for dialysis, or tracheostomy), perioperative myocardial infarction, and acute heart failure. Secondary outcomes include transient neurologic deficit, spinal cord injury

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of guided visualization through immersive virtual reality (VR) and traditional methods on academic stress, perceived stress, physiological stress markers, and exam performance in university students.

The study involves three groups: 
1) Experimental group 1 (EG1) will undergo a 4-week program with 30-minute guided visualization sessions twice a week using VR glasses and a 360° video simulating an exam experience from a first-person perspective. 
2) Experimental group 2 (EG2) will undergo a 4-week program with 30-minute traditional guided visualization sessions twice a week, listening to the audio used in the VR simulation. 
3) The control group (CG) will not receive any intervention.

The primary outcomes are changes in academic stress (measured by the SISCO Inventory version-21) and perceived stress in the last month (measured by the Perceived Stress Scale) within and between groups. Secondary outcomes include perceived stress level, blood pressure, heart rate, salivary cortisol level immediately before exams, and exam performance pondered by the average qualification of the degree.

The

This is a randomized, parallel-group, single-blind clinical trial comparing remimazolam and propofol as induction agents for general anesthesia in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy. The primary outcome measure is the rate of hypotension events during anesthesia induction. Secondary outcomes include induction time and total vasopressor (ephedrine) dose required. The study aims to enroll 88 adult patients (44 per group) aged 20 years or older who are scheduled for laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy under general anesthesia. Patients with a history of severe adverse effects or hypersensitivity to benzodiazepines, acute alcoholic intoxication, coma or shock due to non-cardiac causes, or acute narrow-angle glaucoma will be excluded. The experimental group will receive remimazolam besylate for anesthesia induction, while the control group will receive propofol. The study will employ a modified intention-to-treat analysis approach.

This is a Phase II clinical trial investigating the use of darolutamide, leuprolide acetate, and exemestane in treating recurrent adult-type ovarian granulosa cell tumors. The primary objective is to determine the objective response rate of this drug combination. Secondary objectives include assessing duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, and toxicities. Patients receive oral exemestane and darolutamide, along with intramuscular leuprolide acetate, in 28-day cycles until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity. Radiological assessments, blood tests, and tissue collection are performed throughout the study. The trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this androgen receptor inhibition therapy in recurrent ovarian granulosa cell tumors.

This is a Phase 2 clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of combining the immunotherapy drug nivolumab with chemotherapy (gemcitabine and cisplatin) and radiation therapy for the treatment of newly diagnosed nasopharyngeal carcinoma (NPC) in children, adolescents, and young adults up to 21 years of age.

The primary objective is to assess the safety of this combination by determining the rate of grade 3 or higher immune-related adverse events (irAEs) during the induction chemoimmunotherapy phase.

Secondary objectives include estimating the 2-year event-free survival rate, evaluating the objective response rate after induction chemoimmunotherapy, and assessing the feasibility of completing the induction regimen without significant delays.

The study involves three phases: induction chemoimmunotherapy with nivolumab, gemcitabine, and cisplatin; consolidation chemoradioimmunotherapy with nivolumab, cisplatin, and radiation therapy; and maintenance nivolumab therapy. Patients undergo various imaging tests, biospecimen collection, and quality of life assessments throughout the trial

This is an observational cohort study using MRI to measure gastrointestinal (GI) function, lung structure and function, and liver endpoints in children with cystic fibrosis (CF) aged 6 to 11 years. The study aims to identify whether these measures are changed before and after starting the triple combination therapy elexacaftor/tezacaftor/ivacaftor (ETI).

The study involves two phases: a pilot phase with 3 children with CF and 3 healthy controls, and a main phase with 12 additional children with CF. Participants will undergo MRI scans at baseline (fasted), 240 minutes post-meal, and 300 minutes post-meal to assess GI function, liver volume and elastography, and lung ventilation.

The primary outcome measure is the change in small bowel water content (Delta Small Bowel Water) between 240 and 300 minutes post-meal, adjusted for body surface area. Secondary outcomes include small bowel water content, liver volume, liver elastography, and lung ventilation.

Children with CF must have at least one copy of the Phe508del mutation

This is a prospective, randomized, double-blind, bi-center study comparing the efficacy and safety of methylprednisolone versus dexamethasone as an adjuvant to bupivacaine in caudal block for postoperative analgesia in children aged 1-6 years undergoing hypospadias surgical repair. The primary outcome is the duration of analgesia, measured as the time to first need for rescue analgesia up to 24 hours after the procedure. Secondary outcomes include postoperative pain severity assessed using the FLACC scale at various time points up to 24 hours, and the incidence of side effects such as nausea, vomiting, respiratory depression, and hyperglycemia. Patients will be randomized to receive either 0.5 ml/kg of bupivacaine 0.25% with dexamethasone 0.1 mg/kg or methylprednisolone 0.5 mg/kg via caudal block. The study aims to evaluate if methylprednisolone provides superior postoperative analgesia compared to dexamethasone when added to

This is a prospective randomized pilot study evaluating the addition of hemodiafiltration (HDF) to ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) for the regeneration of marginal donor lungs. The study aims to assess the impact of HDF on the suitability of marginal donor lungs for transplantation after 6 hours of EVLP, and the incidence of primary graft dysfunction (PGD) grade 3 at 72 hours post-transplantation. It involves two arms: the experimental group receiving EVLP with HDF, and the control group receiving EVLP alone. Secondary outcomes include survival, length of mechanical ventilation, ICU and hospital stay, and lung function parameters up to 24 months post-transplantation. The study targets marginal donor lungs meeting specific criteria and excludes certain conditions like bilateral consolidations, trauma, or drowning. Eligible recipients must not be on mechanical ventilation or ECMO prior to transplantation.

This study aimed to compare the effectiveness of white noise and multisensory stimulation in retinopathy examination on premature infants. It employed a randomized controlled experimental design with three groups: control group, white noise group, and multisensory stimulation group. The white noise group received auditory stimulation through white noise, while the multisensory stimulation group received additional visual and tactile stimuli during the examination. The primary outcome measure was neonatal pain, assessed using the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) scale. The study included premature newborns with a gestational age of ≤32 weeks or birth weight <1500g, undergoing their first retinopathy examination. The findings aimed to contribute to the development of effective and well-tolerated retinopathy examination protocols for premature infants, optimizing the examination process, improving success rates, and minimizing discomfort or distress experienced by infants.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate a modified calculation formula for grading meibomian gland dysfunction. The study involves participants aged 18 to 80 years, excluding contact lens wearers, individuals with a history of eye surgeries, systemic health conditions affecting ocular health, and those unable to cooperate with examinations. The trial compares the previous calculation formula with the modified calculation formula. The primary outcome measures include assessing the area of the meibomian glands and the whole eyelids, as well as measuring the white-to-white distance of the cornea at baseline. The study is designed to determine the effectiveness of the modified calculation formula in grading meibomian gland dysfunction.

This is a randomized, single-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the prevention of oral mucositis in patients undergoing radiotherapy for head and neck cancer. The trial compares the efficacy of a zinc gluconate spray (administered three times daily) with a sodium bicarbonate solution (administered five times daily) in preventing oral mucositis. The primary outcome measure is the presence or absence of oral mucositis one week after the end of radiotherapy. Secondary outcomes include the time of onset of oral mucositis and the severity of oral mucositis. The study involves two arms: an experimental arm receiving the zinc gluconate spray and an active comparator arm receiving the sodium bicarbonate solution. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of head and neck cancer undergoing radiotherapy for curative purposes or as an adjuvant to surgical resection.

This is a cross-sectional clinical study aimed at determining the predictive ability of a panel of salivary biomarkers in subjects with different periodontal health statuses. The study includes adults aged 18 years or older, categorized into groups based on their periodontal condition (healthy, gingivitis, treated periodontitis, periodontitis stages I-II, and periodontitis stages III-IV) according to the 2018 classification of periodontal diseases. The intervention involves collecting saliva samples to measure a combination of biomarkers, including C-reactive protein (CRP), triggering receptor expressed on myeloid cells-1 (TREM-1), interleukin (IL)-1beta, metalloproteinase (MMP)-8, IL-10, IL-6, monocyte chemoattractant protein-1 (MCP-1), Macrophage Inflammatory Protein-1 Alpha (MIP-1), interferon-gamma (IFN-gamma), osteoprotegerin (OPG), Receptor activator of nuclear factor kappa B ligand (RANKL), and Tumor Necr

This is a randomized crossover clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of a dual-hormone artificial pancreas system (delivering insulin and glucagon) compared to a single-hormone system (delivering insulin with rescue carbohydrate recommendations) in adults with type 1 diabetes. The primary objectives are to assess the time spent below the target glucose range (70-180 mg/dL) and the occurrence of hypoglycemic events during a 12-hour inpatient study involving an unannounced exercise session and a meal challenge. 

The study will recruit 15 adults aged 18-65 years with type 1 diabetes, with an initial feasibility test of the dual-hormone system in 5 participants, followed by a randomized crossover trial in 10 participants. Each participant will undergo two 12-hour inpatient study sessions, one with the dual-hormone system and one with the single-hormone system, in a randomized order. 

The primary outcomes are the percentage of time spent below 70 mg/dL and the number of level 1 (<70 mg/dL) and level 2 (<54 mg/dL) hypogl

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effect of white noise, heart sound, and music on reducing neonatal pain during heel lance procedures. It was a randomized controlled experimental study involving 84 infants with gestational ages between 28-42 weeks. The infants were randomly assigned to three groups: white noise, heart sound, or music (the music the mother listened to most frequently during pregnancy). Each group received the respective auditory intervention for 10 minutes before, during, and 20 minutes after the heel lance procedure. The primary outcome measure was the Neonatal Infant Acute Pain Assessment Scale (NIAPAS) score, which assessed the pain intensity of the infants before, during, and after the procedure. The secondary outcome measure was the duration of crying time. The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of these auditory interventions in reducing neonatal pain during a painful medical procedure.

This clinical trial aims to compare two methods of training and supervising facilitators for the Caregiver Skills Training (CST) program. The study involves two groups of facilitators: one group from rural settings trained and supervised remotely by master trainers, and another group from an agency near Pittsburgh trained and supervised in-person.

Both groups will receive 15 hours of training over 2-3 months, focusing on introducing the CST model, ensuring understanding of the curriculum, and gaining proficiency in administration. During the training phase, facilitators will practice administering activities and receive feedback. After training, facilitators will initiate CST groups and receive weekly 1-hour supervision, either in-person or remotely, for the duration of the 9 group sessions and 3 home visits per family.

The study will measure changes in caregiver skills, knowledge, confidence, parenting stress, child's adaptive behavior, and social communication abilities from baseline to week 12. The primary outcome is the change in caregiver skills and knowledge measured by the Caregivers Skills and Knowledge Measure. Secondary outcomes include changes in parenting stress (Parenting Stress Index), child's adaptive behavior (Vin

This is a randomized, triple-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of transcranial electrical stimulation (TES) combined with a strengthening exercise program for individuals with subacromial pain syndrome. The study aims to evaluate the effects of this intervention on pain, disability, quality of life, muscle strength, range of motion, proprioception, posture, and shoulder kinematics.

The study will recruit participants aged 18-65 years with unilateral shoulder pain lasting at least 3 months and meeting specific inclusion criteria. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group (EG) or the control group (CG). The EG will receive a strengthening exercise program for the rotator cuff and scapulothoracic muscles combined with real transcranial electrical stimulation (a-TES), while the CG will receive the same exercise program but with sham a-TES.

The primary outcomes include changes in the Shoulder Pain and Disability Index (SPADI), Western Ontario Rotator Cuff (WORC) scale, visual analog scale for pain intensity, and pressure pain threshold. Secondary outcomes include changes in muscle strength, range of

This study aimed to retrospectively evaluate the association between hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) and changes in verbal scores in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). Children aged 2 to 17 years diagnosed with ASD, who received applied behavioral analysis at Oxford Recovery Center and underwent verbal testing every six months, were included. The study had two groups: the HBO Treatment Group received HBOT (40 sessions of 100% medical-grade oxygen for 60 minutes at 2.0 ATA) along with applied behavioral therapy, while the Control Group received only applied behavioral therapy. The primary outcome measures were changes in verbal scores from baseline at 6 months, assessed using the Verbal Behavior Milestones Assessment and Placement Program (VBMAPP) and the Assessment of Basic Language and Learning Skills (ABLLS). The secondary outcome measure was the number of participants with HBOT-related adverse events. The study aimed to determine if HBOT had any impact on improving verbal scores in children with ASD compared to those who did not receive HBOT.

This is a comparative randomized double-blinded study investigating the analgesic efficacy of ultrasound-guided adductor canal block versus 4-in-1 block in patients undergoing knee surgeries. The study aims to compare postoperative pain scores (resting and dynamic) at different time points (6, 12, 18, and 24 hours) between the two groups as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcomes include changes in blood pressure, heart rate, and postoperative opioid requirements.

The study involves two parallel arms: one group will receive an adductor canal block with 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine and 4 mg dexamethasone, while the other group will receive a 4-in-1 block with the same drug combination. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, interventional model with single masking.

Eligible participants are adults aged 20-60 years, of both sexes, with ASA grade 1 or 2, scheduled for knee surgeries under neuraxial anesthesia. Exclusion criteria include patient refusal, allergy to study drugs,

This is a prospective randomized controlled trial investigating whether immediate lymphatic reconstruction (ILR) with lymphatico-venous anastomosis can reduce the occurrence of arm lymphedema in breast cancer patients after axillary lymph node dissection. The study involves female breast cancer patients aged 20-75 years who are scheduled to undergo axillary lymph node dissection or sentinel lymph node biopsy with suspected axillary metastasis. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving ILR along with axillary lymph node dissection or the control group receiving only axillary lymph node dissection. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of arm lymphedema over two years. Secondary outcomes include drainage amount, seroma or lymphocele occurrence, patient-reported outcome measures, and subclinical lymphedema. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of ILR in preventing arm lymphedema, a common complication after axillary lymph node dissection in breast cancer patients.

This is a descriptive study investigating the cosmetic and functional outcomes of patients who received releasing incisions for the management of acute upper limb burns. The study includes adult patients with acute hand burns (less than 3 days old) that required skin grafting, including thermal, chemical, or electrical burns. The primary outcome measures are functional recovery assessed by the QuickDASH score at 3 and 6 months, visual analog scale (VAS) for pain at 3 and 6 months, scar quality assessment by the surgeon, healing time (discontinuation of dressings), and the need for additional surgical procedures. The study aims to evaluate the functional and aesthetic sequelae of releasing incisions used in the management of acute hand burns.

This is a randomized, delayed intervention trial testing a 6-week flexible, multimodal whole-food plant-based dietary (WFPBD) educational program for providers at Stanford. The study aims to assess the impact of the educational intervention on participants' diet quality (measured by Diet ID score), mindset about WFPBD, and motivation/confidence to adopt and prescribe a WFPBD. The intervention includes interactive didactic sessions, cooking classes, and weekly emails with resources and activities. Participants will be randomly assigned to either receive the intervention immediately or after a delay. The primary outcomes are changes in Diet ID score, mindset about WFPBD, and stage of change (motivation/confidence) from baseline to week 6. The study is open to all clinical personnel at Stanford aged 18 years or older.

This is a multicenter study aimed at translating, culturally adapting, and validating the Patient Reported Outcome (PRO) Survivorship Concerns questionnaire for identifying rehabilitation needs in early-stage breast cancer patients. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. The study involves translating and culturally adapting the 17-item PRO Survivorship Concerns questionnaire, which evaluates concerns related to survivorship, screening, symptom management, family and genetic issues, and fear of recurrence on a 0-3 scale.

2. During the transcultural adaptability phase, 80 representative patients will be recruited.

3. During the validation phase, previous patients will be included, and at least 280 additional patients will be recruited.

4. The primary outcome measure is the translation and validation of the PRO Survivorship Concerns questionnaire.

5. The questionnaire will be administered twice, 15 days apart, to assess test-retest reliability using the Intraclass Correlation Coefficient (ICC) model 3.1 for each item.

6. Inclusion criteria: Breast cancer patients in the early stage.
Exclusion criteria

This is a postpartum adaptation study of the Connecting and Reflecting Experience (CARE) parenting program. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a 12-session mentalizing-focused parenting group therapy for postpartum parents experiencing moderate to high levels of depression, anxiety, and/or parenting stress. The primary outcomes measured include changes in postpartum anxiety, depression, parenting stress, parental reflective functioning, parent-infant bonding, and treatment acceptability and feasibility. Secondary outcomes include changes in infant temperament. The study involves a single group receiving the CARE program intervention, with assessments conducted at baseline and post-treatment (approximately 15 weeks after baseline). Eligible participants are birthing parents aged 18-70 years, with infants aged 3-12 months, receiving postpartum services at Montefiore Medical Center, and experiencing postpartum depression and/or anxiety symptoms.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of electroencephalography-based neurofeedback (EEG-NFB) training on cognitive function in healthy young men. A total of 50 participants aged 20-25 years will be randomly assigned to either the training group (TR) or the control group (CO). The TR group will undergo 3 weeks of EEG-NFB training involving 9 sessions, each lasting 30 minutes, aimed at decreasing the theta-beta ratio (TBR) at the C3 electrode site. The CO group will not receive any training. Cognitive function will be assessed using the Trail Making Test (TMT-A and TMT-B) and the Stroop Test (ST-I and ST-II) before and after the training period. The primary outcomes are the performance times on these tests, with shorter times indicating better cognitive processing speed, executive function, selective attention, and inhibition. The study aims to determine if EEG-NFB training can improve cognitive function in healthy young men.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, single-blinded clinical trial comparing radial versus femoral access for endovascular thrombectomy in patients with acute basilar artery occlusion within 24 hours of symptom onset. The primary outcome is favorable neurological function, defined as a modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score ≤ 3 at 90 days post-operation. The secondary outcome is the procedure time of the endovascular thrombectomy. Eligible patients aged 18 years or older with acute ischemic stroke due to basilar artery occlusion, confirmed by imaging, and an NIHSS score ≥ 10 will be randomly assigned to receive endovascular recanalization via either the radial or femoral approach. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the radial versus femoral access routes for thrombectomy in this patient population.

The BUNDLE study is a prospective mixed-methods study aimed at developing and evaluating an integrated prenatal care model that incorporates community doulas into the care team for Black/African American pregnant individuals. The study has three main aims:

1. Develop an integrated prenatal care model involving medical providers and community doulas through focus groups with pregnant/postpartum individuals and healthcare providers, and input from a community advisory panel.

2. Compare the effectiveness of the integrated model to standard prenatal care in improving healthcare engagement, trust, and reducing adverse maternal outcomes through a randomized controlled trial. The primary outcome is perinatal healthcare engagement, and secondary outcomes include trust in provider, perceived discrimination, and severe maternal morbidity.

3. Disseminate findings to scholarly and community forums and pursue opportunities for systems- and policy-level changes to sustain the integrated model.

The study will randomize 412 Black/African American pregnant individuals to either the BUNDLE intervention (integrated care with doulas) or usual prenatal care at Froedtert and the Medical College of Wisconsin. The intervention components include doula attendance at prenatal visits, communication between doulas and providers, education for obstetric teams, and enhanced

This is a Phase 1, open-label, non-randomized, dose-escalation study to evaluate the safety and determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of IBRX-042, an investigational vaccine, in subjects with human papillomavirus (HPV)-associated tumors.

Key aspects:

- Up to 18 subjects with histologically confirmed HPV-associated cancer will receive IBRX-042 by injection once every 3 weeks for a total of 3 injections.

- The study will utilize a 3+3 dose escalation design with 3 dosing cohorts: 1e11 virus particles (VP)/dose, 5e11 VP/dose, and a potential de-escalation cohort of 5e10 VP/dose.

- The primary outcome is to determine the MTD of IBRX-042 by assessing the rate of dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs).

- Secondary outcomes include evaluating the safety profile, reactogenicity, and examining HPV-specific humoral and cellular immune responses to IBRX-042.

- Subjects will be followed

This was a 3-arm randomized controlled trial that compared the effects of connective tissue massage (CTM), classical massage (CM), and a control treatment on pain, functional status, and quality of life in patients with chronic non-specific low back pain. The study included 30 participants aged 18-65 years, randomly assigned to the CTM group (n=10), CM group (n=10), or control group (n=10). The CTM group received connective tissue massage, the CM group received classical massage, and the control group received a standardized physiotherapy program including heat therapy, transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS), and therapeutic ultrasound. The interventions were administered for 4 weeks, with 3 sessions per week lasting 15-20 minutes each. Outcome measures, including the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for pain, Modified Schober Test (MST) and Sit and Reach Test (SRT) for lumbar mobility, Back Pain Functional Scale (BPFS) and Roland Morris Disability Questionnaire (RMDQ) for functional status, and Short Form-36 Questionnaire (SF-36

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial comparing the outcomes of cataract surgery with OMNI canaloplasty alone versus cataract surgery with OMNI canaloplasty and Hydrus microstent implantation in patients with mild to moderate open-angle glaucoma. The primary objective is to determine the difference in intraocular pressure (IOP) lowering effect between the two interventions at 12 months after washout of IOP-lowering medications. Approximately 80 participants aged 18 years and older with visually significant cataracts and open-angle glaucoma will be enrolled. Each participant will have one eye randomized to receive OMNI canaloplasty alone and the other eye will receive OMNI canaloplasty with Hydrus microstent implantation, both in combination with cataract surgery. The primary outcome measure is the change in unmedicated IOP from baseline at 12 months. Secondary outcomes include the reduction in the number of IOP-lowering medications needed and the percentage of patients with greater than 20% IOP reduction from baseline at 12 months.

This is a multicenter, prospective, open-label, randomized, comparative, parallel-arm study evaluating the efficacy and safety of Dorzotimol eye drops (20 mg/mL dorzolamide + 5 mg/mL timolol) versus Cosopt® eye drops (20 mg/mL dorzolamide + 5 mg/mL timolol) in patients with primary open-angle glaucoma. The study enrolled 110 patients aged 18-75 years with elevated intraocular pressure (IOP) due to primary open-angle glaucoma. Patients were randomized to receive either Dorzotimol or Cosopt eye drops twice daily for 12 weeks. The primary outcome was mean change in IOP from baseline. Secondary outcomes included IOP reduction rates to ≤18 mmHg, >20%, and >30%. Safety was assessed by monitoring adverse events, vital signs, laboratory tests, and ophthalmic examinations. The study found no statistically significant differences between Dorzotimol and Cosopt in reducing IOP or in safety parameters, leading to the conclusion that

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group pilot study aimed at evaluating the effectiveness of text message interventions in improving adherence to repeat colonoscopy screening among eligible veterans at a VA hospital. The study has two arms: an experimental arm receiving a series of instructional and motivational text messages before and on the day of the colonoscopy procedure, and a control arm receiving no intervention. The primary outcome measure is participant satisfaction with the text message intervention, assessed using the National Annie Colonoscopy Survey Score. Secondary outcomes include the percentage of participants attending the scheduled colonoscopy appointment and the percentage with adequate bowel preparation. The study targets veterans aged 45-85 years who are due for repeat screening or surveillance colonoscopy, excluding those with personal or family history of certain colorectal conditions. The study aims to evaluate the potential of text messaging as a tool to improve adherence to recommended colorectal cancer screening guidelines.

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial comparing hysteroscopy versus endouterine aspiration for the management of trophoblastic retention after spontaneous miscarriage. The primary objective is to compare the efficacy of the two procedures in achieving uterine vacuity at 6 weeks after surgery, as assessed by endovaginal ultrasound. Secondary objectives include comparing complication rates, need for second-line surgical management, rates of uterine synechiae, time to conception, and fertility rates at 2 years between the two arms.

Eligible participants are women aged 18-42 years with trophoblastic retention after early spontaneous miscarriage (<14 weeks), diagnosed by ultrasound, and desiring future pregnancy. A total of 220 participants will be randomized 1:1 to either operative hysteroscopy (Arm A) or endouterine aspiration (Arm B). The primary outcome is uterine vacuity at 6 weeks, assessed by blinded ultrasound. Secondary outcomes include complication rates, need for second surgery, synechiae rates, time

This is a study investigating human inference strategies across different timescales using an online crowdsourcing platform. The study involves adult participants from the United States who have a high approval rating on the platform and pass a pre-test. Participants will be shown pairs of jars filled with different ratios of red and blue balls and asked to perform various inference tasks. There are three blocks of trials: short-term inference (identify the current jar in use), long-term inference (predict the subsequent jar), and multi-timescale inference (identify the current jar and predict the subsequent jar). Participants can draw balls from the jars as many times as they wish during the short-term and multi-timescale blocks. The primary outcome measure is the binary behavioral decision responses provided by the participants on each trial. The study aims to understand how humans combine information across different timescales to make inferences.

This is a single-patient (N-of-1) trial investigating the efficacy and safety of the insomnia medication lemborexant in a patient with early-onset dementia and insomnia. The trial will last 8 weeks, with the patient receiving lemborexant 5mg, lemborexant 10mg, or placebo in an alternating sequence (ABBABAAB design). The primary outcomes measured daily include total sleep time, sleep onset latency, wake time after sleep onset, number of awakenings, and quality of sleep. Secondary outcomes include presence and severity of adverse drug reactions and dropout due to adverse events. Weekly follow-ups will monitor the patient's response and ensure tolerability. The goal is to evaluate if lemborexant can effectively and safely treat insomnia in patients with early-onset dementia, for whom traditional sleep medications may be inappropriate.

This is a prospective, double-blind, randomized, multicenter clinical trial evaluating the therapeutic effects of sinomenine versus glucocorticoid for early knee osteoarthritis. The study aims to compare the efficacy of sinomenine and glucocorticoid in treating knee osteoarthritis by measuring the change in total WOMAC score, tibial cartilage volume, Timed Up and Go test, and 20m walking time over 24 months after the first injection. Participants aged 40-70 years with Kellgren and Lawrence grade 2 or 3 knee osteoarthritis will be randomly assigned to receive either intra-articular injections of sinomenine or glucocorticoid every 4 months. The primary outcomes are the change in total WOMAC score and tibial cartilage volume, while the secondary outcomes are the change in Timed Up and Go test and 20m walking time. The study aims to determine if sinomenine is non-inferior to glucocorticoid in treating early knee osteoarthritis.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of respiratory exercises applied with virtual reality glasses on dyspnea, anxiety, and quality of life in patients with COPD (Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease). The study aims to determine if breathing exercises performed with virtual reality glasses can improve these outcomes compared to routine treatment and care.

The study will recruit 48 COPD patients (GOLD Stage II-III) and randomly assign them to either the experimental group or the control group. The experimental group will perform 20-minute breathing exercises with virtual reality glasses three times a week for eight weeks (24 sessions total), while the control group will receive routine treatment and care without any additional intervention.

The primary outcomes measured include oxygen saturation, respiratory rate, lung function parameters (FVC, FEV1, PEF, FEV1/FVC), COPD Assessment Test (CAT) score, and Modified Medical Research Council (mMRC) Dyspnea Scale score. Secondary outcomes include anxiety (measured by the Hospital Anxiety Scale), quality of life (measured by the St George's Respiratory Questionnaire), and patient satisfaction with the virtual reality experience.

This is a biobehavioral observational study aimed at understanding the multilevel determinants of cardiovascular health in Black women aged 18-49 years. The study involves a series of lab-based assessments to evaluate vascular health, including measurements of heart rate, blood pressure, blood vessel flow, arterial stiffness, and cerebral blood flow. Additionally, participants will undergo a 10-day free-living monitoring period using wearable devices and a smartphone app to track physical activity, behaviors, social/physical context, mood/stress, and experiences of racial discrimination/microaggression. The primary outcomes include macrovascular function, arterial stiffness, and blood flow measurements in large and cerebral blood vessels. The secondary outcome is daily physical activity level assessed through a wrist-worn accelerometer during the monitoring period. The study aims to identify biomarkers associated with elevated blood pressure and decreased blood flow by collecting venous blood and saliva samples.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel, phase 2 clinical trial to evaluate the efficacy and safety of RCN3028 in treating drug-induced moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms (hot flashes) in breast cancer subjects.

The trial aims to enroll female breast cancer patients aged 18-80 years who have completed chemotherapy and radiotherapy, are on a stable dose of tamoxifen or aromatase inhibitors, and experience at least 7 moderate to severe hot flashes per day or 50 per week.

Participants will be randomized to receive either RCN3028 0.8 mg capsules or placebo capsules orally for 12 weeks, with a 14-day placebo run-in period.

The primary outcomes are the mean change in frequency and severity of moderate to severe vasomotor symptoms from baseline to weeks 4 and 12.

Secondary outcomes include quality of life measures, responder rates, time to onset of efficacy, global assessments by subjects and physicians, treatment-emergent adverse events, and changes in various hot flash measures.

The study aims to determine if R

This is a retrospective cohort study investigating the association between different doses of tranexamic acid (TXA) and the incidence of post-operative delirium after cardiac surgery. The study will analyze routinely collected data from patients who underwent elective or urgent cardiac surgery at Royal Perth Hospital between May 2018 and August 2022. The primary outcome measure is the Richmond Agitation Sedation Score, assessed up to 48 hours after surgery. The secondary outcome measure is 30-day mortality. The study aims to determine if higher doses of TXA are associated with a lower incidence of post-operative delirium, as recent data suggests that TXA may lessen the inflammation of the nervous system caused by surgery and cardiopulmonary bypass. The study excludes patients undergoing specific types of operations, such as those involving deep hypothermic circulatory arrest or solid organ transplantation.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of myofascial decompression therapy and positional release therapy on pain, range of motion, and functional disability in patients with chronic non-specific neck pain.

The study involves two intervention groups:

1. Myofascial Decompression Therapy: Patients will receive moist heat followed by cupping massage along the spine from the cervical to thoracic region for approximately 10 minutes.

2. Positional Release Therapy: Patients will receive moist heat followed by a positional release technique targeting the upper trapezius muscle. The therapist will position the patient's head, shoulder, and arm in a specific position for 90 seconds, followed by passive return to a neutral position. This will be repeated for 5 minutes.

The primary outcomes measured are pain intensity using the Numerical Rating Scale (NPRS) and functional disability using the Neck Disability Index (NDI). Secondary outcomes include cervical range of motion in flexion, extension, side flexion, and rotation.

The study includes patients aged 25-50 years with chronic non-specific neck pain lasting at least 3 months and a pain score of

This is a randomized, parallel-controlled study comparing two different suturing methods for ileostomy in rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma. The study aims to evaluate the complication rate of the stoma as the primary outcome measure, and secondary outcomes include stoma DET (Discoloration, Erosion and Tissue overgrowth) score, stoma pain score, and quality of life scale score for patients with stoma.

Participants are randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving the Dumpling suture method for ileostomy, where the stoma is fixed with sutures in a skin fold method and the incision is progressively reduced, or the control group receiving the traditional suture method for ileostomy, where the stoma is fixed at the skin using traditional sutures.

The study includes adult patients aged 18-100 years scheduled for rectal anterior resection surgery with specimen extraction via stoma, with no serious systemic infection, immunosuppression, or other exclusion criteria. The primary outcome of stoma complication rate and secondary outcomes will be assessed 30 days after surgery.

This clinical trial aims to study the progression of cognitive impairment and associated activities of daily living (ADL) impairment in Parkinson's disease patients. The key aspects are:

- It is a follow-up study of participants from the previous "Amyloid-Beta in cerebrospinal fluid as a risk factor for cognitive dysfunction in Parkinson's Disease (ABC-PD)" study.

- Participants will undergo a comprehensive neuropsychological assessment battery to evaluate global cognition, cognitive domains (executive function, attention, language, memory, visuospatial abilities), and instrumental ADLs.

- The primary outcome is the diagnosis of Parkinson's disease dementia (PDD) or mild cognitive impairment in Parkinson's disease (PD-MCI) based on cognitive impairment and functional impairment criteria.

- Secondary outcomes include changes in instrumental ADL function measured by the Pfeffer ADL scale, global cognitive performance, and cognitive domain-specific performance.

- Assessments will also cover motor symptoms, non-motor symptoms, caregiver reports, and optional biomarker collection.

- The study aims to characterize the progression of

This clinical trial aimed to determine the median effective dose of rocuronium for preventing myofibrillation caused by the injection of succinylcholine. The study included participants aged 18-80 years, divided into three age groups: 18-44, 45-59, and 60-80 years old. Participants received an intravenous injection of rocuronium before the administration of succinylcholine. The initial rocuronium dose was set at 0.04 mg/kg, and subsequent doses were adjusted based on the presence or absence of myofibrillation. The primary outcome measure was the appearance of myofibrillation, assessed within an average of 45 seconds after the rocuronium injection. The study followed a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment design with three experimental arms corresponding to the age groups.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, parallel-group study investigating the effects of dietary phospholipids on measures of human brain health, cognitive function, and psychological well-being. The study will recruit 220 healthy participants aged 25-49 years and randomly assign them to receive either a bioactive whey protein concentrate containing phospholipids (40g powder mixed with water) or a matched placebo (pea protein powder) for 12 weeks. Participants will attend the research center for cognitive assessments, mood questionnaires, and blood sampling at baseline, 6 weeks, and 12 weeks. The primary outcome is cognitive function, specifically memory performance, measured using tasks from the Computerised Mental Performance Assessment System (COMPASS). Secondary outcomes include mood states, perceived stress, physical symptoms, sleep disturbance, fatigue, task demand, and changes in blood plasma phospholipid profiles. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of dietary phospholipids on brain health, cognitive performance, and psychological well-being.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the presence of environmental pollutants, specifically volatile organic compounds and microplastics, in atherosclerotic plaques obtained from patients undergoing carotid endarterectomy. The study will enroll 300 consecutive asymptomatic patients with high-grade carotid stenosis. Plaque specimens will be analyzed using various techniques, including pyrolysis-gas chromatography-mass spectrometry, transmission electron microscopy, immunohistochemistry, ELISAs, and Western Blot, to assess the presence and amount of pollutants, as well as inflammatory and plaque stability markers. Patients will be categorized post-hoc as having polluted or non-polluted plaques based on the presence of detectable pollutants. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of a composite of myocardial infarction, stroke, and all-cause mortality in patients with polluted versus non-polluted plaques over 24 months, analyzed using Cox regression analysis adjusted for confounding factors. Additionally, the study will explore the relationship between the burden of pollutants and the composite outcome among patients with polluted plaques, categorized into

This is a study investigating the use of transarterial radioembolization (TARE) with Therasphere (Y90 glass microspheres) for the treatment of colorectal cancer liver metastases. The primary objective is to compare the mean effective tumor doses (in Gy) between patients who respond and those who do not respond to TARE, measured at 3 months after treatment. The secondary objective is to investigate the dose-response and dose-toxicity relationships at 6 months after TARE. Eligible participants are adults over 18 years old with histopathologically proven colorectal cancer and liver metastases, who have received TARE with lobar or segmental administration of Therasphere and have follow-up data for at least 6 months after treatment. Patients without recent imaging studies, poor image quality, or previous local treatment or surgery for the liver are excluded.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the clinical performance of chemically cured conventional glass ionomer restorations with and without light-emitting diode (LED) radiant heat enhancement. The study involves 18 healthy patients aged 21-45 years, each with two occluso-mesial cavities in second molar teeth. One tooth in each patient will be restored with conventional glass ionomer cement (Ketac Universal Aplicap) without enhancement (control group M1), while the other tooth will receive the same material but with LED radiant heat enhancement for 60 seconds (experimental group M2). The restorations will be clinically evaluated immediately after placement, at 6 months, and at 12 months using FDI criteria for assessing biological and functional properties of dental restorations. The primary outcomes are the clinical performance of biological and functional properties at 12 months.

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the FAPO-X clinical trial:

The FAPO-X trial was an interventional, randomized, parallel-group study conducted at the Heart Institute of the University of São Paulo. It aimed to develop and validate an assisted digital telemonitoring platform for patients with postoperative atrial fibrillation (POAF) after cardiovascular surgery. 

The study had two groups: a telemonitored group (TLM) and a control group (CTL). The TLM group used the Samsung Galaxy Watch5 smartwatch for remote monitoring of health data like blood pressure, heart rate, ECG, and oxygen saturation. This data was transmitted to the FAPO SI³ platform integrated with the hospital's electronic medical records. The control group received standard care without telemonitoring.

The study involved six phases: pre-operative evaluation, informed consent, intra-operative data collection, post-operative evaluation, 30-day telemonitoring period for the TLM group, and a final outpatient visit with quality of life assessment.

The primary outcomes measured were rehospitalization rate, scheduled consultations,

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial aimed at testing whether the adoption of two digital solutions, HSmartBPM and HyperHealth, by healthcare professionals and patients improves the management of patients with hypertension, compared to standard care. Patients diagnosed with essential hypertension will be randomly assigned to one of the two digital solutions or standard care. The primary outcome is changes in systolic and diastolic blood pressure measured at 2 and 6 months. The secondary outcome is user satisfaction with the digital solutions measured on a 0-100 visual analog scale at 2 and 6 months. The digital solutions consist of devices like blood pressure monitors and body composition scales, along with user-facing services and interfaces. Patients in the digital solution arms will receive training and use the solutions based on recommendations from their physicians during the trial period.

The Liver Care Trial is a randomized controlled study aimed at screening for liver disease in individuals attending treatment for alcohol use disorder. The trial involves two arms: the intervention arm, where participants receive an invitation for a liver stiffness measurement (transient elastography), blood sampling, and a leaflet on alcohol-related diseases; and the control arm, where participants receive an invitation for screening by blood sampling with Fib-4. The primary outcome measure is alcohol abstinence or light consumption (≤ 10 units/week) in the last 30 days, assessed 6 months after randomization. Secondary outcome measures include heavy drinking days in the last 30 days, change in AUDIT-C score since randomization, and other alcohol-related measures. The study targets individuals aged 18-110 years, attending outpatient treatment for alcohol use disorder at specific treatment centers in Denmark.

This is a study investigating the value of trio exome sequencing (genetic testing of the affected individual and both biological parents) in identifying the genetic causes of specific non-syndromic language and learning disorders (SLLD). The study aims to enroll individuals aged 3-40 years with severe learning disorders requiring special education or intensive therapy, and their biological parents. The primary outcome measure is the identification of a genetic cause, defined as the presence of at least one pathogenic or likely pathogenic variant (ACMG class 4 or 5). The study involves collecting blood samples from the trio for exome sequencing, a consultation for results delivery at 4 months, and interviews with a subset of families to study the humanities and social sciences aspects. Individuals with intellectual disability, syndromic diagnoses, or previous genetic testing are excluded from the study.

The Five Days for Health (FDH) study is a small group-based lifestyle modification program aimed at weight loss for overweight or obese adults. The program involves groups of 7-10 participants and is conducted over five days outside of a medical facility. It includes education, practical workshops, and support on nutrition, physical activity, and psychological aspects related to weight loss. The program incorporates interactive lectures, healthy meal preparation, daily physical exercises, goal setting, and strategies for behavioral change. Participants receive follow-up support and monitoring of weight, body composition, and metabolic parameters (fasting glucose, insulin, lipid profile) at various time points up to one year. The primary outcome measure is weight loss at 12 months, with secondary outcomes including changes in body composition and metabolic parameters.
