The program is designed to promote a healthy lifestyle through dietary modifications, regular physical activity, psychological support, and small group intervention.

This is a Phase I clinical trial evaluating the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, immunogenicity, and antitumor activity of Bio-008, an investigational biological drug, in patients with advanced or metastatic solid tumors. The trial has two parts: a dose escalation study (Phase Ia) and a dose expansion study (Phase Ib). 

Key aspects:

- Patients with advanced solid tumors who have failed standard therapy or have no standard treatment options are eligible.
- In Phase Ia, patients will receive escalating doses of Bio-008 intravenously every 3 weeks to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase 2 dose (RP2D).
- In Phase Ib, patients with tumors expressing CLDN18.2 will receive the RP2D to further evaluate safety and efficacy.
- Primary outcomes include adverse events, dose-limiting toxicities, MTD, objective response rate, and RP2D.
- Secondary outcomes include pharmacokinetic parameters (AUC, Cmax, Tmax, T1/2), immunogenicity, disease control

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of different types of music listened to during retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) examination on pain and comfort levels of premature infants. The study has three arms:

1. Experimental group 1: Infants will listen to the sound of a rain stick during the ROP examination. 

2. Experimental group 2: Infants will listen to intrauterine sounds from "The Happiest Baby" by Dr. Harvey Karp during the ROP examination.

3. Control group: Infants will receive routine care without any music during the ROP examination.

The primary outcome is measured using the Premature Infant Pain Profile (PIPP) scale to assess pain levels. Secondary outcomes include oxygen saturation, heart rate, and comfort levels measured by the PBIC (Premature Infant Comfort Scale). Measurements will be taken before, during, and after the ROP examination by video recording.

The study aims to determine if listening to different types of music can reduce pain and increase comfort levels in premature infants undergoing the ROP examination compared to routine care without music.

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, parallel, placebo-controlled phase III clinical study to assess the safety and efficacy of sovateltide (PMZ-1620, IRL-1620), a highly selective endothelin B receptor agonist, in patients with acute cerebral ischemic stroke.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of sovateltide by measuring the proportion of patients with a good functional outcome, defined as a modified Rankin Scale (mRS) score of 0-2, at day 90 post-randomization as the primary outcome. Secondary outcomes include excellent functional outcome (mRS 0-1), improvement in National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale (NIHSS), mRS, and Barthel Index (BI) scores, overall clinical outcome, quality of life, incidence of recurrent stroke, mortality, intracranial hemorrhage, and adverse events.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18-80 years with radiologically confirmed acute ischemic stroke, presenting within 24 hours of symptom onset, with an NIHSS score of ≥8 and <20. Patients will be random

This is an ambispective cohort study investigating the prognosis and influencing factors of borderline personality disorder (BPD). The study involves both retrospective data collection from electronic medical records and prospective follow-up assessments. Patients diagnosed with BPD based on ICD-10 criteria are eligible for inclusion, excluding those with severe physical diseases, neurological disorders, or intellectual disabilities. The primary outcome measure is the remission rate of BPD, calculated as the proportion of patients who no longer meet the diagnostic criteria for at least 6 months during the 2-year follow-up period. Secondary outcome measures include social disability assessed by the Social Disability Screening Schedule (SDSS) and quality of life evaluated using the WHOQOL-BREF across physical, psychological, social, and environmental domains. Data analysis will employ Cox Proportional Hazard Model to examine factors influencing BPD remission and Generalized Estimating Equation Model to investigate factors associated with social function and quality of life.

This is a randomized, triple-masked, parallel-group study evaluating the management of dry eye disease with intense pulsed light (IPL) in combination with diquafosol tetrasodium (DQS) eye drops. The study has three arms: IPL+DQS, IPL alone, and DQS alone. Participants in the IPL+DQS group will receive two sessions of IPL two weeks apart along with DQS eye drops six times daily for four weeks. The primary outcomes are changes in non-invasive tear break-up time (NIBUT) and Ocular Surface Disease Index (OSDI) score from baseline to weeks 2 and 4. Secondary outcomes include conjunctival/corneal staining, meibomian gland function, tear film lipid layer, tear meniscus height, and conjunctival hyperemia. The study aims to assess the efficacy of combining IPL and DQS in managing dry eye disease.

This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two mental health interventions, Cognitive-Behavioral Therapy (CBT) and Mindfulness-Based Cognitive Therapy (MBCT), for improving patient-centered outcomes, quality of life, well-being, and functional impairment among autistic adults with co-occurring anxiety and/or depressive disorders. It is a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with two active comparator arms: CBT (Unified Protocol) and MBCT. The primary outcome measure is change in anxiety and depression symptoms assessed by the Patient Health Questionnaire Anxiety-Depression Scale (PHQ-ADS). Secondary outcomes include changes in mental health, psychiatric diagnosis, quality of life, well-being, self-acceptance, functional impairment, disability, potential negative effects of intervention, intervention services satisfaction, and intervention therapist and therapy satisfaction. The study aims to explore patient characteristics that may moderate the relationship between CBT or MBCT and patient outcomes, as well as compare the acceptability and feasibility of the two interventions using mixed methods.

This is a single-arm, open-label clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of methotrexate in treating immune-related arthritis or arthralgias (irAA) in patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitor (ICI) therapy for cancer. The study includes patients aged 18 or older with histologically confirmed cancer receiving anti-PD-1, anti-PD-L1, or anti-CTLA-4 monoclonal antibody ICI therapy who develop grade ≥2 irAA. Participants will receive methotrexate 20 mg orally once weekly for 12 weeks, along with folic acid 1 mg daily and a tapering dose of prednisone starting at 20 mg daily for 8 weeks. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients able to discontinue prednisone by 12 weeks without recurrence of grade ≥2 irAA. Secondary outcomes include total steroid usage, development of other immune-related adverse events, adverse events, re-initiation of ICI therapy, and progression-free survival. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of metho

This is a randomized, parallel-group, triple-blinded clinical trial comparing the effects of general anesthesia versus regional anesthesia on sleep quality in patients undergoing total hip arthroplasty. The primary outcome is subjective sleep quality measured by the Pittsburgh Insomnia Rating Scale (PIRS-20) preoperatively, the day before surgery, and one week postoperatively. Secondary outcomes include subjective anxiety levels measured by the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI) and subjective pain levels measured by the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) at the same time points. A total of 60 patients aged 18-85 years, with an ASA score of I-III, scheduled for elective total hip arthroplasty will be randomized to receive either general anesthesia or regional anesthesia (spinal/epidural). Postoperative analgesia will be provided via patient-controlled analgesia. Patients will be monitored for complications and morbidity for 3 months postoperatively. The study aims to evaluate whether regional anesthesia provides better sleep quality compared to general anesthesia by preserving circadian rhythms and

This is a Phase 2/3, multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study with an active treatment extension to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of oral atogepant for the prevention of migraine in Japanese adults with episodic migraine.

The study includes four arms: three experimental arms receiving different doses of atogepant (Dose A, Dose B, Dose C) once daily for 24 weeks, and a placebo arm receiving placebo for the first 12 weeks, followed by re-randomization to one of the atogepant dose arms for the remaining 12 weeks.

The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days up to 12 weeks. Secondary outcomes include changes in mean monthly headache days, acute medication use days, percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in monthly migraine days, and changes in migraine-specific quality of life and activity impairment scores.

The study aims to assess the efficacy and safety of atogepant, an oral medication, in preventing migraine in Japanese adults with episodic migraine, who have a history

This is a Phase 2, randomized, double-blind, controlled, single-site trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of efgartigimod, an anti-neonatal Fc receptor (FcRn) immunoglobulin G1 Fc fragment, in patients with Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS). The study aims to assess the potential of efgartigimod as a treatment for GBS compared to the standard-of-care intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg) therapy.

The study involves two parallel arms: the experimental arm receiving 20mg/kg of intravenous efgartigimod on days 1 and 5, and the active comparator arm receiving 0.4g/kg of IVIg daily for 5 days. Participants will undergo various assessments, including physical examinations, vital signs measurements, electrocardiograms, pulmonary function tests, blood and cerebrospinal fluid sampling, nerve conduction studies, and outcome assessments using the GBS Disability Scale (GBS-DS), Neuropsychological Impairment Scale (NIS

This is a Phase 2b, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel group, dose-ranging study to evaluate the virological response and safety of the oral antiviral drug PF-07817883 in non-hospitalized symptomatic adult participants with COVID-19. The study aims to understand the effect and safety of PF-07817883 in adults aged 18 to 64 years who have symptoms of COVID-19 but are not hospitalized.

The study has four arms: three experimental arms receiving different doses (low, medium, and high) of PF-07817883, and one placebo arm. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level at day 5. Secondary outcomes include changes in SARS-CoV-2 RNA level at other timepoints, incidence of treatment-related adverse events, serious adverse events, clinically significant abnormal laboratory values, adverse events leading to discontinuation, and clinically significant abnormal vital signs and ECGs.

The study has specific inclusion and exclusion criteria, including confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, onset of COVID-

This is a prospective cohort study evaluating the therapeutic effect of adding letrozole to the combined treatment of cesarean scar pregnancy (CSP) with methotrexate (MTX). The study involves two arms: 1) MTX monotherapy arm receiving a single dose of 100 mg MTX intravenously and 50 mg MTX intra-amniotically, along with potassium chloride if fetal heartbeat is present, followed by hysteroscopic evacuation of products of conception (POC), and 2) MTX + letrozole add-on arm receiving the same MTX treatment plus oral letrozole 5 mg daily for 10 days from day 0, followed by hysteroscopic evacuation of POC. The primary outcomes include blood loss during the procedure measured by decrease in hemoglobin and blood volume, and conversion rate from hysteroscopy to laparoscopy or laparotomy due to hemorrhage. Secondary outcomes assess the effect of treatment on bone marrow function (blood counts) and liver and kidney function (biochemical parameters). The study includes women aged 18-45 years with confirmed CSP and increasing β

This is a feasibility pilot study investigating the use of red blood cell concentrates collected from liver donors during organ procurement and transfusing them to the respective liver transplant recipients intraoperatively. The primary objective is to determine the number and percentage of liver transplant recipients who successfully receive donor red blood cell concentrates for transfusion support during the transplant surgery. Secondary objectives include assessing the need for additional blood products compared to a matched control group, and evaluating the rate of graft failure at 3 months post-transplant. The study involves a single arm with adult liver transplant recipients receiving red blood cell concentrates from their respective donors, provided there are no contraindications such as ABO incompatibility or CMV mismatch. The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and potential benefits of this approach in reducing the need for allogeneic blood transfusions during liver transplantation.

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sublingual versus subcutaneous allergen immunotherapy in patients with bronchial asthma. The study was conducted at Mansoura University Hospitals, Chest Medicine Department, and involved 100 asthmatic patients recruited from the allergy outpatient clinic.

Participants were randomly assigned to two groups: 50 patients received sublingual immunotherapy (SLIT), and 50 patients received subcutaneous immunotherapy (SCIT). All patients were symptomatic and on bronchodilators or inhaled corticosteroids. Serum IgE levels and sputum eosinophil counts were measured before and after 6, 12, and 18 months of treatment with immunotherapy vaccines.

The primary outcome measures were total IgE levels and sputum eosinophil counts at different time points (6, 12, and 18 months) after immunotherapy. The study aimed to compare the efficacy of SLIT and SCIT in reducing IgE levels and sputum eosinophil counts, which are indicators of allergic inflammation in asthma.

The study

This is a prospective, single-center, observational cohort study aimed at determining the minimum number of tissue samples needed to establish a reliable histopathological diagnosis for lesions visible only on recombined (contrast-enhanced) images during contrast-enhanced mammography (CEM), referred to as 'recombined-only lesions' (ROLs). The study involves non-pregnant women over 18 years old with a recently detected ROL on CEM. Participants will undergo contrast-enhanced stereotactic biopsy (CESB), where 18 tissue samples will be collected using a vacuum-assisted biopsy device and analyzed in chronological order. The primary outcome is to calculate the cumulative diagnostic yield per specimen to define the minimum number of biopsies or tissue volume required for a reliable diagnosis using CESB. Secondary outcomes include complication rates, histopathological results, and patient discomfort during the procedure. The study aims to establish the optimal tissue sampling approach for CESB in diagnosing ROLs detected on CEM.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effects of concentric quadriceps strengthening exercises and facilitatory kinesiotaping on gait parameters in individuals with knee osteoarthritis (OA). The study involves two intervention groups: Group A will undergo concentric muscle training exercises (leg press, knee flexion, knee extension, and quad drills) at 60% of one-repetition maximum (1RM) for 12 repetitions, twice a week for 6 weeks. Group B will receive facilitatory kinesiotaping applied to the quadriceps muscle with 20% tension, from the mid-quadriceps region down to the tibia tuberosity, twice a week for 6 weeks.

The primary outcome measure is the assessment of temporo-spatial gait parameters (gait velocity, cadence, step length, step width, and single support time) using a mobile app. Secondary outcome measures include the Numeric Pain Rating Score (NPRS) for knee OA pain, the Western Ontario and McMaster Universities Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) for functional status, and quadriceps strength measured by a hand-held dynamometer.

The study is a randomized

This study is a supplement to the Family Therapy Training and Implementation Platform (FTTIP) parent study. The supplement aims to collect qualitative data to understand the experiences of trainees and agency leaders with the FTTIP platform. 

Twenty therapists and 16 agency leaders from the parent study will participate in qualitative interviews. Therapists will be interviewed at two time points: 1) after completing the 20-hour FTTIP training to assess their perceptions and experiences of learning and practicing the competencies, and 2) after four months of implementing the evidence-based treatment (EBT) with families to understand their experiences with implementation, delivery of competencies, and real-world application. 

Agency leaders will also be interviewed at two time points: 1) before the start of training or implementation to understand their experiences in facilitating EBTs and identify barriers, and 2) after four months of treatment implementation to assess their experiences with the platform, consultation process, perceived cost-benefit, and agency readiness.

The study aims to gather in-depth qualitative data to complement the quantitative data from the parent study, providing a comprehensive understanding of the experiences of trainees and agency leaders with

This clinical study aimed to investigate the analgesic effect of a freshly manufactured 35kDa hyaluronan fragment (HA35) in treating pain caused by herpes zoster, shoulder, neck, back, and temporal conditions. HA35 was prepared by mixing hyaluronidase injection extracted from bovine testis and high-molecular-weight hyaluronan injection at room temperature for 20 minutes.

The study involved 26 patients with shoulder, neck, back, and temporal pain, and 10 patients with herpes zoster pain. Patients aged between 39 and 63 years were eligible for the study, excluding those with severe spinal pathology.

The intervention involved locally injecting 100 mg of HA35 at the pain point or where the nerve trunk innervated the pain point once a week. The primary outcome measure was the pain scores assessed using a 0-10 pain scale, evaluated before and 3 hours after treatment. Statistical analysis was performed to evaluate the pain intensity.

This was an open-label, single-arm, self-controlled study designed to investigate the treatment effect of HA35 on various types of pain

This is a prospective randomized clinical trial studying two different modalities for hysteroscopic septoplasty (surgical removal of a uterine septum) in women of reproductive age with a septate or subseptate uterus and a history of recurrent pregnancy loss, subfertility, or preterm birth. The study aims to compare the operative time, fluid deficit, complications, need for second intervention, pregnancy rate, and live birth rate between two groups:

Group A: Hysteroscopic septoplasty using scissors and saline as the distending medium.
Group B: Hysteroscopic septoplasty using a monopolar resectoscope, Collins knife, and glycine 1.5% as the distending medium.

The study plans to enroll 40 patients (20 in each group) and follow them for at least 6 months after the intervention. The primary outcomes are operative time, fluid deficit, operative and post-operative complications, and need for second intervention. Secondary outcomes include pregnancy rate and live birth rate. The study will be conducted at Mansoura University Hospital for at least 24 months.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a breathing control technique called cardiac coherence on reducing long COVID symptoms in patients at the Reunion University Hospital. The study involves two parallel groups: an experimental group receiving cardiac coherence respiratory training for 6 months in addition to usual care, and a control group receiving only usual care for long COVID. The primary outcome measure is the mean score on the Long COVID Symptom Tool scale at 6 months, with higher scores indicating worse outcomes. Secondary outcomes include overall symptom reduction over time, as well as specific symptoms like fatigue, dyspnea, anxiety, depression, cognitive disorders, and post-traumatic stress disorder, measured using various scales. The study also evaluates the impact of long COVID on daily life using the Long COVID Impact Tool scale. Eligible participants are adults over 18 years old living in Reunion with a diagnosis of long COVID, confirmed SARS-CoV-2 infection, and a negative antigen test at inclusion.

This is a single-center cohort study investigating the cardiovascular complications of ibrutinib therapy in patients receiving ibrutinib treatment for hematologic reasons. The study includes patients aged 18 and over who have provided informed consent, excluding those with a history of atrial fibrillation, previous ibrutinib treatment, or planned follow-up at another center.

The study involves two interventions: ophthalmological examination (OCT-retinal angiography) at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months, and a blood test at baseline to measure biomarkers predisposing to cardiovascular complications.

The primary outcome measure is the rate of patients developing atrial fibrillation (AF) within 12 months after initiating ibrutinib treatment. The study aims to compare the values of selected biomarkers between patients who develop AF and those who do not, to identify potential risk factors for cardiovascular complications associated with ibrutinib therapy.

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effect of bicarbonate profiling in dialysis fluid on phosphate removal and blood pH during hemodialysis. The study involved 20 chronic hemodialysis patients who were divided into two groups. Group 1 received dialysis with a constant bicarbonate concentration of 35 mmol/L in week 1, followed by a bicarbonate concentration of 35 mmol/L for the first two hours and 30 mmol/L for the remaining two hours in week 2, and vice versa in week 4. Group 2 followed the same protocol but with the order of bicarbonate profiling reversed. The primary outcome measure was the change in blood phosphorus concentration, and the secondary outcome measure was the maintenance of acid-base balance. The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bicarbonate profiling in improving phosphate removal and maintaining acid-base balance during hemodialysis.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group study evaluating the effectiveness of transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) combined with metacognitive therapy (MCT) for treating major depressive disorder. The study has three arms: 1) active tDCS alone, 2) sham tDCS and MCT, and 3) active tDCS combined with MCT. The primary outcome is change in the Hamilton Depression Rating Scale scores over 12 months of follow-up. Secondary outcomes include changes in TMS-EEG connectivity measures, self-reported depression/anxiety scales, neuropsychological tests, and rumination scales. The study aims to assess if combining tDCS and MCT has an additive or synergistic therapeutic effect compared to either intervention alone in treating depression.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the proton pump inhibitor (PPI) lansoprazole in patients with moderate gastrointestinal bleeding risk who have coronary artery disease and are undergoing percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) while on dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT). The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either lansoprazole 15 mg once daily or no intervention for 6 months. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of upper gastrointestinal clinical events, including bleeding with clear or unclear origin, potential bleeding, or perforation. The secondary outcome measure is the occurrence of cardiovascular clinical events, such as cardiovascular death, non-fatal myocardial infarction, coronary artery reopening, or ischemic stroke. The study aims to determine if prophylactic PPI use can reduce gastrointestinal bleeding risk while on DAPT without increasing cardiovascular events in patients with moderate bleeding risk undergoing PCI.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the influence of hot and cold cognition on prospective memory in HIV-positive patients. The study involves two groups: HIV-positive patients on antiretroviral therapy and healthy control subjects. Both groups will undergo neuropsychological testing, including the Memory for Intentions Screening Test (MIST) to assess prospective memory, the Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MOCA) to evaluate global cognitive performance, the Interpersonal Reactivity Index (IRI) to assess cognitive and affective empathy (hot cognition), and the Modified Five Point Test to assess figurative fluency (cold cognition). The primary outcome measure is prospective memory in HIV-positive patients and healthy subjects, while the secondary outcome measures include the influence of global cognitive performance, hot cognition, and cold cognition on prospective memory. The study aims to understand the impact of different cognitive domains on prospective memory in HIV-positive individuals.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effects of vertical sitting traction versus supine lying traction on pain, range of motion, and function in patients with chronic radicular low back pain (CRLBP). The study involves two parallel groups: Group A will receive continuous mechanical traction in a vertical sitting position with a belt around the chest for 30 minutes per day, 5 days a week for 12 weeks, while Group B will receive supine lying traction with a traction force equal to 50% of their body weight for 20 minutes per day, 5 days a week for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measures are the Oswestry Disability Index and the Numeric Pain Rating Scale, which will be assessed at the 12-week follow-up. The study includes patients aged 20-50 years with CRLBP for at least 3 months, excluding those with spinal cord involvement, pregnancy, spinal trauma, or systemic diseases. The trial aims to determine the optimal traction position for treating CRLBP and provide physiotherapists with an effective treatment protocol.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effects of dry needling and laser therapy in treating greater trochanteric pain syndrome (GTPS) or trochanteric bursitis. The study aims to compare the efficacy of these two interventions in reducing pain intensity, improving hip function, and enhancing lower limb function in individuals aged 35-60 years with chronic lateral hip pain.

The study involves two treatment groups: the experimental group receiving dry needling and the active comparator group receiving laser therapy. The dry needling group will undergo deep needling of trigger points in the posterolateral hip muscles, while the laser therapy group will receive infrared laser treatment at standardized points in the same region.

The primary outcome measure is the change in pain intensity assessed using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) at baseline, immediately after treatment, and 12 weeks post-treatment. Secondary outcome measures include changes in hip function evaluated by the VISA-G questionnaire, and lower limb function assessed by the Timed Up and Go Test (TUG) and the 30-second Sit to Stand Test.

The study will involve six weeks of treatment,

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of a rapid technique for detecting intestinal anti-transglutaminase antibodies (anti-TG2) and endomysial antibodies (EMA) in mechanically lysed intestinal biopsy specimens. The primary outcomes are the sensitivity and specificity of the rapid anti-TG2 test and EMA assay on biopsy specimens compared to the reference standard (serology + histopathology) for diagnosing celiac disease. The secondary outcome is the concordance of these tests with the culture-EMA results. The study includes patients aged 1-22 years undergoing an elective esophagogastroduodenoscopy for suspected celiac disease or other gastrointestinal conditions. The trial aims to assess the potential of this rapid technique for real-time diagnosis of celiac disease during endoscopic examination.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, open-label study investigating the effects of cognitive-behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I) in nurses with post-COVID-19 condition. The experimental group will receive 6 weeks of CBT-I, while the control group will receive usual care. The primary outcomes are insomnia severity measured by the Insomnia Severity Index, sleep quality measured by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index, and sleep efficiency measured by Fitbit Charge 5, assessed over 20 weeks. Secondary outcomes include anxiety, depression, and health-related quality of life, also measured over 20 weeks. The study includes nurses aged 20-65 years with post-COVID-19 condition, excluding those with sleep apnea, narcolepsy, pregnancy, seizures, or pacemakers.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial evaluating the acceptability and impact of a web-based patient decision aid called RAPID AFib (Risk Assessment and Personal preferences to Improve Decisions for Atrial Fibrillation) on shared decision-making for stroke prevention therapy in patients with recent onset atrial fibrillation.

The study aims to assess if the RAPID AFib decision aid, which estimates an individual's stroke and bleeding risk, allows comparison of anticoagulant options based on risk profile and preferences, and provides a summary report, leads to more effective shared decision-making compared to standard care.

Patients with non-valvular atrial fibrillation diagnosed within 12 months, either not on anticoagulation or treated for less than 90 days, and scheduled for an initial specialist visit within 7-30 days, will be randomized to receive either the RAPID AFib decision aid plus information website (intervention) or just the information website (control) before their clinic visit.

The primary outcome is the 9-Item Shared Decision Making Questionnaire score measured immediately after the clinic visit, which evaluates the shared decision-making process from the patient's perspective

This is a Phase I clinical trial evaluating the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of a new investigational drug called NNC0491-6075 in healthy participants and those with dyslipidemia (high levels of fat in the blood). The trial consists of three parts:

Part A: Single ascending doses of NNC0491-6075 or placebo administered subcutaneously or intravenously to healthy participants.

Part B: Multiple ascending doses of NNC0491-6075 or placebo administered subcutaneously once weekly for 4 weeks to participants with dyslipidemia. 

Part C: Single ascending doses of NNC0491-6075 or placebo administered subcutaneously or intravenously to healthy Japanese participants.

The primary outcome is the number of treatment-emergent adverse events. Secondary outcomes include pharmacokinetic parameters such as area under the curve, maximum concentration, half-life, and time to maximum concentration of NNC0491-6075. The study aims to assess the safety profile and pharmacokinetic properties of this new investigational drug in healthy individuals and those with dyslipidemia

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficiency of high-flow nasal cannula (HFNC) versus non-invasive ventilation (NIV) in treating adult patients with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure (type 2 respiratory failure). The study involves two groups: Group A receiving HFNC and Group B receiving NIV. The primary outcome measure is the failure of treatment modality to improve pH within 1 hour. Secondary outcomes include mortality during ICU stay and length of ICU stay within 28 days. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-70 years with acute moderate hypercapnic respiratory failure (pH 7.25-7.35 and PCO2 >45mmHg) admitted to the ICU. The study excludes patients with altered consciousness, hemodynamic instability, need for immediate intubation, contraindications to NIV, and post-cardiac arrest patients.

This is a study aimed at implementing and evaluating a digital-first care delivery model for heart failure patients in Uganda. The study has two main interventions:

1. Core HF intervention: All clinical care providers involved in heart failure care will be trained in an evidence-based heart failure service bundle, including a care protocol, self-care training for patients and providers, and medication stock management.

2. Medly Uganda digital health intervention: This involves a patient-facing mobile health application designed to improve self-care among heart failure patients. It includes a mobile app that processes patient-reported symptoms and generates self-care guidance, and a clinician-facing dashboard for monitoring and management recommendations.

The study will enroll heart failure patients (NYHA Class II-III) with access to a mobile phone and basic reading skills. After a run-in period, all sites will receive the Core HF intervention first, followed by the Medly Uganda intervention at randomized start points.

The primary outcomes are changes in self-care behavior (measured by the Self-Care of Heart Failure Index) and clinical effectiveness (a composite of mortality and heart failure hospitalizations). Secondary outcomes include medication adherence, vital signs, exercise capacity, bio

This is an open-label, randomized, single-dose, two-treatment, two-sequence, two-period, two-way crossover pharmacokinetic study comparing the bioavailability of a compound ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride modified-release tablet (test product) with separate ibuprofen and diphenhydramine hydrochloride tablets (reference products) in healthy adult subjects under fasting conditions. The study aims to evaluate the bioequivalence of the test and reference products by measuring key pharmacokinetic parameters such as area under the curve (AUC), peak concentration (Cmax), time to reach peak concentration (Tmax), terminal half-life (T1/2), and mean residence time (MRT). The primary outcomes are AUC0-last, AUC0-inf, and Cmax,tp, with bioequivalence determined if the 90% confidence intervals for the geometric mean ratios fall within the range of 0.8-1.25. The study involves 16 healthy adult participants randomized into two groups, with a 7-day washout period between the two treatment periods. Blood

This is a prospective observational study evaluating the impact of apalutamide in patients with metastatic hormone-sensitive prostate cancer (mHSPC). The primary outcome measure is the undetectable PSA rate (PSA <0.2ng/ml) at the end of year 1 and year 2 in mHSPC patients receiving apalutamide. Secondary outcomes include the impact of apalutamide on fatigue (assessed by Brief Fatigue Inventory), cognitive function (FACT-Cog questionnaire), and health-related quality of life (EQ-5D-5L questionnaire). The study includes male patients aged 18 years or older with histologically confirmed metastatic adenocarcinoma of the prostate and a treatment decision for apalutamide by the clinician. Patients with non-metastatic prostate cancer, prior chemotherapy or other specified treatments, or inability to complete patient-reported outcome questionnaires are excluded.

This is a single-arm, open-label study evaluating the hair and scalp benefits of Duobrii (0.045% tazarotene/0.01% halobetasol) lotion in adults with moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. Eligible participants will apply Duobrii lotion once daily to the affected scalp area for 12 weeks. The primary outcomes are improvement in hair growth and reduction in scalp itch at week 12. Assessments will be performed at baseline, week 4, week 8, and week 12, including evaluation of erythema, scaling, induration, hair shine, manageability, frizziness, color, growth, and cuticle structure by both the investigator and participants. Digital photography of the scalp will also be conducted. A consumer perception survey will be administered at week 12. The study aims to demonstrate the hair and scalp benefits of Duobrii lotion in treating scalp psoriasis.

This is a Phase 1b clinical trial evaluating the combination of idasanutlin and selinexor in children, adolescents, and young adults with progressive/relapsed atypical teratoid/rhabdoid tumors (AT/RT), extra-CNS malignant rhabdoid tumors (MRT), or synchronous/metachronous rhabdoid tumors.

The trial has a dose-finding/safety phase to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) of the combination therapy. Patients will receive idasanutlin daily on days 1-5 of a 28-day cycle, starting at 80% of the RP2D from a prior pediatric trial. Selinexor will be given on day 4 of the first 3 weeks, with the dose level based on a prior trial. Different dose levels of both drugs will be evaluated.

Once the RP2D is established, the trial will proceed to an expansion phase with three strata: Stratum A for AT/RT, Stratum B for MRT, and Str

This is a comparative study evaluating two surgical procedures, radial shortening and capitate shortening, for the treatment of Kienbock's disease (avascular necrosis of the lunate bone) with ulna minus variance in patients aged 18-65 years. The study has a randomized, parallel-group design with two active treatment arms. The radial shortening group will undergo a volar approach with 2.5 mm shortening of the distal radius, while the capitate shortening group will have a dorsal approach with 2.5 mm shortening of the capitate bone. The primary outcome measure is the Modified Mayo Wrist Score, which assesses wrist pain, hand grip, work status, and range of motion, evaluated at 1 year after the procedure. The study aims to compare the efficacy of these two surgical interventions in treating Kienbock's disease with ulna minus variance.

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effects of a 4-week multimodal prehabilitation program in patients with localized pancreatic or periampullary cancer undergoing surgery. The prehabilitation intervention includes exercise training, nutritional therapy, and anxiety reduction techniques aimed at improving functional capacity, nutritional status, and quality of life before surgery compared to usual care.

The primary outcomes are postoperative complications measured by the Comprehensive Complication Index at 90 days, functional capacity measured by the 6-minute walk test, pro-inflammatory cytokine levels, and cancer cachexia-related factors. Secondary outcomes include time to functional recovery, length of hospital stay, body composition measures, and patient-reported quality of life.

Eligible patients will be randomized 1:1 to either the multimodal prehabilitation intervention or usual care control group. Assessments will occur at baseline, pre-surgery, and 30, 60, and 90 days post-surgery. The target sample size is 226 patients.

The study aims to evaluate if prehabil

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of dual task exercise training in improving balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children aged 5-12 years with cerebral palsy (hemiplegic, monoplegic, unilaterally affected or diplegic) and Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) levels 1 or 2. The study has two groups: an intervention group receiving conventional rehabilitation plus dual task exercise training (e.g., simple math during active stretching, carrying a ball while on a balance pad) for 12 weeks, and a control group receiving only conventional rehabilitation. The primary outcomes measured are Pediatric Balance Scale, Timed Up and Go Test, One Leg Standing Test, 3-Meter Backward Walk Test, 6 Meter Walk Test, and the Generic Children's Health-Related Quality of Life Questionnaire (KINDL), assessed at baseline and after 12 weeks of intervention. The study aims to determine if adding dual task exercise training to conventional rehabilitation can improve balance, mobility, physical performance, and quality of life in children with cerebral palsy.

This is a pilot study in Belgium aimed at actively surveilling zoonotic transmission events of influenza viruses from animals to humans. The study involves four participant groups:

1. People involved in avian influenza outbreak management on farms, who will self-sample with nasopharyngeal swabs every 2 days for 2 weeks and provide serum samples.

2. A sentinel network of poultry farm workers, who will self-sample with nasopharyngeal swabs every 2 weeks throughout the study duration. 

3. A sentinel network of workers at wild bird/wildlife rehabilitation centers, who will self-sample with nasopharyngeal swabs every 2 weeks.

4. A sentinel network of veterinarians working in the pig industry, who will self-sample with nasopharyngeal swabs every 2 weeks.

The primary outcomes are the number of participants from the sentinel networks and outbreak groups who test positive for non-seasonal influenza viruses via RT-qPCR testing of respiratory specimens. A secondary outcome is the number of outbreak participants with seroconversion against non-seasonal influenza viruses, measured by serological assays. The study

This is a longitudinal within-person study evaluating the impact of a 6-week canine-assisted therapy program on emotion regulation, behavioral issues, and self-esteem in youth residing at a residential treatment facility. The study has two parallel conditions: an experimental group receiving the 6-week Recovery & Care Canine-Assisted Therapy intervention, and a waitlist control group receiving treatment as usual. The intervention involves structured weekly sessions focused on dog obedience, trick training, and agility, with a graduation ceremony in the final week. Primary outcomes include emotional regulation (measured by Emotional Stroop and Flanker tasks), self-esteem (Rosenberg scale), and changes in positive/negative affect during each session. Secondary outcomes include attendance, disruptive behaviors, and attitudes towards pets. Assessments occur at baseline, during each intervention session, and up to 1 month post-intervention. The study aims to evaluate the therapeutic benefits of animal-assisted interventions for youth in residential treatment.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of myofascial release using foam rollers in addition to foot core exercises on lower extremity performance in young adults aged 18-25 years with asymptomatic flexible pes planus (flat feet). The study has two parallel groups: an experimental group receiving foam roller myofascial release and foot core exercises, and a control group receiving only foot core exercises. The foot core exercise program consists of 7 different exercises performed for 6 weeks, with 3 sets of 10 repetitions per day. The experimental group additionally performs 60 seconds of foam roller myofascial release on the thoracolumbar fascia, iliotibial band, hamstrings, gastrocnemius-soleus complex, peroneals, and plantar fascia, 2 days per week for 6 weeks. The primary outcome is change in balance measured by the Y Balance Test. Secondary outcomes include changes in flexibility (sit and reach test), power (vertical jump test), and gait (10-meter walk test). The results after the 6-week intervention will be compared between the two groups to determine the additional effect of myofasc

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of an 8-week daily arm training program on reducing pain during peripheral venous catheter insertion and improving vein status in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. The study involves two parallel groups: an experimental group receiving the arm training intervention and a control group receiving normal care. The primary outcomes are pain levels measured using the Numeric Rating Scale at baseline, 5 weeks, and 8 weeks. Secondary outcomes include the number of usable veins assessed via ultrasound at the same time points. The study aims to determine if arm training can reduce pain and improve vein status for patients requiring repeated peripheral venous catheter insertions during chemotherapy treatment.

This is a study investigating the genetic and immunological factors associated with early pregnancy loss using products of conception derived from ultrasound-guided manual vacuum aspiration (USG-MVA). The key aspects of the trial are:

1. It aims to analyze the chorionic villi (fetal tissue) obtained from USG-MVA for genetic abnormalities, including aneuploidies, copy number variants, mosaicisms, structural rearrangements, absence of heterozygosity, and single nucleotide variants, using next-generation sequencing techniques.

2. It also aims to study the maternal decidual tissue for immunological factors, such as leukocyte subpopulations and their activation markers, using immunohistochemistry staining.

3. The study compares the genetic and immunological findings between miscarriages with trisomy 16 conceptuses, chromosomally normal male conceptuses, and gestational age-matched controls.

4. The study focuses on women undergoing USG-MVA for first-trimester miscarriage or termination of pregnancy, with specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

5. The primary outcomes are the histopathologic

This is a phase 1, open-label, single-arm clinical trial investigating the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and pharmacodynamics of Lu AF28996 in Japanese adults with Parkinson's disease. The study will enroll participants aged 45-75 years with idiopathic Parkinson's disease, Hoehn and Yahr stage ≤3 in the ON state and ≤4 in the OFF state, experiencing motor fluctuations, and on a stable dose of levodopa. Participants will receive ascending oral doses of Lu AF28996 once daily for 14 days, followed by down-titration. The primary outcomes include the number of treatment-emergent adverse events, area under the plasma concentration-time curve, maximum observed plasma concentration, and oral clearance of Lu AF28996. The study aims to evaluate the safety profile and pharmacokinetic properties of Lu AF28996 in this patient population.

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a quasi-experimental study in Bangladesh assessing the acceptability, cost-effectiveness, and required capacity for a facility-based seasonal influenza vaccination program targeting high-risk groups (children 6 months-8 years, pregnant women, elderly ≥60 years, and adults with chronic diseases). 

The study has three main objectives:

1. Assess acceptability and health beliefs about influenza vaccination using the Health Belief Model survey.

2. Determine the cost-effectiveness of seasonal influenza vaccination by comparing vaccinated and unvaccinated cohorts in terms of health outcomes, costs, and disability-adjusted life years (DALYs). 

3. Estimate the required capacity (vaccine doses, injection equipment, storage) for implementing a hospital-based influenza vaccination program.

The study involves running a free influenza vaccination campaign at one hospital (intervention arm) and following up vaccinated and unvaccinated participants to track outcomes. Data is being collected on costs associated with influenza illness episodes. Secondary data will be used to estimate disease burden parameters. Cost-effectiveness will be evaluated using incremental cost-

The SUSPECT Italian Prospective Study is a clinical trial evaluating the performance characteristics and technical outcomes of single-use duodenoscopes. The study aims to assess the technical and procedural performance of these devices over a 24-month period. Participants must be 18 years or older, willing to comply with study procedures, and scheduled for a clinically indicated endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) or other duodenoscope-based procedure. The study excludes potentially vulnerable subjects, such as pregnant women, individuals for whom endoscopic techniques are contraindicated, and those enrolled in conflicting investigational studies. The primary outcome measures are the technical and procedural performance of the single-use duodenoscopes.

This is a feasibility study evaluating a hybrid pulmonary rehabilitation program for patients with respiratory diseases like COPD and bronchiectasis. The hybrid program combines in-person sessions with remote delivery of exercise classes, education, and monitoring via a smartphone app called Active+me REMOTE.

The key aspects are:

- It compares outcomes of the hybrid program to a propensity-matched control group that received standard pulmonary rehabilitation.
- Primary outcomes assess feasibility aspects like recruitment, retention, data availability, matching success, staff/patient acceptability, and safety.
- Secondary outcomes measure patient uptake, adherence, exercise capacity, symptoms, quality of life, anxiety/depression, disease knowledge, and healthcare resource utilization.
- It includes qualitative interviews/focus groups with staff and patients to explore their experiences.
- The goal is to generate evidence to support a larger trial comparing the effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of hybrid versus standard pulmonary rehabilitation delivery models.

This is an observational cohort study using secondary data to describe the baseline demographics and clinical characteristics of immunocompromised patients aged ≥12 years who received EVUSHELD (tixagevimab/cilgavimab) as pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) against SARS-CoV-2 infection/COVID-19 in Japan. The study will include patients with a record of EVUSHELD administration and follow them for up to 6 months after the first administration. The primary outcome is to describe the proportion of patients by age, gender, and clinical characteristics of interest (e.g., comorbidities, concurrent medications) in the 12 months preceding the first EVUSHELD administration. Secondary outcomes include event rates and time to events for medically attended COVID-19, COVID-19 hospitalization, in-hospital mortality due to COVID-19, and all-cause mortality up to 180 days after the first EVUSHELD administration. The expected sample size is approximately 280 patients.

This is a Phase 4, multicenter, randomized, double-blind study evaluating the safety and efficacy of subcutaneously injected risankizumab for the treatment of adults with moderate to severe genital psoriasis or moderate to severe scalp psoriasis. The study has two parts - one for genital psoriasis (Study-G) and one for scalp psoriasis (Study-S). 

In Study-G, participants with moderate to severe genital psoriasis are randomized to receive either risankizumab or placebo for 16 weeks, followed by risankizumab for 36 weeks. In Study-S, participants with moderate to severe scalp psoriasis are randomized similarly.

The primary outcomes are the percentage of participants achieving a static Physician Global Assessment of Genitalia (sPGA-G) score of 0 or 1 at week 16 for Study-G, and percentage achieving a Scalp Investigator Global Assessment (IGA) of 0 or 1 at week 16 for Study-S. 

Secondary outcomes include additional measures of genital/scalp ps

This is a descriptive cross-sectional study aimed at determining the prevalence of the Linburg-Comstock Variation (LCV) in patients with symptomatic thumb carpometacarpal (CMC) arthritis. The study plans to recruit 500 male and female patients aged 35-89 years with a diagnosis of thumb CMC arthritis through convenience sampling. Participants will undergo a brief clinical examination during their regular office visit to check for the presence of LCV, which involves bending the tip of the thumb. The study will collect demographic data, as well as dichotomous data indicating whether the LCV is present in one or both hands. The study is observational in nature, with no interventions or control group. Data will be collected for up to two years at various locations in Albany, New York. The study poses no risks to participants, and there is no compensation for participation. The primary outcome measure is the positive or negative clinical examination for LCV.

This is a Phase 3, multicenter, 12-week, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to evaluate the safety and efficacy of the drug atogepant for the preventive treatment of episodic migraine in pediatric participants aged 6-17 years. The study has an open-label pharmacokinetic (PK) substudy to determine appropriate dosing for the 6-11 year age group, followed by a double-blind treatment period where participants are randomized to receive either high dose atogepant, low dose atogepant, or placebo once daily for 12 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change from baseline in mean monthly migraine days. Secondary outcomes include changes in monthly headache days, acute medication use days, percentage of participants achieving at least 50% reduction in monthly migraine days, and changes in quality of life and disability scores. Eligibility criteria include a history of episodic migraine, 4-14 migraine days per month, and a weight between 20-135 kg. Key exclusions are chronic migraine, certain migraine subtypes, and frequent hospitalizations for migraine.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of a 2-week home-based touchscreen training program on motor learning in patients with Parkinson's disease (PD). The study aims to examine the immediate and retention effects of targeted touchscreen training on upper limb motor skills in PD patients.

The study will include 36 PD patients (Hoehn and Yahr stages I-III) who will be randomized into an experimental group and a control group. The experimental group will receive 10 training sessions (5 days/week, 10 minutes/session) over 2 weeks, practicing a Swipe Slide Pattern (SSP) task on a tablet in both single-task (ST) and dual-task (DT) conditions. The control group will not receive any intervention.

The primary outcome measure is the average slide duration (in ms) on the SSP task, assessed at baseline and immediately after the 2-week training period. Secondary outcomes include performance accuracy, retention effects after a 4-week follow-up, consolidation of learning (assessed through dual-task interference and transfer to an untrained mobile phone task), and cognitive and non-motor assess

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effect of intensified tactile contact between a mother and newborn on the mother's emotional transformation after physiological delivery. The study employed a non-randomized, quasi-experimental design with an experimental group and a matched control group.

The experimental group received an intervention involving Shantali massage, which involved intensified tactile contact between the mother and newborn. The massage was performed at least twice a day for 10 minutes each, starting from the 3rd day after delivery and lasting until the end of the 12th week postpartum.

The primary outcomes measured were changes in postpartum depression, anxiety, positive and negative affects, and parental competence, assessed using standardized psychological questionnaires. These measures were taken at two time points: on the 3rd day after delivery and within the 13th week postpartum.

The study included women aged 18-40 years who had a first physiological delivery, with no previous miscarriages, and a normal pregnancy and fetal development. Exclusion criteria included complications during delivery, poor health of the mother or newborn, and external factors that could affect the mother's emotional state during the observation period.

This is a non-comparative randomized phase II trial evaluating the combination of paclitaxel-bevacizumab with or without atezolizumab in patients with advanced non-squamous non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) progressing after immunotherapy and chemotherapy. The study has two arms: Arm A receives paclitaxel and bevacizumab, while Arm B receives paclitaxel, bevacizumab, and atezolizumab. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival at 6 months determined by independent review. Secondary outcomes include progression-free survival, objective response rate, overall survival, time until definitive health-related quality of life score deterioration, incidence and severity of adverse events, and overall health status. Eligible patients must have advanced NSCLC of non-squamous histology, have progressed after prior immunotherapy and platinum-based chemotherapy, and meet other specified inclusion/exclusion criteria.

This is a pilot prospective cohort study investigating the role of osteopathic manipulative treatment (OMT) in managing persistent post-COVID-19 symptoms. The study aims to assess the feasibility of patient recruitment and data completion rates as primary outcomes. Secondary outcomes include measuring neurocognitive, psychological, and physical symptoms, global health, and return to work status using various questionnaires and scales. Participants must be at least 18 years old and have experienced at least one new symptom related to COVID-19, such as fatigue, dyspnea, anosmia, arthralgia, headache, sleep disturbances, anxiety/depression, or other mental health problems, which has persisted for at least 4 weeks after diagnosis. The study involves providing OMT at the discretion of the treating physician based on the patient's response to previous treatments. Outcomes will be measured 3 days after every other OMT session for up to 4 months after enrollment and 2 months after the participant's final OMT session.

This is a pilot study comparing two imaging modalities, indocyanine green (ICG) microangiography and conventional angiography, in the assessment of severe frostbite patients undergoing thrombolysis. The primary objective is to evaluate the concordance between these two imaging techniques in demonstrating ischemic tissue present in severe frostbite, as scored by the Hennepin Frostbite Score. The study also aims to assess the safety of administering ICG dye in close temporal proximity to contrast dye used in conventional angiography, by monitoring for adverse events.

The study will enroll adult patients (>18 years) diagnosed with severe frostbite by conventional angiography, undergoing thrombolysis with catheter-directed lytics, cognitively able to provide consent, and with normal kidney function. Pregnant individuals and those with iodine allergy will be excluded.

Participants will receive an ICG angiogram directly after the conventional angiogram, as part of the assessment for severe frostbite. The primary outcome measure is the assessment of ischemic tissue present in severe frostbite, as demonstrated by both imaging modalities and

This is a randomized open-label controlled study investigating the impact of a multidisciplinary approach in the perioperative geriatrics unit (GPOU) on functional status of patients aged 70 and over undergoing colorectal cancer surgery. The study has two arms: the control group receiving classical management in the digestive surgery department, and the GPOU group receiving specialized geriatric care in the perioperative geriatrics unit, including interventions like early mobilization, comorbidity management, and detailed discharge planning. The primary outcome measure is the change in functional status, assessed by the Instrumental Activities of Daily Living (IADL) score, between the two groups at 3 months after surgery. Secondary outcomes include functional status at 6 months, basic activities of daily living, motor ability, patient satisfaction, length of hospital stay, medical and surgical complications, discharge destination, weight change, quality of life, place of abode, overall survival, and unscheduled re-hospitalizations. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the multidisciplinary geriatric approach in improving functional outcomes and perioperative care for elderly patients undergoing colorectal cancer surgery.

This is a pilot clinical trial investigating the use of 64Cu-DOTA-pembrolizumab (64CDP) positron emission tomography (PET) imaging in patients with metastatic solid tumors receiving stereotactic body radiation therapy (SBRT). The primary objectives are to describe toxicities associated with 64CDP PET imaging and to identify changes in 64CDP uptake in radiated metastatic lesions before and after SBRT. Eligible patients will receive standard pembrolizumab treatment at baseline, followed by 64CDP intravenously on days 1 and 29, with PET scans on days 2 and 30. Patients will also undergo standard SBRT between days 8-18. The study will assess dose-limiting toxicities, changes in 64CDP uptake and standard uptake value (SUV-max) in radiated lesions, and incidence of adverse events related to 64CDP administration.

This is a Phase 3b, non-randomized, open-label, multi-country, cohort study to describe the safety of participants who received the RSVPreF3 maternal vaccine or control from previous RSV maternal immunization studies (RSV MAT-001, RSV MAT-004, RSV MAT-010, RSV MAT-011, RSV MAT-009, RSV MAT-012, and RSV MAT-039) during any pregnancy conceived post-vaccination/control. The study includes a retrospective cohort of participants from prior studies who have already conceived a pregnancy post-vaccination/control, as well as a prospective cohort of participants who may conceive during the study period. The primary outcomes measure the percentage of maternal participants reporting pregnancy outcomes, pregnancy-related adverse events of special interest (AESIs), and infant AESIs from the first pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination up to 42 days post-delivery. Secondary outcomes evaluate the same measures for any pregnancy conceived within 2 years post-vaccination and assess the impact of selected risk factors on these outcomes. The study aims to describe the safety profile of the RSVPreF3

This is a cross-sectional pilot study aimed at evaluating the feasibility and acceptability of using 19F MRI to assess lung ventilation in healthy children and children with mild cystic fibrosis (CF) lung disease. The study involves inhaling a biologically inert contrast gas, perfluoropropane, combined with 19F-tuned MRI imaging during breath-hold and tidal breathing. The primary outcomes include participation rate, completion rate, and parental and child acceptability scores. Secondary outcomes measure ventilation defect parameters and the fraction of lung volume with slow gas washout time in both healthy and CF participants. The study targets children aged 6-17 years, with specific inclusion and exclusion criteria for the CF and healthy groups. The study aims to assess the practicality and implementation of this imaging technique in a pediatric population.

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing the effects of open kinetic chain exercises and closed kinetic chain exercises on pain, function, and balance in athletes aged 18-30 years with patellofemoral pain syndrome. The study will be conducted in Pakistan, with participants randomly assigned to two groups. Group A will receive open kinetic chain exercises (3 sets of 10 repetitions for each exercise) along with general training, while Group B will receive closed kinetic chain exercises (3 sets of 10 repetitions for each exercise) along with general training. The interventions will be provided in 3 sessions per week for 6 weeks. The primary outcomes measured are pain (using the Numerical Pain Rating Scale), function (using the Lower Extremity Functional Scale), and balance (using the Y Balance Test). Assessments will be done at baseline and after 6 weeks of treatment. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these exercise approaches in managing patellofemoral pain syndrome in athletes.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effects of the MIND (Mediterranean-DASH Intervention for Neurodegenerative Delay) diet on oxidative stress, inflammation, and neurodegenerative risk biomarkers in American football players. The study aims to assess whether the MIND diet, which has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties, can improve these biomarkers in athletes exposed to repetitive head impacts.

The study will recruit male American football players aged 18 or older who have played for at least 2 years and have a MIND diet score below 7.5. Participants will be randomized into a MIND diet group or a control group maintaining their usual diet. The MIND diet group will receive guidance and provisions to follow the MIND diet, including recommended foods like berries, fish, and a grape juice substitute for wine.

Primary outcomes include biomarkers associated with neurodegeneration, oxidative stress, and inflammation, such as tau protein, neurofilament light polypeptide, S100B protein, brain-derived neurotrophic factor, telomere length, zonulin, NADPH oxidase, 8-hydroxy

This is a prospective and retrospective cohort study evaluating the efficacy and safety of left bundle branch area pacing (LBBAP) in heart failure patients with reduced or mid-range ejection fraction (EF ≤50%). The primary outcome is the acute success rate of LBBAP, defined by meeting specific criteria during the procedure. Secondary outcomes include acute procedure-related complications, incidence of repeat procedures, pacemaker upgrade to cardiac resynchronization therapy, heart failure hospitalization, cardiovascular and all-cause mortality, changes in left ventricular function and dimensions, and LBBAP lead parameters over 1 year. The study involves two cohorts: a prospective group undergoing attempted LBBAP and a retrospective group who previously underwent LBBAP, both using the Biotronik Selectra 3D sheath and Solia S60 lead. Eligible participants are heart failure patients aged ≥19 years with EF ≤50% and an indication for cardiac pacing or resynchronization therapy.

This is a Phase 1a, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, single ascending dose study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of CSX-1004, a recombinant human immunoglobulin G monoclonal antibody specific for fentanyl and related analogs, in healthy adults aged 18 to 50 years. The study has an experimental arm receiving single doses of CSX-1004 injection and a placebo comparator arm receiving sterile saline injection. The primary outcomes include treatment-emergent adverse events, clinical laboratory assessments, vital signs, electrocardiograms, physical examinations, and infusion site examinations. Secondary outcomes measure the pharmacokinetic parameters of CSX-1004, such as maximum serum concentration, area under the curve, time to maximum concentration, and elimination half-life. The study aims to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetic profile of CSX-1004 as a potential treatment for opioid overdose and opioid use disorder.

This is a prospective cohort study investigating the diagnostic accuracy of joint fluid aspiration (JFA) in detecting prosthetic joint infections or implant failures in patients with dysfunctional hip, knee or shoulder prostheses. The key aspects are:

1. Patients aged over 18 years with hip, knee or shoulder joint prostheses who require JFA due to suspected prosthesis complications will be included.

2. At the initial visit (V0), patients will be classified into supposedly septic, supposedly aseptic or intermediate groups based on clinical, radiological and biological data.

3. At visit V1, JFA will be performed, and additional joint fluid will be collected for biomarker analysis.

4. Patients may undergo prosthesis revision surgery (V2) if chronic prosthetic joint infection (PJI) or implant failure is confirmed.

5. The primary outcome is the analysis of the bacteriological concordance between JFA and perioperative samples, measured by the number of patients whose JFA results match the perioperative samples.

6. The study aims to evaluate the diagnostic accuracy of JFA in detecting prosthetic joint infections or implant failures,

This is a clinical trial studying the use of dynamic 19F MRI to quantify and spatially register airways dysfunction in cystic fibrosis patients. The key aspects are:

- Participants are adults (≥18 years) with cystic fibrosis who meet specific inclusion/exclusion criteria related to lung function, smoking history, and ability to undergo MRI.

- All participants will inhale the contrast gas perfluoropropane and undergo 19F MRI scans at multiple visits over 14 days and 1 year.

- The primary outcomes measure changes in ventilation defect parameters (VDP) and functional lung volume (FLVlongtau2) over 14 days and 1 year, as well as changes during pulmonary exacerbations.

- Secondary outcomes include changes in MRI severity scores over 1 year and correlation of these scores with VDP and FLVlongtau2 at baseline.

- The study aims to quantify and spatially map airways dysfunction in cystic fibrosis using the novel 19F MRI technique, which could provide valuable insights into disease progression and treatment response.

This is a randomized, open-label, single-dose, two-sequence, two-cycle, double-crossover bioequivalence study of the oral drug STI-1558 in healthy Chinese subjects. The study aims to compare the bioavailability of a test formulation and a reference formulation of STI-1558 (200 mg capsules) under fasting conditions. 

32 healthy adults aged 18-45 years will be randomly assigned to receive either the test or reference formulation on day 1, followed by the alternate formulation on day 8, with a 7-day washout period in between doses. The primary outcomes are the maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the curve from time 0 to the last measurable concentration (AUC0-t), and AUC from time 0 extrapolated to infinity (AUC0-inf) of STI-1558. Secondary outcomes include time to reach Cmax (Tmax), elimination half-life (t1/2), terminal elimination rate constant (λz), and percentage of AUC extrapolated to infinity (%AUCex).

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of detaching the breathing circuit on the rate of double-lumen endotracheal tube (DLT) malposition after postural change in patients undergoing thoracic surgery. The study involves two groups: an experimental group where the breathing circuit is disengaged when the patient transitions from supine to lateral position, and a control group where the breathing circuit remains connected. The primary outcome measure is the malposition rate of the DLT immediately after the postural change. Secondary outcomes include the degree of lung collapse, blood oxygen saturation, and length of stay in the post-anesthesia care unit (PACU). The study includes adult patients aged 18-65 years undergoing elective thoracic surgery requiring a left-sided DLT, with specific inclusion and exclusion criteria. The trial aims to evaluate if detaching the breathing circuit can prevent DLT malposition and improve surgical exposure and patient outcomes.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study evaluating the effect of personalized comprehensive diabetes support among families of children aged 16 years or younger with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes. The study has two arms: an intervention arm receiving personalized comprehensive diabetes support for 6 months following diagnosis, and a control arm receiving no intervention. The primary outcomes are diabetes distress measured by the Diabetes Distress Scale and Problem Areas in Diabetes (PAID) scale at 24 months. The study aims to assess the impact of personalized comprehensive diabetes support on reducing diabetes-related distress in families of children with newly diagnosed type 1 diabetes.

This is a randomized multicenter clinical trial evaluating the efficacy of telemedicine monitoring in the management of major depressive disorder (MDD) after hospitalization in medicine, surgery or obstetrics (MSO) units, compared to usual care.

The study aims to assess if telemedicine monitoring added to usual outpatient care can improve response rates to antidepressant treatment at 6 months, reduce costs associated with depressive symptoms over 3 years, and optimize secondary prevention strategies by maintaining treatment adherence in MDD patients after MSO hospitalization.

Patients with MDD initiated on antidepressants during MSO hospitalization will be randomized into two groups:

1) Usual care group: Standard follow-up care prescribed during hospitalization.

2) Telemedicine monitoring group: In addition to usual care, patients will receive telemedicine sessions led by a nurse/psychologist to evaluate treatment efficacy, depressive symptoms, daily difficulties, and provide recommendations. Session frequency varies based on symptom severity.

The primary outcome is the treatment response rate (≥50% reduction in depression score) at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include cost-utility analysis, quality of

This clinical trial aims to develop an artificial intelligence (AI) algorithm that can differentiate between benign and malignant soft tissue masses using quantitative MRI data. The study involves acquiring additional quantitative MRI sequences for patients undergoing standard MRI scans for suspected soft tissue sarcoma. The extra MRI sequences will add a maximum of 10 minutes to the patient's standard scan. The primary outcome measure is the diagnostic accuracy of the AI algorithm in distinguishing between benign and malignant soft tissue lesions, assessed through ROC analysis of sensitivity and specificity. A secondary outcome measure is the classification accuracy of the AI algorithm in grading malignant lesions. A subset of patients will be invited for a second MRI scan to test the reproducibility of the quantitative scans and the AI algorithms. The study aims to improve the diagnostic process for soft tissue sarcomas and reduce the need for invasive biopsies.

This is a 24-month split-mouth randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the effectiveness of microneedling alone versus microneedling combined with hyaluronic acid in increasing gingival thickness in patients with thin gingival phenotype. The study will recruit 20 systematically healthy patients aged 18-40 years with thin gingival phenotype (gingival thickness <1mm) in the mandibular anterior region. Each patient will undergo two interventions, with one side of the mandibular anterior region randomly assigned to receive microneedling alone (control group) and the other side receiving microneedling combined with hyaluronic acid injection (test group). The primary outcome measure is the change in gingival thickness at 9 months, measured using an endodontic spreader and Vernier caliper. Secondary outcomes include changes in keratinized tissue width, gingival index, bleeding on probing, and probing depth at different time points up to 9 months. The interventions will be performed three times with a 10-day interval between each session.

This is a multicenter randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of preoperative immunonutrition on patients undergoing elective colorectal surgery for neoplasm. The study aims to evaluate the impact of oral supplementation with Impact Nestle, an immunonutrition formula, on surgical outcomes and adipose tissue inflammation.

The study involves two parallel arms: the active comparator arm receives oral Impact Nestle three times daily for 10 days before surgery, while the placebo comparator arm receives a placebo on the same schedule. All participants undergo colorectal surgery according to standard clinical practice.

The primary outcome measure is the incidence of surgical site infections within 30 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes include anastomotic leakage, length of hospital stay, and histological analysis of inflammatory infiltration, fibrosis, and adipocyte cross-sectional area in subcutaneous and visceral adipose tissue samples.

The study includes adults aged 20-85 years with primary colorectal neoplasms eligible for elective minimally invasive resection. Patients with emergency surgeries, major intraoperative complications, chronic diseases, inflammatory bowel diseases, or previous bow

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of adding an oculomotor therapy treatment to a cervical manual therapy protocol in patients with migraine. The study involves two groups: a control group receiving cervical treatment for 6 weeks, and an experimental group receiving both cervical and oculomotor treatments for 6 weeks. The primary outcome measure is changes in the impact of migraine, assessed using the Headache Impact Test (HIT-6) Questionnaire. Secondary outcome measures include changes in pain, disability, depression, anxiety, sleep quality, kinesiophobia, catastrophizing, central sensitization, neck disability, head repositioning, strength of deep cervical flexors, ocular movements, cervical range of motion, and quality of life. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with single masking. Participants aged 18-65 years with migraine are eligible, while those receiving preventive physiotherapy treatment, preventive medication, or having certain medical conditions are excluded. The trial aims to investigate the potential additional benefits of incorporating oculomotor therapy in the management of migraine.

The CRATOS clinical trial is evaluating the Cratos™ Branch Stent Graft System for the treatment of descending aorta lesions, including aortic dissection type B, intramural hematoma, and penetrating aortic ulcer. It is a single-arm, open-label study with the primary outcome measure being all-cause mortality at 30 days. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older with thoracic aortic pathology requiring surgical repair in Zone 2, with specific anatomical criteria for the proximal aortic landing zone, left subclavian artery landing zone, and distal aortic landing zone. Key exclusion criteria include concomitant disease of the ascending aorta or abdominal aortic aneurysm, active infection, recent myocardial infarction or stroke, pregnancy, connective tissue disorders, and contraindications to antiplatelet or anticoagulant therapy. The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of the Cratos™ Stent Graft System in treating descending aorta lesions through a minimally invasive thoracic end

This is a comparative study aimed at evaluating two ultrasound-guided approaches for lumbar plexus block (BPLE): the Trident technique and the Shamrock technique. The study involves adult participants undergoing lumbar ultrasound examination, excluding those with a history of spinal surgery or malformations.

The primary outcome measure is the projection of line C (obtained by placing the probe on the iliac crest) on the costiform processes, analyzed using the Trident technique. Secondary outcome measures include the depth of the lumbar plexus, image quality, and the presence of vessels, analyzed using both the Trident and Shamrock techniques.

During the study, participants will undergo lumbar ultrasound examinations using both techniques.
