For the Trident technique, the costiform processes from T12 to L5 will be identified, and the quality of the image, depth of the lumbar plexus, and presence of vessels will be noted. For the Shamrock technique, the projection of line C will be marked with an invisible ink pen, and the probe will be oriented cephalically (line >C) and caudally (line <C). For each line,

This is a prospective randomized trial investigating the efficacy of standardized preoperative pelvic floor physical therapy (PFPT) in reducing stress urinary incontinence (SUI) and improving quality of life following holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP) for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH). The study aims to determine if starting PFPT one month before HoLEP surgery, rather than after surgery (standard of care), can minimize post-operative SUI and associated complications.

Participants will be randomized into two groups: the experimental group will receive preoperative PFPT starting one month before HoLEP, while the control group will start PFPT after surgery (standard of care). The primary outcome measure is the time to recover from transient post-operative SUI, assessed at 6 months after surgery. Secondary outcomes include uroflow, post-void residual, international prostate symptom score, operative time, length of hospital stay, catheter duration, infectious complications, and emergency room visits related to the surgery.

The study includes men aged 18 years or older scheduled for HoLE

This is a randomized, prospective, multicenter, controlled, single-blind, cluster study with a stepped-wedge design. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a clinical decision support system (CDSS) and dedicated procedures in reducing adverse drug events (ADEs) such as acute renal failure and hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients aged 65 years and above.

The study has two arms: an intervention group receiving CDSS support and a control group receiving routine care without CDSS support. The primary outcome measure is the number of ADEs such as acute renal failure and/or hyperkalemia in older hospitalized patients. Secondary outcomes include the presence of adverse events related to the intervention, therapeutic adaptations implemented for acute renal failure or hyperkalemia, relevance of CDSS alerts, number of accepted pharmaceutical interventions, changes in ADE prevention/management work processes, and cost-effectiveness of the pharmaceutical intervention.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of incorporating specific rules into a CDSS and dedicated procedures in reducing ADEs in older hospitalized patients, ultimately improving patient safety and healthcare quality.

This clinical trial aims to investigate mesenteric bacterial translocation in Crohn's disease patients undergoing ileocecal resection surgery. The study involves two groups: Crohn's disease patients requiring ileocecal resection and a control group of patients undergoing the same surgery for reasons other than Crohn's disease.

The primary outcomes measured are:

1. Differences in the proportions and abundance of bacterial taxa between the mesentery, ileal tissue, and blood in Crohn's disease patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence.
2. Differences in the functional bacterial profile (metagenome function analysis) between the mesentery, ileal tissue, and blood in Crohn's disease patients with and without early post-surgical disease recurrence.

The secondary outcome is the association analysis of genetic variants related to innate immunity (ATG16L1, NOD2/CARD15, and IRGM) and the bacterial microbiome profile of Crohn's disease patients.

The study aims to investigate the role of mesenteric bacterial translocation and its potential association with genetic factors in the pathogenesis and recurrence of Crohn

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment study evaluating the effect of injection site on the relative bioavailability of a single dose of LY3437943 in healthy participants with a high body mass index (BMI) between 27.0 and 45.0 kg/m². The study has two parts: Part A involves subcutaneous administration of LY3437943 in either the thigh, upper arm, or abdomen, while Part B involves intravenous administration. The primary outcomes are the area under the plasma concentration-time curve from zero to infinity (AUC[0-∞]) and maximum concentration (Cmax) of LY3437943 after subcutaneous administration (Part A). Secondary outcomes include AUC[0-∞] and Cmax after intravenous administration (Part B). The study aims to assess the pharmacokinetics of LY3437943 and the impact of injection site on its bioavailability in individuals with high BMI.

This is a research registry study on aggressive pituitary neuroendocrine tumors (PitNETs). The study aims to characterize the aggressiveness of pituitary tumors through transcriptome analysis, with the goal of identifying a molecular and transcriptomic signature predictive of prognosis. The primary outcome measure is the characterization of aggressiveness of pituitary tumors by transcriptome analysis, to be measured over a 3-year time frame. The study includes adult patients (aged 18 years and above) with a diagnosis of pituitary tumor, whose files have been presented to the national HYPOcare RCP. Patients who object to participating in the research are excluded. The study has a single participant group consisting of all eligible patients with pituitary tumors.

The OPTI-DOSE study is a randomized pilot study investigating the optimal dosing of oral anticancer drugs in older adults (aged 65 years or older) with various types of cancer, including renal cell carcinoma, ovarian carcinoma, thyroid carcinoma, breast carcinoma, and endometrium carcinoma. The study aims to evaluate whether starting with a lower dose of anticancer tablets (pazopanib, olaparib, lenvatinib, sunitinib, or palbociclib) and gradually increasing the dose based on tolerability can lead to better treatment utility compared to the standard recommended starting dose.

The study has two arms: the control group receives the standard starting dose as per the drug label, with dose adjustments for toxicity as needed, while the intervention group starts with the lowest dose described in the drug label and has the dose escalated every two weeks if tolerated well. The primary outcome measure is the feasibility of investigating the lower starting dose approach, assessed by the percentage of eligible patients willing to participate, the percentage completing the first 12 weeks, and the percentage of data points successfully collected during this period. Secondary outcomes include overall treatment utility,

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized controlled study evaluating the efficacy and safety of preoperative short-course radiation followed by envafolimab (an anti-PD-L1 antibody) plus CAPEOX (capecitabine and oxaliplatin) chemotherapy in patients with microsatellite stable (MSS) locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma.

The study aims to assess the pathologic complete response (pCR) rate as the primary outcome after neoadjuvant treatment followed by total mesorectal excision surgery. Secondary outcomes include tumor regression grade, overall survival, progression-free survival, treatment-related adverse events, surgical complications, and quality of life.

Eligible patients are aged 18 years or older with locally advanced rectal adenocarcinoma (cT2-4a N+, cT3/T4a N0) that is MSS and within 12 cm from the anus. Patients will be randomized to receive either neoadjuvant chemoradiotherapy combined with envafolimab plus CAPEOX followed by surgery or neoadjuvant chemo

This is a two-stage clinical trial evaluating the efficacy, safety, pharmacokinetics, pharmacodynamics, and immunogenicity of various doses of levilimab (an anti-IL-6R monoclonal antibody) in healthy subjects and subjects with active rheumatoid arthritis (RA).

Stage 1 is an open-label, non-randomized study in healthy subjects receiving single intravenous or subcutaneous doses of levilimab at ascending dose levels. The primary outcome is the safety profile.

Stage 2 is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study in subjects with active RA resistant to methotrexate. Subjects receive levilimab plus methotrexate or placebo plus methotrexate for 24 weeks, followed by an open-label extension to 52 weeks. The primary outcome is the proportion of subjects achieving low disease activity (DAS28-ESR <3.2) at week 24. Secondary outcomes include remission rates, ACR responses, pharmacokinetics, quality of life, and radiographic progression.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety and

This is a randomized, double-blind, crossover clinical trial investigating the efficacy of white kidney bean extract on oral glucose tolerance test. The study involved healthy adults aged 25-45 years with a BMI of 24. Participants were randomly assigned to either receive white kidney bean extract (Wonderlab Product) or placebo (maltodextrin) in two phases separated by a 72-hour washout period. The primary outcome measure was the change in blood glucose levels based on the oral glucose tolerance test after intervention with the white kidney bean extract or placebo. Secondary outcome measures included changes in fasting blood glucose levels. The study aimed to evaluate the potential of white kidney bean extract in supporting glucose tolerance and management.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the implementation of evidence-based facility and community interventions to reduce the treatment gap for depression. The trial has two arms:

1. Facility Model: Existing healthcare workers (counsellors) within health centres will be trained to deliver the Healthy Activity Program (HAP), a manualized psychological treatment based on behavioral activation, to individuals with moderately severe or severe depression.

2. Community Model: In addition to the facility model, this arm will receive community intervention strategies delivered by community volunteers (Sangathis) to enhance demand for HAP, promote engagement, and provide continuing care through home visits and engaging family members.

The primary outcomes are contact coverage (proportion screening positive for depression) and effectiveness coverage (mean depression severity) at 3 months. Secondary outcomes include sustained effectiveness, remission, response to treatment, costs, disability, depression awareness, perceived social support, treatment completion, and behavioral activation measured at 3 and 6 months.

The trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of integrating community-based strategies with facility-based care in reducing the treatment gap for depression in the study area.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the acute and chronic effects of low-intensity resistance training with and without blood flow restriction, performed in normoxic (normal oxygen levels) and hypoxic (low oxygen levels) conditions, on various physiological and performance measures in physically active adults.

The study involves five parallel groups:

1. Low-intensity resistance training in normoxia
2. High-intensity resistance training in normoxia
3. Low-intensity resistance training with blood flow restriction in normoxia
4. Low-intensity resistance training in hypoxia
5. Low-intensity resistance training with blood flow restriction in hypoxia

The primary outcomes include force output, one-repetition maximum, maximum number of repetitions, countermovement jump height and power output, catecholamine response, muscle stiffness, and muscle thickness. Secondary outcomes include perception of pain, perception of effort, and blood pressure.

The study aims to evaluate the effects of these different training modalities on muscle strength, endurance, power, hormonal responses, muscle properties, and subjective measures of effort and pain. The findings may provide insights into the potential benefits and mechanisms of low-intensity training with blood flow restriction and hypoxic exposure

This is a Phase II, single-arm, open-label clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of subcutaneous mosunetuzumab monotherapy in patients with follicular lymphoma who have relapsed or progressed within 24 months of starting first-line treatment (POD24). The primary objective is to evaluate progression-free survival at 2 years. Secondary objectives include overall response rate, complete response rate, duration of response, time to next treatment, overall survival, safety/tolerability, rate of transformation to higher-grade lymphoma, and quality of life. Eligible patients will receive subcutaneous mosunetuzumab for up to 17 cycles, with response assessed after 8 cycles. The trial aims to evaluate if mosunetuzumab, a bispecific T-cell engaging antibody, can provide improved outcomes compared to standard salvage regimens in this high-risk POD24 population.

This is a Phase I/II clinical trial evaluating the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of combining two drugs, PLX2853 (a BRD4 inhibitor) and trametinib (a MEK inhibitor), in the treatment of advanced uveal melanoma.

The primary objectives are:
- Phase I: Determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) and recommended Phase II dose of the drug combination.
- Phase II: Evaluate if the combination demonstrates clinical activity, with a best response rate of at least 25% compared to a historical rate of 10%.

Secondary objectives include assessing overall response rate, progression-free survival, overall survival, adverse event profile, and pharmacokinetics of the drug combination.

Eligible patients have advanced, unresectable or metastatic uveal melanoma, with measurable disease per RECIST criteria. The study involves oral administration of PLX2853 and trametinib, along with CT/MRI imaging and blood collection for biomarker analysis.

Key eligibility criteria include age ≥18 years, ECOG performance status 0-2, adequate organ function, and no prior treatment with B

The ASCERTAIN study is a 2-arm, multicenter, phase IV, randomized, open-label study evaluating the implementation and utility of a new primary care model compared to usual care in patients with atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease (ASCVD) or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated LDL-C levels. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of a new model of care implementation strategy involving patient engagement through SMS reminders, nurse-led support calls, and guideline-directed management therapy (GDMT) education for general practitioners (GPs), compared to usual care with GDMT education alone. The primary outcome measure is the effect on LDL-C concentration at baseline and day 180. Secondary outcomes include LDL-C concentration at day 365. The study will enroll approximately 600 participants aged ≥18 years with a history of ASCVD or ASCVD-risk equivalents and elevated LDL-C levels (≥1.8 mmol/L for ASCVD patients or ≥2.0 mmol/L for ASCVD-risk equivalents) across 20 sites

This is a randomized, controlled, single-blinded study comparing the efficacy of three different ultrasound-guided regional anesthesia techniques (erector spinae block, thoracic paravertebral block, and quadratus lumborum block) in patients undergoing open renal surgeries under general anesthesia. The study aims to evaluate the total morphine requirements within 24 hours postoperatively as the primary outcome measure. Eligible participants are adults aged 21-65 years with ASA physical status I or II, scheduled for elective open renal surgeries. The study involves four groups: erector spinae block group, thoracic paravertebral block group, quadratus lumborum block group, and a control group receiving intravenous morphine before skin incision. The study is being conducted at Al-Azhar University Hospital, with patient recruitment planned from February 2022 to January 2023.

This is a mixed-methods study aimed at evaluating the musculoskeletal health and its impact on adult survivors of hematological cancers (lymphoma and leukemia) who are 5 or more years post-treatment. The study involves administering questionnaires and conducting interviews to assess the prevalence of musculoskeletal conditions, fracture risk, sarcopenia, frailty, and quality of life in these survivors. The questionnaire component will measure these outcomes using validated tools, while the interview component will explore the survivors' experiences with musculoskeletal health, care, and information provision. The study aims to describe the musculoskeletal health status of this population and identify potential risk factors associated with poor musculoskeletal health outcomes. Participants will be stratified based on gender, age at diagnosis, and years since cancer treatment completion.

This is a Phase 2 basket study evaluating the efficacy and safety of disitamab vedotin, an antibody-drug conjugate targeting HER2, in adult patients with previously treated, locally advanced unresectable or metastatic solid tumors that express HER2. The study includes four cohorts: head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC), ovarian cancer, and endometrial cancer. Eligible patients must have progressed on prior standard therapies and have measurable disease. The primary outcome is confirmed objective response rate per RECIST v1.1. Secondary outcomes include adverse events, dose alterations, disease control rate, duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, pharmacokinetics, and incidence of anti-drug antibodies. Disitamab vedotin is administered intravenously every 2 weeks until disease progression or unacceptable toxicity.

This study aims to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of using in-vehicle driving assessments and neurocognitive tests to assess driving safety and behaviors in older adults who have experienced delirium and cognitive impairment after an intensive care unit (ICU) stay. The study will enroll 24 participants aged 55 and older who have had an ICU stay with delirium and were active drivers prior to hospitalization. Participants will undergo neurocognitive assessments and have their driving data collected through in-vehicle sensors over a 6-month period after hospital discharge. The primary outcome measure is total driving time, while secondary outcomes include depression, executive function, attention, working memory, processing speed, health-related quality of life, anxiety, employment, driving trips, and driving behaviors. The study also involves stakeholder advisory panels to gather insights on the priorities and data presentation needs for driving assessments in this population. The goal is to develop an evidence-based, in-vehicle driving assessment system to provide actionable data and rehabilitation strategies tailored to ICU survivors.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of a brief acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT) workshop on psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, valued living, weight self-stigma, body image, emotional eating, physical activity, diet quality, and body weight in women with obesity. The study aims to recruit 70 women aged 40-70 years with a BMI > 30 kg/m2. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group receiving a 4-hour ACT workshop focused on developing healthy lifestyle behaviors or a waitlist control group. Outcomes will be assessed at baseline, 1 week, and 1 month post-intervention. The primary outcomes are changes in psychological flexibility, distress tolerance, and valued living, while secondary outcomes include changes in weight self-stigma, body image, emotional eating, physical activity, diet quality, and body weight. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of a brief ACT intervention for promoting healthy behaviors and psychological well-being in women with obesity.

This is a one-arm prospective observational clinical study investigating a drug holiday treatment approach based on minimal residual disease (MRD) detection for high-risk gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST) patients who have completed 3 years of adjuvant imatinib therapy after surgery. The study aims to evaluate the value of MRD detection in monitoring postoperative recurrence, investigate the effect of the drug holiday approach on disease recurrence and patient survival, and explore whether it can delay the occurrence of drug-resistant mutations.

Key aspects:

- Participants: High-risk GIST patients aged 18-75 who have completed 3 years of adjuvant imatinib therapy after surgery and achieved disease control, with negative baseline circulating tumor DNA (ctDNA) and no primary imatinib resistance mutations.

- Intervention: Patients will stop imatinib treatment (drug holiday) and undergo regular monitoring with MRD detection and imaging.

- Primary outcomes: Progression-free survival, drug re-use rate, and drug retreatment response rate within 3 years of entering the drug holiday.

- Secondary outcomes: Overall survival

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of Dohsa hou exercises on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome aged 6-12 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group receiving Dohsa hou exercises or the control group receiving standard treatment protocol. The Dohsa hou exercise group will receive 1-hour therapy sessions, 3 times a week for 6 weeks, including instruction, skill practice, and closing activities. The control group will receive standard treatment including soft tissue massage, task-specific training, bicycle training, and aerobic exercises for the same duration. The primary outcome measures are the Trunk Impairment Scale, assessing balance and coordination in sitting and standing, and the Timed Up and Go Test, evaluating mobility and fall risk. The study aims to compare the effects of Dohsa hou exercises, a psychomotor therapy using bodily movements and relaxation, with standard treatment on functional mobility in children with Down syndrome.

This is a randomized controlled trial aimed at increasing physical activity levels and physical literacy among 3rd-5th grade students from low-income schools. The study involves two groups: an intervention group receiving the Rising New York Road Runners (RNYRR) program, and a control group following standard school procedures. The RNYRR program is a school-based physical education curriculum with a family engagement component, designed to build competence, confidence, and motivation for physical activity. The primary outcomes are baseline and end-point physical activity levels measured by accelerometers. Secondary outcomes include baseline and end-point assessments of fundamental movement skills in running, locomotion, object control, and balance. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the RNYRR program on children's physical literacy and physical activity, and examine potential differences by sex or weight status. It also aims to test whether changes in physical literacy mediate changes in physical activity.

This is a Phase III, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled, parallel-group study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of BI 456906 (survodutide) administered subcutaneously once weekly compared to placebo in Japanese patients with obesity. The study has a 76-week treatment period. The primary outcomes are the percentage change in body weight from baseline to Week 76 and the achievement of body weight reduction ≥5% from baseline to Week 76. Secondary outcomes include additional body weight reduction thresholds, changes in anthropometric measures, blood pressure, eating behavior, glycemic parameters, lipid profile, liver enzymes, liver fat content, and body composition assessed by MRI. The study includes patients aged ≥18 years with a BMI ≥35 kg/m² or ≥27 kg/m² with obesity-related comorbidities such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension, or dyslipidemia. Patients are randomized to receive either BI 456906 3.6 mg, BI 456906 6.0 mg, or placebo once weekly.

This is a prospective cohort study that aims to evaluate gastric volume in pediatric patients undergoing adenotonsillectomy surgery using ultrasound. The study will include patients aged 1-18 years, ASA I-III, undergoing elective adenotonsillectomy. Gastric volume will be assessed using ultrasound in the right lateral position preoperatively, after intubation, and before extubation. The primary outcome is gastric volume (ml/kg) during the operation. Secondary outcomes include cross-sectional area of the stomach at different time points, postoperative nausea and vomiting, blood volume in the suction system, and duration of surgery. The study aims to compare the gastric volumes with values considered risky for aspiration and evaluate the potential risk factors for increased gastric volume and postoperative nausea and vomiting in this patient population.

This is a randomized controlled study investigating the effect of pituitrin (a medication containing vasopressin and oxytocin) on postoperative outcomes in patients with pulmonary hypertension undergoing cardiac surgery. The study aims to determine if pituitrin can improve prognosis and reduce complications in this patient population.

Patients aged 18-80 years with pulmonary hypertension scheduled for elective cardiac surgery involving cardiopulmonary bypass will be randomly assigned to receive either pituitrin or placebo (normal saline) intravenously during and after surgery. 

The primary outcome is a composite of mortality or severe postoperative complications (stroke, prolonged ventilation, infection, reoperation, acute renal failure) within 30 days after surgery. Secondary outcomes include incidence of various complications like infection, septic shock, duration of ventilation, time to hemodynamic stability, need for vasoactive drugs, acute myocardial infarction, arrhythmias, pulmonary embolism, respiratory distress, delirium, need for renal replacement therapy, ICU readmission, length of stay, and levels of antidiuretic

This is a 12-week, open-label feasibility study of a pragmatic, two-arm parallel-group, randomized controlled trial comparing home initiation of noninvasive positive pressure ventilation (NiPPV) to standard in-hospital polysomnography (PSG) initiation in children with medical complexity aged 5-17 years newly prescribed NiPPV.

The primary outcomes are recruitment and retention rates, proportion of eligible patients randomized, and proportion of patients that crossover based on safety criteria. Secondary outcomes include mean nightly NiPPV usage, proxy and self-reported psychological scales, caregiver sense of mastery, patient/family study experience and preference, and differences in NiPPV settings between home titration and PSG titration.

In the intervention arm, NiPPV settings are titrated during an awake trial, then further titrated at home guided by telemonitoring, oximetries, and symptoms over 12 weeks, with a PSG at 12 weeks. In the control arm, NiPPV is initiated during a one-night in-hospital PSG with setting changes allowed at follow-ups

This is a single-blind randomized clinical trial investigating the effects of dry needling on vertical jump performance in female volleyball players with latent myofascial trigger points in the gastrocnemius muscle. The study involves two groups: an intervention group receiving dry needling treatment and a control group without intervention. The primary outcome measure is the counter-movement jump performance, assessed at four time points: before intervention, immediately after intervention, 72 hours after intervention, and 7 days after intervention. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of dry needling on vertical jump performance in athletes with latent trigger points.

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the clinical features of refractory gastrointestinal Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP) and the clinical outcome of using mycophenolate mofetil (MMF) in these patients. The study included children aged 3 to 18 years with refractory gastrointestinal HSP, defined as involvement of the digestive tract with acute abdominal colic, intussusception, or gastrointestinal bleeding, and lack of response to intravenous corticosteroids. Patients received MMF treatment, and the primary outcome measure was the incidence of abdominal pain, hematemesis, and bloody stools over 6 months. Secondary outcomes included the count of red blood cells in stool over 6 months. The study was an open-label, single-arm trial with no control group.

This is a Phase II/III open-label, single-arm interventional study investigating the safety, feasibility, and preliminary efficacy of adjunctive, midline prefrontal, lower intensity, shorter session, EEG-enhanced, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (eTMS) for chronic trauma and stressor-related disorders (TSRD) in veterans. The study has two stages: Stage 1 will enroll 30 participants to assess safety and feasibility, with primary outcomes being the number of participants with device-related serious adverse events and the rate of participants completing 80% of scheduled eTMS sessions over 6 weeks. Secondary outcome is the mean change in mental component scores of the Veterans RAND 36-item health survey at 6 weeks. If safety benchmarks are met, Stage 2 will enroll an additional 270 participants using randomization to multiple baselines for efficacy analyses. The eTMS intervention involves approximately 2000 pulses per session at 50% or less of motor threshold, calibrated to the participant's resonant alpha frequency, given over 12 minutes daily for 30 sessions as an adjunct to standard TS

This is a retrospective, open-label, multi-institutional, single-arm study investigating the combination of radiotherapy (3D conformal or intensity-modulated) and EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitors (TKIs) like gefitinib, erlotinib, osimertinib, and afatinib in patients with stage III EGFR-mutant lung cancer. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), defined as the time from treatment initiation to documented disease progression or death, measured over 2 years. Eligible patients are aged 18-80 years, have an ECOG performance status ≤2, and have not received surgery or chemotherapy. The radiotherapy dose is 54-66 Gy in 27-33 fractions, combined with the respective oral TKI until disease progression or intolerance.

This clinical trial aims to identify the specific species of Streptococci bacteria responsible for acute head and neck infections. The study will collect samples from patients over 18 years old suffering from acute head and neck infections caused by Streptococci at Northampton General Hospital. The primary outcome measure is the identification of Streptococci species through DNA analysis and biochemical testing over a 4-year period. Secondary outcome measures include patient characteristics (age, sex, infection site), clinical outcomes (length of hospital stay, antibiotic treatment, diabetic diagnosis), and their association with the identified Streptococci species. The study aims to determine common traits and patterns in acute head and neck infections caused by Streptococci bacteria.

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of functional magnetic stimulation (FMS) and pelvic floor muscle training (PFMT) on pelvic floor muscle function, urinary incontinence symptoms, and quality of life in women with stress urinary incontinence.

The study included 48 women aged 29-49 years with stress urinary incontinence for at least 4 weeks. Participants were randomly divided into two groups: Group I (n=24) received FMS, and Group II (n=24) underwent a PFMT program. Assessments were conducted before and after the 6-week intervention period.

The primary outcome measures were the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Short Form (ICIQ-SF) for assessing urinary incontinence symptoms and quality of life, the Incontinence Impact Questionnaire-Short Form (IIQ-7) for evaluating the impact of incontinence on quality of life, and perineometry for assessing pelvic floor muscle strength and endurance.

The study aimed to determine the effectiveness of FMS and PFMT in improving pelvic floor muscle function, reducing

This clinical trial aims to optimize the selection and treatment outcomes of biologic therapies for patients with psoriatic arthritis (PsA) and seronegative rheumatoid arthritis (RA). The study involves phenotyping of synovial immune and stromal cells using single-cell protein and transcriptomics (CITE-Seq) and spatial transcriptomics of synovial tissue samples from various patient groups, including:

1. Psoriasis (PsO) patients at risk of developing PsA
2. Treatment-naive PsA patients
3. PsA patients resistant to TNF inhibitors
4. PsA patients resistant to IL-17 inhibitors
5. PsA patients in remission induced by TNF inhibitors
6. PsA patients in remission induced by IL-17 inhibitors
7. PsA patients resistant to conventional disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (c-DMARDs)
8. RA patients resistant to c-DMARDs

The primary outcome measures include achieving minimal disease activity status, development of PsA (for PsO patients with arthralgia), and rem

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study investigating the use of artificial tears to prevent nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO) in patients receiving radioactive iodine therapy for thyroid cancer. The study has two arms: an experimental arm where participants self-administer artificial tears (methylcellulose) according to a specific schedule for 4 days following radioactive iodine therapy, and a control arm with no intervention. The primary outcome measure is the incidence of post-radiotherapy NLDO, determined by tear duct irrigation by an ophthalmologist, over a 2-year period. The study aims to evaluate whether the use of artificial tears can prevent NLDO, a potential complication of radioactive iodine therapy for thyroid cancer.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase II clinical trial investigating the use of atorvastatin for preventing disease recurrence and metastasis in patients with resected high-risk stage IIA cutaneous melanoma.

The primary objective is to compare recurrence-free survival (RFS) between patients treated with atorvastatin versus placebo. Secondary objectives include comparing distant metastasis-free survival (DMFS) and overall survival (OS) between the two treatment arms. An exploratory objective is to assess the clinical utility of gene expression profiling in melanoma.

Eligible patients will be randomized to receive either atorvastatin or placebo orally once daily for up to 5 years, along with regular computed tomography (CT) and/or magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) monitoring. The primary outcome is RFS, defined as the time from randomization to any recurrence (local, regional, or distant) or death. Secondary outcomes include DMFS and OS.

The study aims to evaluate the potential benefit of atorvastatin, a statin medication, in improving outcomes for patients with high-risk melanoma after surgical resection.

This clinical trial aims to test the effectiveness of three implementation strategies (training, coaching, and facilitation) in supporting outpatient clinics to deliver timely care for pregnant individuals with severe hypertension. The study involves 20 prenatal care clinics in central North Carolina, divided into three cohorts. The clinics will receive a multi-component implementation strategy called ACHIEVE, which includes training on an Outpatient Hypertension (O-HTN) bundle, facilitation of workflow changes, and simulations of severe hypertension cases. The primary outcomes measure the fidelity to blood pressure measurement technique and delivery of patient education on hypertension. Secondary outcomes assess the recognition and response to simulated and actual episodes of severe hypertension. The clinics will be evaluated before, during, and after the implementation phase to determine the impact of the ACHIEVE intervention on improving care for pregnant individuals with severe hypertension.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of three text-messaging programs for reducing hazardous drinking among older adults (aged 50-85). The study aims to compare the effects of (A) loss-framed messaging (focusing on consequences of hazardous drinking), (B) gain-framed messaging (focusing on benefits of reducing drinking), and (C) combined loss and gain-framed messaging.

The study will recruit 150 older adults with hazardous drinking levels. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of the three text-messaging conditions for 8 weeks. They will receive daily text messages tailored to their assigned condition, along with brief normative feedback on their drinking levels at baseline.

The primary outcomes are weekly sum of standard drinks and heavy drinking days, measured at baseline, week 4, week 8, and week 16. Secondary outcomes include adherence to daily and weekly drinking assessments via text messages and willingness to continue the program for another 8 weeks.

The study will explore how the effects of the text-messaging conditions are impacted by gender and age through moderation analysis. The findings will provide insights into the effectiveness of gain and loss-framed messaging for

This is a clinical trial evaluating the safety and efficacy of the radiotracer [18F]-Fluselenamyl for PET imaging of beta-amyloid in Alzheimer's disease. The primary objectives are:

1. To determine the safety of [18F]-Fluselenamyl by assessing its biodistribution, kinetics, and calculating human dosimetry in healthy volunteers through whole-body PET/CT scans.

2. To assess the sensitivity of [18F]-Fluselenamyl in imaging amyloid beta in participants with mild cognitive impairment or Alzheimer's dementia, and compare its performance with the established tracer [11C]-PIB.

The study involves two groups: healthy participants and participants with mild cognitive impairment. Both groups will receive a single intravenous injection of [18F]-Fluselenamyl (10 mCi ± 20%) and undergo PET/CT scans. The healthy group will also receive [11C]-PIB for comparison.

Key eligibility criteria include being 18 years or older, having Alzheimer's disease or being a healthy volunteer, and

This clinical trial aims to investigate the long-term effect of transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) in patients with primary progressive aphasia (PPA). The study has two parallel arms: an active comparator group receiving active TMS over the left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex along with language therapy, and a sham comparator group receiving sham TMS and language therapy. The primary outcome measure is changes in brain metabolism assessed by FDG-PET imaging at 0 and 6 months. Secondary outcome measures include changes in spontaneous language, language assessments (Mini-Linguistic State Examination, trained and untrained word accuracy), daily living activities, and neuropsychiatric symptoms, evaluated at 0, 3, and 6 months. The study includes adults diagnosed with PPA, with language as the most prominent symptom, and excludes individuals with severe dementia, history of epilepsy, or other contraindications for TMS.

This is a Phase 2a, double-blind, randomized, placebo-controlled trial investigating the effects of methylprednisolone, an immunosuppressant drug, on cognitive deficits in patients with post-COVID-19 syndrome (PCS). The trial aims to evaluate if methylprednisolone can improve memory satisfaction, as measured by the Multifactorial Memory Questionnaire (MMQ), in PCS patients with suspected autoimmune involvement compared to placebo.

The study involves two parallel arms: an active comparator group receiving methylprednisolone and a placebo comparator group. Participants will be randomly assigned in a 1:1 ratio to receive either methylprednisolone (including a tapering phase) or placebo for 6 weeks, followed by an additional 6 weeks of open-label methylprednisolone treatment after a 6-week pause. The primary outcome is the improvement in memory satisfaction measured by the MMQ at 8 weeks. Secondary outcomes include long-term memory satisfaction, memory ability, memory strategy, neurocognitive functions, quality of life, physical and mental fatigue, mood, and safety

This is a clinical trial investigating the effects of an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols on malnutrition related to inflammation. The study aims to analyze the aetiological factors of malnutrition, specifically the role of inflammation and oral intake.

Key aspects:

1. Participants: Adults (≥18 years) diagnosed with disease-related malnutrition (DRM) based on GLIM criteria, with an inflammatory component (CRP >3 mg/dL), and eligible for medical nutritional treatment.

2. Intervention: Participants will receive an oral nutritional supplement rich in omega-3 and olive oil polyphenols, along with a physical exercise program.

3. Primary Outcomes: Blood biochemistry data, including albumin, prealbumin, C-reactive protein, ferritin, neutrophils, lymphocytes, and platelets, will be measured over 3 consecutive months.

4. Secondary Outcomes: Bioelectrical impedance data (body composition), functional parameters (mobility and grip strength), oral intake (energy, macronutrients, fatty acids, fiber), and malnut

This is a randomized, parallel-group study evaluating the impact of providing financial support for healthy foods and free home delivery on glycemic control and other outcomes in food-insecure adults with type 2 diabetes. The study has two arms: 1) an intervention arm receiving 6 months of monetary support to purchase healthy foods like fruits and vegetables through Instacart, along with free home delivery and waived service fees for up to 4 orders per month, and 2) a control arm receiving only free home delivery and waived service fees for up to 4 orders per month through Instacart for 6 months. The primary outcome is change in glycosylated hemoglobin levels at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include glycemic control at 12 months, hospitalizations/ED visits, food security, nutrition security, dietary habits, diabetes-related quality of life, and readiness to change dietary habits. Assessments occur at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months. The study aims to evaluate if providing financial assistance for healthy foods improves glycemic control and other outcomes in a food-insecure, high-risk population with type 2 diabetes

This is a four-arm, double-blind, randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the effect of prolonged evaporation time of solvent in two universal adhesives on the quality of composite resin restorations for non-carious cervical lesions.

The study involves 140 non-carious cervical lesions divided into four groups:

1. Experimental group 1 (35 lesions): Alcohol/water-based universal adhesive (Scotchbond Universal Plus) with 25 seconds solvent evaporation time. 

2. Experimental group 2 (35 lesions): Acetone-based universal adhesive (Gluma Universal Bond) with 25 seconds solvent evaporation time.

3. Control group 1 (35 lesions): Alcohol/water-based universal adhesive with 5 seconds solvent evaporation time. 

4. Control group 2 (35 lesions): Acetone-based universal adhesive with 5 seconds solvent evaporation time.

The primary outcome is retention of restorations measured by World Dental Federation criteria over 24 months.

This is a Phase 2/3 randomized, double-blinded, parallel controlled trial evaluating the immunogenicity, safety and efficacy of heterologous booster doses of COVID-19 mRNA vaccines (bivalent) in previously vaccinated subjects against COVID-19. The study has two phases:

Phase 2 (200 participants ≥18 years):
- Group 1 (n=100): Single 25μg dose of SWIM816 mRNA vaccine  
- Group 2 (n=100): Single 25μg dose of SW-BIC-213 mRNA vaccine

Phase 3 (600 participants ≥18 years):  
- Group 1 (n=300): Single 25μg dose of SWIM816 mRNA vaccine
- Group 2 (n=300): Single 30μg dose of Pfizer bivalent mRNA vaccine  

Primary outcomes include geometric mean titers of neutralizing antibodies against Omicron and other SARS-CoV-2 strains at different timepoints, non-inferiority analysis comparing SWIM816 to

This is a cross-sectional study investigating the relationship between ergonomic exposure, physical capacity, work ability, and musculoskeletal pain in workers aged 55-70 years in the municipality of Esbjerg, Denmark. The study aims to provide knowledge on the consequences of high physical workload on the musculoskeletal system in older workers. The study population consists of 336 citizens divided into 12 groups stratified by gender, age (<60 years, 60-64 years, and >64 years), and occupational group (white-collar or blue-collar). The study involves physical tests, questionnaires, and a blood test to assess various outcomes, including work ability (measured by the Work Ability Index), height, weight, body mass index, waist-to-hip ratio, blood pressure, pressure pain threshold, temperature sensitivity, temporal summation, conditioned pain modulation, physical activity (measured by the International Physical Activity Questionnaire), musculoskeletal pain (measured by the Nordic Musculoskeletal Questionnaire), ergonomic exposure, functional tests (sit-to-stand, balance, stair climb), maximal aerobic capacity, i

This is a phase I dose-escalation study evaluating the safety and feasibility of using autologous T cells genetically engineered to express L1CAM-specific chimeric antigen receptors (CAR) for the treatment of locally advanced or metastatic small cell neuroendocrine prostate cancer.

Key aspects:

- Patients undergo leukapheresis to collect T cells, which are then genetically modified to express L1CAM-specific CARs (CAR-T cells).
- Patients receive lymphodepleting chemotherapy (cyclophosphamide/fludarabine or bendamustine) followed by infusion of the CAR-T cell product.
- Based on response and CAR-T cell persistence, patients may receive additional lymphodepletion and CAR-T cell infusion within 6-24 weeks.
- Primary outcomes are incidence of adverse events and dose-limiting toxicities.
- Secondary outcomes include objective response rate, radiographic progression-free survival, and overall survival.
- Patients undergo various imaging studies (CT, bone scan, x-ray) and biospecimen collection throughout the study.
- The

This is a before and after study comparing the safety and efficacy of Whipple over the splenic artery (WOTSA) versus total pancreatectomy (TP) as treatments for pancreatic ductal cell adenocarcinoma (PDAC). The study group consisted of 40 consecutive patients who underwent WOTSA, while the historical control group had 30 patients who underwent TP. The primary outcomes measured were clinicopathological characteristics, including remnant pancreatic volume before and 1 week after surgery. Secondary outcomes included remnant pancreatic volume, physiological parameters, postoperative chemotherapy, and follow-up at 1 month post-surgery. The study aimed to assess if WOTSA, a new technique preserving the pancreatic tail and spleen by excising the splenic vessels, could replace TP for certain PDAC cases traditionally requiring TP. Eligibility criteria included PDAC patients, excluding those with distant metastases or undergoing palliative pancreatectomy.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of providing breastfeeding education to fathers via WhatsApp messaging application during the postpartum period on breastfeeding outcomes. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-group, double-blind trial with four groups: two experimental groups receiving breastfeeding education and two control groups without intervention.

The experimental groups (Training group 1 and Training group 2) will receive breastfeeding education for fathers through WhatsApp messages for 39 days, starting from the 3rd postpartum day. The control groups (Control group 1 and Control group 2) will not receive any intervention.

The primary outcome measures are the Breastfeeding Support Scale, which evaluates fathers' support for breastfeeding, and the Partner Breastfeeding Influence Scale, which measures mothers' social motivations for breastfeeding and spousal support. These scales will be administered to fathers and mothers, respectively, on the 3rd postpartum day.

Secondary outcome measures include the same scales administered on the 42nd postpartum day.

The study aims to assess the impact of providing breastfeeding education to fathers on

This is a non-interventional study investigating biomarker testing and treatment patterns among patients with PIK3CA mutation in advanced breast cancer. The study aims to evaluate the following key aspects:

1. The number of patients with PIK3CA mutations and the characteristics of these patients, including hormone receptor and HER2 status.

2. The timing of PIK3CA evaluation relative to breast cancer diagnosis, advanced disease diagnosis, and initiation of first-line treatment for advanced disease.

3. The relationship between PIK3CA evaluation and CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment, including the time from progression on CDK4/6 inhibitor to PIK3CA evaluation.

4. Details of the PIK3CA evaluation process, such as the year of evaluation, test results, type of biopsy, tissue sample source, and analytical methods used.

5. Patient characteristics, including age at advanced diagnosis, cancer stage, metastatic sites, performance status, height, weight, and body mass index.

6. Treatment patterns, including the number of patients per line of treatment, time from advanced diagnosis to treatment initiation, systemic therapies used, treatment sequences, and supportive treatments.

The

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of melatonin on sleep spindles in children with autism spectrum disorder (ASD) aged 12-18 years. The study is designed as a single-group, open-label trial. Participants will receive a 5mg melatonin gummy 30 minutes before bedtime for two consecutive nights. The primary outcome measure is the change in sleep spindle density during non-rapid eye movement (NREM) sleep between baseline and melatonin nights, measured using a portable EEG device. The secondary outcome measure is the change in sleep quality between baseline and melatonin nights. The study will be conducted over five nights of sleep within two weeks. Participants with various conditions, such as pregnancy, substance abuse, chronic medical conditions affecting sleep, neurological disorders, and known genetic causes of ASD, will be excluded from the study.

This is a non-randomized, open-label, single-arm treatment trial evaluating the combination of trastuzumab and pertuzumab in adult, teenage/young adult, and pediatric patients with cancers harboring HER2 amplification or activating mutations. The primary objectives are to assess the objective response rate and durable clinical benefit rate. Secondary objectives include evaluating duration of response, progression-free survival, overall survival, safety, and quality of life measures. Eligible patients must have a confirmed malignancy with HER2 amplification or activating mutation, be at least 12 years old, and meet certain organ function criteria. The trial plans to enroll 30 evaluable patients, with the potential to expand specific cohorts showing promising activity. Patients will receive trastuzumab and pertuzumab until disease progression, unacceptable toxicity, or withdrawal of consent, with response assessments performed regularly. The goal is to translate positive findings to provide new treatment options for rare adult, pediatric, and teenage/young adult cancers.

This clinical trial aims to study the etiology of persistent velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) in children aged 7-12 years with operated velopalatine clefts by analyzing their velopharyngeal motor skills using static and dynamic MRI. The study involves four experimental groups: children with operated isolated labial cleft, isolated operated velopalatal cleft with severe VPI and normal velum anatomy, isolated operated velopalatal cleft with soft VPI and abnormal velum anatomy, and isolated operated velopalatal cleft with normal anatomy and soft VPI. The participants will undergo real-time MRI scanning in a supine position, with measures taken for the ratio between pharynx diameter at rest and during phonation, closure distance between the velar knee and posterior pharyngeal wall, and the distance between the velar knee and posterior pharyngeal wall. The primary outcomes are related to these measurements, which will be used to investigate the causes of persistent VPI in children with operated velopalatine clefts.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of a remotely-delivered exercise training program on cognition and mobility in older adults (aged 50 years or older) with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study aims to evaluate the feasibility and efficacy of a home-based exercise intervention program for improving cognitive function, physical function, and walking ability in this population.

The study involves two intervention groups:

1. Aerobic and Resistance Exercise Program (GEMS program): A 16-week home-based, remotely supported aerobic and resistance exercise training intervention delivered via telerehabilitation. Participants will perform moderate-intensity walking and resistance training exercises targeting various muscle groups.

2. Flexibility and Stretching Program (FLEX-MS program): A 16-week home-based, remotely supported stretching program emphasizing flexibility and range of motion, serving as an active comparator.

The primary outcomes include cognitive function (assessed by Brief International Cognitive Assessment for Multiple Sclerosis and National Institute of Health Toolbox cognitive tests), physical function (Short Physical Performance Battery), lower-extremity function (30-Second Sit to Stand Test), functional mobility (Timed Up and Go

This is a pilot, non-interventional study aimed at measuring the clinical and biological effects of using the oXiris hemofiltration membrane in critically ill patients with vasoplegic shock requiring hemodynamic support and extrarenal purification. The study involves collecting additional blood samples at baseline, 24 hours, and 72 hours during oXiris hemofiltration treatment to analyze the clearance of vasoactive metabolites, including angiotensins (I, II, III, IV, and intermediate peptides), regulatory enzymes (renin, angiotensin-converting enzymes), and endothelial permeability markers. The primary outcome measure is a 50% reduction in vasoinotropic score within 24 hours of initiating oXiris treatment. Secondary outcomes include the evolution of vasoinotropic score up to 72 hours, quantitative determination of angiotensins and regulatory enzymes, clearance of endothelial permeability markers, markers of sepsis-induced immunosuppression, and 90-day mortality. The study aims to evaluate the hemodynamic stabilization and clearance of vasoactive metabolites with the oXiris

This is a randomized controlled study comparing two different surgical techniques for urinary bladder dissection during total laparoscopic hysterectomy in patients with previous cesarean section. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of the central (medial) versus lateral approach for bladder dissection.

The study involves two parallel arms:

Group A (central group): A metal catheter is inserted into the bladder, and the bladder is dissected with monopolar scissors with the catheter in place. The posterior leaflet of the broad ligament is opened to the cervix, and the bladder is dissected downwards.

Group B (lateral group): The broad ligament is dissected down until the uterine vascular bundle is identified. The space above these vessels is dissected to reach the lateral margins of the cervix, and the bladder is dissected and lifted off from the cervix.

The primary outcome measure is the rate of urinary bladder injury during dissection. Secondary outcomes include operative time, amount of blood loss, and late urological complications such as genitourinary fistula and ureteric injury.

The study aims to determine which approach (central or lateral) is more

This is a 6-month observational study investigating the association between the asthma microbiome and disease characteristics, severity, and treatment response. The study includes patients aged 18 years or older who have been referred with possible asthma or have an established diagnosis of asthma. Participants will undergo various assessments, including medical history, symptom questionnaires, pulmonary function testing, and sample collection (blood, oral rinse, nasopharyngeal swab, exhaled breath condensate, stool, and induced sputum) at multiple visits over 6 months. A subset of patients will also undergo bronchoscopy for lower airway sampling. The study aims to describe the microbiome signature across the spectrum of asthma severity, establish any association between asthma phenotype and microbiome signature, and determine whether the microbiome signature can predict treatment response or resistance. The study includes two groups: a biologic-naïve group (50 patients on bronchodilators and/or inhaled corticosteroids) and a biologic group (10 patients suitable for commencing biologic therapy).

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of split-body and full-body resistance training on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players. The study will recruit 28 male cricket players aged 20-30 years without any systemic diseases or recent surgeries/rehabilitation. Participants will be randomly allocated to two groups of 14 each. 

The first group will undergo a split-body resistance training regime, targeting different muscle groups on different days (e.g., arms on day 1, legs on day 2, etc.) for 4 days a week. The second group will perform full-body resistance training twice a week, with all major muscle groups trained in each session.

Both groups will train for 6 weeks. The primary outcome measures are bench press test, leg press test, and 30-second sit-to-stand test, which will be assessed at the end of the 6-week training period. The study aims to compare the effects of the two training regimes on strength and functional performance in amateur cricket players.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of providing breastfeeding education to fathers on breastfeeding, parent-baby bonding, and breastfeeding self-efficacy levels. The study involves three groups: Experimental Group 1 (breastfeeding training given to both mothers and fathers), Experimental Group 2 (breastfeeding training given only to mothers), and a Control Group (no intervention, routine hospital care).

The primary outcomes measured include breastfeeding self-efficacy (for both mothers and fathers), mother-infant bonding, father-infant attachment, and baby evaluation (feeding method, pacifier/bottle use, growth measurements). Data will be collected within the first 24 hours after birth, and at 1 week, 1 month, and 3 months postpartum.

The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-group trial with double-blinding. Eligible participants are parents aged 20 years or older, with the mother being a first-time parent, having a term baby, and access to a smartphone. The intervention involves face-to-face theoretical and practical breastfeeding training, with additional father-supported training for

This is a randomized, double-blind controlled trial investigating the effects of an Amway bundle combination of products on osteoarthritis and sarcopenia. The study involves four participant groups: Bundle Group 1 with Nutrilite Lifestyle, Bundle Group 2 without Nutrilite Lifestyle, Control Group 1, and Control Group 2 with Nutrilite Lifestyle.

The Bundle Groups receive Amway's all-plant protein booster, calcium & magnesium supplements, glucosamine supplements, and electric muscle stimulation (EMS) training. Bundle Group 1 also follows the Nutrilite Lifestyle nutrition guideline.

The Control Groups receive placebos for the supplements and either follow the Nutrilite Lifestyle guideline (Control Group 2) or not (Control Group 1).

The primary outcome measure is the change in Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score from baseline to day 180. Secondary outcomes include changes in WOMAC Questionnaire scores, Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), Chalder Fatigue Scale (CFS), fat and muscle portions measured by Inbody S10, hand and grip strength

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the implementation and effectiveness of an evidence-based approach called Screening, Brief Intervention, and Referral to Treatment (SBIRT) for addressing risky alcohol and substance use among reproductive-aged individuals in family planning clinics. The key aspects of the trial are:

- It is a randomized, parallel-group trial comparing SBIRT to usual care in family planning clinics.
- The SBIRT intervention involves screening for risky alcohol/substance use, providing a brief motivational interviewing intervention, and referring those with severe substance use disorders to treatment.
- The primary outcomes include measures of alcohol/substance use, depression, sexual risk behaviors, and implementation outcomes like fidelity.
- Secondary outcomes include measures of anxiety, quality of life, contraceptive use, sexually transmitted infections, and unintended pregnancy.
- The trial aims to develop an evidence-based, stakeholder-driven SBIRT model for scaling up integrated alcohol/substance use services in reproductive health settings to promote health equity.
- It will be conducted in a large family planning clinic network serving a diverse, structurally disadvantaged population at high risk for alcohol/substance use disorders.

The trial seeks to address

This is a randomized, double-blinded, parallel-group study investigating the effects of habitual consumption of three different herbal tea blends (rhubarb root, senna, and green tea) on gut microbiome, blood lipid markers, and well-being. The primary outcomes include changes in total cholesterol, LDL cholesterol, and HDL cholesterol levels after 21 days of tea consumption. Secondary outcomes measure changes in triglycerides, non-HDL cholesterol, diet quality, BMI, and plasma short-chain fatty acid concentrations. The study involves healthy adult participants who will consume one cup of the assigned tea daily after their last meal/snack for 21 days. Blood samples, stool samples, anthropometric measurements, and dietary data will be collected at baseline and after the intervention period. The study aims to evaluate the potential health benefits of the herbal tea blends, particularly on lipid profiles and gut health.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of adding strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles to knee exercises on pain, function, muscle strength, and knee proprioception in patients with knee osteoarthritis. The study involves two groups: a control group receiving knee exercises (stretching for hamstring and calf, and strengthening for quadriceps), and an experimental group receiving the same knee exercises plus strengthening exercises for hip rotators and ankle muscles. The study will measure pain levels using a visual analogue scale, functional levels using the Arabic Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score questionnaire, isometric muscle strength of various muscles using a handheld dynamometer, and knee proprioception by assessing joint position sense with a digital inclinometer. Measurements will be taken at baseline and after 4 weeks of treatment. The study includes adults aged 40-55 years with chronic knee osteoarthritis, with specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical study evaluating the safety and effectiveness of a bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent (Novabel) compared to a marketed bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent for the treatment of chronic sinusitis. The study involves patients aged 18 years or older diagnosed with chronic sinusitis who are scheduled to undergo endoscopic sinus surgery. The primary outcome measure is the non-reintervention rate at 30 days, which assesses the need for postoperative interventions based on video endoscopic findings reviewed by an independent blinded surgeon. Secondary outcomes include Lund-Kennedy endoscopic scores, Lund-Mackay CT scores, visual analog scale (VAS) pain scores, sinus patency rates, and implantation success rates at various time points up to 1 year. The study aims to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of the Novabel bioabsorbable steroid-releasing stent in preventing the need for further interventions and improving clinical outcomes in patients with chronic sinusitis undergoing sinus surgery.

This clinical trial aims to study the impact of providing cancer care closer to home for patients with multiple myeloma. The trial has two arms: one where participants transition their care to a satellite location, and another where participants continue receiving care at the primary cancer center site.

The primary outcome measure is the proportion of eligible participants who successfully transfer their care to a provider at a satellite location. Secondary outcomes include qualitative data on the types of candidacy used by providers for transfer decisions, treatment burden, satisfaction with patient-provider interactions, financial toxicity, and participant rationales for opting to transfer or not.

The study is designed as a non-randomized, parallel assignment trial with an open-label intervention model. Participants must be at least 18 years old, diagnosed with multiple myeloma, receiving care at the primary cancer center site, residing within the catchment area of a satellite site, and able to provide informed consent.

The trial aims to explore the potential benefits of providing cancer care closer to home, such as reduced travel burden and financial toxicity, while also assessing patient satisfaction and treatment burden.

This is a prospective, randomized controlled, interventional study comparing the use of virtual reality (VR) goggles to nitrous oxide for analgesia and anxiolysis during dental procedures in pediatric patients aged 4-12 years. The study aims to determine if VR distraction can be as effective as nitrous oxide in reducing pain and discomfort during painful dental treatments requiring anesthesia injection.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the control group (receiving nitrous oxide first, then VR goggles) or the treatment group (receiving VR goggles first, then nitrous oxide). Pain and behavior will be assessed using the FLACC (Faces, Legs, Arms, Crying, Consolability) scale, Wong-Baker FACES Pain Scale, and Houpt Behavior Scale during the procedures.

The primary outcomes measure the effectiveness of VR goggles in reducing pain compared to nitrous oxide, using the FLACC and Wong-Baker scales. The secondary outcome compares the overall effectiveness of VR distraction to nitrous oxide using the Houpt Behavior Scale.

The study is designed as a randomized, open-label, cross

This is a prospective study aimed at identifying patients at high risk of developing recurrent colorectal lesions and optimizing the intervals for surveillance colonoscopies, especially for high-risk patients, based on mutation burden and clinical-pathological phenotype. The study involves 200 patients who have undergone colonoscopy and removal of colorectal polyps larger than 10mm. The key aspects of the study include:

1. Determining the mutation profile and mutation burden in the index and synchronous lesions of the patients using PCR/DCE-based heteroduplex method.

2. Clinical and histopathological evaluation and mutational profiling of any metachronous lesions found during a five-year surveillance period.

3. Correlating clinical, histopathological, and mutational parameters to identify patients at high risk of developing metachronous lesions.

4. Comparing the mutation profiles of index lesions with metachronous lesions.

5. Analyzing the similarity of mutation profiles of lesions found in the same or close areas of the colorectum.

The primary outcome measure is the development and clinical utility of a new method to identify high-risk patients

The SAM Project (Science Against Malnutrition Project) is a clinical trial investigating malnutrition. The study aims to characterize malnutrition through the identification of specific biomarkers and involves the collection of clinical data, anamnesis, lifestyle data, fecal samples, blood samples, and saliva samples from participants affected by malnutrition due to deficiency or excess, as well as sex- and age-matched healthy controls. The primary outcome measures include untargeted microRNA expression profiles in blood and saliva samples, analysis of plasmatic and salivary extracellular vesicles, metagenomic and metabolomic analysis of fecal and salivary samples. The study is designed to identify potential biomarkers and gain insights into the underlying mechanisms of malnutrition through comprehensive multi-omics analyses.

This is a study investigating different strategies to promote exercise and physical activity in people with Parkinson's disease. The study will enroll participants with Parkinson's disease from two clinics in the Chicago area and evaluate their physical activity levels over a 12-month period under three different conditions:

1. Standard care (Year 1)
2. Written exercise guidance provided by neurologists (Year 2) 
3. Consultative physical therapy (Year 3)

Participants will wear activity trackers and complete assessments every 3 months to measure their moderate-to-vigorous physical activity levels and step counts. The primary outcome is minutes per day of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity, and the secondary outcome is steps per day.

The study aims to understand how different levels of support from clinicians and the community can impact exercise participation and physical activity trajectories in individuals with Parkinson's disease. The findings may inform strategies to promote exercise and improve physical activity levels in this population.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of multi-channel time-resolved functional near-infrared spectroscopy (tr-fNIRS) for detecting and preventing perioperative brain injury during shoulder surgery performed in the beach chair position. The study will involve adult patients undergoing elective shoulder surgery under general anesthesia. During the surgery, the tr-fNIRS device will be used to monitor regional cerebral oxygenation across multiple brain regions. The primary outcome measure is the impact of intraoperative hemodynamic parameters on regional differences in cerebral oxygenation between brain regions. Secondary outcomes include assessing regional differences in cerebral autoregulation and the association between cerebral desaturation events and clinical outcomes such as stroke and delirium. The study is observational, and no interventions will be administered based on the tr-fNIRS results. The goal is to evaluate the potential of tr-fNIRS for early detection and prevention of perioperative brain injury by providing comprehensive monitoring of cerebral oxygenation and autoregulation during surgery.

This is a randomized clinical feasibility trial investigating the use of mechanical insufflation-exsufflation (MI-E or cough assist) in critically ill adults receiving invasive mechanical ventilation. The trial aims to assess the feasibility, safety, and potential efficacy of MI-E in this patient population.

In the experimental arm, invasively ventilated patients will receive MI-E sessions twice daily (morning and afternoon) for a maximum of 7 days or until successful extubation. Each MI-E session consists of three cycles of 2-second insufflation followed by 2-second exsufflation at a pressure of 40 cmH2O, with the possibility of auto-triggering by the patient.

The primary outcome measure is the proportion of complete MI-E sessions delivered each calendar day. Secondary outcomes include safety measures such as the incidence of pneumothorax, endotracheal tube obstruction, severe hypoxemia, hypotension, and hypertension. Other secondary outcomes assess the acceptability, appropriateness, and feasibility of the intervention, as well as potential efficacy measures like ventilator-associated pneumonia, duration of mechanical ventilation

The Enavogliflozin Outcome Trial in Functional Tricuspid Regurgitation (EVENT) is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study to assess the effects of enavogliflozin, a sodium-glucose co-transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, on clinical and echocardiographic outcomes in patients with functional tricuspid regurgitation (TR) and heart failure with preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (HFpEF).

The study aims to investigate whether enavogliflozin therapy for 18 months, compared to placebo, can improve clinical outcomes and echocardiographic parameters in HFpEF patients with moderate or severe functional TR.

Key aspects:

- Participants: Non-diabetic or type 2 diabetes patients aged 20-80 years with HFpEF, moderate or severe functional TR, and preserved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF ≥ 50%).
- Intervention: Enavogliflozin 0.3 mg once daily or placebo for 18

This is a proof-of-concept study investigating the relationship between daily physical activity, measured by the number of steps using a SenseWear armband device, and the pharmacokinetics (PK) of infused recombinant factor VIII (FVIII) concentrate in patients with severe hemophilia A under prophylaxis. The primary outcome measure is to study the association between physical activity, measured by the mean number of daily steps, and the area under the curve (AUC) PK parameter in these patients. The study aims to evaluate whether and how the FVIII PK parameters are significantly associated with the mean number of daily steps. Eligible participants are males aged 12-60 years with severe hemophilia A under FVIII concentrate prophylaxis, without malignant tumors, anticoagulant/antiplatelet treatment, or other congenital coagulation disorders. It is a single-group, open-label study with no intervention other than the use of the SenseWear armband device to monitor physical activity and lifestyle.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the optimal timing for initiating locomotor training interventions, such as body weight supported treadmill training (BWSTT), following incomplete spinal cord injury (SCI). The study involves four groups: an early intervention group receiving BWSTT within 60 days post-injury, a sub-acute intervention group receiving BWSTT at 3 months post-injury, a chronic intervention group receiving BWSTT between 6-12 months post-injury, and a standard of care group without additional BWSTT. The primary outcome measure is the 10-meter walk test, assessing walking speed. Secondary outcomes include the 6-minute walk test, Walking Index for Spinal Cord Injury, and daily step counts. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with double-blinding. Participants aged 16-74 with incomplete SCI (AIS B, C, or D) between C5-T12 neurological levels are eligible. The trial aims to determine the critical time window for initiating locomotor training to promote optimal recovery outcomes in individuals with incomplete SCI.

This is a randomized controlled study investigating the effect of education based on the Health Promotion Model on premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating behavior, and perceived stress in women aged 18-30 years. The study aims to evaluate whether training using the Philips 66 technique, which involves active learning, problem-solving, and collaborative learning, can improve premenstrual symptoms, emotional eating habits, and stress levels.

The study will recruit 60 participants who meet the inclusion criteria, such as experiencing at least five premenstrual syndrome (PMS) symptoms every month, having regular menstruation, and not having any chronic diseases or using any methods to cope with PMS. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group or the control group.

The experimental group will receive education based on the Health Promotion Model, including a PowerPoint presentation, brochures, and training sessions using the Philips 66 technique. The control group will not receive any intervention.

The primary outcomes measured include PMS symptoms (using the Premenstrual Syndrome Scale), emotional eating behavior (using the Emotional Eating Scale), perceived stress (using the Perceived Stress Scale), and other related measures

The AMP SCZ® Observational Study: PREDICT-DPACC is a multi-site, non-interventional study examining clinical trajectories and predictors of outcomes in individuals at clinical high risk (CHR) for psychosis. The study is part of the Accelerating Medicines Partnership (AMP®) Schizophrenia program, a public-private partnership aimed at developing biomarker-informed characterization and longitudinal profiling of CHR individuals.

The study involves two Clinical High Risk (CHR) research networks: ProNET (based at Yale University) and PRESCIENT (based at the University of Melbourne and Orygen, Melbourne). The Data Processing, Analysis, and Coordination Center (DPACC) is based at Brigham and Women's Hospital and Mass General Brigham.

The study aims to capture data from the research networks in a uniform manner, build infrastructure for multiple data types, develop data processing and quality control pipelines, provide data coordination and management, develop tools to identify and validate biomarkers and predict individual trajectories, assist in data archiving, and disseminate information and tools to the research community.

Participants include individuals aged 12

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating the feasibility and acceptability of implementing the Problem Management Plus (PM+) intervention for prisoners in Dutch prisons. PM+ is a brief, scalable psychological intervention designed to address common mental health problems like depression and anxiety, and is delivered by trained non-specialists.

The study aims to assess factors such as PM+ fidelity, stakeholder perceptions, intervention delivery indicators, retention rates, and recruitment/consent rates to determine the feasibility and acceptability of PM+ in this setting.

The study will enroll 60 Dutch-speaking adult prisoners with elevated psychological distress levels, who will be randomized to either receive PM+ (5 sessions) plus care-as-usual (CAU) or CAU alone. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, 1 week, and 3 months post-intervention to measure symptoms of depression, anxiety, self-identified problems, quality of life, trauma, and suicidal vulnerability.

A qualitative study will also be conducted after the pilot RCT to evaluate the implementation process, involving interviews with various stakeholders (participants, PM+ helpers, supervisors, professionals, and family

This is a Phase I clinical trial studying the safety and efficacy of the drug xevinapant in combination with radiation therapy and chemotherapy (carboplatin and paclitaxel) for patients with locally advanced squamous cell carcinoma of the head and neck who are ineligible for cisplatin. The primary objective is to determine the maximum tolerated dose and recommended phase 2 dose of xevinapant when given with chemoradiation.
