The study has an escalation phase with different dose levels of xevinapant (50mg, 100mg, 150mg, 200mg) given daily for 2 weeks of a 3-week cycle along with weekly carboplatin, paclitaxel and radiation for 7 weeks. This is followed by 3 additional cycles of xevinapant alone. There is also a dose expansion cohort at the recommended phase 2 dose. Key eligibility criteria include locally advanced head and neck cancer, ineligibility for cisplatin, adequate organ function, and no prior systemic therapy for the cancer. The primary endpoint is determining the maximum tolerated dose of xevinapant. Secondary endpoints include progression-free

This is a Phase 1, open-label, single-arm study evaluating the pharmacokinetics, safety, and tolerability of ARV-471 as a single agent in Chinese participants with ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer. The primary objectives are to characterize the single and multiple-dose pharmacokinetics of ARV-471, including maximum plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the curve (AUC), and other PK parameters. Secondary objectives include assessing objective response rate, clinical benefit rate, duration of response, presence of biomarkers, and safety/tolerability based on ECG changes, laboratory abnormalities, vital signs, and adverse events. Eligible participants have ER+/HER2- advanced breast cancer previously treated with endocrine therapy and up to 2 prior chemotherapy regimens. ARV-471 will be administered orally once daily with food in 28-day cycles. The study will evaluate PK parameters, anti-tumor activity, and safety over up to 24 weeks of treatment.

This is a clinical trial investigating the combination of olaparib and alpelisib for the treatment of metastatic HER2-negative breast cancer. The trial has three cohorts:

Cohort 1: PARP-inhibitor naive patients receive olaparib and alpelisib combination therapy.

Cohort 2: PARP-inhibitor naive patients are randomized to receive either olaparib and alpelisib combination therapy or olaparib alone. Patients on the olaparib alone arm can cross over to the combination arm upon disease progression.

Cohort 3: PARP-inhibitor resistant patients receive olaparib and alpelisib combination therapy. 

The primary objectives are to evaluate progression-free survival with the combination versus olaparib alone in PARP-inhibitor naive patients (Cohort 2), and to assess the objective response rate of the combination in PARP-inhibitor resistant patients (Cohort 3).

Secondary objectives include evaluating overall response rates, overall survival, clinical benefit rates, safety/tolerability, and concordance between diagnostic tumor profiles and pre-treatment biopsy/

This is a multi-center, two-arm, parallel group, assessor-blinded, randomized controlled superiority trial investigating the efficacy of Schema Therapy (ST) compared to treatment as usual (TAU) for patients with chronic treatment-resistant depression (CTRD). The primary aim is to evaluate if 30 sessions of ST outperforms TAU on depression outcomes at 12 months after baseline, as well as at 6 and 24 months. Secondary aims include assessing functional impairment, well-being, personal recovery, and other outcomes. The study will also explore potential mediators and moderators of treatment effect. Participants with CTRD will be randomized to either ST or TAU, with both arms receiving appropriate medical treatment. Assessments will occur at baseline, 6, 12, and 24 months. The primary outcome is change in clinician-rated depression symptoms on the Hamilton-6 Rating Scale for Depression at 12 months. Secondary outcomes include various self-report measures of depression, functioning, well-being, anger, negative effects, and patient-defined problems at multiple timepoints. The study aims to refine the understanding and staging of CTRD

This is a prospective, multicenter, randomized, controlled, open-label, phase III cluster trial evaluating a paramedical protocol for ventilation management in patients with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The trial aims to assess the efficacy of having nurses adjust ventilator settings according to a pre-established protocol that complies with international recommendations, compared to usual care where ventilator settings are adjusted per standard practice at each center. The primary outcome is a composite of mortality and number of days without mechanical ventilation at day 28, prioritizing survival over shorter ventilation duration. Secondary outcomes include measures of ventilation parameters, oxygenation, duration of ventilation, weaning, rescue therapies, length of stay, and mortality. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years or older, hospitalized in the intensive care unit, intubated and mechanically ventilated, with ARDS evolving for less than 72 hours based on the Berlin definition criteria. The trial employs a stepped wedge cluster randomized design where clusters (centers) are sequentially transitioned from the control (usual care) to the intervention (nurse-led ventilation protocol) arm over multiple periods.

This is a prospective, quasi-experimental, single-arm pilot study aimed at testing a culturally tailored engagement and retention intervention called Haitian immigrant iENGAGE (H-iENGAGE) for Haitian immigrants living with HIV (HILWH) in the U.S. The study involves three aims:

1. Mixed-methods data collection on barriers and facilitators to viral suppression among HILWH.
2. A pilot health intervention with HILWH participants, involving research questionnaires at enrollment, post-intervention, and 6-month follow-up, along with 4 individual meetings over 6 months.
3. A Photovoice activity with 6 participants from Aim 2, involving 6 additional meetings to use photographs to illustrate their experience in the study.

The primary outcomes measured are changes in the Care of Engagement Index Score (comfort and communication with provider) and viral suppression (HIV load <200 copies/ml) from baseline to post-intervention and 6-month follow-up. The study targets recently diagnosed or non-virally suppressed HILWH adults recruited from two Feder

This is a prospective, randomized, non-blinded, single-center clinical trial comparing the effectiveness and safety of three different methods for root canal debridement in patients with apical periodontitis. The study involves 109 participants randomly assigned to one of three arms:

1. Passive Ultrasonic Irrigation (PUI) group (n=40): Root canal shaping up to working length with 25.06 file, followed by ultrasonic irrigation with sodium hypochlorite.

2. Endoclean (EC) group (n=40): Root canal shaping up to working length with 20.06 file, followed by the Endoclean device using hydraulic inertial cavitation with saline solution, with the tip kept 3mm short of working length. 

3. Conventional group (n=29): Root canal shaping up to working length with 25.06 file, followed by conventional irrigation with sodium hypochlorite.

The primary outcome is successful healing of periapical lesions at 12 months, assessed by reduction in radiolucency and absence of clinical symptoms. Secondary outcomes include postoperative pain up to 7

This is a clinical trial evaluating the impact of artificial intelligence (AI)-enhanced image analysis on the diagnostic accuracy of frontline clinicians in detecting fractures on plain X-rays. The study involves 18 readers from different clinical specialties (emergency medicine, trauma and orthopedic surgery, emergency nurse practitioners, physiotherapists, general radiologists, and radiographers) with varying levels of experience. The readers will review 500 X-ray cases in two phases: first without AI assistance, and then with an AI report for each case after a washout period. The primary outcomes measure the performance of the AI algorithm (sensitivity, specificity, and area under the ROC curve) and the performance of readers with and without AI assistance (sensitivity, specificity, area under the ROC curve, and reading speed). Two consultant musculoskeletal radiologists will establish the ground truth findings on the X-rays, with a third senior radiologist for arbitration. The study aims to evaluate the potential of AI-enhanced image analysis to improve fracture detection accuracy and efficiency in frontline clinical settings.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate fine motor function, hand grip strength, and anthropometric characteristics of the hand and forearm in children aged 6-12 years with Specific Learning Disorders (SLD), and compare them with typically developing children. The study will assess fine motor skills using the Bruininks-Oseretsky Test of Motor Proficiency-2 (BOT-2) and the Purdue Pegboard Test. Hand grip strength will be measured using a hand dynamometer, and finger strength will be evaluated using a pinch gauge. Anthropometric measurements of the hand and forearm will also be taken. Additionally, the study will examine the impact of fine motor skills on quality of life and participation in activities at home, school, and community settings, using the Participation and Environment Measurement Child & Youth (PEM-CY) and the Pediatric Quality of Life Inventory (PEDS-QL). The trial will include an experimental group of children with SLD and a control group of typically developing children.

The IM-ZBULLE study is a multicenter, prospective, randomized, double-blind, controlled trial with two parallel groups. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of combining the Z-track and Airlock techniques during intramuscular injection of haloperidol decanoate in adult patients with schizophrenia or related disorders.

The experimental group will receive intramuscular injection of haloperidol decanoate using the Z-track and Airlock techniques, while the control group will receive the injection using standard techniques.

The primary outcome measure is pain reduction, assessed using a visual analog scale (VAS) 5 minutes after the injection. Secondary outcomes include drug leakage reduction, impact of the injection on potential complications, participant satisfaction (measured by the CSQ-8 questionnaire), and therapeutic alliance (measured by the Working Alliance Inventory scale).

The study also aims to identify the levers and obstacles to changing nursing practices through a qualitative descriptive study.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years or older, diagnosed with schizophrenia or related disorders (ICD-10 codes F20-F29), prescribed haloperidol

This is a feasibility trial investigating the use of preoperative 5-day hypofractionated radiotherapy (HFRT) for primary soft tissue sarcoma (STS) of the extremity or trunk. The key aspects are:

- Intervention: Patients will receive preoperative HFRT (30Gy in 5 fractions over 5 consecutive weekdays) followed by standard wide local excision surgery 2-6 weeks later.

- Primary Outcome: Feasibility of 5-day HFRT, defined as the proportion of eligible patients who elect to participate in the trial.

- Secondary Outcomes: Rate of favorable pathologic response, major wound complications, local control, acute toxicity, and 1-year late HFRT toxicity.

- Exploratory Analysis: Evaluation of serum levels of SFRP2 (a potential biomarker) before and after HFRT, and association of SFRP2 changes with tumor fibrosis/hyalinization.

- Rationale: Preoperative HFRT can shorten treatment duration compared to conventional fractionated

This is a randomized controlled study comparing the effectiveness of pericapsular nerve group (PENG) block combined with lateral femoral cutaneous nerve (LFCN) block versus patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) with intravenous morphine for postoperative analgesia after hip replacement surgery.

The study involves two groups of patients undergoing hip replacement surgery. One group receives PENG block and LFCN block, where an ultrasound-guided injection of ropivacaine is administered around the hip joint. The other group receives intravenous morphine analgesia via PCA.

The primary outcomes measured are pain scores at rest and during movement using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) and the incidence of side effects such as vomiting, nausea, itching, urinary retention, and respiratory failure. Data is collected from the initiation of the analgesia method until 72 hours after surgery.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of the PENG block and LFCN block in providing postoperative analgesia compared to the standard PCA with morphine after hip replacement surgery.

This is a comparative study investigating pelvic organ mobility using dynamic MRI in patients with and without pelvic endometriosis. The primary outcome measure is the mean vertical displacement of the anterior vaginal wall between rest and maximum pushing force during dynamic MRI. Secondary outcomes include mean vertical displacement of the cervix, posterior vaginal wall, and variation in displacement of pelvic organs between the two patient groups. The study also aims to assess the association between endometriosis symptoms and pelvic organ displacement during dynamic MRI. Eligible participants are nulliparous women aged 18-50 years referred for suspected pelvic endometriosis. The intervention involves adding a dynamic MRI sequence during routine pelvic MRI examinations.

This is a retrospective, observational study using data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD) and Hospital Episode Statistics (HES) databases in England. The study aims to evaluate the uptake of influenza vaccines, particularly the live attenuated influenza vaccine (LAIV), in children aged 2 to 17 years between 2012 and 2020. It also aims to describe the usage patterns of LAIV, healthcare resource utilization (HCRU) associated with influenza-like illness (ILI) and laboratory-confirmed influenza, and the impact of LAIV on HCRU compared to no vaccination. The study will analyze factors associated with LAIV uptake using logistic regression models. The primary outcome is the proportion of eligible individuals receiving influenza vaccination (LAIV, quadrivalent inactivated vaccine, or unspecified) per flu season. Secondary outcomes include rates of GP consultations, hospitalizations, emergency department visits, outpatient visits, length of hospital stay, and antibiotic/antiviral prescriptions related to ILI or influenza. The study will provide updated epidemiological evidence on the uptake of

This is a pilot pre-post interventional trial without a control group, aimed at evaluating the feasibility and potential benefits of using fun activities for reciting Tang poems to promote happiness in primary school ethnic minority students (South Asian children aged 6-9 years) in Hong Kong. The intervention involves three weekly 1.5-hour sessions of Tang poem classes and one performance session, led by experienced instructors. The primary outcomes include the number of successful recited poems assessed objectively and subjectively, and changes in self-reported happiness. Secondary outcomes include changes in acculturation, ability in speaking Chinese, and attitude towards Chinese learning and Tang poem recitation. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, before and after each session, and at a 12-week follow-up. Parents can attend the sessions passively to show support. The study aims to explore whether these fun activities can promote happiness and enjoyment in this population.

This is a randomized controlled trial aimed at testing the effectiveness of a digital platform called Vira in improving clinical outcomes for adolescents aged 13-18 years at high risk for suicide. The trial will be conducted at the Intensive Adolescent and Family DBT Program (Columbia Doctors) and will involve 200 participants randomized into two groups: (a) Vira group (n=100) receiving intensive outpatient dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) supported by the Vira platform, and (b) treatment as usual control group (n=100) receiving intensive outpatient DBT without the Vira platform.

The Vira platform integrates mobile sensing, self-report assessment, and just-in-time nudges/notifications into the practitioner's workflow. The app passively collects data from the patient's smartphone sensors (physical activity, sleep patterns, mobility, language patterns) indicative of risk-relevant behavioral patterns and psychological states. Patients also answer a daily check-in question, and the data is processed to provide an automated assessment of the user's functioning. Practitioners can schedule reminders and notifications to support the patient's behavior change plan and DBT treatment.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of sex and age on non-visual light input that affects sleep and circadian rhythms. The study involves participants aged 18-85 years who meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to their sleep patterns, vision, medical conditions, and medication use.

The study design is a single-group assignment with open-label interventions. All participants will undergo pupillometry testing on two consecutive days, with measurements taken in the afternoon and evening on the first day, and morning and evening on the second day. Participants will be randomized to receive different combinations of light stimuli during the pupillometry testing.

On the first night, participants will be exposed to red light to determine their circadian timing based on melatonin levels measured from saliva samples. On the second night, they will be exposed to blue/green light, and their melatonin levels will be compared to those from the first night to assess the hormone response to different light wavelengths.

The primary outcome measures include pupil size during the pupillometry testing, melatonin levels for circadian timing assessment on the first night, and melatonin levels for hormone response comparison between the two nights.

This is a randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating the efficacy and feasibility of a new parent training program called Improving Parenting Skills Adult ADHD (IPSA) for parents with ADHD. The study is being conducted at the Center of Neurodevelopmental Disorders at Karolinska Institutet (KIND) in Sweden.

The study involves two parallel groups: the treatment group receiving IPSA directly, and the control group receiving continued routine services and offered IPSA approximately six months later. Eligible participants are parents aged 18 or older with a formal ADHD diagnosis and at least one child aged 3-11 years.

The primary outcome measure is parental self-efficacy, assessed using the Parental Self-Efficacy scale. Secondary outcomes include parental stress, household disorganization, and child behavior problems, measured using various scales.

The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of IPSA by examining changes in the primary and secondary outcomes from pre-intervention to post-intervention and follow-up (1.5-3 months after completion). It also assesses the feasibility of IPSA by evaluating attendance, treatment satisfaction

This is a single-arm study examining the preliminary efficacy of the Substance Use and Health Risk Intervention (SUHRI) for justice-involved youth aged 14 to 18 years old. The intervention is a technology-based application administered via tablet, addressing substance use and risky sexual practices within the context of personal relationships. The study aims to assess proximal outcomes such as problem recognition, decision-making, intention to reduce personal risk, and service initiation, as well as distal outcomes like substance use and sexual/STI health risk. Participants are recruited from a juvenile probation department and must meet eligibility criteria, including being on community supervision, having at least one indicator of substance use, being English-speaking, and showing no signs of suicide risk or thought disorder. The study involves completing assessments and participating in four individualized intervention sessions facilitated by a research assistant.

This is a phase II open-label, single-center, single-arm futility trial investigating the use of remote ischemic conditioning (RIC) for reducing disability progression in patients with primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS). The primary objective is to evaluate the non-futility of RIC for reducing progression of disability, as measured by the timed 25-foot walk (T25FW), in PPMS patients. The intervention involves daily self-administration of 40-minute RIC sessions using an electric auto-control device for 12 months. The primary outcome measure is worsening of disability, defined as an increase of 20% or more in the T25FW at 12 months compared to baseline. Secondary outcomes include the Nine Hole Peg Test, MRI measures of remyelination, and the Single Digit Modalities Test (SDMT). The study follows a Simon-2-stage MiniMax design for futility studies and includes PPMS patients aged 18-65 years with an Expanded Disability Status Scale score between 4.0 and 6.5 and a screening T25FW of 5.5 seconds

This clinical trial aimed to evaluate whether prothrombin time at diagnosis can predict response to steroid treatment in patients with severe alcoholic hepatitis. The study included patients aged 18-70 years with a first episode of severe alcoholic hepatitis, meeting specific diagnostic criteria, and eligible for corticosteroid therapy. The primary outcome measure was response to standard medical treatment, assessed using the Lille score at day 7. Secondary outcomes included death, early liver transplantation, and occurrence of infections during the 28-day follow-up period. The intervention involved measuring prothrombin time at diagnosis and assessing its correlation with the Lille score at day 7, which determines response to steroid treatment. The study aimed to determine if prothrombin time could be used as a predictor of steroid response in severe alcoholic hepatitis.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effects of functional task training versus functional therapy program on gross motor function, range of motion, and balance in children with cerebral palsy. The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving functional task training, and a control group receiving functional therapy program (Bobath technique). The functional task training group will perform non-walking activities (standing from a seated position, reaching for an object overhead, stepping on and off a bench) and walking activities (walking up and down stairs, walking on flat surfaces and ramps). The functional therapy program group will receive goal-directed training to optimize the child's practice of specific goals. The treatment duration is 8 weeks, with sessions lasting 50 minutes per day, 3 times per week. The primary outcome measures are range of motion (measured by goniometer), balance (measured by Pediatric Balance Scale), and gross motor function (measured by Gross Motor Function Measure scale). The study aims to evaluate the comparative effects of these two interventions on improving gross motor function, range of motion, and balance in children with cerebral palsy aged 6-12 years, with a Gross Motor Function Classification System (GMFCS) score

This is a retrospective observational study evaluating the prognostic value of neutrophil-lymphocyte ratio (NLR), absolute lymphocyte count (ALC), and thrombocyte-lymphocyte ratio (TLR) in predicting outcomes of tetralogy of Fallot (ToF) primary repair surgery. The study included patients with ToF who underwent primary repair at National Cardiovascular Center Harapan Kita between January 2020 and December 2022. Preoperative demographic data, complete blood count, differential count, intraoperative data, and postoperative complications and mortality were analyzed. The primary outcomes measured were the number of patients requiring redo surgery, mortality, and complications categorized as mild, moderate, or severe. Secondary outcomes included hospital length of stay and postoperative length of stay. The study aimed to evaluate the prognostic value of NLR, ALC, and TLR in predicting the outcomes of ToF primary repair surgery.

This is a pilot randomized double-blind clinical trial assessing the effectiveness of patient-applied aqueous lidocaine via tampon as a pre-treatment prior to intrauterine device (IUD) placement. The study aims to evaluate if the lidocaine pretreatment can reduce pain and improve the experience during IUD insertion compared to a saline placebo.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, where they will apply a 4% aqueous lidocaine solution to a tampon and insert it one hour before the IUD placement procedure, or the placebo group, where they will apply sterile saline to the tampon instead of lidocaine.

The primary outcomes measured are the procedure time (from uterine sounding to cutting strings) and the patient-reported pain level on a 0-10 visual analog scale immediately after the procedure. Secondary outcomes include patient satisfaction, interest in subsequent procedures, and provider-reported procedural difficulty.

The study includes women aged 18-54 years who request IUD insertion and excludes those with known allergies to lidocaine or tampons, or current vaginal or cervical injuries.

This is a single-center, interventional pilot study assessing the feasibility and acceptability of universal capillary screening for early detection of chronic metabolic, cardiovascular, and autoimmune diseases in the general population of Cantalupo, Italy. The study will enroll volunteers aged 1-100 years and perform capillary blood sampling to measure glucose, lipid levels, glycated hemoglobin, and autoantibodies for type 1 diabetes and celiac disease. Blood pressure will also be measured. The primary outcome is to evaluate the feasibility and acceptability of the screening program. Secondary outcomes include measuring disease markers, estimating disease prevalence, correlating indicators with demographics and clinical data, and multiparametric risk assessment. Positive cases for type 1 diabetes or celiac disease will undergo confirmatory venous blood testing.

The SMaRT Mom study is an intervention study aimed at helping breastfeeding mothers manage and reduce their smartphone use during breastfeeding. The study involves two groups: an intervention group where mothers are instructed not to use their smartphones while breastfeeding for one week, and a control group without any intervention. The primary outcomes measured are changes in infant temperament and maternal self-efficacy before and after the intervention week. Secondary outcomes include maternal reports of breastfeeding as a rewarding experience, maternal attention towards the infant, and changes in breastfeeding mothers' neural activity, physiological responses (heart rate variability, electrodermal activity, and cardiograph impedance) during baseline, breastfeeding, and mother-infant interaction. The study involves lab visits and remote sessions to support the implementation of the intervention plan.

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial:

This is a single-blind randomized controlled trial investigating the use of photobiomodulation therapy (PBMT) for treating plantar fasciitis in active duty military personnel aged 18-54 years. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either active PBMT or sham (placebo) PBMT, in addition to usual care of stretching and cryotherapy for 6 weeks. The active PBMT group will receive 9 treatments over 3 weeks using the LightForce® XPi therapy laser. The primary outcomes are the Foot and Ankle Ability Measure (FAAM), Defense and Veterans Pain Rating Scale (DVPRS) scores, and plantar fascia thickness measured by ultrasound at baseline, 3 weeks, 6 weeks, 3 months and 6 months. After the initial 6 week treatment period, participants in the sham group will have the option to cross over and receive the active PBMT treatment for another 6 weeks. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of PBMT as a treatment for plantar

This is a single-center, open-label, randomized, single-dose, two-period crossover bioequivalence study to evaluate the bioequivalence of a test formulation of entacapone, levodopa, and carbidopa tablets compared to a reference formulation in healthy Chinese subjects under postprandial conditions. The study aims to assess the peak plasma concentration (Cmax), area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time 0 to the last measurable concentration (AUC0-t), and area under the plasma concentration-time curve from time 0 to infinity (AUC0-∞) of the test and reference formulations. A total of 36 healthy adult subjects will be enrolled and randomly assigned to receive either the test or reference formulation in the first period, followed by the alternate formulation in the second period after a washout period of at least 2 days. The study has strict inclusion and exclusion criteria to ensure the safety of participants and the validity of the results.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the use of combined electroencephalography (EEG) and 7 Tesla magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) for fine-scale mapping of brain anatomy and function in healthy participants and patients with tremor, psychosis, and epilepsy. The study involves several participant groups, including healthy volunteers, essential tremor patients, psychosis patients, healthy controls matched to the psychosis group, and epilepsy patients. The interventions include simultaneous EEG-fMRI at 7 Tesla, which is a non-invasive technique without ionizing radiation or injected contrasts, and structural MRI at 7 Tesla. The primary outcome measures focus on contrast-to-noise ratio between thalamic nuclei in 7T structural MRI, Pearson correlation between thalamocortical brain regions in 7T functional MRI, and microstate duration in EEG acquired concurrently with 7T functional MRI. The secondary outcome measure is the publication of fully anonymized neuroimaging datasets in suitable public data repositories.

This is a two-phase study investigating the effect of weight loss on hepcidin levels and iron status in individuals with obesity. 

Phase 1 is a cross-sectional study comparing hepcidin levels, iron status, inflammatory markers, and other parameters between people with and without obesity.

Phase 2 is an open, randomized controlled trial involving participants with obesity and iron deficiency from Phase 1. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of two calorie-restricted diet groups: one including red meat and one excluding red meat. Both groups will receive iron supplementation. The primary outcome is the change in serum hepcidin levels after 2 months. Secondary outcomes include changes in iron status markers, inflammatory markers, body composition, lipid profile, and gut microbiota composition.

The study aims to assess the impact of weight loss through different dietary interventions on hepcidin levels, iron status, inflammation, and related parameters in individuals with obesity and iron deficiency.

This is a prospective cohort study investigating the use of continuous non-invasive electrophysiological (eCTG) monitoring using the Nemo Fetal Monitoring System (NFMS) in high-risk pregnancies. The study aims to assess if continuous eCTG monitoring can improve perinatal and maternal outcomes compared to conventional intermittent cardiotocography (CTG) monitoring. The primary outcome is the incidence of perinatal mortality and major neonatal morbidity. Secondary outcomes include maternal mortality, neonatal morbidity, patient and caregiver satisfaction, duration of pregnancy, monitoring method switch, duration of admission, timing and number of obstetric interventions, and NICU admission and duration. The study will enroll 1911 pregnant women aged ≥18 years with a singleton pregnancy between 23+0 and 32+0 weeks of gestation requiring hospitalization for maternal or fetal surveillance. A random sample of 464 women will receive continuous eCTG monitoring with NFMS, while the remaining prospective cohort and 1400 historical controls will receive conventional intermittent CTG monitoring. The study

This is a study investigating the genetic susceptibility to severe infections. The key aspects are:

- It aims to identify chromosomal regions and candidate genes associated with rare and severe infections through genetic analysis of patients and their relatives up to the 3rd degree.

- Eligible participants include patients with proven rare and severe infections requiring hospitalization, recurrent infections, infections leading to sequelae, or disseminated opportunistic infections. Relatives up to the 3rd degree of eligible patients can also participate.

- The study involves collecting blood samples (10ml) and potentially skin biopsies from participants for genetic analysis using techniques like whole genome genotyping, exome/genome sequencing, and homozygosity mapping.

- The primary outcomes are identifying chromosomal regions associated with the diseases through homozygosity mapping, identifying candidate susceptibility genes through sequencing, and validating the pathogenic effects of identified mutations through functional studies.

- The study excludes patients with acquired immunodeficiencies, pregnant women at the time of illness, and persons under court protection.

- The expected duration of the study is around 10 years to complete the genetic analyses and functional validation experiments.

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the prevalence, type, and risk factors of urinary incontinence (UI) in married women and its effect on their quality of life. UI is a common condition that significantly impacts women's physical, psychosocial, and economic well-being, leading to social isolation, reduced self-esteem, and substantial individual and societal costs. The study involved married women over 18 years old who agreed to participate. The primary outcome measure was the Incontinence Quality of Life, which assessed the impact of UI on participants' quality of life using a score ranging from 22 to 110, with higher scores indicating a better quality of life. The study employed a diagnostic test intervention, where participants were briefed about the research purpose and procedure, informed about voluntary participation and data confidentiality, and provided informed consent. The study aimed to raise awareness about UI, promote early diagnosis and treatment, and develop a comprehensive understanding of this condition to improve the management and prevention of UI in women.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of two different cell sources, bone marrow aspirate concentrate (BMAC) and minimally manipulated adipose tissue (MM-AT), for intra-articular injection in the treatment of knee osteoarthritis. A total of 204 patients with symptomatic unilateral knee osteoarthritis will be randomly assigned to receive either a single intra-articular injection of BMAC or MM-AT. The primary outcome measure is the Western Ontario and McMaster University Osteoarthritis Index (WOMAC) pain subscale at 6 months follow-up. Secondary outcomes include WOMAC total score, Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), Visual Analogue Scale (VAS), EuroQol Visual Analogue Scale (EQ-VAS), Tegner Activity Level Scale, range of motion, circumferences, Patient Acceptable Symptom State (PASS), Minimally Clinical Important Difference (MCID), treatment expectations, Kellgren-Lawrence score, 3T MRI, and analysis of circulating microRNAs. Patients will be evaluated

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase III clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of CBD TPM capsules in adults for reducing insomnia severity. The study has three arms: placebo, 75mg CBD, and 150mg CBD taken as nightly capsules before bedtime. The primary outcomes are the mean change from baseline in insomnia severity index (ISI) score and subjective sleep efficiency (sSE) at 8 weeks. Key eligibility criteria include adults aged 18 or older meeting DSM-5 criteria for insomnia disorder, with an ISI score ≥15 and confirmed insomnia symptoms from sleep diaries. Major exclusions include other sleep disorders, depression, anxiety, recent cannabis use, and various medical conditions. The study aims to assess if CBD capsules can effectively reduce insomnia severity and improve sleep efficiency compared to placebo.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the pattern of intestinal parasitic infections among cirrhotic patients at Sohag University Hospital. The study involves two groups: 100 cirrhotic patients with gastrointestinal complaints (cases group) and 100 patients with gastrointestinal complaints but without any comorbidities (control group). Both groups will undergo stool analysis to detect the prevalence and pattern of intestinal parasitic infections. The primary outcome measure is to determine the pattern of intestinal parasitic infections among cirrhotic patients, compare it with non-cirrhotic patients, and identify the most common risk factors for these infections in cirrhotic patients. The study has an open-label, parallel-group, randomized design and will be conducted over 12 months.

The REtinal Detachment Outcomes Study (REDOS) is a factorial, randomized controlled trial investigating the outcomes of different surgical approaches for treating rhegmatogenous retinal detachment (RRD). The study aims to compare the effectiveness of pars plana vitrectomy (PPV) with or without scleral buckle (SB), and the use of either sulfur hexafluoride (SF6) or perfluoropropane (C3F8) gas tamponade.

The primary outcome measure is the single surgery anatomic success, defined as freedom from reoperation for recurrent RRD until the final 1-year follow-up. Secondary outcomes include pinhole and best-corrected visual acuity, time to onset of RD recurrence, severity and number of complications, and quality of life questionnaire scores.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of RRD, excluding cases with specific conditions such as proliferative vitreoretinopathy, chronic RRD, proliferative diabetic retinopathy with tractional RD, macular holes, and others.

The study employs

This is a randomized, triple-blinded, parallel-group interventional study investigating the effects of different concentrations of ropivacaine (0.25%, 0.5%, and 1%) on the onset and duration of ultrasound-guided ankle blocks in patients undergoing forefoot surgery for hallux valgus repair. The primary outcome is the difference in the duration of sensory blocks across the three groups, measured over 48 hours. Secondary outcomes include the difference in onset time of sensory block (measured at 30 minutes), postoperative pain scores (measured over 72 hours), and opioid consumption (measured over one week). The study aims to evaluate if using 1% ropivacaine results in significantly faster onset and longer duration of sensory block and analgesia compared to 0.25% and 0.5% concentrations. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-65 years scheduled for elective forefoot surgery under unilateral ankle block, meeting specific inclusion and exclusion criteria.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study investigating the effect of compression stockings on the severity of restless leg syndrome (RLS), sleep quality, and well-being in pregnant women between 27-40 weeks of gestation. The study has two arms: an experimental group wearing compression stockings and a placebo comparator group wearing knee socks. The primary outcome is the change in RLS severity measured by the RLS Severity Rating Scale after 21 days of intervention. The secondary outcome is the change in sleep quality assessed by the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index. Eligible participants are pregnant women aged 18-40 years with moderate to severe RLS, without certain chronic conditions or high-risk pregnancies. The study aims to evaluate if compression stockings can alleviate RLS symptoms and improve sleep quality in pregnant women.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of a home-based strength and Tai-chi exercise program, called "exercise snacking" and "Tai-chi snacking", for improving physical function in older adults aged 65 and above. The study will last for 12 weeks and involve remote assessments as well as in-person assessments for a subset of participants. The primary outcome is changes in the Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) score measured every 4 weeks. Secondary outcomes include measures of strength, balance, agility, flexibility, quality of life, physical activity levels, mental health, self-efficacy for exercise, and attitudes towards exercise. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the exercise intervention group, where they will perform progressive levels of exercise and Tai-chi snacking at home, or a waitlist control group. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, mid-intervention (weeks 4 and 8), and post-intervention (week 12) to evaluate the effects of the intervention.

This is a randomized, case-control study evaluating the efficacy of pre-emptive caudal epidural analgesia with ropivacaine with or without dexamethasone for postoperative pain relief in lumbosacral spine surgeries. The study aims to compare the quality of analgesia, duration of analgesia, hemodynamic effects, and associated side effects between two groups:

Group RD: Patients receiving caudal epidural injection with 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml containing dexamethasone 8 mg.
Group R: Patients receiving caudal epidural injection with 0.25% ropivacaine 20 ml alone.

The primary outcomes measured are postoperative Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) scores at various time points (immediate postoperative period, 4, 8, 12, and 24 hours) and the time to demand for rescue analgesia (VAS ≥ 4) within 24 hours. The study involves 60 patients aged 18-65 years undergoing lumbosacral spine surgeries, random

The provided text describes a randomized controlled experimental study that aims to investigate the effect of nursing care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory on the comfort, satisfaction, and sleep quality of intensive care patients. The study plans to recruit a total of 80 participants, with 40 in the intervention group receiving care based on Kolcaba's comfort theory, and 40 in the control group receiving standard care. The primary outcome measures include the General Comfort Scale, Comfort Behaviors Checklist, and Richard-Campbell Sleep Scale, which will be assessed 24 hours after the intervention. The study is designed as a parallel assignment, double-blind trial, with participants randomly allocated to either the experimental or control group. The study targets adult patients aged 18-80 years, who meet specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to their cognitive and physical condition, and their ability to communicate.

The P-KIDs CARE Health Systems Intervention in Tanzania is a study aimed at developing and piloting an intervention to address health systems delays in care for injured children in Tanzania. The study consists of three aims:

Aim 1: Conduct formative research to inform the development of the P-KIDs CARE intervention. This includes enrolling 100 children into a pediatric injury registry, conducting capacity assessments of two study facilities, in-depth interviews with family members of pediatric injury patients, and focus group discussions with healthcare providers.

Aim 2: Use the formative data to develop the P-KIDs CARE intervention during a 2-day workshop with an interdisciplinary study team. The intervention will include the WHO Basic Emergency Care Course for training on patient assessment and stabilization, and a decision support tool integrating the Pediatric Resuscitation and Trauma Outcome model for mortality risk assessment and the Field Triage Decision Scheme for timely referral decisions.

Aim 3: Pilot the intervention in two study facilities in the Kilimanjaro Region. Approximately 200 pediatric injury patients (100 pre-intervention and 100 post

This is a preliminary randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of combining pelvic floor rehabilitation with postural re-education versus pelvic floor rehabilitation with spinal mobilization in women aged 18-75 years with stress urinary incontinence and chronic low back pain. The study has two parallel arms: one receiving postural re-education exercises along with perineal exercises, and the other receiving spinal mobilization along with perineal exercises. The primary outcome is change in the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire-Urinary Short Form score, assessing urinary incontinence frequency, severity, and quality of life impact. Secondary outcomes include changes in pain visual analogue scale and modified Oxford scale for pelvic floor muscle strength. Assessments are done at baseline, after 10 treatment sessions over 5 weeks, and 1 month post-treatment. The study aims to evaluate the potential benefits of combining postural re-education or spinal mobilization with pelvic floor rehabilitation for managing stress urinary incontinence and low back pain in women.

This clinical trial aims to develop a pharmacodynamic model for propofol in older adults (aged 65-99 years) undergoing non-cardiac elective surgery under general anesthesia. The study will involve administering intravenous propofol to participants with prespecified plasma targets, while recording bispectral index (BIS) values, frontal electroencephalography (EEG), and clinical signs of consciousness. Two models will be created and compared retrospectively: a BIS model (Eleveld Validation) and a new model based on frontal EEG markers. The primary outcome measure is the performance error, which quantifies the difference between measured and predicted propofol concentrations. Secondary outcomes include median absolute performance error, median prediction error, and the time points of loss of response, burst suppression, and return of response. The goal is to develop a pharmacokinetic-pharmacodynamic model that better predicts the hypnotic effect of propofol in older adults compared to the existing Eleveld model, allowing for more accurate titration of propofol dosing in this population.

This is a multicenter, open-label, randomized controlled non-inferiority trial comparing a very short course (1 day) of antibiotic therapy to a standard course (4-7 days) in patients with acute cholangitis after adequate endoscopic biliary drainage. The primary outcome is the clinical cure rate by day 14 without relapse by day 30. Secondary outcomes include 90-day mortality, relapse rates, subsequent infections, adverse events, length of hospital stay, quality of life, and cost-effectiveness analysis. Eligible patients have acute cholangitis due to bile duct stones or obstruction, undergo successful biliary drainage via ERCP, and do not have concomitant conditions like pancreatitis or cholecystitis. The trial aims to determine if a 1-day antibiotic course is non-inferior to the standard longer course in achieving clinical cure after adequate biliary drainage in cholangitis patients.

This is a prospective randomized double-blinded clinical study comparing two methods of lung recruitment maneuver in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of conventional versus ultrasound-guided lung recruitment maneuvers in improving lung aeration and preventing atelectasis and desaturation during surgery.

The study will enroll 60 morbidly obese patients scheduled for laparoscopic bariatric surgery. Patients will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:

1. Conventional group (n=30): Lung recruitment will be performed by manual inflation with a pressure of 30 cmH2O for 30 seconds.

2. Ultrasound-guided group (n=30): Lung recruitment will be performed under real-time ultrasound guidance, starting at 10 cmH2O for 10 seconds and increasing by 10 cmH2O every 10 seconds until no collapsed areas are visible, up to a maximum of 40 cmH2O.

The primary outcome is the change in lung ultrasound score. Secondary outcomes include the incidence of atelect

This is a prospective randomized open-label trial aimed at optimizing the fractionation schedules for radiotherapy in the treatment of heel spurs (plantar fasciitis). The study compares the efficacy of a single-dose radiotherapy regimen with the standard fractionated regimen (6 Gy in 4 fractions of 1.5 Gy twice weekly) in terms of pain relief for heel spur patients.

Patients over 40 years old with a diagnosed painful unilateral plantar heel spur for at least six months are randomized into six groups receiving different total doses and fractionation schedules:

- Arm A: 6 Gy in 4 fractions of 1.5 Gy twice weekly (standard arm)
- Arm B: 3 Gy in 2 fractions of 1.5 Gy twice weekly  
- Arm C: Single fraction of 0.5 Gy
- Arm D: Single fraction of 1.0 Gy
- Arm E: Single fraction of 1.5 Gy

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of adding a behavioral weight reduction program to pain neuroscience education and cognition-targeted exercise therapy for overweight or obese individuals with chronic low back pain. The primary objective is to examine if the combined intervention (weight reduction program + pain education + exercise therapy) is superior to pain education and exercise therapy alone in reducing average pain intensity at 12 months follow-up. Secondary objectives include evaluating the effects on other pain-related outcomes, anthropometrics, energy balance behaviors, and health economics. The study involves 252 overweight or obese adults aged 18-65 years with chronic low back pain, randomized into two groups: an experimental group receiving the combined intervention, and a control group receiving only pain education and exercise therapy. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, post-treatment, and multiple follow-up timepoints up to 12 months, measuring outcomes such as pain intensity, interference, beliefs, body composition, physical activity, diet, sleep, healthcare utilization, productivity, and quality of life.

This is a randomized controlled prospective multicenter trial comparing the clinical outcomes and efficacy of single versus double pyloromyotomy technique for gastric per-oral endoscopic pyloromyotomy (G-POEM) in the treatment of refractory and severe gastroparesis.

The study aims to evaluate the clinical success, Gastroparesis Cardinal Symptom Index (GCSI) scores, technical success rate, procedure time, adverse events, and symptom recurrence between the two techniques at 3, 6, and 12 months follow-up.

Patients with refractory and severe gastroparesis (GCSI > 2) and confirmed impaired gastric emptying will be randomized to undergo either single or double pyloromyotomy during the G-POEM procedure. The primary outcomes are clinical success, GCSI scores, and technical success rate. Secondary outcomes include procedure time, adverse events, and symptom recurrence.

The study will provide insights into the comparative effectiveness of the two pyloromyotomy techniques in the endoscopic management of refractory and severe gastroparesis.

This is a single-arm, open-label study evaluating the efficacy of Minayo Iron-rich Yeast Drink with SOD on female nutritional anemia, skin condition, and qi-blood deficiency syndrome. The study includes females aged 18-35 years with hemoglobin levels below 110g/L. Participants will consume one 25ml piece of the Minayo Yeast Drink Product daily for 4 consecutive weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in serum ferritin level from baseline to week 4. Secondary outcomes include changes in hemoglobin, superoxide dismutase (SOD), glutathione (GSH) levels, and skin lines/wrinkles measured by 3D imaging. The study aims to assess the potential benefits of this iron-rich yeast drink supplement on improving anemia, antioxidant levels, and skin condition in young women with nutritional anemia.

This is a crossover study investigating the effects of combining acute intermittent hypercapnic hypoxia (AIHH) exposure with transcutaneous spinal cord stimulation (tSCS) paired with respiratory and upper extremity strength training in individuals with chronic cervical spinal cord injury.

The key aspects are:

- Participants will receive 4 interventions in a randomized crossover design: 1) AIHH + tSCS-paired training, 2) Sham AIHH + tSCS-paired training, 3) AIHH + Sham tSCS-paired training, 4) Sham AIHH + Sham tSCS-paired training.

- Primary outcomes include changes in respiratory and upper extremity cortical/spinal drive, respiratory muscle strength, lung function, and upper extremity function measured before and after each intervention.

- Secondary outcome is cardiovascular response during AIHH exposure.

- The study aims to test if combining AIHH and tSCS with task-specific training can synergistically improve respiratory and upper limb function more than either treatment alone in chronic cervical S

This is a prospective, randomized controlled trial with a 2x2 factorial design investigating the effects of anesthetic maintenance agents (propofol vs. sevoflurane) and vasopressors (phenylephrine vs. ephedrine) on cerebral hemodynamics and metabolism in adult patients undergoing surgery under general anesthesia. The primary outcome is the difference in cerebral metabolic rate of oxygen consumption (CMRO2) during surgery between the anesthetic and vasopressor groups, measured using a hybrid time-resolved near-infrared spectroscopy and diffuse correlation spectroscopy system. Secondary outcomes include changes in cerebral blood flow (CBF) and CMRO2 during anesthesia induction. The study aims to assess how CBF and CMRO2 change under different anesthetic and vasopressor regimens, and whether there is an interaction effect between the two interventions. Eligible participants are adults aged 19 and above undergoing general anesthesia for surgery lasting longer than 1 hour, with certain exclusion criteria related to neurological conditions and contraindications to the study interventions. The RaDiCo-IDMet study is a national cohort study on imprinting disorders (IDs) and their metabolic consequences. It aims to investigate the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of various IDs, including Silver Russell Syndrome, Beckwith-Wiedemann Syndrome, Transient Neonatal Diabetes Mellitus, Angelman Syndrome, Prader-Willi Syndrome, Temple Syndrome, Kagami-Ogata Syndrome, Pseudohypoparathyroidism, and Familial Precocious Puberty, in both pediatric and adult patients.

The primary outcomes of the study are to assess the clinical, genetic, biological, and morphometric characteristics of IDs over a 10-year period. The secondary outcomes include exploring the association between metabolic phenotypes and biological profiles, determining the prevalence of metabolic abnormalities, estimating the risk of metabolic complications (obesity, diabetes, cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome), describing therapeutic approaches, analyzing quality-of-life scores, and studying the transmission of (epi)genetic mutations in probands and relatives.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, open-label clinical trial comparing unipolar versus bipolar interlocking intramedullary nailing for the treatment of humeral shaft fractures in adults. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with radiologically assessed bone healing at 12 months. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years or older with a diagnosis of humeral shaft fracture requiring surgical treatment with intramedullary nailing. Participants will be randomized to receive either unipolar or bipolar interlocking intramedullary nailing. Data will be collected through questionnaires (EQ-5D-5L and SF-12) and CT scans at 9 months, and at 12 months if the humerus is not consolidated at 6 months. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these two surgical techniques in achieving bone healing in humeral shaft fractures.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of combining cognitive and social cognitive training with a personalized real-time intervention for motivational enhancement (PRIME app) in improving cognition, motivation, and functional outcomes in individuals with early psychosis. The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving cognitive training, social cognitive training, and the PRIME app, and a control group receiving treatment as usual in their early psychosis coordinated specialty care program.

The primary outcomes measured include changes in cognitive function (assessed by Test My Brain scores), defeatist beliefs (Dysfunctional Attitudes Scale - Defeatist Beliefs Subscale), quality of life, behavioral inhibition and activation (Behavioral Inhibition and Activation Scale), and motivation and pleasure (Motivation and Pleasure Scale - Self Report). Secondary outcomes include depression and anxiety symptoms (COMPASS-10).

The study targets individuals aged 18-40 years enrolled in an early psychosis coordinated specialty care clinic, with an estimated IQ of 70 or above, clinical stability, and access to a smartphone or computer. The intervention group will receive 20 hours of cognitive and social cognitive training over 12 weeks, along with the PRIME app,

This is a prospective, randomized, parallel-group clinical trial assessing the use of wearable fitness trackers to monitor and optimize prehabilitation (pre-operative exercise) in patients with non-metastatic esophagogastric, hepatobiliary, or lung cancer scheduled for curative surgical resection.

The study aims to evaluate if prescribing exercise based on personalized heart rate zones and using fitness trackers to monitor heart rate improves adherence and achievement of moderate-intensity exercise targets compared to the standard approach of using rating of perceived exertion (RPE).

Participants will be randomized into two groups:
1) Control group: Exercise prescribed based on RPE goal of 12-14
2) Intervention group: Exercise prescribed based on maintaining heart rate above 50% of heart rate reserve

The primary outcome is the total number of minutes of moderate-intensity exercise achieved over 8 weeks, measured by the fitness tracker. Secondary outcomes include physical activity volume, weekly exercise adherence, comparison of self-reported vs. recorded exercise duration and intensity, and patient feedback on acceptability, usability, and user experience of the fitness trackers.

The study will enroll 82

This is a multicentre, single-blinded, randomized, controlled, superiority trial comparing two minimally invasive treatments for pilonidal disease: pit-picking surgery alone versus pit-picking surgery combined with sinus laser-assisted closure (SiLaC). The study aims to evaluate the success rate of treatment, defined as wound healing outcomes at 1 year, including closure of all pits, absence of symptoms, absence of persisting sinuses, and absence of recurrence. Secondary outcomes include long-term success rate, pain scores, patient-reported outcomes, wound healing and complications, work rehabilitation, return to daily activities, recurrence rate, need for secondary or revision surgery, patient satisfaction, and quality of life. Eligible participants are aged 12 years and older with primary pilonidal sinus disease (Types 1b and 3 of the Dutch staging system). The study involves randomization to either pit-picking surgery alone or pit-picking surgery followed by sinus laser-assisted closure using a radial diode laser probe at 1470 nm wavelength. The primary outcome will be assessed at 1 year, and secondary outcomes will be evaluated up to 5 years after treatment.

This clinical trial aims to identify the sociodemographic characteristics, personality traits, and patterns of substance abuse among patients admitted to the Addiction Management Unit of Assiut University Hospital in Egypt. The study involves patients aged 18 years or older with substance use disorders who are admitted to the unit for treatment.

The primary objectives are:

1. To identify the sociodemographic characteristics of patients, including personal information, socioeconomic status, previous detoxification attempts, and adverse life events, through a specially prepared survey and psychiatric interviews.

2. To identify personality traits of patients using psychiatric interviews, the Symptom Checklist-90-Revised (SCL-90-R), and the Five-Factor Model of Personality.

3. To identify patterns of substance abuse, including the substances used, doses, routes of administration, and circumstances of use, through psychiatric interviews, the Severity of Dependence Scale (SDS), and urine drug screening.

The intervention involves supportive psychotherapy, counseling, and rehabilitation to help patients detoxify and reintegrate into society. The study aims to provide valuable information to healthcare professionals, authorities, and policymakers for better planning and implementation of prevention

This is a phase 2, single-arm, open-label study investigating the efficacy and safety of combining immune checkpoint inhibitors (durvalumab and tremelimumab) with radioembolization (yttrium-90 microspheres) for the treatment of previously untreated metastatic hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The primary outcomes are best objective response rate and rate of abscopal effect (response of tumors outside the radiation field). Secondary outcomes include progression-free survival, overall survival, treatment-related side effects, local and distant control rates. Eligible patients must have metastatic HCC, adequate organ function, and meet other specified criteria. All patients will receive durvalumab, tremelimumab, and radioembolization according to the treatment schedule outlined in the study design.

This is a Phase II, single-arm, open-label study evaluating the combination of neoadjuvant durvalumab (anti-PD-L1), tremelimumab (anti-CTLA-4), gemcitabine, and cisplatin in patients with borderline resectable or resectable but high-risk intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma. The primary objective is to assess the rate of conversion from unresectable to resectable disease after 4 or 8 cycles of the combination therapy. Key eligibility criteria include histologically proven intrahepatic cholangiocarcinoma, absence of extrahepatic metastases, and resectable disease if tumor shrinkage occurs. Patients will receive durvalumab, tremelimumab, gemcitabine, and cisplatin for up to 8 cycles, with surgical resection planned if the tumor becomes resectable after cycle 4 or 8. The study will evaluate the conversion rate, objective response rate, pathological complete response, survival outcomes, resection rates, and safety/tolerability. This trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this neoadj

This is a multi-center clinical study aimed at establishing normal reference values for the structure and hemodynamics of extremity arteries in healthy Han Chinese adults using high-frequency ultrasound. The study will measure the intima thickness and blood flow velocity of the dorsalis pedis artery and proper palmar digital artery, which can reflect early changes in vascular structure and hemodynamics, respectively. The study will enroll healthy Han Chinese volunteers aged 18-79 years with normal vital signs, blood tests, and no history of cardiovascular, connective tissue, or peripheral vascular diseases. The participants will undergo a non-invasive high-frequency ultrasound examination of the extremity arteries to quantify the arterial structure and blood flow parameters. The study aims to provide quantitative reference values for early diagnosis, severity assessment, and treatment monitoring of extremity arterial diseases such as atherosclerosis and connective tissue disorders.

This is a pivotal, prospective, single-center, split-mouth, randomized, controlled study evaluating the efficacy and safety of STERIFY GEL, a mucoadhesive polymeric hydrogel, in the treatment of periodontitis following scaling and root planing (SRP). The study aims to assess if STERIFY GEL, when applied into periodontal pockets after SRP, can promote better healing compared to SRP alone.

The study includes patients with grade III and IV chronic periodontal disease, aged 18 years or older. Participants will undergo whole-mouth extended SRP, with STERIFY GEL administered into the periodontal pockets of one or two segments, while the contralateral segments serve as controls (split-mouth design).

The primary outcome measure is the change in periodontal pocket depth, measured by a periodontal probe at pre-treatment, 1 month, 2 months, and 3 months. Secondary outcomes include gingival recession, clinical attachment level, plaque index, bleeding index, furcations, grade of mobility, and quantification of bacterial contamination.

This is a randomized, parallel-group study that aims to evaluate the effect of combining hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) with hippocampal training (physical and cognitive training) on enhancing recovery of inaccessible traumatic memories in male veterans (aged 25-60 years) with combat-associated post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and peritraumatic amnesia.

The study will enroll 40 participants who will be randomly assigned to receive either:

1) HBOT alone: 60 daily sessions of 90 minutes 100% oxygen at 2 atmospheres absolute (ATA) pressure, or 

2) HBOT + hippocampal training: Same HBOT protocol combined with physical and cognitive training 3 times per week prior to HBOT sessions.

The primary outcomes are changes in memory gaps assessed by a traumatic scene form, and time to surfacing of inaccessible memories. Secondary outcomes include brain activity changes (fMRI), cognitive performance, and memory test scores.

The study aims to investigate if hippocampal training can augment the neuroplasticity effects of HBOT and further enhance

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT imaging for the diagnosis of cardiac sarcoidosis, an inflammatory condition affecting the heart. The study involves four groups of participants:

Group A: 22 patients with suspected cardiac sarcoidosis
Group B: 22 patients with known cardiac sarcoidosis
Group C: Up to 10 patients with suspected or confirmed acute lymphocytic myocarditis
Group D: 22 patients with neuroendocrine tumors without inflammatory heart disease (control group)

Participants in Groups A, B, and C will undergo a 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scan in addition to routine clinical procedures. Group D data will be retrospectively included from previous 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT scans performed as part of their clinical care.

The primary outcome measure is the proportion of patients with tracer uptake in the heart on 64Cu-DOTATATE PET/CT in patients with verified cardiac sarcoidosis and the proportion without tracer uptake in the control group.

Secondary outcomes include adverse events over 24 months, tracer

This is a randomized, double-blinded, placebo-controlled, single-center pilot/exploratory trial investigating the effect of probiotics on immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea among renal transplant recipients. The study aims to assess whether probiotics can reduce diarrhea and analyze inflammatory biomarkers and their association with fecal microbiome in these patients.

The study includes two arms: an active comparator group receiving one probiotic capsule (Florajen Digestion) daily for six months after the onset of post-surgical non-infectious diarrhea, and a placebo comparator group receiving a placebo capsule daily for the same duration.

The primary outcomes measured are the reduction in immunosuppressive-drug-associated diarrhea, assessed through gastrointestinal questionnaires and the Bristol Stool Chart, and the analysis of inflammatory biomarkers (TNF, IFN, Treg cytokines, and MMPs) in whole blood samples. Additionally, the association between inflammatory markers and fecal microbiome, analyzed through 16S PCR and Next-Gen sequencing, will be evaluated.

This is a randomized clinical trial investigating the efficacy of inhaled sedation with sevoflurane compared to intravenous sedation for improving oxygenation in ICU patients at high risk of developing acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). The primary outcome is the longitudinal evolution of the PaO2/FiO2 ratio within 5 days from randomization. Secondary outcomes include progression to ARDS, rate of pneumonia, ventilator-free days, organ failure, mortality, length of ICU stay, physiological measures (oxygenation, PaCO2, pH, PEEP, plateau pressure, pneumothorax, respiratory drive), hemodynamic measures, acute kidney injury, supraventricular tachycardia, ICU-acquired delirium, and biomarker measurements. Eligible participants are ICU patients aged 18 or older with risk factors for ARDS, under invasive mechanical ventilation, and expected to require sedation for at least 4 hours. The study has two parallel arms: inhaled sedation with sevoflurane and intravenous sedation as per current practice. It is a single-

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study evaluating different treatment modalities for massive rotator cuff tendon tears in patients aged 50-80 years. The study compares three interventions: 1) arthroscopic rotator cuff partial repair with superior capsular augmentation using the long head of biceps brachii tendon (LHBBT), 2) arthroscopic partial rotator cuff repair, and 3) arthroscopic complete rotator cuff repair. There is also a conservative treatment group receiving physiotherapy. The primary outcomes include changes in shoulder strength, range of motion, and functional scores (ASES, CMS, DASH, VAS pain). Secondary outcomes assess tendon integrity on MRI using the Sugaya classification, quality of life (EEK-2), and kinesiophobia (Tampa scale). Assessments are done preoperatively and at 6, 12, and 24 months postoperatively. The study aims to evaluate the functional outcomes and tendon healing with different surgical techniques for treating massive rotator cuff tears.

The Injection-Related InfectionS (IRIS) Program is a clinical trial aimed at optimizing the treatment of injection-related infections for people who inject drugs in Hamilton, Ontario. The study involves a single-arm intervention group that will receive a holistic, one-stop, low-barrier combined care model to address their injection-related infections, substance use treatment, peer support, and care coordination/systems navigation.

The primary outcome measure is the number of emergency department visits and hospital readmissions within 30 days of initial hospital admission or program enrollment. Secondary outcomes include completion of intended treatment course for the infection, number of hospital readmissions and emergency department visits specifically for the primary infection within 90 days, number of new initiations or continuation of substance use treatment within 90 days, mortality rates within 6 months, and rates of program drop-out and reasons for discontinuation within 6 months.

The study is open to individuals aged 16 or older who can provide informed consent, have a confirmed or suspected injection-related infection, have a history of injection drug use within 3 months, and live in Hamilton, Ontario.

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the use of a mobile app (CanImmunize) and a web-based platform for surveillance of adverse events following influenza immunization. The study aims to assess the useability of these two platforms through a user experience survey. Participants aged 18 years or older who received the seasonal influenza vaccine are eligible. They are randomly assigned to either the mobile app arm or the web-based notification arm. In the app arm, participants download the CanImmunize app, activate their account, and can spontaneously report adverse events or receive notifications for a safety survey 8 days after vaccination. In the web-based arm, participants receive email notifications with a survey link 8 days after vaccination and a reminder on day 11 if not completed. The primary outcome measure is useability, assessed through a user experience survey evaluating perceived ease of use, perceived usefulness, attitudes, intention of use, and vaccine confidence and safety.

This is a case-control study that aims to investigate the relationship between peri-implantitis and the following factors:

1. COX-2 gene polymorphisms: The study will analyze if certain COX-2 gene polymorphisms are associated with peri-implantitis by collecting buccal swab samples from participants and performing genetic analysis.

2. Pathogenic microbiota: Using next-generation sequencing (16S rRNA), the study will characterize the microbial profile associated with peri-implantitis lesions by collecting samples from peri-implant crevices. 

3. Diagnostic accuracy of ImplantSafe MMP-8 test: The study will evaluate the diagnostic performance of the ImplantSafe rapid test, which measures active matrix metalloproteinase-8 (aMMP-8) levels in peri-implant crevicular fluid, as a biomarker for peri-implantitis.

The study plans to recruit a minimum of 100 patients diagnosed with peri-implantitis according to the

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of virtual reality on pain, anxiety, and patient comfort during trigger point injection. The study has an experimental group and a control group. Patients in the experimental group will wear virtual reality glasses and watch videos of their choice, such as nature scenes or underwater videos with background music, for 10 minutes during the trigger point injection procedure. The control group will undergo the routine practice without virtual reality. The primary outcomes measured are state anxiety levels using the State Anxiety Scale, comfort levels using the General Comfort Scale, and pain levels using the Visual Analog Scale. These outcomes will be assessed 10 minutes after the procedure for anxiety and comfort, and during the middle of the procedure for pain. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with a single-blind masking. Eligible participants are adults aged 18-65 years who can understand and speak Turkish, have good cognitive abilities, and do not have visual or hearing loss or epilepsy.

This is a prospective observational study investigating the effect of autonomic dysfunction on hemodynamic instability during per-oral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) in achalasia patients. The study involves two groups: patients with autonomic dysfunction (determined by preoperative heart rate variability test) and patients with normal autonomic function. Both groups will undergo POEM under standardized general anesthesia. The primary outcome measure is the wobble of systolic arterial pressure (SAP) during surgery, which will be calculated using a specific formula to assess hemodynamic instability. The study aims to evaluate whether autonomic dysfunction contributes to hemodynamic instability during POEM, which could have implications for anesthetic management in these patients.

This is a summarization of the provided clinical trial document:

The study aimed to evaluate the use of virtual reality (VR) glasses during inhaler treatment in children aged 2-5 years. It was a prospective, single-blind, randomized, controlled study conducted at a pediatric emergency department. Children were divided into three groups: VR audio-visual users with Roller Coasters (group 1), VR audio-visual users with Wild Dolphins (group 2), and a control group without any additional equipment (group 3). 

The primary outcome measure was the change in pain scoring systems, helping with uncomfortable procedures for children. Crying times, changes in respiratory rate, oxygen saturation, heart rate, and pre- and post-treatment physician and family questionnaires were compared among the groups during the 15-minute inhaler treatment.

Children with various conditions, such as neuromotor retardation, chronic diseases, obesity, or malnutrition, were excluded from the study. A total of 135 children were included and randomly assigned to the three groups using a computer-generated block method.

The study aimed to investigate the potential benefits of using VR glasses as a distraction

This is a clinical open trial evaluating the feasibility, acceptability, and effects of a transdiagnostic psychological treatment called the Unified Protocol (UP-C/A) for children and youth aged 7-17 years with anxiety disorders and/or depression, and their parents. The study is conducted at two primary care clinics. The UP-C/A is a group treatment intervention based on the third-wave of Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT), delivered over 11 sessions to children and adolescents, with parallel parent training groups. The primary outcome measure is the Emotion Regulation Index for Children and Adolescents (ERICA). Secondary outcomes include the Revised Children's Anxiety and Depression Scale (R-CADS), Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ), Kidscreen-10 Index, Children's Global Assessment Scale (C-GAS), Client Satisfaction Questionnaire (CSQ-8), and clinician-reported measures of intervention appropriateness, acceptability, and feasibility. The study aims to recruit around 30 participants across 5 treatment groups, with assessments conducted pre-intervention, post-intervention (12

This is a study (PALISA) evaluating pain and stress levels in preterm infants (≥27 weeks gestation) during less-invasive surfactant administration (LISA) procedure. The primary outcome measure is the median peaks per second of skin conductance, which reflects sympathetic nerve activity, at specific time points adjusted for baseline. Secondary outcomes include Neonatal Pain, Agitation and Sedation Scale (N-PASS) scores, number of apneas, desaturations, bradycardias, hypotensions, and surfactant reflux during LISA, as well as differences in skin conductance, vital signs, and oxygenation parameters before and after these events. Other outcomes are LISA failure, need for intubation, air leaks, and intraventricular hemorrhage within 72 hours. Skin conductance will be measured using electrodes on the infant's foot, while video recording will allow blinded N-PASS scoring. The study aims to objectively assess pain and stress during the less-invasive surfactant administration procedure in preterm neonates.

This is a feasibility cluster randomized controlled trial investigating a home-based depression care intervention for older adults in Nigeria, delivered by lay providers. The trial aims to assess the effectiveness of an adapted version of the World Health Organization's Mental Health Gap Action Programme Intervention Guide (emhGAP-IG) combined with Problem-Solving Therapy for Primary Care (PST-PC) in treating depression among older adults. The study has two arms: the experimental arm receiving the adapted emhGAP-Age intervention, and the active comparator arm receiving the generic emhGAP-IG intervention. The primary outcome measure is depression remission, defined as a Patient Health Questionnaire (PHQ-9) score below 6, measured at six months post-trial entry. Eligible participants are aged 60 years or older, with a PHQ-9 score of 11 or higher during routine consultation, and without severe comorbidities, cognitive impairment, active suicidal intention, or severe mental health disorders.
