This is a prospective, single-center, single-blinded, randomized controlled trial comparing the efficacy of augmented anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) reconstruction using a platelet-rich plasma (PrP) enriched collected autologous bone composite versus standard ACL reconstruction technique. The study aims to evaluate if the use of the bone/PrP composite in the tibial tunnel can reduce tunnel widening, improve graft integration, and enhance overall graft maturation and knee function over a 24-month follow-up period.

The study will enroll 107 patients aged 18-50 years with primary ACL rupture, scheduled for ACL reconstruction surgery. Participants will be randomly allocated 1:1 to either the experimental arm (ACL reconstruction with bone/PrP composite) or the control arm (standard ACL reconstruction).

The primary outcomes are changes in tibial tunnel diameter and volume, assessed by CT scans at 10-14 months post-surgery. Secondary outcomes include femoral tunnel changes, graft maturity and integration assessed by MRI, bone healing and integration of the autologous bone matrix, and knee function evaluated clinically, functionally,

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the use of high flow nasal oxygen cannula (HFNOC) for preoxygenation during rapid sequence induction (RSI) in infants and small children undergoing surgery. The study aims to evaluate the impact of HFNOC preoxygenation on oxygen saturation and heart rate during anesthesia induction, as well as its safety and efficacy compared to traditional face-mask preoxygenation.

The study involves three parallel groups: 1) RSI with face-mask preoxygenation, 2) RSI with HFNOC preoxygenation, and 3) RSI with both HFNOC and face-mask preoxygenation. Eligible participants are pediatric patients up to 6 years old requiring RSI for surgery.

The primary outcomes are the incidence of oxygen desaturation below 90% and the need for manual ventilation during RSI. Secondary outcomes include desaturation below 80%, time to desaturation, time needed for muscle relaxation and intubation, time to reach 100% oxygen saturation, first intubation attempt

This is an open-label extension study evaluating the long-term safety, tolerability, and efficacy of the combination therapy pozelimab and cemdisiran in adult patients with paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). The study has two arms: 1) PNH patients transitioning from a parent study who received the combination therapy, and 2) PNH patients with a documented C5 polymorphism rendering them refractory to eculizumab or ravulizumab. The primary outcomes measure the incidence and severity of serious adverse events, adverse events of special interest, and adverse events leading to treatment discontinuation up to week 108. Secondary outcomes assess maintenance of adequate hemolysis control, transfusion avoidance, breakthrough hemolysis, hemoglobin stabilization, changes in fatigue and quality of life scores, and other PNH-related measures through week 108. Safety, pharmacokinetic, and pharmacodynamic parameters are also evaluated. The study aims to provide long-term data on the safety and efficacy of this novel combination therapy for PNH patients.

This is a 24-week prospective cohort study examining predictors of initial six-month subscription and subscription renewal rates for the WayBetter health and fitness app among approximately 400 new adult users (aged ≥18 years). The primary outcomes are rates of (a) initial six-month subscription and (b) subscription renewal at six months. Secondary outcomes include app engagement metrics like app opens per week, date of joining first game, game adherence, number of games started and won, non-usage attrition, and re-engagement. The study will collect data on socio-demographics, past health behaviors, psychological determinants, and app engagement metrics. Users receive a 7-day free trial and $10 deposit to try games requiring specific behavioral goals with $10-30 deposits. Winners share the deposit pot. The study aims to identify predictors of app uptake, subscription, and engagement using latent class analysis, regression models, and descriptive statistics.

This is a randomized clinical trial comparing the effects of aerobic exercises and Pilates exercises on depression and sleep quality in primigravida (first-time pregnant) females during their third trimester of pregnancy. The study aims to enroll 42 participants aged 18-35 years who are in their 26th to 33rd week of pregnancy and have symptoms of depression. Participants will be randomly assigned to either an aerobic exercise group or a Pilates exercise group. Both groups will receive 16 sessions of their respective exercise intervention, with two sessions per week for 8 weeks. The primary outcomes measured are depression symptoms using the Center for Epidemiologic Studies Depression Scale (CES-D) and sleep quality using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI). Assessments will be conducted at baseline and after 8 weeks of the exercise interventions. The study excludes participants with conditions like gestational diabetes, pregnancy hypertension, placenta previa, previous miscarriage history, or any medical condition prohibiting exercise. The trial aims to evaluate the comparative effects of aerobic and Pilates exercises as potential treatments for improving depression and sleep quality in primigravida females during the third trim

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effect of swaddling and inhaling breast milk odor on pain and comfort levels during peripheral intravenous catheter placement in term infants. The study had four groups: 1) swaddled infants, 2) infants exposed to breast milk odor, 3) infants both swaddled and exposed to breast milk odor, and 4) a control group with no intervention. The trial enrolled 120 term infants hospitalized in the neonatal intensive care unit, with 30 infants randomly assigned to each group. The primary outcome measure was the effect of swaddling on pain and comfort levels, assessed using the Neonatal Infant Pain Scale (NIPS) and Newborn Comfort Behavior Scale before, during, and after the procedure. The secondary outcome measure was the effect of inhaling breast milk odor on pain and comfort levels, evaluated using the same scales and timepoints. The study aimed to determine the efficacy of these non-pharmacological interventions in reducing pain and improving comfort during peripheral intravenous catheter placement in term infants.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the biological mechanisms underlying the efficacy of psychotherapy for depression using functional Near-Infrared Spectroscopy (fNIRS). The study hypothesizes that levels of oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglobin in different brain regions may fluctuate at different stages of depression and treatment, reflecting changes in brain activation.

The trial involves three parallel groups: 1) medication therapy with antidepressants, 2) Interpersonal Psychotherapy (IPT), and 3) a combination of medication and IPT. Participants aged 16-50 years with a diagnosis of depression will be randomly assigned to one of these groups.

The primary outcome measures are changes in fNIRS signals and remission rates based on the Hamilton Depression Scale (HAM-D24) after treatment. Secondary outcomes include remission rates assessed by the Patient Health Questionnaire-9 (PHQ-9), Beck Depression Inventory (BDI), and Beck Scale for Suicidal Ideation (SSI).

The study will use fNIRS to measure relative changes in oxygenated and deoxygenated hemoglo

This is a single-arm, open-label study evaluating the safety and diagnostic performance of indium In 111 panitumumab (111In-panitumumab) as a molecular imaging agent for nodal staging in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC). The primary objective is to assess the safety of 111In-panitumumab. Secondary objectives include comparing the sensitivity and specificity of identifying sentinel lymph nodes by systemic injection of 111In-panitumumab versus conventional local injection of an optical dye during surgery. Exploratory objectives involve determining if 111In-panitumumab SPECT/CT can identify tumor-positive lymph nodes preoperatively and evaluating its performance compared to preoperative MRI and 18F-FDG PET/CT. Eligible patients will receive a panitumumab loading dose followed by 111In-panitumumab injection, undergo SPECT/CT imaging before surgery, receive an optical dye injection during surgery, and undergo intraoperative and near-infrared imaging. Safety will be assessed by monitoring adverse events, and diagnostic performance measures will be evaluated.

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the efficacy and mechanism of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation combined with medication for the treatment of generalized anxiety disorder. The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving active transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation plus anti-anxiety medication, and a placebo group receiving sham stimulation plus anti-anxiety medication. The primary outcome measure is the change in Hamilton Anxiety Scale scores from baseline to week 2 of treatment. Secondary outcomes include changes in Hamilton Anxiety Scale and Hamilton Depression Scale scores at week 4, changes in Generalized Anxiety Scale scores at weeks 2 and 4, changes in brain function indicators (measured by functional near-infrared spectroscopy and event-related potentials) from baseline to end of treatment, and incidence of adverse events. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and potential mechanisms of transcutaneous vagus nerve stimulation as an adjunctive treatment for generalized anxiety disorder.

This clinical study aimed to evaluate the efficacy and factors associated with treatment failure of dacryoendoscopic-assisted laser dacryoplasty with silicone intubation (DLDI) for the management of nasolacrimal duct obstruction (NLDO). The study included patients aged 18-80 years with confirmed NLDO diagnosis based on dacryoendoscopic examination and radiologic confirmation. Patients were divided into three groups: group A with higher nasolacrimal duct obstruction, group B with lower nasolacrimal duct obstruction, and group C with nasolacrimal duct stenosis. The intervention involved inserting a dacryoendoscopy into the lacrimal duct, performing laser dacryoplasty to widen the obstructed or stenotic section, and then inserting a silicone tube into the lacrimal passage. The primary outcome measure was the cumulative success rate of DLDI within a 2-year follow-up period, obtained using the Kaplan-Meier estimator. The study aimed to report the treatment outcomes of DLDI for NLDO and identify factors associated with treatment

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the immediate effects of proprioceptive neuromuscular facilitation (PNF) with lower leg kinesio taping on ankle dorsiflexion, gait, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke.

The study involves three parallel arms:
1) Lower leg kinesio taping applied to the tibialis anterior for 30 minutes
2) PNF hold-relax technique applied to the ankle with 15-30 repetitions on the affected side
3) Combination of lower leg kinesio taping and PNF hold-relax technique

The primary outcome measures include the Timed Up and Go test, Barthel Index, Motor Assessment Scale, and Dynamic Gait Index, assessed at baseline and 1 hour after the intervention.

The study aims to evaluate the immediate effects of these interventions on improving ankle dorsiflexion, gait parameters, and functional mobility in patients with chronic stroke who have insufficient ankle dorsiflexion during the swing phase of gait.

Participants aged 40-70 years with chronic stroke (>6 months), able to walk independently for 10 meters without

This is a mixed-methods, multi-center, non-randomized, quasi-experimental, before-and-after, open, cross-sectional study with three phases to develop and evaluate an algorithm for vascular access management. 

Phase 1 (4 months) is an observational phase to describe current practices for peripheral venous catheter placement. 

Phase 2 (4 months) implements the A-DIVA Scale (a classification score for difficult intravenous access) and evaluates its impact on catheter placement practices. 

An 8-month interphase follows to co-construct a decision-making tree (the A-DIVA Tool) using data from Phases 1 and 2. 

Phase 3 (4 months) implements and evaluates the algorithm composed of the A-DIVA Scale and the co-constructed A-DIVA Tool, assessing its impact on the quality of peripheral venous catheter placement.

The primary outcome is the number of venipunctures per patient after algorithm implementation. Secondary outcomes include acceptability and feasibility of using the tools, patient pain scores, venipuncture attempts, catheter insertion

This is a single-arm, open-label clinical trial evaluating the performance and safety of the STARgraft-3 device for hemodialysis access in patients with end-stage renal disease. The study involves implanting a 6mm diameter STARgraft-3 graft as an upper arm brachial artery to axillary vein shunt for hemodialysis access. The primary outcome measure is the primary unassisted patency rate at 6 months post-implantation, defined as the percentage of subjects without access thrombosis or procedures to maintain patency. Secondary outcomes include patency rates at various time points up to 12 months, frequency of interventions, blood flow rates in the grafts, and safety outcomes such as adverse events. The study has specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to patient characteristics, vascular anatomy, and medical history. Key eligibility criteria include being a candidate for a new upper arm arteriovenous graft, acceptable cardiac function, and absence of certain conditions like pregnancy, immunodeficiency, or recent COVID-19 infection.

This is a randomized clinical trial investigating the efficacy of a digital emotion regulation treatment called Primary Care Online Emotion-regulation Treatment (POET) for adolescents aged 12-17 years with mental health problems. The trial aims to evaluate the effects of POET on mental health problems and emotion regulation compared to an active control condition (supportive treatment). 

The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the POET treatment group or the supportive treatment (active control) group.

2. POET is a 6-week digital treatment program that includes guided online modules for adolescents and their parents, focusing on psychoeducation, addressing maladaptive beliefs about emotions, and teaching adaptive emotion regulation strategies.

3. The supportive treatment (active control) also involves 6 weeks of guided online modules for adolescents and parents, but with educative material on mental health and self-reflection exercises.

4. The primary outcome measure is the Clinical Global Impressions-Severity scale (CGI-S), which assesses symptom severity.

5. Secondary outcome measures include scales assessing anxiety, depression, emotion regulation, functioning, quality of life

This is a multicenter, randomized, open-label, phase III trial evaluating the impact of hypofractionated radiotherapy strategies after surgery for non-melanoma skin cancer in older patients aged ≥70 years. The trial has three arms:

Arm A: Surgery alone 
Arm B: Surgery + Moderate hypofractionation (45Gy in 15 fractions over 5 weeks) 
Arm C: Surgery + Extreme hypofractionation (30Gy in 5 fractions over 5 weeks)

The primary outcome is local tumor control at 3-year follow-up. Secondary outcomes include health-related quality of life (EORTC QLQ-C30, QLQ-ELD14), treatment burden, toxicity (CTCAE v4.03), regional recurrence, progression-free survival, and overall survival at 3 years.

Eligible patients have non-melanoma skin cancer (squamous cell carcinoma or basal cell carcinoma) with high-risk features after surgery, performance status 0-3, and no prior radiotherapy to the treatment site.

This is a study investigating the risks and benefits of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults (age 75 and above) who previously had precancerous polyps (adenomas) removed. The key aspects are:

1. Aim 1: Compare the cumulative colorectal cancer (CRC) risk after age 75 in older adults with a history of normal colonoscopy vs. those with a history of colonoscopy with polypectomy (removal of adenomas) prior to age 75.

2. Aim 2: Among older adults with polypectomy prior to age 75, assess the comparative effectiveness of exposure vs. no exposure to surveillance colonoscopy after age 75 in reducing CRC risk and mortality.

3. Aim 3: Obtain perspectives from Veterans, providers, and policymakers regarding CRC risk and outcomes of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults through interviews and an expert panel. The goal is to provide recommendations on the use of surveillance colonoscopy in this population.

The study aims to fill critical evidence gaps on the benefits of surveillance colonoscopy in older adults with prior adenomas, considering the increasing risks of complications and competing causes of mortality with age.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of early bedside cycling exercises on physical and psychological outcomes in patients after heart valve surgery. The study will recruit 50 patients aged 20-40 years with valvular heart disease undergoing valve replacement or intervention at the National Heart Institute in Cairo, Egypt.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group (n=25) or the control group (n=25). The intervention group will receive daily bedside cycling exercises in addition to routine medical treatment and physiotherapy, starting from when they are extubated and stable until hospital discharge. The cycling will be low to moderate intensity, with a session duration of 20 minutes once daily. The control group will receive only routine physiotherapy and medical treatment.

The primary outcomes measured include functional capacity (6-minute walk test), forced vital capacity (spirometry), psychological status (Depression Anxiety Stress Scales), activities of daily living (Barthel Index), quality of life (SF-12), and length of hospital stay. Secondary outcomes include 1-month follow-up assessments of functional capacity, psychological status, quality of life, incidence of adverse events, and prothrombin international normalized ratio (INR

The provided text summarizes a clinical trial called the "Sloane Project" which aims to conduct molecular analysis of screen-detected non-invasive breast cancer and atypical breast hyperplasias. The study includes participants with conditions such as ductal carcinoma in situ (DCIS), lobular carcinoma in situ (LCIS), atypical ductal hyperplasia, and atypical lobular hyperplasia. Only females are eligible for the study. The primary outcome measure is the progression of breast disease, which will be measured from the time of diagnosis until the end of 2016.

This is a randomized, parallel-group, quadruple-masked clinical trial investigating the concurrent treatment of obesity and type 1 diabetes with tirzepatide, a GLP-1/GIP agonist drug. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of tirzepatide in reducing body weight and improving glycemic control in adults aged 18-70 years with type 1 diabetes and obesity (BMI ≥30 kg/m2).

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, receiving tirzepatide (dose escalated up to 15 mg once weekly) in addition to their usual insulin therapy, or the control group, continuing their typical insulin treatment alone. The primary outcome measure is the percent change in body weight after 32 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcomes include changes in HbA1c levels, continuous glucose monitoring metrics (time in range, hypoglycemia, hyperglycemia), insulin requirements, waist and neck circumference, blood pressure, lipid parameters, renal function, and markers of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease.

The study has strict inclusion and exclusion criteria, including a recent diagnosis of type 1 diabetes, obesity

This is a randomized, parallel-assignment, single-blind clinical trial investigating the efficacy of losartan in preventing paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy in breast cancer patients receiving paclitaxel chemotherapy. The study involves two arms: a control arm receiving standard care for chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, and an intervention arm receiving standard care plus 100mg losartan. The primary outcomes are the incidence and grade of paclitaxel-induced peripheral neuropathy at 12 weeks, assessed using NCI criteria. Secondary outcomes include quality of life measured by the FACT/GOG-NTX questionnaire and serum levels of the nerve growth factor biomarker at 12 weeks. The study is recruiting female breast cancer patients over 18 years old scheduled for paclitaxel chemotherapy, excluding those with conditions like hypertension, diabetes, renal impairment, liver disease, metastatic cancer, pregnancy, or pre-existing neuropathy.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, parallel-group clinical trial investigating the effects of Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets on cognitive function in patients with type 2 diabetes and mild cognitive impairment. The study involved 370 participants aged 60-90 years, randomly assigned to either the experimental group receiving Ginkgo biloba ketone ester tablets (0.5g, three times daily) plus conventional hypoglycemic treatment or the control group receiving placebo plus conventional hypoglycemic treatment for 6 months. The primary outcome measure was cognitive function assessed by the Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale-Cognitive section (ADAS-cog). Secondary outcomes included memory function (Auditory Word Learning Test), daily living ability (Functional Activity Questionnaire), executive function (Shape Connection Test A and B), and attention (Symbolic Digital Form Test). The study also measured biomarkers such as C-reactive protein, interleukin-6, oxidative stress, ApoE4 genotype, phosphorylated tau protein, irisin, and β-amyloid protein, as well as vascular parameters like ankle-brachial

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial comparing two treatment regimens for newly diagnosed severe aplastic anemia (SAA) in elderly patients (aged ≥60 years). The trial aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of ciclosporin A (CsA) + avatrombopag (AVA) versus CsA + anti-thymocyte immunoglobulin (ATG) + AVA in this patient population.

The primary outcome measure is the overall response rate, defined as the proportion of patients achieving partial or complete response at 6 months. Secondary outcomes include complete response rate, relapse rate, and adverse event rate at various time points.

Patients in the first arm will receive CsA (3-5 mg/kg/day orally), ATG (rabbit anti-human thymocyte immunoglobulin, 3 mg/kg/day intravenously for 5 days), and AVA (60 mg/day orally for 24 weeks). The second arm will receive CsA and AVA at the same doses but without ATG.

The trial aims to determine if the

This is a diagnostic study evaluating the use of zirconium Zr 89 panitumumab (89Zr-panitumumab) with PET/CT imaging for detecting indeterminate metastatic lesions in patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma. The primary objectives are to determine the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT in detecting these lesions. Secondary objectives include comparing the sensitivity and specificity of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT to standard imaging modalities like MRI, CT, and 18F-FDG PET/CT. Patients will receive panitumumab, 89Zr-panitumumab, and undergo PET/CT imaging as part of the study procedures. The study aims to assess the diagnostic accuracy of 89Zr-panitumumab PET/CT in identifying metastatic lesions in head and neck cancer patients over a follow-up period of up to 7 years.

This is a prospective, open-label, multicenter, randomized controlled phase III study investigating the efficacy of prophylactic central neck dissection in low-risk papillary thyroid cancer patients. The study aims to assess the effect of prophylactic central neck dissection on achieving excellent response and improving recurrence-free survival in patients with cN0 (no clinically evident lymph node metastasis) low-risk papillary thyroid cancer. Eligible participants aged 18-70 years with cT1b-T2 (tumor size 11-40 mm) papillary thyroid cancer will be randomized to either undergo prophylactic central neck dissection (test group) or no central neck dissection (control group) during thyroidectomy. The primary outcome is the rate of excellent response at 1 year, and the secondary outcome is recurrence-free survival at 1 and 2 years.

This is a three-arm, single-blinded, cluster-randomized superiority trial conducted in Tiebissou, Côte d'Ivoire, to evaluate the efficacy of two next-generation long-lasting insecticidal nets (LLINs) for malaria control. The study arms are: 1) Veeralin LLIN (alpha-cypermethrin + piperonyl butoxide), 2) Interceptor G2 LLIN (alpha-cypermethrin + chlorfenapyr), and 3) MAGNet LLIN (alpha-cypermethrin only, control arm). The primary outcome is malaria case incidence measured by rapid diagnostic tests in children aged 6 months to 10 years over one year of follow-up. Secondary outcomes include malaria infection prevalence in all ages at baseline, 6 months, and 12 months post-intervention, vector density, sporozoite rate, and entomological inoculation rate. The study aims to detect a 35% relative reduction in malaria cases and prevalence in the intervention arms compared to the control arm. Entomological monitoring will

The PRECISION study is a Phase II single-arm trial investigating the safety and efficacy of 3 fractions of stereotactic body radiotherapy (SBRT) for low and favorable intermediate risk localized prostate cancer. The key aspects of the trial are:

- Patients will receive 3 fractions of SBRT delivered on consecutive days, using the RayPilot system and HypoCath image guidance for continuous prostate tracking during treatment.

- Primary outcomes are the number of patients experiencing acute Grade ≥2 urinary and bowel toxicity up to 12 weeks post-treatment, assessed by RTOG and CTCAE criteria.

- Secondary outcomes include late (≥6 months) Grade ≥2 urinary and bowel toxicity, cumulative late toxicities, and quality of life measures like EPIC-26, IPSS, IIEF-5 and Vaizey scores up to 24 months.

- Key eligibility criteria include localized low/intermediate risk prostate cancer, prostate volume <80cc, IPSS <20, no prior pelvic radiotherapy or inflammatory bowel disease.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of low-level laser therapy (LLLT) in reducing root resorption of the upper incisors during intrusion movement using mini-implants in adult patients with deep overbite.

The study involves two groups: a control group receiving traditional orthodontic treatment with nickel-titanium coil force adjustment every 4 weeks, and an experimental group receiving LLLT in addition to the traditional treatment. The LLLT group will receive laser irradiation (808 nm wavelength, 250 mW power, 4 J/point energy density) applied to the roots of the upper incisors at specific points for a total of 128 seconds per tooth, on the day of intrusion initiation, and then at specific intervals throughout the treatment.

The primary outcomes measured are the change in root volume and root length of the upper incisors, assessed using cone-beam computed tomography (CBCT) scans taken before and after the intrusion procedure, which is expected to last 4-5 months.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of LLLT in reducing the risk of orthodontically induced inflammatory root re

This is a multicenter observational study conducted in Italy to analyze the lymphadenectomy performed during right hemicolectomy for colon cancer. The study aims to investigate the relationship between the extent of lymph node dissection and the radicality of surgical resection. Patients aged 18-95 years undergoing elective laparoscopic or robotic right hemicolectomy for colon adenocarcinoma will be enrolled. The study will collect data on various aspects of lymphadenectomy, including tumor-free margin, terminal ileum length, levels of vascular ligation, mesocolon integrity, number of lymph nodes harvested, and number of positive lymph nodes. Additionally, the study will examine the anatomical variability of mesenteric vessels and its impact on the extent of lymphadenectomy. The primary outcome measure is the analysis of lymphadenectomy in relation to the radicality of surgical resection, while the secondary outcome measure is the vascular anatomical variability. The study aims to enroll 788 patients and will have a follow-up period of 6 months.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of Cawthorne Cooksey exercises and Swiss ball exercises on balance and quality of life in children aged 7-12 years with sensorineural hearing deficits (hearing loss greater than 90dB). The primary outcome measure is the Pediatric Berg Balance Scale, which assesses balance function on a scale from 0 (lowest function) to 56 (highest function). The secondary outcome measure is the Four-step square test, which evaluates dynamic balance and requires participants to step over sticks arranged in a cross pattern on the floor. The study has two parallel intervention arms: one group will receive Cawthorne Cooksey exercises for balance training, while the other group will perform Swiss ball exercises. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of these exercise interventions in improving balance and quality of life in children with profound hearing loss, who often experience vestibular dysfunction and balance problems.

This is a qualitative study aimed at exploring the psychological impact on women with gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN) who have completed chemotherapy treatment. The key aspects are:

- It will involve semi-structured telephone interviews with 20 women who received chemotherapy for GTN between 6 weeks and 24 months prior to the study.

- The interviews will focus on gaining insight into the emotional impact of GTN post-treatment, assessing if adequate psychological support was provided, identifying sources of support accessed, and potential areas for improving follow-up care.

- Thematic analysis will be used to generate in-depth descriptions of patients' experiences, including common themes related to psychological experiences post-chemotherapy, opinions on post-treatment support received, and suggestions for improving patient care.

- The findings aim to help healthcare professionals better understand the patient perspective and improve the support and care provided to this unique group of patients after treatment completion.

- Ethical considerations, such as informed consent, confidentiality, and minimizing potential distress, have been addressed.

- The results will be disseminated within the multidisciplinary team, presented at relevant conferences, and may lead to recommendations for enhancing

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the utility of bone grafts in open wedge corrective osteotomy and plate fixation for patients with malunited distal radius fractures. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-group trial with two arms: one group receiving bone grafting from the iliac crest during the osteotomy procedure, and the other group undergoing the osteotomy without bone grafting. The primary outcomes include complications, quality of life (measured by EQ-5D-5L), and time to complete bone healing. Secondary outcomes include subjective functional outcomes (DASH and PRWE questionnaires), objective functional outcomes (range of motion), and cost-effectiveness analysis. The study includes patients over 18 years old with symptomatic malunion of the distal radius, eligible for open wedge osteotomy and plate fixation. The follow-up period is at least one year.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of a brief, individually-tailored behavioral teacher training program for children with behavioral difficulties at school. The primary objective is to examine the short-term effectiveness of the training on the severity of four daily rated target behaviors in specific classroom situations. Secondary objectives include assessing the training's impact on the severity of the same behaviors in other situations, overall behavioral difficulties at school and home, teacher-student relationship, teacher's sense of efficacy, and teacher's behavior management strategies. The study will recruit elementary school teachers of children in grades 1-8 displaying disruptive behaviors. Teachers will be randomly assigned to receive either the 3-session behavioral teacher training plus practice as usual (PAU), or PAU alone. Assessments will occur at baseline, post-treatment, and 3-month follow-up for the training group. The control group will have assessments at baseline and post-treatment timepoints only. Primary and secondary outcomes will be analyzed using multilevel modeling, accounting for potential moderators.

This is a mixed-methods pilot study investigating the feasibility, acceptability, and usability of a 6-week tele-rehabilitation program combining immersive virtual reality exercises and therapeutic education for chronic non-specific neck pain. The intervention involves weekly 15-20 minute virtual reality neck exercises using the Pico G2 4K headset, 30-minute teleconsultations with a physiotherapist, and educational brochures on pain management. The primary outcomes assess feasibility through retention rate, adherence, safety, home implementation, and online consultation metrics. Acceptability is evaluated through satisfaction ratings, and usability is measured using the System Usability Scale and interviews. Secondary outcomes include cervical range of motion, neck disability, pain intensity, kinesiophobia, illness perception, global perceived effect, and qualitative experiences. Participants are adults with chronic non-specific neck pain meeting specific inclusion/exclusion criteria. The study aims to determine the feasibility, acceptability, and usability of this novel tele-rehabilitation approach for managing chronic neck pain.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the implementation of a home-based Hand-Arm Bimanual Intensive Therapy Including Lower Extremities (HABIT-ILE) intervention for children with bilateral cerebral palsy. The study aims to assess if the home-based HABIT-ILE therapy is non-inferior to the classic on-site HABIT-ILE camp in improving physical abilities, functional activities, and participation. Additionally, it evaluates if a 9-week follow-up HABIT-ILE therapy at home after the initial 2-week intervention can further potentialize the therapeutic effects.

The study involves four parallel groups: 1) home-based HABIT-ILE without follow-up, 2) home-based HABIT-ILE with follow-up, 3) classic on-site HABIT-ILE without follow-up, and 4) classic on-site HABIT-ILE with follow-up. The primary outcome is the change in gross motor function measured by the GMFM-66 scale. Secondary outcomes include changes in bimanual performance, unimanual dexterity, endurance, activities of daily living, locomot

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing digital exams versus speculum exams for patients with preterm prelabor rupture of membranes (PPROM) between 22 and 33 weeks of gestation. The primary outcome measure is pregnancy latency, defined as the time from admission to delivery, up to 10 weeks. Secondary outcomes include maternal complications such as chorioamnionitis, endomyometritis, sepsis, wound infections, ICU admission, and death, as well as neonatal morbidities like need for respiratory support, sepsis, intraventricular hemorrhage, necrotizing enterocolitis, hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, pneumonia, length of NICU stay, and neonatal death. The study aims to determine if one examination method is superior to the other in terms of pregnancy latency and maternal/neonatal outcomes in cases of PPROM.

This is a single-center, prospective, single-arm study evaluating the efficacy of sequential adult left lateral lobe liver transplantation (SALT) in treating patients with liver cirrhosis and hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC). The key aspects are:

- Patients with liver cirrhosis and HCC meeting the Up-to-Seven criteria will undergo a two-stage procedure: 1) hemihepatectomy combined with left lateral lobe liver transplantation, and 2) residual liver resection after the transplanted graft grows to sufficient functional volume.

- The primary outcome is overall survival at 3 years after the second liver resection. 

- Secondary outcomes include disease-free survival at various time points post-transplant (1 month, 3 months, 6 months, 1 year, 2 years, 3 years).

- Eligibility criteria include age 18-75, Child-Pugh A-B, HCC meeting Up-to-Seven criteria, good performance status, and signed informed consent.

- The study aims to evaluate the efficacy of this novel SALT approach in expanding the

This clinical trial aims to establish the validity and reliability of a dexterity assessment tool for patients with degenerative cervical myelopathy (DCM) and healthy individuals. The study involves two participant groups: patients diagnosed with DCM aged 35-75 years, and healthy volunteers aged 35-75 years. The intervention is a diagnostic test using a dexterity assessment tool that measures finger dexterity with pressure sensor pads. The primary outcomes include dexterity measurements in DCM patients to define disease severity, correlation between the new tool and the validated GRASSP-M tool for concurrent validity, inter-rater reliability by correlating measurements from two testers in healthy participants, and test-retest reliability by correlating measurements in healthy participants one week apart. The study aims to validate the dexterity assessment tool for use in DCM and establish its reliability.

This is a non-interventional, single-center, multi-surgeon, observational study evaluating the effect of intraocular lens (IOL) centration and tilt on visual performance in patients who have undergone Clareon® Vivity® or Vivity® Toric IOL implantation for cataract surgery. The study will retrospectively review data from 100 implanted patients (200 eyes) and collect postoperative data at 1 or more months after surgery. The primary outcome measure is monocular best-corrected distance visual acuity (BCDVA). Secondary outcomes include IOL decentration, tilt, uncorrected distance and intermediate visual acuity, distance-corrected intermediate visual acuity, and manifest refraction/spherical equivalent. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 years or older who had uneventful cataract surgery with Clareon® Vivity® or Vivity® Toric IOL implantation and meet other specified criteria. The study aims to evaluate the impact of IOL centration and tilt on visual performance with these extended depth of focus and toric IOLs.

This is a randomized, prospective, controlled study investigating the efficacy of ultrasound-guided serratus posterior superior interfascial plane block (SPSIPB) for postoperative pain control in female patients undergoing mastectomy and axillary lymph node dissection surgery.

The study involves two groups: the SPSIPB group (Group S) and the control group (Group C). In Group S, patients will receive SPSIPB with 30 ml of 0.25% bupivacaine, while in Group C, patients will receive wound infiltration with the same volume and concentration of bupivacaine by the surgical team.

The primary outcome measure is postoperative pain scores assessed using the Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) at 1, 2, 4, 8, 16, and 24 hours after surgery. Secondary outcomes include the need for rescue analgesia (meperidine), adverse events related to opioid use (nausea, vomiting, itching), and dermatomal coverage of SPSIPB in Group S.

Eligible participants are female patients aged 18-65

This is a single-arm, open-label, exploratory study to assess the clinical value of delayed ductal imaging using contrast-enhanced spectral mammography (CESM) 4-6 hours after routine iopromide-enhanced ductography in preoperative assessment of pathological nipple discharge in females aged 18-65 years. The primary outcome measure is the percentage of changes in imaging diagnosis caused by the delayed ductal imaging results, including changes in disease classification, number/location/size of lesions, and severity/nature of the disease. Secondary outcomes include diagnostic accuracy of delayed imaging for lesion nature, changes in diagnosis in patients with dense breasts or non-palpable masses, agreement between radiologists on delayed imaging evaluation, and changes in radiologists' diagnostic confidence after delayed imaging. The study aims to optimize ductography technique, describe mammary duct structure, and evaluate the diagnostic effectiveness, radiation safety, and patient tolerance of this delayed imaging protocol.

This is a prospective clinical study investigating the association between postoperative dyslipidemia and organ rejection in heart transplant patients. The study includes patients aged 18 and above who have undergone heart transplantation and had symptomatic heart failure for at least 6 months prior to screening. The primary outcome measures are blood lipid measurements (triglycerides, total cholesterol, HDL-C, LDL-C, and ApoB) and graft/patient survival over a 4-year period. The secondary outcome measure is left ventricular ejection fraction at rest, determined by contrast echocardiography, also over 4 years. The study aims to explore the potential link between dyslipidemia and organ rejection in heart transplant recipients.

This is a prospective cohort study comparing the effectiveness of virtual pelvic floor physical therapy, a pelvic floor trainer device (Pelex Upp), and a combination of both in treating stress urinary incontinence in women over 18 years old. The study has three arms: 1) Pelex Upp device only, 2) Pelex Upp device plus virtual pelvic floor physical therapy, and 3) virtual pelvic floor physical therapy only. Participants will use the assigned intervention(s) for 4 weeks, with a mid-study check-in. The primary outcome measure is the change in stress urinary incontinence symptoms, assessed using the International Consultation on Incontinence Questionnaire - Urinary Incontinence Short Form (ICIQ-UI SF) before and after the 4-week treatment period. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these interventions in reducing stress urinary incontinence symptoms in women.

This is a study aimed at improving attendance and reducing alcohol and substance misuse (ASM) in a multi-level behavioral intervention called Community Wise (CW). The study will use a 2^3 full factorial experiment design to test the effectiveness of three intervention delivery strategies on improving attendance and reducing ASM:

1. Recruiting individuals under supervision (parole, drug court, probation, or methadone maintenance) versus not under supervision.
2. Providing financial incentives for attendance versus no incentives.
3. Delivering the intervention in an open group format versus a closed group format.

The study will enroll 144 participants living in marginalized communities with a history of substance use disorder, including both men and women, with or without prior incarceration. The primary outcome measure is the number of sessions attended, with the goal of having at least 50% of participants attend 50% or more of the intervention sessions. Secondary outcomes include reduction in ASM and intervention satisfaction measures.

The study aims to identify efficient strategies for improving attendance and maximizing the intervention's effect in reducing ASM. The findings will inform the selection of strategies for future testing of the CW intervention's effectiveness and potential for broader implementation

This is a randomized, double-blind, parallel-group clinical trial comparing the efficacy of interpectoral area block + serratus anterior area block (IPSA) versus erector spinae block (ES) for postoperative pain management in patients undergoing minimally invasive cardiac surgery.

The primary outcome is postoperative pain scores measured using the Numerical Rating Scale (NRS) up to 48 hours after surgery. Secondary outcomes include opioid consumption, recovery criteria (extubation time, postoperative carbon dioxide levels, drainage amount), intraoperative changes in near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) values, and Critical Care Pain Observation Tool (CPOT) scores until extubation.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18-75 years undergoing minimally invasive cardiac surgery for the first time, with an American Society of Anesthesiologists (ASA) physical status of I-II, average bleeding profile, and ability to use patient-controlled analgesia. Patients will be randomly allocated to receive either IPSA or ES block after induction of general anesthesia.

The study aims to investigate the effectiveness of these two regional an

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy of botulinum toxin (Botox) injection and internal sphincterotomy in controlling pain after hemorrhoidectomy. The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial with three arms: 1) Botox injection in the internal sphincter after hemorrhoidectomy, 2) internal sphincterotomy after hemorrhoidectomy, and 3) hemorrhoidectomy alone (control group). The primary outcome measure is post-operative pain assessed using the visual analogue scale (VAS) at 2 weeks. The secondary outcome measure is the time taken to return to daily activities, measured at 4-6 weeks. The study includes patients aged 18-70 years with grade III or IV hemorrhoids who have failed conservative treatment, excluding those with certain comorbidities or complications. The trial aims to determine if Botox injection or internal sphincterotomy can effectively reduce post-hemorrhoidectomy pain and facilitate earlier return to daily activities compared to hemorrhoidectomy alone.

This is a phase II, single-arm, prospective study evaluating the efficacy and safety of modified fruquintinib as maintenance treatment for colorectal cancer liver metastases after achieving no evidence of disease (NED) following initial treatment. The primary objective is to assess the 2-year recurrence and metastasis rate in patients receiving fruquintinib maintenance therapy. Key eligibility criteria include colorectal adenocarcinoma with liver metastases, age 18-75 years, previous disease control with first-line chemotherapy, achievement of NED after local treatment, and adequate organ function. Patients will receive oral fruquintinib 5 mg daily for 3 weeks followed by 1 week off in 4-week cycles for 6 months or until disease recurrence/progression or intolerable toxicity. Secondary outcomes include 2-year disease-free survival rate and overall survival. Regular imaging and tumor marker monitoring will be performed to evaluate treatment response and disease status.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover trial investigating the efficacy of methylphenidate (MPH) for treating post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and associated neurocognitive complaints in military veterans. The study aims to assess the impact of MPH compared to placebo on PTSD symptoms, depression, and neurocognitive functioning in veterans with PTSD, with or without comorbid mild traumatic brain injury (mTBI). The trial will enroll 70 veterans across two sites, each receiving sequential 4-week periods of MPH (10mg twice daily) and placebo, in randomized order, separated by a 1-week washout period, for a total of 20 weeks. The primary outcome is PTSD symptom severity measured by the PTSD Checklist for DSM-5 (PCL-5). Secondary outcomes include cognitive function assessed by the Neuro-QoL Cognitive Function short form and Symbol Digit Coding task. The study will also characterize baseline predictors of treatment response to MPH, including the potential for greater response in veterans with a history of mTBI. If

This is a prospective study aimed at validating the use of absolute coronary flow (AF) and minimal microvascular resistance (MMR) measured by continuous thermodilution as predictors of angina and microvascular dysfunction in patients with no obstructive coronary artery disease (INOCA). The primary objective is to assess the capacity of coronary flow reserve (CFRflow) in predicting the presence of angina at 3 months, measured by the Seattle Angina Questionnaire (SAQ7). Secondary objectives include identifying factors related to persistent angina, establishing the prevalence of microvascular dysfunction, identifying predictors of major cardiovascular events, validating the pathological values of MMR and AF, and evaluating the concordance between continuous and bolus thermodilution measures. The study involves patients undergoing coronary angiography with no significant obstructive lesions, who will undergo diagnostic testing with continuous thermodilution to measure coronary flow reserve and microvascular resistance.

This is a Phase 2a clinical trial evaluating the addition of ruxolitinib to tacrolimus and methotrexate for graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) prophylaxis in pediatric and young adult patients undergoing allogeneic hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) for acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL), or myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS).

The primary objectives are to assess the safety of this regimen (safety lead-in segment) and evaluate the efficacy based on 1-year GVHD-free and relapse-free survival rates (Phase II segment). Secondary objectives include estimating the incidence of acute and chronic GVHD, non-relapse mortality, overall and progression-free survival, relapse rate, infection rate, and development of second malignancies.

Patients receive ruxolitinib orally twice daily from day -1 to day +100, along with tacrolimus intravenously on day -1 and methotrexate intravenously on days +1

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a Temple Stay experience in improving symptoms and quality of life for patients with diarrhea-predominant irritable bowel syndrome (IBS). The study will enroll patients aged 20-69 with diarrhea-predominant IBS. The intervention involves an 8-day Temple Stay experience, which includes dietary changes (vegetarian meals, mindful eating, no overeating), meditation, and participation in daily monastic tasks. The primary outcome measure is the IBS Symptom Severity Score (IBS-SSS), which will be assessed before, during, and 4 weeks after the Temple Stay. The secondary outcome measure is the fecal microbiome composition, diversity, and changes in the proportion of specific bacterial species, which will also be evaluated at the same time points. The study hypothesizes that the Temple Stay experience, with its dietary and lifestyle modifications, will enrich the gut microbiome and consequently reduce IBS symptoms and improve quality of life for patients.

This clinical trial aims to assess asthma patients' and prescribers' perspectives on changing inhalers for environmental reasons. The study involves an educational intervention where asthma patients will receive information about the climate impact of different inhalers and the option to switch from the metered-dose inhaler (MDI) Ventolin to the dry powder inhaler (DPI) Bricanyl Turbuhaler, which has a lower carbon footprint.

The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants who change their inhaler from Ventolin MDI to Bricanyl Turbuhaler within 30 days of the study visit. Secondary outcomes include the rate of failure (switching back to Ventolin within 90 days), the proportion who filled the Bricanyl prescription but did not possess the medication, patients' awareness of the climate impact of inhalers, patients' and prescribers' willingness to change inhalers for environmental reasons, and the importance they attribute to environmental impact, cost, and ease of use.

The study involves a single group of asthma patients who will receive the educational intervention. Eligible participants are adults aged 18 or older, followed in the asthma

This is a single-center, randomized, single-blinded clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of a hybrid argon plasma coagulation and endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (HAPC-ESG) procedure compared to traditional endoscopic sleeve gastroplasty (ESG) alone for weight loss and improvement in obesity-related comorbidities.

The study involves two arms: 
1) Experimental arm: Hybrid APC will be used to ablate the gastric mucosa along the greater curvature of the stomach, followed by endoscopic full-thickness tissue acquisition and plication using sutures (HAPC-ESG).
2) Active comparator arm: Endoscopic full-thickness tissue acquisition and plication using sutures (ESG alone).

The primary outcome is the durability of plications and endoscopic sutures at 6 months, assessed by blinded physicians grading sleeve-like anatomy, tissue bonding, and tightness of sutures.

Secondary outcomes include percentage of total body weight loss (%TBWL), percentage of excess weight loss (%EWL), blood pressure, HbA1c,

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effect of cancer education based on the Health Belief Model on the awareness levels and screening behaviors of women with physical disabilities for common cancers in women, such as breast and cervical cancer.

The study involves two intervention groups:

1. Intervention 1: Participants will receive cancer awareness training based on the Health Belief Model through home visits and reinforcement materials (e.g., calendars, booklets, phone reminders) for 3 months.

2. Intervention 2: Participants will receive standard cancer education provided by the Ministry of Health through home visits and SMS reminders for 3 months.

The primary outcome measure is the Gynecological Cancers Awareness Scale, which assesses awareness of gynecological cancers. The secondary outcome measure is Champion's Health Belief Model Scale for Breast Cancer and Screening, which evaluates perceived barriers to breast self-examination and mammography.

The study targets women with physical disabilities aged 18-65 years who are not regularly performing breast self-examination, vulva self-examination, or receiving recommended cancer screenings (mammography, Pap smear).

The randomized controlled trial aims to determine

This systematic review aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of neoadjuvant chemotherapy combined with trastuzumab in achieving pathological complete response (pCR) in patients with HER2-positive breast cancer. The researchers analyzed data from nine clinical trials involving 1,209 patients with non-metastatic, operable, locally advanced, or inflammatory HER2-positive breast cancer. The trials used different chemotherapy regimens, including paclitaxel, docetaxel, fluorouracil, epirubicin, carboplatin, cyclophosphamide, and methotrexate, along with trastuzumab. The dosage of trastuzumab varied, with either a 4 mg/kg loading dose followed by 2 mg/kg every 3 weeks or an 8 mg/kg loading dose followed by 6 mg/kg every 3 weeks. The primary outcome measure was the pCR rate, defined as the absence of residual invasive cancer in the breast and lymph nodes or the absence of invasive neoplastic cells at microscopic examination of the primary tumor. The overall pCR rate among the 1

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the clinical trial document:

This is a 6-month pilot feasibility study examining the use of a coach-led digital health platform with an intelligent coaching assistant (ICA) in the community of Athy, Co. Kildare, Ireland. The primary aims are to assess the feasibility of implementing the platform based on recruitment rates, user engagement/adherence, and qualitative feedback from participants. Secondary aims include evaluating changes in mental health, wellbeing, and healthy lifestyle behaviors using validated surveys administered through the app at baseline and monthly intervals. 

The study will recruit adults (≥18 years) living, working or spending time within 5km of Athy town center. Participants will have access to the smartphone app with health education content, ability to interact with a human coach, connect wearable device data, and engage in gamification features. In-person educational sessions will also be provided in the community.

Key outcomes measured include reach of recruitment, adoption and engagement with the app, qualitative participant experiences, and changes in perceived stress, wellbeing (PERMA-NHL), and lifestyle behaviors (ACLM lifestyle medicine assessment).

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial investigating the effects of progressive muscle relaxation (PMR) and deep breathing exercises on dyspnea, fatigue, and sleep quality in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The study has three arms: PMR group, deep breathing exercise (DBE) group, and a control group receiving no intervention. The PMR group performed systematic muscle relaxation exercises twice daily for 8 weeks, guided by an exercise guide and audio recordings. The DBE group received training on proper deep breathing techniques and practiced deep breathing exercises 3 times daily for 8 weeks. The primary outcomes measured were fatigue (using the COPD and Asthma Fatigue Scale), dyspnea (using the Dyspnea-12 Scale), and sleep quality (using the Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index). Assessments were done at baseline and after 2 weeks of intervention. The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of these relaxation techniques in improving dyspnea, fatigue, and sleep quality in COPD patients.

This is a study evaluating the diagnostic accuracy of ultrasonic flow ratio (UFR) in assessing the functional significance of coronary artery lesions, using fractional flow reserve (FFR) as the reference standard. The primary outcome measure is the sensitivity and specificity of UFR in predicting functionally significant coronary stenosis at the patient level, compared to FFR. Secondary outcomes include the diagnostic accuracy of UFR at the patient and vessel levels, as well as the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUC) of UFR for coronary stenosis using FFR as the gold standard. The study involves performing intravascular ultrasound (IVUS), FFR, and UFR measurements in patients with intermediate coronary lesions (30-80% diameter stenosis). The key inclusion criteria are stable or unstable angina, or post-myocardial infarction, and the main exclusion criteria are prior coronary artery bypass grafting, recent myocardial infarction, severe heart failure, and renal impairment.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of Balint group activities on burnout and self-efficacy among nurse leaders in China. The study involves two groups: an experimental group participating in Balint group activities for three months, and a control group receiving no intervention. The primary outcomes measured are the three subscales of the Maslach Burnout Inventory (emotional exhaustion, depersonalization, and personal accomplishment), assessed at baseline and after three months. The secondary outcome is self-efficacy, measured by the General Self-Efficacy Scale at the same time points. The Balint group activities consist of two lectures and 10 monthly one-hour small group discussion sessions focused on the professional nurse-patient relationship. The study aims to evaluate the impact of Balint group participation on reducing burnout and enhancing self-efficacy among nurse leaders in clinical settings.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of non-pharmacological and traditional Chinese medicine (TCM)-based treatments for cognitive impairment in people with long COVID symptoms. The study has three intervention arms: 1) acupuncture, 2) TCM-based lifestyle management (including dantian breathing, Baduanjin, and self-acupressure), and 3) a combination of acupuncture and TCM-based lifestyle management. There is also a wait-list control group that receives no intervention. The primary outcome is global cognitive function, measured at baseline, mid-intervention (4 weeks), and post-intervention (8 weeks). Secondary outcomes include cardiopulmonary function, fatigue, health-related quality of life, psychological distress, neurocognitive functions, and neurobiological markers (IL-6, TNF-α, and cortisol). Participants must have had a SARS-CoV-2 infection at least 3 months prior, with persistent cognitive symptoms or mild cognitive impairment, and meet other eligibility criteria.

This is a clinical trial (myCare-102) designed to evaluate the clinical utility and usability of Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports in facilitating patient treatment decisions for pan-cancer patients. The study involves surveying physicians and molecular tumor boards to gather their perspectives on the benefit of these reports.

The trial has two arms:

1. Singula arm: Patients with a diagnosis of cancer who have already received first-line therapy.
2. Ventura arm: Patients with a diagnosis of relapsed or refractory cancer.

The primary outcome measure is to determine if the majority of physicians and molecular tumor boards have a positive view of the Cellworks Singula™ and Cellworks Ventura™ reports.

Secondary outcome measures include patient demographics (sex, ethnicity, age), institution demographics (type, number of orders placed, placement within orders), patient disease status (indication, ECOG score).

The study has specific inclusion and exclusion criteria related to cancer diagnosis, NGS testing, treatment status, life expectancy, and other factors.

The trial is expected to last approximately 24 months and aims to assess the clinical

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of Cognitive Stimulation Therapy (CST) on apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and activities of daily living in elderly individuals diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease. The study is designed as a single-center, randomized, parallel-group trial with a pre-test, post-test, and follow-up assessment. The intervention group will receive CST, which involves standard tasks focusing on cognitive functions, designed to meet varying levels of difficulty. The CST will be delivered in 14 sessions of 45-50 minutes, twice a week, by a trained researcher. The primary outcomes include measuring the levels of apathy, loneliness, anxiety, and functional disability in Alzheimer's patients after the CST intervention. The study will be conducted at the Moral House affiliated with Gaziantep Metropolitan Municipality Disabled and Health Services Department, Turkey, and will enroll individuals aged 60 years or older with mild Alzheimer's disease, who meet the specified inclusion and exclusion criteria.

This is a prospective, randomized controlled trial examining the effect of counseling and follow-up after breast cancer awareness education on early diagnosis behaviors and healthy lifestyle behaviors among female administrative staff at Mersin University.

The study involves 160 participants randomly assigned to two groups: an experimental group receiving counseling and weekly SMS reminders for 6 months after an initial breast cancer education session, and a control group receiving only the education session.

The primary outcomes measured at 6 months include breast cancer early diagnosis behaviors (breast self-exam, clinical exam, mammography), counseling details, and healthy lifestyle behaviors (health responsibility, physical activity, nutrition, spiritual development, interpersonal relationships, stress management).

The aim is to evaluate whether ongoing counseling and reminders after an educational session can improve early breast cancer detection practices and promote healthier lifestyles among this population of women.

This study aimed to determine the effect of simulation-based postpartum hemorrhage management training on the application skills, satisfaction, self-confidence, and self-efficacy of third-year midwifery students. The study had a randomized, parallel-group design with an intervention group (n=39) receiving simulation-based training using a high-fidelity simulator, and a control group (n=39) receiving training on a standard patient model. The primary outcomes measured were student satisfaction and self-confidence in learning, self-efficacy, and postpartum hemorrhage management skills. Data was collected using various scales and skill assessment forms at pre-test, post-test, and follow-up time points. The study findings could provide insights into the effectiveness of simulation-based education for improving midwifery students' competencies in managing postpartum hemorrhage.

This clinical trial aimed to study the effect of a mangrove sword bean food bar on the weight of older people affected by a landslide disaster in Cihanjuang Village, Sumedang District, West Java, Indonesia. The trial had two groups: a treatment group that received 50g of mangrove sword bean food bar daily for 15 days, and a control group that received 50g of regular sword bean food bar daily for the same duration. Both groups received balanced nutrition education once during the first week. The primary outcome measure was the change in weight of the participants after two weeks, measured using a digital weighing scale. The secondary outcome measure was the change in balanced nutrition knowledge, assessed through baseline and end-line questionnaires. The study included older adults aged 60-80 years, of both genders, with normal, under-, or over-nutrition status, and without chronic or degenerative diseases. The trial had a non-randomized, parallel-group design with a single-blind masking.

The pAIn-sense study aims to develop a novel telemonitoring system that combines wearable sensors, digital platforms, and artificial intelligence (AI) to understand the physiological and psychosocial components of pain in patients with nociceptive or neuropathic pain. The study involves monitoring patients and healthy controls using wearable devices that collect physiological data (e.g., skin conductance, blood volume pressure, heart rate, activity) and a digital platform that collects psychological assessments, pain levels, medication intake, and sleep quality. Advanced AI models will then analyze this data to characterize the nature of the patient's pain (emotional vs. physical) and enable personalized treatments.

The primary outcomes include measuring pain levels, psychosocial components (e.g., anxiety, depression, pain catastrophizing), physiological components (e.g., skin conductance, heart rate), psychological and clinical factors, and medication intake over a one-month period. Secondary outcomes include assessing the effects of rehabilitation, physiotherapy, sleep, activity, predictors of pain chronification, quality of life, and responsiveness to medication.

The study aims to provide a radically novel approach to monitoring and treating pain patients by

This is a Phase 2a/b open-label, single-arm study evaluating the safety and efficacy of intracystic administration of TARA-002, a biological preparation containing treated Streptococcus pyogenes cells, for the treatment of macrocystic and mixed cystic lymphatic malformations in participants aged 6 months to less than 18 years. The primary outcome measure is the proportion of participants with clinical success after one treatment cycle of TARA-002, assessed 8 weeks after the last injection. Secondary outcomes include safety assessments, durable response, clinical success by lymphatic malformation type, investigator assessment of clinical improvement, and changes in quality of life measures. Participants will receive up to 4 intracystic injections of TARA-002 spaced approximately 6 weeks apart. The study aims to evaluate the potential of TARA-002 as a treatment option for lymphatic malformations in the pediatric population.

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of adding chiglitazar (48mg/day) to metformin and insulin glargine therapy in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) who have poor glycemic control. The study aims to enroll 128 patients who will be randomly assigned 1:1 to receive either chiglitazar or placebo in addition to their existing metformin and insulin glargine treatment for 18 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in HbA1c from baseline at 18 weeks. Secondary outcomes include changes in daily insulin dose, triglycerides, fasting blood glucose, and fasting C-peptide levels. Key eligibility criteria include T2DM diagnosis, age ≥18 years, BMI 18.5-35 kg/m2, HbA1c 7.5-10.5%, stable insulin and metformin treatment for ≥3 months, and no severe complications or comorbidities. The study aims to evaluate if adding chiglitazar improves glycemic

This is a technical evaluation study of the EarSwitch device, a novel ear-worn assistive technology that detects voluntary eardrum movements. The study aims to assess the robustness of the EarSwitch in detecting tensor tympani muscle contractions and gather feedback from assistive device users on their ability to perform these voluntary movements.

The study involves four main parts:

1. Co-design questionnaires to understand participants' current assistive technology use and gather feedback.

2. Fitting and insertion of the EarSwitch device, assessing comfort and ease of use.

3. Ear rumbling test, where participants perform tasks to voluntarily contract their tensor tympani muscle while the EarSwitch records their eardrum movements. Reaction times, consecutive rumbles, and duration will be measured.

4. Optional usability testing with interfaces controlled by the EarSwitch, followed by questionnaires.

The primary outcome is the robustness of the EarSwitch in detecting eardrum movements, measured by metrics like F-score, Matthews correlation coefficient, and area under the ROC curve. Secondary outcomes include accuracy of voluntary tensor tympani contractions, differences between assist

This is a prospective multi-center cohort study aimed at validating and assessing the performance of an electronic health record (EHR)-based pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC) risk prediction model called PRISM. The study will involve deploying the PRISM model within the TriNetX federated network database across 44 healthcare organizations in the USA. The key aspects are:

1. Generate PDAC risk prediction scores for individuals aged ≥40 years without a personal history of PDAC, using the PRISM neural network (PrismNN) and logistic regression (PrismLR) models.

2. Follow all individuals for up to 3 years to assess the primary endpoint of PDAC development.

3. Evaluate the discriminative performance of PRISM using the area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC), sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), and negative predictive value (NPV) at 6 months, 1 year, 2 years, and 3 years.

4. Assess the calibration of PRISM by comparing the predicted and

This is a randomized, parallel-group, single-blinded comparative study evaluating the efficacy of two cartilage regeneration techniques, autologous adipose tissue graft with hyaline cartilage versus microfracture, for treating articular cartilage defects in the knee. The study involves 105 participants aged 18-60 years with symptomatic full-thickness cartilage defects (2-5 cm2) in the femoral condyles, classified as Outerbridge grade II or III. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) autologous adipose tissue graft with hyaline cartilage and high tibial osteotomy, 2) microfracture with high tibial osteotomy, or 3) high tibial osteotomy alone (placebo comparator). The primary outcome measure is the International Knee Documentation Committee (IKDC) score assessed at one year. The study aims to compare the clinical outcomes of the two cartilage regeneration techniques in treating articular cartilage defects.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between exercise training and recovery strategies on physical performance and health status. The study will randomize 150 highly active and healthy participants aged 18-45 years into three groups for 8 weeks: 1) a control group maintaining a 35-hour/week exercise regimen, 2) a lower exercise volume group reducing exercise by 15% to 30 hours/week, and 3) an extended recovery group performing 35 hours/week with longer recovery intervals between exercises. Primary outcomes include changes in immune system markers, cardiometabolic markers, endocrine response, aerobic capacity, anaerobic threshold, strength, and body composition. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, 4 weeks, and 8 weeks. The study aims to determine the effect of different recovery strategies during high-volume exercise training on immune function, cardiometabolic health, endocrine response, and physical performance.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether phosphodiesterase 4B (PDE4B) levels are reduced in the brains of individuals with major depressive disorder (MDD) using positron emission tomography (PET) imaging with the radiotracer [18F]PF-06445974. The primary objective is to determine if PDE4B density (distribution volume VT) is lower in the brains of MDD patients experiencing a major depressive episode compared to healthy volunteers. Secondary objectives include determining the optimal scan duration, assessing test-retest variability and reliability of [18F]PF-06445974, and evaluating the correlation between PDE4B binding and clinical rating scales for depression severity.

The study involves a single arm where all participants (aged 18-70 years) will receive an intravenous injection of [18F]PF-06445974 followed by PET scanning. Eligibility criteria are outlined for both MDD patients and healthy controls. Key exclusion criteria include significant medical conditions, substance use disorders, suicidal ideation/behavior, and contraindications for PET or MRI scans.

The primary outcome measure is the

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the importance of weight-bearing and knee flexion in assessing joint space width in patients with knee osteoarthritis using 3D MRI imaging. The study involves patients aged 18 years or older with symptomatic knee osteoarthritis (Kellgren-Lawrence grade 2 or 3). Participants will undergo four MRI scans using a 0.25T scanner, with scans performed in both weight-bearing and non-weight-bearing conditions, as well as with the knee in flexed and extended positions. The primary outcome measure is the medial joint space width, and the secondary outcome measure is the lateral joint space width, both evaluated across the four scan positions within a 1-hour time frame. The study aims to provide insights into the importance of weight-bearing and knee flexion in accurately assessing joint space narrowing, a key feature of knee osteoarthritis.

This is a randomized, parallel-group study evaluating the effectiveness of an at-home swallowing rehabilitation program using surface electromyography (sEMG) biofeedback (i-BiSSkApp) compared to traditional behavioral swallowing therapy in individuals with Parkinson's disease (PD) and oropharyngeal dysphagia (swallowing impairment).

The study aims to assess the impact of the i-BiSSkApp, a tablet application that provides visual feedback on swallowing strength and timing, on swallowing safety and efficiency. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental group, receiving daily at-home exercises with the i-BiSSkApp and weekly clinic visits for 12 weeks, or the active comparator group, receiving traditional swallowing therapy once a week for 12 weeks with daily at-home exercises.

The primary outcomes are the Penetration Aspiration Scale (PAS) score, assessing swallowing safety, and total pharyngeal residue, measuring swallowing efficiency, evaluated at baseline and after 12 weeks of intervention. Secondary outcomes include the Eating Assessment Tool-10 (EA

The Global Burden Estimation of Human Papillomavirus (GLOBE-HPV) study aims to estimate the prevalence and incidence of high-risk human papillomavirus (HPV) infection among girls and women aged 9-50 years in low socio-economic populations across 8 countries in South Asia and Sub-Saharan Africa. The study involves two main components: cross-sectional surveys (CSS) to estimate the point prevalence of HPV infection, and longitudinal studies (LS) to estimate the incidence of persistent HPV infection over 2 years. The CSS will enroll participants aged 9-50 years, divided into four age strata, while the LS will enroll sexually active girls and women aged 15-35 years. Urine samples and self-collected vaginal swabs will be used for HPV testing. The study will also collect data on demographics, socioeconomic status, sexual and reproductive history, knowledge and attitudes towards cervical cancer screening and HPV vaccination, and potential risk factors for HPV infection. Additionally, qualitative sub-studies will be conducted in five selected countries to explore perceptions, gender norms, and barriers

This is a double-blind randomized controlled trial investigating the efficacy of strategic memory training combined with non-invasive brain stimulation (transcranial direct current stimulation, tDCS) in healthy older adults and individuals with subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The primary aim is to assess whether applying tDCS during strategic memory training enhances the effects of the training.

The study involves two groups: an experimental group receiving strategic memory training plus active tDCS, and a control group receiving strategic memory training plus sham tDCS. The intervention consists of 5 sessions (2-3 sessions per week, 1 hour per day) of strategic memory training combined with online tDCS or sham stimulation applied to the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex.

Participants aged 65-85 years with no cognitive impairment will be recruited. Outcome measures include scores on various memory tests (associative learning, list learning, name-face learning, place learning, text learning, and grocery learning) assessed immediately after the intervention, and at 1-month and 3-month follow-ups.

The study aims to investigate whether the combined intervention of strategic memory training and tDCS can

This is a model development and validation study aimed at predicting the risk of new-onset heart failure from population-based nationwide electronic health records. The study will use anonymized patient-level primary care data linked to secondary administrative data from the Clinical Practice Research Datalink (CPRD-GOLD and CPRD-AURUM) databases. The study population includes individuals aged 16 years and older with no history of heart failure and a minimum of one year of follow-up data. The primary outcomes are to develop and validate a model for predicting the risk of new-onset heart failure, and to identify and quantify the magnitude of predictors of new-onset heart failure. The study will consider various potential predictors, including sociodemographic variables, lifestyle factors, medical history, and clinical measurements. The study period is from January 2, 1998, to February 28, 2022. This is an observational study with no intervention given.
