This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study investigating the impact of recommended time to resume sexual activity after hysterectomy on sexual function and complication rate. The study includes sexually active women aged 18 years or older undergoing hysterectomy for benign gynecological conditions. Participants are randomized to receive recommendations to resume sexual intercourse either 4 weeks or 8 weeks after hysterectomy. The primary outcome is the Female Sexual Function Index (FSFI®) score assessed one year after surgery. Secondary outcomes include postoperative complications (dyspareunia, pain, bleeding, infection, vaginal suture release) and adherence to the recommended time for resuming sexual activity. The study aims to determine the optimal timing for resuming sexual activity after hysterectomy to preserve sexual function and minimize complications.

This clinical trial aims to investigate whether human skeletal muscle possesses an epigenetic memory of testosterone exposure and resistance exercise training. The study involves sedentary males aged 55-70 years and is designed as a randomized, parallel-assignment, triple-masked trial with four arms:

1. Placebo group: Receives saline injections and continues regular physical activity.
2. Testosterone group: Receives testosterone undecanoate injections and continues regular physical activity.
3. Resistance exercise training + Placebo group: Undergoes resistance training and receives saline injections.
4. Resistance exercise training + Testosterone group: Undergoes resistance training and receives testosterone undecanoate injections.

The study consists of four phases: a 10-week treatment period, a 12-week detraining and abstinence period, a 10-week retraining period, and follow-up assessments. The primary outcomes include changes in fat-free mass, skeletal muscle size and cross-sectional area, and skeletal muscle fiber cross-sectional area. Secondary outcomes include DNA methylation, gene expression, myonuclei, satellite cells, isometric and

This is a seroprevalence study aimed at estimating the percentage of the population in the metropolitan area of Buenos Aires, Argentina that has been previously infected with dengue virus. The study will use a stratified two-stage sampling design, with census sections as primary sampling units stratified by income levels. Around 1,500 dwellings will be selected, and one adult aged 18 or above from each dwelling will be tested for dengue IgG antibodies using ELISA. The primary outcome is the seroprevalence of dengue IgG antibodies in the study population. Secondary outcomes include prevalence of antibodies cross-reacting with other flaviviruses and the specific dengue virus serotypes among those testing positive for dengue IgG. The study aims to provide insights into the extent of past dengue virus transmission in this metropolitan area.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the performance of two rapid COVID-19 antigen tests, the Abbott Panbio™ COVID-19 Ag Rapid Test and the SD Biosensor COVID-19 Ag test kit, in detecting SARS-CoV-2 antigens in nasal swabs from individuals crossing ports of entry in the Greater Gaborone Health District. The primary outcome measure is the sensitivity and specificity of these antigen tests compared to the reference standard reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) test. The secondary outcome measure is the cost estimates of antigen testing compared to PCR testing for COVID-19 case detection. The study will recruit individuals aged 18-75 years crossing ports of entry who are able to provide informed consent. The study aims to assess the performance and potential use of these rapid antigen tests and algorithms in low-prevalence screening programs.

The DESC-HBR trial aims to compare the impact of de-escalating P2Y12 inhibitor therapy to clopidogrel 75mg, prasugrel 5mg, or ticagrelor 60mg bid versus continuing full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitors in patients at high bleeding risk after a recent acute coronary syndrome. The primary outcome is the proportion of patients achieving optimal platelet reactivity measured by the VerifyNow system at peak level after the maintenance dose at 14±2 days. Secondary outcomes include bleeding events, platelet reactivity at different timepoints, adverse clinical events (death, myocardial infarction, stroke, revascularization), and cost-effectiveness analysis. The study is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial with four arms: clopidogrel 75mg, prasugrel 5mg, ticagrelor 60mg bid, and continued full-dose potent P2Y12 inhibitor. Eligible participants are those at high bleeding risk who underwent percutaneous coronary intervention for a recent acute coronary syndrome and were initially treated with full-dose potent P2

This is a study investigating the effects of different dietary interventions and exercise on blood glucose levels and metabolic responses in individuals with prediabetes or type 2 diabetes. The key aspects of the trial are:

1. Participants will wear continuous glucose monitors (CGM) and fitness trackers for 10 days.
2. On days 1-6, participants will consume a standardized portion of white rice (50g carbohydrates) within 1.5 hours of waking up.
3. On days 1, 3, and 5, participants will consume one of three mitigators (fat, protein, or fiber) along with the rice.
4. On day 6, participants will exercise for 20 minutes before consuming the rice.
5. Participants will collect blood microsamples at various time points before and after the rice meals.
6. The primary outcomes are changes in blood glucose levels and postprandial metabolite responses measured by metabolomics and proteomics.
7. Secondary outcomes include changes in personal metabolic states throughout the day, measured by metabolomics and proteomics.
8. Optional tests include oral glucose tolerance test (

This is a randomized controlled trial aimed at preventing fetal alcohol spectrum disorders (FASD) and adverse infant outcomes by adapting and testing a behavioral intervention with contingent incentives and text-based support for pregnant and breastfeeding women who use alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis. The study will recruit women aged 18 or older who are in their second trimester of pregnancy or breastfeeding within one month postpartum, and who test positive for alcohol, tobacco, or cannabis use. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive contingent incentives for abstinence from alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis, as well as text-based educational support, or the usual care group, which will receive community treatment referrals. The primary outcomes measured at 3 months postpartum include urinalysis and blood tests for alcohol, tobacco, and cannabis use, as well as self-reported substance use and cravings. Secondary outcomes include gestational incidents, infant weight, height, head circumference, and gestational age at birth. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of the behavioral intervention in reducing substance use during pregnancy and breastfeeding, and improving infant health outcomes.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effectiveness of operant conditioning with peripheral stimulation in reducing phantom limb pain in individuals with limb amputation. The study involves two groups: an intervention group receiving operant conditioning feedback with peripheral stimulation, and a control group receiving only peripheral stimulation without feedback.

The primary outcomes measured are changes in pain intensity and quality assessed by the Short form-McGill Pain Questionnaire (SF-MPQ), and changes in somatosensory evoked potential (SSEP) amplitude and latency measured by a tactile event-related potential test. Secondary outcomes include changes in the impact of pain on quality of life assessed by the West Haven-Yale Multidimensional Pain Inventory (WHYMPI).

The study involves three 1-hour sessions per week for 8-9 weeks, followed by follow-up sessions at 3 and 6 months after the last session. Assessments are conducted at baseline, after the last session, and during follow-up sessions. The study aims to strengthen weakened sensorimotor responses and reduce phantom limb pain through operant conditioning training.

This is a single-center retrospective study evaluating the use of ultrasound-guided axillary vein catheterization in trauma patients admitted to the trauma intensive care unit (TICU). The primary outcome measure is the accurate placement of the central venous catheter (CVC) tip for measuring central venous pressure or invasive hemodynamic monitoring. Secondary outcomes include puncture complications, thromboembolism events, TICU mortality, length of stay, and duration of ventilator support. The study includes trauma patients of all ages who received axillary vein catheterization during their TICU stay. The axillary vein catheterization procedure is performed under ultrasound guidance using standard central venous catheterization techniques. The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of this approach in the trauma intensive care setting.

This is a Phase 2, single-arm, open-label study evaluating cevostamab consolidation therapy following BCMA-directed CAR T-cell therapy for relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma. The primary objective is to assess the proportion of participants achieving minimal residual disease (MRD)-negative complete remission at 12 months post-CAR T-cell therapy. Key eligibility criteria include having received BCMA CAR T-cell therapy 6-10 weeks prior, without progressive disease since infusion. Cevostamab is administered intravenously every 3 weeks starting around 10 weeks post-CAR T, with an initial 8 cycles planned. Treatment may continue for an additional 8 cycles if MRD-negative complete remission is not achieved after the first 8 cycles. Secondary outcomes include safety, feasibility of administering cevostamab post-CAR T, and impact on other clinical outcomes like overall response rates. The study aims to evaluate cevostamab consolidation following CAR T-cell therapy in relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma patients.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the impact of rehabilitative ultrasonography imaging on core muscle function in patients with visceral adiposity (abdominal obesity). The study involves 45 participants aged 25-45 years with a waist circumference greater than 102 cm for men and 88 cm for women, and a body mass index (BMI) between 25-29.9 kg/m2. Participants are randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) cavitation ultrasonic lipolysis on the abdomen combined with exercise, 2) rehabilitative ultrasound imaging (RUSI) guided core muscle exercise, or 3) a combination of cavitation and RUSI. The primary outcomes measured are diaphragm excursion and transverse abdominis contraction ratio using ultrasound imaging. Secondary outcomes include visceral fat thickness and waist circumference. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these interventions on improving core muscle function and reducing visceral adiposity.

This is a prospective, single-arm, open-label pilot study investigating the impact of atrial fibrosis surface area on the occurrence of atrial fibrillation in patients with ischemic stroke of undetermined origin. The study involves performing cardiac MRI with contrast agent on eligible patients who have experienced a cryptogenic ischemic stroke within 7 days of inclusion. Patients will also undergo implantation of an implantable cardiac monitor within 3 months of the stroke to detect silent atrial fibrillation episodes. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of atrial fibrillation episodes lasting more than 30 seconds on the implantable loop recorder, which will be assessed at 3-year follow-up. The study aims to evaluate the diagnostic utility of atrial fibrosis surface area in predicting the risk of atrial fibrillation in patients with ischemic stroke of unknown cause.

This is an open-label randomized phase II study evaluating the efficacy of adding the AKT inhibitor capivasertib and/or the immunotherapy durvalumab to hormone therapy (goserelin and fulvestrant) in premenopausal or perimenopausal patients with estrogen receptor-positive locally advanced or metastatic breast cancer. Patients will be randomized to one of four treatment arms: 1) goserelin/fulvestrant (control), 2) goserelin/fulvestrant/capivasertib, 3) goserelin/fulvestrant/capivasertib/durvalumab, or 4) goserelin/fulvestrant/durvalumab. The primary endpoint is progression-free survival comparing the three experimental arms to the control arm. Secondary endpoints include objective response rate and biomarker analysis. Key eligibility criteria include premenopausal/perimenopausal status, ER-positive breast cancer, and limited prior treatment for advanced disease.

This is a parallel-group, two-arm, prospective, randomized, non-blinded, fallback design, controlled superiority study conducted at the University of Maryland Charles Regional Medical Center (UM CRMC). The study aims to evaluate the impact of a new transitional care model on reducing 30-day unplanned hospital readmissions among patients at higher risk of readmission.

The study has two primary endpoints:
1. 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the overall study population.
2. 30-day post-discharge unplanned hospital readmission in the medium-high risk population (RecuR Score 2 & 3).

Participants are randomized 1:1 to either:
Arm 1 (Standard of Care): Diagnosis education, follow-up appointment scheduling assistance, community resources, weekly follow-up calls, and social determinants of health assessment.
Arm 2 (Enhanced Care): Arm 1 interventions plus additional educational training using iPads, focus on readmission risk during care transition rounds, and home health services.

The study includes inpatients at UM

This is a randomized, open-label, monocenter trial (ANCAR Trial) aimed at evaluating the effects of an acupuncture treatment protocol for nasal congestion in allergic rhinitis (AR) compared to azelastine nasal spray (Carelastin®). The study involves two parallel arms: an experimental arm receiving a fixed set of acupuncture points, and an active comparator arm receiving Carelastin® nasal spray. The primary outcome measure is the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) score for nasal congestion after 6 weeks of treatment. Secondary outcomes include VAS, Peak Nasal Inspiratory Flow (PNIF), and Adapted Nasal Obstruction Symptom Evaluation (NOSE) scores at various time points to assess nasal congestion, other nasal and ocular symptoms, general health, concentration, energy level, and middle ear pressure equalization. The study aims to evaluate the immediate, post-treatment, and long-term effects of acupuncture on nasal congestion in AR patients compared to an intranasal antihistamine therapy.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the feasibility, safety, and potential benefits of intracoronary cooling and dilution during primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) for ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). The study aims to enroll 60 STEMI patients undergoing primary PCI at Harefield Hospital. Patients will be randomized 1:1 to receive either intracoronary cooling and dilution with room temperature saline infusion through the guiding catheter (intervention group) or standard care (control group). The primary outcomes are recruitment rate, feasibility of collecting planned measurements, and safety. Secondary outcomes include invasive physiological assessments of coronary flow and microvascular function, biomarkers, myocardial salvage and infarct size on cardiac MRI, and clinical outcomes such as left ventricular function, hospitalization for heart failure, and mortality. The study will evaluate the potential cardioprotective effects of intracoronary cooling and dilution during primary PCI for STEMI.

This is a feasibility pilot clinical trial investigating the potential of dietary interventions, including fish oil, probiotics, and dietary modifications, to improve mental health outcomes in pregnant women with a history of anxiety and/or depression. The study aims to recruit 100 participants, aged 18-43 years, who are 12-35 weeks pregnant and have a clinical diagnosis of lifetime depression or anxiety but are currently stable. Participants will be randomly assigned to one of four groups: Gutopia (dietary modification, fish oil, and probiotics), Gutboost (fish oil and probiotics), Gutless (fish oil and placebo probiotics), or Gutnone (standard care and one-time dietary consultation).

The primary outcome is to assess the feasibility of the study, measured by the ability to recruit the targeted number of participants within the anticipated timeframe and the completion of at least four out of six study visits by each participant. Secondary outcomes include adherence to supplement intake, adherence to dietary protocols, and documentation of obstacles encountered during the study.

Data collection will involve dietary intake assessments, mental health scores, stool samples, and lifestyle questionnaires at six study visits over a two-year period, with

This is a randomized study evaluating remotely delivered, culturally tailored weight loss interventions among Latina breast cancer survivors. The study has two stages:

Stage I:
- Participants are randomized to one of two arms:
    Arm I: Online ¡Vida! program with health education sessions, dietary modifications, home exercise, Fitbit devices, and access to a cooking website.
    Arm II: Same as Arm I, plus remote lifestyle health education sessions.

Stage II: 
- Participants who achieve ≥2% weight loss at week 4 continue their assigned intervention.
- Those with <2% weight loss are re-randomized to one of four arms:
    Arm III: Same as Stage I, Arm II
    Arm IV: Same as Arm III, plus individualized telephone health coaching
    Arm V: Same as Arm IV
    Arm VI: Same as Arm IV, plus monthly delivery of groceries

The primary outcome is percent change in body weight at 12 months. Secondary outcomes include assessing if intervention effectiveness is moderated by baseline characteristics.

The study involves biospecimen collection, use

This is a retrospective study evaluating the use of high-dose follitropin delta, a recombinant follicle-stimulating hormone, in combination with either human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) or highly-purified human menopausal gonadotropin (HP-hMG) for ovarian stimulation in women aged 18-42 years undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF) or intracytoplasmic sperm injection (ICSI) cycles using an antagonist protocol. The study has two arms: one with follitropin delta + hCG and another with follitropin delta + HP-hMG, with dosing regimens individualized based on anti-Müllerian hormone levels and body weight. The primary outcome measure is the number of good quality blastocysts obtained up to day 6 after fertilization. The study excludes women with conditions such as endometriosis stage III/IV, recurrent miscarriages, and those undergoing ovarian stimulation for fertility preservation or participating in other research projects.

This is a randomized, parallel-group study evaluating the effectiveness of telemedicine in the management of inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD), including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis. The study involves 60 patients with IBD, aged 18 years or older, who will be randomly assigned to either a telemedicine intervention group or an observation group for 6 months.

The telemedicine intervention group will log into a web platform monthly to complete questionnaires assessing disease activity (SCCAI for ulcerative colitis, Harvey-Bradshaw index for Crohn's disease, and IBD disk). They will also have access to online consultations with gastroenterologists and educational resources on IBD management. The observation group will receive standard outpatient care.

The primary outcomes are changes in quality of life measured by the SIBDQ and WHOQOL-26 questionnaires. Secondary outcomes include disease remission rates, adverse drug reactions, treatment satisfaction, psychological well-being (assessed by HADS, VSI, and TAS-26), surgical interventions, hospitalizations, and outpatient visits.

After 6 months, both

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment clinical trial investigating the continuation or withdrawal of somatostatin analogs (SSAs) upon progression in patients with locally advanced or metastatic, non-functional, well-differentiated gastroenteropancreatic neuroendocrine tumors (GEP-NETs). The trial aims to evaluate the difference in progression-free survival (PFS) and time to deterioration (TTD) between the two arms: continuing SSAs (octreotide LAR or lanreotide) every 4 weeks for 18 months versus withdrawing SSA treatment for 18 months. The trial includes two substudies, one for patients starting sunitinib or everolimus as second-line therapy, and another for patients starting peptide receptor radionuclide therapy (PRRT) with Lutetium (177Lu) oxodotreotide as second-line therapy. The primary outcomes are PFS and TTD at 18 months after starting second-line treatment. Secondary outcomes include PFS rate, overall survival, response rates, quality of life, cost-effectiveness, and safety. The study is open

This is a randomized controlled trial studying the effects of a peer-mediated intervention on children with language impairment and social isolation in preschool classrooms. The study involves 25 inclusive preschool classrooms, with 12 classrooms assigned to the treatment condition and 13 to the control condition.

In each classroom, one target child is selected based on having low pragmatic language skills and being socially isolated from their classroom social network. The treatment condition involves peer-mediated pivotal response training (PRT), where classroom facilitators train and support peers to use strategies to engage the target child during center time. The strategies include offering play options, showing how to play, complimenting the target child, and encouraging turn-taking.

The primary outcome measure is the Preschool Language Screener 5 (PLS-5), which assesses expressive language skills. Secondary outcomes include the Developmental Pragmatic Profile (DPP) for pragmatic skills, the Teacher-Child Rating Scale (TCRS) for social, behavioral, and emotional competence, and observational measures of peer interactions, play interactions, incoming peer talk, and outgoing talk from the target child.

The

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of combining dalfampridine (a drug that improves nerve conduction) with physical therapy on mobility in people with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study has three arms: 1) dalfampridine only, 2) physical therapy only, and 3) dalfampridine plus physical therapy. The primary outcome is change in the Timed 25-Foot Walk test from baseline to the end of each treatment phase. Key aspects include:

- Participants: 48 individuals with MS-related mobility impairment (EDSS ≤6.5)
- Design: Parallel assignment, three arms 
- Interventions: 
    1) Dalfampridine 10mg twice daily for 6 weeks
    2) Physical therapy (motor relearning) twice weekly for 6 weeks  
    3) Dalfampridine 10mg twice daily + physical therapy twice weekly for 6 weeks
- Primary aim: Determine if dalfampridine can augment the effects of physical therapy on mobility
- Secondary aims: Compare the combined intervention to each monotherapy

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the test-retest reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability of the CLEFT-Q questionnaire, which assesses health-related quality of life in patients with cleft lip and/or palate. The study involves five participant groups: 1) 50 patients answering CLEFT-Q twice within 1-2 weeks for test-retest reliability, 2) 50 patients undergoing secondary nose surgery, 3) 50 patients undergoing secondary lip surgery, 4) 50 patients undergoing jaw surgery, and 5) 50 patients undergoing secondary speech-improving surgery. These groups will complete the CLEFT-Q before and after their respective surgeries (6 months or 1 year follow-up). Additionally, 20 healthcare professionals will be interviewed about their experiences with the CLEFT-Q. The primary outcome measure is the change in CLEFT-Q scores, while secondary outcomes include photographs and speech recordings before and after surgery. The study aims to assess the reliability, responsiveness, and interpretability of the CLEFT-Q in evaluating the health-related quality of life of patients with cleft lip

This clinical trial aimed to compare the effectiveness of core stabilization exercises and dynamic stretching exercises in reducing the symptoms and improving the quality of life in young women with primary dysmenorrhea (painful menstrual cramps). The study involved two groups of participants aged 18-25 years: one group performed stretching exercises, and the other group performed dynamic core stabilizing exercises for 8 weeks. The primary outcomes measured were the WaLIDD (working ability, location, intensity, days of pain, dysmenorrhea) score, side bridge test for core strength, McGill Quality of Life questionnaire, and the PFSD (pain, frequency, severity, duration) scale. The study aimed to determine which type of exercise, stretching or core stabilization, was more effective in alleviating the symptoms and improving the quality of life in individuals with primary dysmenorrhea.

This is a prospective observational study investigating the relationship between cerebral perfusion, as measured by transcranial Doppler (TCD) of the middle cerebral artery, and changes in mean arterial pressure (MAP) during general anesthesia. The primary objectives are to identify a linear relationship between the percentage change in mean blood velocity (Vm) and the percentage change in the 95% spectral frequency front (SEF95) of the frontal electroencephalogram (EEG) during MAP changes, and to compare cerebral perfusion measured by TCD with cerebral oxygen saturation measured by near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS). The study will include 100 adult patients undergoing scheduled surgery under general anesthesia with blood pressure optimization using norepinephrine. Continuous measurements will be made of MAP, Vm by TCD, frontal EEG parameters (including SEF95 and burst suppression), and cerebral oxygen saturation by NIRS. The study aims to determine if there is an individual autoregulatory threshold for MAP below which cerebral perfusion is impaired, and if this threshold differs between patients with and without cardiovascular risk factors. This is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) evaluating the feasibility and potential efficacy of the PediQUEST Response to Pain Of Children with Neurologic Disability (PQ-ResPOND) intervention for children and adolescents/young adults (AYA) with severe neurologic impairment (SNI) and moderate to severe recurrent pain. The study aims to assess the feasibility of conducting a full-scale RCT by evaluating recruitment, adherence, retention, and acceptability of the intervention. It also aims to explore the potential efficacy of the intervention by estimating effect sizes and variability of outcomes related to child's recurrent pain, symptom burden, and parent outcomes.

The study will enroll 45 parent-child dyads, with 30 randomized to the PQ-ResPOND intervention and 15 to usual care. The intervention combines parent-mediated activation through weekly reporting of child's pain and symptoms via an app, feedback to parents and clinicians, and integration of a pediatric palliative care (PPC) team using a standardized approach. The control group will receive usual care.

Primary outcomes focus

This is a prospective observational study evaluating minimal residual disease (MRD) dynamic monitoring in first-line treatment of extensive small cell lung cancer with serplulimab plus chemotherapy. The study includes patients aged 18-75 years with previously untreated extensive small cell lung cancer and adequate organ function. Participants receive 6 cycles of serplulimab (4.5 mg/kg) plus chemotherapy (etoposide with carboplatin/cisplatin). MRD testing is performed before treatment, after 2 and 6 cycles, 6 months and 1 year after chemotherapy completion. The primary outcome is progression-free survival at 1 year after chemotherapy completion. Secondary outcomes include overall survival, objective response rate, and disease control rate at 1 year. The study aims to assess the efficacy of serplulimab plus chemotherapy and the utility of MRD monitoring in this setting.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group pilot study evaluating the effectiveness of the Aktivplan digital intervention for supporting regular heart-healthy physical activity following completion of a phase II cardiac rehabilitation program. The study has two arms: the experimental arm receiving the Aktivplan intervention, which is a smartphone app for planning and monitoring physical activity, and the control arm receiving usual care according to standard guidelines. The primary outcomes include recruitment rate, dropout rate, data completeness, adherence to the intervention, usability, user experience, user acceptance, technical stability, use of additional strategies, and qualitative experiences of patients and professionals. Secondary outcomes include exercise capacity, physical activity behavior, weight, blood pressure, cholesterol, HbA1c, smoking, quality of life, exercise self-efficacy, and patient safety. The study aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and preliminary effectiveness of the Aktivplan digital intervention in supporting physical activity after cardiac rehabilitation.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, crossover study evaluating the effects of intranasal oxytocin on social and repetitive behaviors in youth aged 12-20 years with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study involves two treatment periods, where participants receive either 24IU of oxytocin nasal spray or placebo nasal spray twice daily for four weeks, with a washout period in between. The primary outcomes are social behavior assessed by the Social Responsiveness Scale-Second Edition (SRS-2) and repetitive behavior assessed by the Repetitive Behavior Scale-Revised (RBS-R), both completed by caregivers. Secondary outcomes include behavioral inflexibility, social cognition, repetitive cognition, and vagally-mediated heart rate variability. The study aims to investigate the potential therapeutic effects of oxytocin on social and repetitive symptoms in individuals with ASD.

This is an observational study aimed at creating and validating a Clinical Evaluation Scale for Abdominal Condition of the Premature (ECAP). The study involves premature newborns (born before 37 weeks of gestation) who are at least 3 days old and hospitalized in neonatal intensive care units. The newborns will be evaluated daily from the 3rd day of life by a nurse, physiotherapist, and resident using the ECAP scale. The evaluations will be conducted at least 8 times over 21 days, with each evaluator assessing the newborn's abdomen blindly within a 30-minute window. If an abdominal massage is performed, the ECAP assessment will be done before and after the massage by the physiotherapist. The primary outcome measure is the ECAP scale score, ranging from 0 to 20. Secondary outcome measures include the indication for abdominal massage based on the ECAP scale, the validity of the ECAP scale in term birth population, and the impact of massage on the ECAP scale score. The study aims to validate the ECAP scale and assess its usefulness in

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of the Empowered Relief (ER) program, a psycho-educational pain skills training intervention, delivered by ER-trained nurses from the American Society for Pain Management Nursing (ASPMN). The study aims to assess the feasibility, acceptability, and effectiveness of ER in reducing pain catastrophizing and pain intensity among adults with persistent pain.

The study will recruit 170 participants aged 18 and above with self-reported or clinically diagnosed persistent pain for more than 3 months. Participants will be randomized into two groups: the ER treatment group and a wait-list control group. The ER group will receive a 2-hour online ER class delivered by an ER-trained ASPMN nurse, while the control group will continue their usual pain care for 2 months before being offered the ER class.

The primary outcome measure is the change in pain catastrophizing, assessed through self-report at baseline, 2, 4, and 8 weeks. The secondary outcome measure is the change in pain intensity, measured using a 0-10 pain severity scale at the same time points.

The

This clinical trial aims to investigate the mental effort and confidence associated with choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings from the perspectives of patients and nurses. The key aspects are:

1. Exploratory aim to compare the mental effort required for choosing and understanding different pain intensity rating scales, recall periods, and body areas (Aim 1).

2. Primary aim to compare patients' and nurses' perceptions of mental effort in choosing and understanding pain intensity ratings (Aim 2). 

3. Exploratory aim to determine the relationship between perceived mental effort and the importance of decreasing that effort for patients and nurses (Aim 3).

4. Exploratory aim to evaluate the equivalence of patients' and nurses' confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain intensity rating patterns (Aim 4).

5. Exploratory aim to test the relationship between confidence in the accuracy of fictional pain patterns and the importance of increasing that confidence for patients and nurses (Aim 5).

The study involves surveying patients with chronic musculoskeletal pain and nurses who routinely assess pain. It explores factors influencing the cognitive load and confidence associated with pain ratings, aiming to improve pain communication between patients and healthcare providers.

This is a clinical study investigating the use of mesenchymal stromal cells (MSCs) for the treatment of poor graft function (PGF) after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (allo-HSCT). The study is designed as a single-arm, open-label trial. Eligible participants are patients aged 18-60 years who are undergoing allo-HSCT and develop PGF. The intervention involves administering 1×10^6/kg MSCs from cord blood weekly for 4 consecutive weeks in addition to conventional PGF treatment. The primary outcome measure is the recovery of hemogram parameters (white blood cells, red blood cells, and platelets) within 20-40 days after transplantation. Secondary outcomes include infection rate, graft-versus-host disease, and 1-year overall and disease-free survival rates. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of MSC treatment for improving engraftment and clinical outcomes in patients with PGF after allo-HSCT.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of two mind-body interventions - mindful yoga and arts-based therapy - in improving the psychosocial-spiritual well-being of individuals with mild to advanced Parkinson's disease (PD). The study aims to address the significant unmet psychosocial-spiritual needs of PD patients, which can greatly impact their quality of life. The primary outcomes measured include perceived stress levels, overall and PD-specific quality of life, PD-related symptoms, and self-compassion. Secondary outcomes include self-efficacy, perceived social support, constipation severity, bowel habits, gut microbiota composition, and user satisfaction. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the mindful yoga intervention or the arts-based therapy intervention, each consisting of six 90-minute group sessions delivered both in-person and online. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, 3 months, 6 months, and 9 months after the baseline. The study seeks to provide holistic interventions for early identification, prevention, and alleviation of the psychosocial-spiritual effects of PD, as well as promote community support and reduce stigma associated

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of an integrated digital intervention called Quit Genius Alcohol (QG-A) for treating alcohol use disorder (AUD). The study compares QG-A, which combines cognitive-behavioral therapy (CBT) delivered through a mobile app with pharmacotherapy (naltrexone), to a control group receiving medical management (MM) with naltrexone alone.

Key aspects:

- Population: Adults aged 18+ with moderate or severe AUD, residing in the U.S.
- Intervention arm (QG-A): Mobile app providing CBT, motivational enhancement therapy, and community reinforcement, along with naltrexone prescribed via telemedicine and support from a counselor.
- Control arm (MM): Standard medical management with naltrexone prescribed via telemedicine and brief monthly provider visits.
- Primary outcome: Change in past 30-day alcohol use from baseline to 6 months post-treatment entry.
- Study design: Two-arm, parallel-group, randomized controlled trial with 12, 24, 36, and 52-week follow-ups.
- Aim: To evaluate the

This is a Phase I open-label clinical trial investigating a novel combination therapy for previously untreated metastatic pancreatic cancer. The key aspects are:

- The trial aims to determine the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of the anti-CTLA-4 antibody botensilimab when combined with balstilimab (anti-PD-1), triplet chemotherapy (nab-paclitaxel, gemcitabine, cisplatin), chloroquine, and celecoxib.

- Part 1 is a dose escalation study to establish the MTD of botensilimab. Part 2 is an expansion cohort treated at the MTD determined in Part 1. 

- The primary outcomes are MTD, safety and tolerability. Secondary outcomes include complete response rate, overall response rate, progression-free survival, and overall survival.

- The rationale is to maximize endoplasmic reticulum stress and unfolded protein response to drive pancreatic cancer cells towards apoptosis by using the intensive combination therapy along with chloroquine (autophagy inhibitor) and celecoxib (anti-inflammatory).

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the clinical pregnancy rate of frozen embryo transfer (FET) in natural cycles versus substituted cycles. The study involves two participant groups: one undergoing FET in a natural cycle without hormones, and the other undergoing FET in a substituted cycle with estrogen and progesterone administration. The primary outcome measure is the clinical pregnancy rate, defined as the presence of a fetal heartbeat at the viability ultrasound performed 6 to 8 weeks after the FET. The study includes women under 40 years old who have undergone either a natural cycle FET or a substituted cycle FET at Clinique OVO. Exclusion criteria include egg or embryo recipients, history of recurrent miscarriages, uterine abnormalities, abnormal hormonal profiles, and history of recurrent implantation failure.

This is a randomized, double-blind clinical trial comparing the effects of inhalational anesthesia (sevoflurane) versus intravenous anesthesia (propofol) in older adults aged 75 years and above undergoing elective, non-cardiac surgery. The primary aims are to determine the incidence of postoperative delirium, postoperative cognitive dysfunction, postoperative functional decline, and changes in patient-reported outcomes and blood biomarkers (phosphorylated tau 181, neuroinflammation, and Alzheimer's disease pathology markers) between the two anesthesia groups. The study hypothesizes that intravenous anesthesia will be associated with lower incidences of postoperative delirium, cognitive dysfunction, functional decline, and better patient-reported outcomes and biomarker profiles compared to inhalational anesthesia. Participants will undergo comprehensive cognitive, functional, and biomarker assessments at baseline, postoperatively, and up to one year after surgery. The study aims to optimize anesthesia management to prevent postoperative cognitive and functional decline in older surgical patients.

This is a summary of the clinical trial document on "Nutrition in Congenital Heart Disease":

The study aims to assess the nutritional status of children with congenital heart disease, both cyanotic and acyanotic types. It will include children aged between 5 weeks and 18 years presenting at Assiut University Hospital. Detailed medical history, including perinatal, natal, and postnatal history, will be taken. General and systemic examinations, with a focus on heart disease, will be conducted. Nutritional assessment and anthropometric measurements, such as weight, height, length, head circumference, mid-arm circumference, and BMI, will be performed and plotted on WHO growth charts. The primary outcome measure is to adopt a protocol to avoid nutritional deficiency and achieve normal growth in children with congenital heart disease. Children with comorbidities like severe sepsis, endocarditis, empyema, autoimmune diseases, liver cirrhosis, or those receiving immunosuppressive therapy will be excluded from the study.

This is a prospective, randomized controlled trial investigating the use of pH-sensitive amine chemical exchange saturation transfer (CEST) MRI to guide surgical resection of glioblastoma. The study aims to evaluate if maximal safe resection of CEST-positive non-enhancing (NE) regions, which are associated with infiltrating tumor cells, can improve progression-free survival (PFS) in patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma.

Patients with newly diagnosed glioblastoma will undergo standard pre-operative MRI and CEST-EPI imaging. Those randomized to the experimental arm will have CEST-positive NE regions identified and uploaded to intraoperative neuronavigation software to guide resection of these areas in addition to the contrast-enhancing tumor. The control arm will undergo standard resection of only the contrast-enhancing tumor.

All patients will receive standard adjuvant temozolomide and radiation therapy. The primary outcome is PFS, with secondary outcomes including overall survival, surgical complication rates, and quality of life measured by the Karnofsky Performance Scale. The study plans to enroll 60 patients to detect a

This clinical trial aims to investigate the patterns of urinary bladder cancer in Darfur, Sudan, from 2020 to 2022. It is a cross-sectional, hospital-based study conducted at Nyala Specialized Hospital. The primary outcome measure is to understand the clinical outcomes, etiology, histology, and demographic distribution of urinary bladder cancer in the region. The study includes all Sudanese patients aged 18 and above who live in Darfur and present with a urinary bladder mass. Patients who do not reside in Darfur or refuse to participate in the study are excluded.

This is a cross-sectional study investigating the relationship between mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy. A total of 1000 patients undergoing colonoscopy at Renji Hospital from May 2023 to August 2023 will be enrolled based on inclusion and exclusion criteria. The study will collect general information and assess the participants' physical and mental stress levels using questionnaires. The quality of bowel preparation will be evaluated during the colonoscopy using the Boston Bowel Preparation Scale (BPS), which scores the cleanliness of the colon on a 9-point scale. The primary outcome measure is the quality of bowel preparation, assessed by the BPS during the colonoscopy, approximately 20 minutes after the procedure begins. The study aims to analyze the correlation between mental stress and the quality of bowel preparation for colonoscopy.

This is a study investigating the effects of playful interactions, operationalized through dramatic improvisation techniques, on cognitive, social, and emotional outcomes in older adults. The study has a crossover design with four arms:

1. Playful interactions in a face-to-face format
2. Active control condition (introductory conversation and movement exercises) in a face-to-face format  
3. Playful interactions in an online format
4. Active control condition in an online format

Participants (aged 60+) will be randomly assigned to the four arms and will undergo both the playful interaction and active control condition in a counterbalanced order, separated by a week. Cognitive tests (digit span, phonetic fluency, flanker task), mood (positive and negative affect), social measures (perceived partner responsiveness, closeness), and other measures like flow, mindfulness, and subjective arousal will be assessed at baseline, before and after each session.

The study aims to examine the beneficial effects of short playful interactions on cognitive, social, and emotional outcomes in older adults, compare online vs. face-to-face formats, and explore the role of individual characteristics like personality traits and cognitive functions.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the efficacy of the SkillFlix for Parents online video library in improving sexual health communication skills of parents of teens with autism spectrum disorder (ASD). The study involves parent-youth dyads, with parents over 18 years old and youth aged 13-17 with ASD, reciprocal communication skills, and in mainstream classrooms for at least one class. 

The dyads will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group, which will receive access to the SkillFlix for Parents video library covering communication skills for discussing relationships and sexual health topics, or the control group, which will receive written materials. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, immediately after the 3-month intervention period, and at a 3-month follow-up.

The primary outcome measure is the demonstrated skill score in communicating with their teens about sexual health, based on a rubric. Secondary outcomes include parent-reported frequency of discussions, conversation quality scores, parent and teen confidence in communication skills, family sex communication quotient, teen's sexual health knowledge, attitudes, and behaviors.

The study aims to assess the impact of the SkillFlix for Parents resource on parent skill

This is a clinical trial studying the role of DDX17 and Gasdermin D (GSDMD) in septic vascular endothelial pyroptosis (a form of programmed cell death) and their correlation with disease severity and prognosis in sepsis patients.

Key aspects:

- Inclusion criteria: Patients with sepsis or septic shock, aged 18-80 years.
- Exclusion criteria: Conditions that may involve vascular endothelial damage like hypertension, liver diseases, renal diseases, autoimmune disorders.
- Data collection: Patient demographics, disease details, treatment measures, lab results like leukocyte count, PCT, hs-CRP on days 1, 3, and 7. 28-day follow-up.
- Sample collection: Plasma samples on days 1, 3, and 7 for ELISA detection of DDX17 and GSDMD levels.
- Primary outcome: 28-day mortality.
- Secondary outcomes: Correlation between plasma DDX17/GSDMD levels and vascular endothelial injury, disease severity, and progn

This is a single-center prospective study aimed at evaluating non-invasive methods for diagnosing postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients. The study includes patients aged 18-75 years who are eligible for liver transplantation, excluding those unable to provide informed consent, re-transplant patients, and those with fulminant hepatitis. The primary outcome measure is early allograft dysfunction (EAD), defined by specific criteria related to bilirubin levels, international normalized ratio (INR), and liver enzyme levels within the first two weeks after transplantation. The study aims to assess the effectiveness of non-invasive diagnostic methods in identifying EAD and other postoperative complications in liver transplant recipients.

This is a multi-center, phase II, randomized, controlled clinical trial investigating the efficacy and safety of adding Elemene to the standard Stupp Protocol for the treatment of newly-diagnosed glioblastoma (GBM), a highly aggressive brain tumor. The trial aims to compare two treatment arms:

1. Stupp Protocol alone (control arm): Patients receive maximal safe tumor resection, concurrent radiotherapy and temozolomide (TMZ), followed by adjuvant TMZ. A placebo matching Elemene is given orally during the adjuvant TMZ phase.

2. Elemene plus Stupp Protocol (experimental arm): Patients receive the same Stupp Protocol treatment, with the addition of Elemene (an anti-tumor drug extracted from a plant) given orally during the adjuvant TMZ phase.

The primary outcome is the overall survival rate at 12 months after randomization. Secondary outcomes include overall survival, progression-free survival, progression-free survival rate at 6 months, and adverse events.

Eligible participants are newly-diagnosed, IDH-wildtype GBM patients aged 18-70 years with adequate organ

This is a crossover study investigating the physiological effects of prone versus supine positioning on lung recruitability in infants/children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Eligible patients with ARDS (PaO2/FiO2 ≤ 200 mmHg) will undergo a decremental PEEP trial in the supine position, followed by measurements of gas exchange, respiratory mechanics, and lung volumes assessed by electrical impedance tomography (EIT). Patients will then be placed in the prone position for 1 hour, with the same measurements repeated. The primary outcome is the PaO2/FiO2 ratio at the end of each position. Secondary outcomes include other gas exchange parameters, ventilatory ratio, EIT-derived lung volumes and tidal volume distribution, lung strain, and safety endpoints like oxygen desaturations and endotracheal tube displacements. The study aims to evaluate the effects of prone positioning on lung recruitment and oxygenation in pediatric ARDS patients.

This clinical trial aimed to investigate and compare the effects of progressive relaxation training (PRT) on pain characteristics, attack frequency, activity self-efficacy perception, and social participation in women with tension-type headache (TTH) and migraine. The study involved 44 women aged 20-45 years, with 22 in the TTH group and 22 in the migraine group. Both groups received PRT sessions twice a week for 30 minutes each over 6 weeks, led by a physiotherapist. The sessions involved contracting and relaxing different muscle groups through deep breathing exercises.

The primary outcomes measured were occupational self-assessment, disability assessment, pain catastrophizing, headache impact, and pain intensity using various scales and questionnaires. Secondary outcomes included migraine disability assessment. The study aimed to provide comprehensive evaluation and intervention approaches for clinicians working with women suffering from TTH and migraine, addressing challenges encountered in daily life activities and social participation.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the potential use of microRNA biomarkers for neonatal opioid withdrawal syndrome (NOWS). The study involves collecting buccal swab saliva samples from infants with chronic in-utero opioid exposure at 24 hours of life and at discharge. The primary outcome measures include neurodevelopmental outcome scores at 6 months of age, maximum concentration of morphine required for withdrawal symptom control, and salivary levels of specific microRNAs (let-7a, miR-146a, and miR-192) measured through qPCR. The study is designed to evaluate the relationship between these microRNA levels and the severity of NOWS, as well as potential neurodevelopmental outcomes. Eligible participants are newborns of at least 35 weeks gestation with chronic in-utero opioid exposure, born or transferred to Penn State Hershey Medical Center within 48 hours after birth. The study aims to provide insights into the potential use of microRNA biomarkers for early detection and monitoring of NOWS.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of patient education on pain level and fear of pain in orthopedics and traumatology patients undergoing elective surgery. The study had two groups: an intervention group that received patient education on pain management including non-pharmacological and pharmacological methods, and a control group that received standard education without specific pain management education. The primary outcome was pain level measured by a Visual/Visual Analogue Scale, and the secondary outcome was fear of pain measured by the Fear of Pain Scale-III. A total of 52 patients were enrolled, with 26 in each group. Data was collected preoperatively, postoperatively every 4 hours for 24 hours, and at discharge. The study aimed to test the hypotheses that the intervention group would have lower postoperative pain levels and lower fear of pain compared to the control group. The results could inform strategies for improving pain management through patient education in surgical patients.

The Patch BRIDGE trial is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled study investigating the use of a buprenorphine transdermal patch for induction during pregnancy in individuals with opioid use disorder. The primary objective is to evaluate the severity of withdrawal symptoms during induction, measured by the Subjective Opioid Withdrawal Scale (SOWS) scores from days 0 through 4. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the experimental arm receiving the buprenorphine transdermal patch or the placebo comparator arm receiving a sham patch. Secondary outcomes include induction success, treatment adherence measured by positive buprenorphine urine screens during pregnancy, and recovery success measured by negative non-prescribed opioid urine screens during prenatal care. The study aims to provide a safer and more effective induction method for pregnant individuals with opioid use disorder.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the use of transcutaneous oximetry (TcpO2) in assessing vascular compression in patients suspected of having thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS). The primary outcome measure is the variation in upper limb ischemia, estimated by TcpO2 measurement and calculating the DROPmin (TcpO2 variation regarding a reference), depending on the type of vascular damage (arterial, venous, or both). The secondary outcome measure is to assess the correlation between the severity of upper limb ischemia measured by TcpO2 and the degree of arterial stenosis observed in diagnostic arteriography. The study includes patients suspected of having TOS who have undergone additional diagnostic tests such as venous and arterial Doppler or dynamic arteriography and venography, and have also undergone dynamic TcpO2 recording. The intervention involves comparing the TcpO2 values recorded during dynamic maneuvers with the estimated rate of compression of the subclavian and axillary vessels determined on dynamic angiography.

This is a feasibility study evaluating the use of a mobile health app called SmartCP for symptom monitoring in patients with chronic pancreatitis. The key aspects of the trial are:

- It is a single-arm, unblinded, 16-week feasibility study with no control group.
- Participants will use the SmartCP app, which includes features like symptom tracking, diet/activity logging, alerts for escalating symptoms, quality of life assessment, educational content, and messaging with healthcare providers.
- The primary outcomes measure feasibility aspects such as recruitment, acceptability, retention, adverse events, and user engagement statistics.
- Secondary outcomes include occurrence of crisis events (phone calls, ER visits, urgent clinic visits), symptom frequency and severity, quality of life scores, hospitalizations, and use of the app's communication and educational features.
- The study aims to determine if the SmartCP app is feasible for managing chronic pancreatitis patients, complementing specialist clinical care.
- Eligibility criteria include residing in Ireland, ability to read/write English, access to a compatible smartphone and home internet.

The study will evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, and potential benefits of

This is a retrospective cross-sectional study conducted at Mansoura University isolation hospital from September 2020 to November 2020, investigating the incidence of anal fissure among survivors of COVID-19 infection. The study included patients aged 20-70 years who were treated for COVID-19, discharged safely, and presented with anal fissure during follow-up. Patients without anal pain or fissure, and those who died, were excluded. Data was collected from electronic medical records and telephone interviews. The primary outcome measure was the incidence of anal fissure among COVID-19 survivors, while the secondary outcome measure was the risk factors associated with the development of anal fissure in this group. The study aimed to identify the outcomes, risk factors, and management approaches for anal fissure in COVID-19 survivors.

This is a randomized prospective controlled study that aimed to assess the effects of platelet-rich fibrin (PRF) on wound healing following palatal connective tissue harvesting for root coverage surgery. Patients with Miller class 1 or 2 gingival recession who required root coverage surgery were included. The study had two groups: a test group where autologous leukocyte-rich PRF (L-PRF) membrane was placed at the palatal donor site after connective tissue harvesting, and a control group where no additional material was applied. Ultrasonographic assessments were performed at various time points (days 0, 3, 7, 14, 21, 30, and 90) to measure palatal tissue thickness (primary outcome) and tissue vascularization (secondary outcome) using B-mode, color Doppler, and pulsed wave Doppler modes. The study aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of L-PRF application on wound healing and tissue regeneration at the palatal donor site.

The ARRC III Trial is a pilot registry study at the Royal Adelaide Hospital (RAH) evaluating the Advanced Recovery Room Care (ARRC) model for post-surgical care. The ARRC model has previously shown improvements in patient outcomes, hospital utilization, and cost-effectiveness compared to usual ward care. The study aims to collect high-quality data on the ARRC model to ensure maintained or improved outcomes, enable benchmarking across institutions, identify surgical subgroups benefiting from ARRC, and generate hypotheses on how the benefits are achieved.

The primary outcome measure is the number of days spent at the usual place of residence within 90 days after surgery (Days at Home after surgery). Secondary outcomes include in-hospital complications, mortality up to 1 year after surgery, and cost-effectiveness compared to usual care.

The study includes patients aged 18 and above scheduled for elective or unplanned surgery at RAH, with an expected hospital stay of at least one night and a 30-day mortality risk of 0.5% to 8% based on the US National Safety and Quality Improvement Program risk score. Patients undergoing cardiac surgery or scheduled for postoperative intensive care

This is a Phase 3b, open-label, hybrid type 2 implementation and effectiveness trial aimed at assessing the implementation and effectiveness of oral (event-driven and daily) and long-acting pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) in mobile men in South Africa and Uganda. The study has the following key aspects:

- It is a multi-country, multi-setting, randomized controlled trial comparing persistence in care for oral PrEP (tenofovir disoproxil fumarate/emtricitabine, TDF-FTC) and long-acting injectable cabotegravir (CAB-LA) in mobile men.
- HIV-negative mobile men aged 18+ years will be recruited from outreach settings in South Africa and Uganda (target sample size: 400).
- Participants will be randomized into two groups: Group A will receive oral TDF-FTC PrEP (event-driven or daily) for 9 months, and Group B will receive CAB-LA for 9 months.
- After 9 months, participants from both groups will be offered a choice of PrEP (TDF-F

This clinical trial aimed to assess the psycho-emotional state of patients with temporomandibular disorders (TMD) compared to a control group without TMD. The study involved 260 participants, with 130 patients diagnosed with TMD (group I) and 130 patients without TMD (group II). The participants completed a questionnaire consisting of 30 questions related to their emotional state over the past four weeks, including mood, irritability, sadness, lack of desire for daily activities, lack of concentration, self-isolation, critical thoughts, and nervousness. The responses were scored on a scale from 0 (most favorable) to 4 (most unfavorable), and the results were divided into four sections (A, B, C, D). The study aimed to evaluate the potential psychological and emotional impact of TMD by comparing the questionnaire responses between the two groups.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of different types of touch interventions on brain connectivity, electroencephalogram (EEG) activity, and metabolic biomarkers in preterm infants. The study has three parallel arms: 1) Therapeutic touch based on osteopathic manipulative treatment, 2) Affective touch, and 3) Static/non-specific touch as a placebo control. The primary outcome measure is changes in brain activity measured by functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) before and after the touch intervention. Secondary outcomes include changes in EEG slow delta wave power, and changes in urinary metabolites measured by nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy, liquid chromatography-mass spectrometry, and gas chromatography-mass spectrometry at multiple time points up to 40 weeks. The study includes preterm infants born between 32.0 and 33.6 weeks gestational age without significant comorbidities. The trial aims to evaluate the potential benefits of different touch interventions on brain development and metabolic processes in preterm infants.

This is a Phase I/II non-myeloablative haploidentical hematopoietic cell transplantation (HCT) study for patients with sickle cell disease (SCD), including those with compromised organ function. The primary objective is to evaluate the regimen success rate, defined as successful engraftment (persistent donor chimerism and free of acute SCD complications) and absence of acute grade 3 or higher graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) or moderate to severe chronic GVHD at 1 year post-transplant. The study involves two cohorts receiving different doses of post-transplant cyclophosphamide (PT-Cy). All participants will receive the investigational briquilimab antibody and abatacept added to the established regimen of alemtuzumab, total body irradiation, sirolimus, and infusion of filgrastim-mobilized peripheral blood hematopoietic cells from haploidentical related donors. Secondary objectives include evaluating event-free survival, overall survival, incidence of viral reactivation and disease, autoimmune and hyperinflamm

This is a randomized controlled trial comparing the effectiveness of two sperm preparation methods, microfluidic chip and density gradient centrifugation, on the euploidy rate of blastocysts in pre-implantation genetic testing (PGT) for couples undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF).

The study involves recruiting couples where the woman is undergoing PGT for monogenic diseases, chromosomal rearrangements, or aneuploidy. Women will undergo ovarian stimulation, oocyte retrieval, and intracytoplasmic sperm injection. On the day of oocyte retrieval, the couples will be randomly assigned to either the microfluidic chip group or the density gradient centrifugation group for sperm preparation.

In the microfluidic chip group, the Sperm Separation Device will be used to prepare the sperm sample. In the density gradient centrifugation group, a discontinuous density gradient centrifugation method will be used for sperm preparation.

The primary outcome measure is the euploidy rate of blastocysts biopsied. Secondary outcomes include live birth rate, pregnancy rates, miscarriage rate,

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of Brain-derived Neurotrophic Factor (BDNF) single nucleotide gene polymorphism and Nerve Growth Factor as risk factors that increase the severity of allergic rhinitis. The study involves genotyping and measuring serum levels of various biomarkers in patients with chronic allergic rhinitis. The primary outcome measures include BDNF gene single nucleotide polymorphism, Nerve Growth Factor serum level, IL-1 serum level, and C-reactive protein serum level, which will be measured in blood samples over a period of 2 months. The study is designed to assess the association between these genetic and biochemical factors and the risk or severity of allergic rhinitis.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effect of a mindfulness-based intervention on EEG brain activity, cognitive function, and psychological well-being in healthy older adults aged 60-75 years. The study will enroll 60 participants who will undergo cognitive and psychological assessments, as well as EEG recordings at baseline, 2 weeks, and 24 weeks after the intervention. The intervention consists of an 8-week mindfulness program with weekly 2-hour group sessions and daily home practice. The primary outcomes include changes in dispositional mindfulness, verbal memory, and interoceptive awareness from baseline to week 8. Secondary outcomes include changes in EEG alpha power. The study is designed as a single-arm, open-label trial with the primary purpose of prevention. Data analysis will involve descriptive statistics, correlation analyses, and longitudinal modeling using generalized estimating equations.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the prevalence of Mycoplasma genitalium (MG) infection, associated antimicrobial resistance, and other sexually transmitted infections (STIs) among HIV-infected males in Hong Kong. A total of 750 HIV-infected males attending an HIV specialist clinic will be recruited. Participants will self-administer an online questionnaire and self-collect urine, rectal, and pharyngeal samples for MG, Chlamydia trachomatis (CT), and Neisseria gonorrhoeae (NG) screening using nucleic acid amplification tests. MG genotypic resistance mutations for macrolides and fluoroquinolones will also be detected. Clinical data will be transcribed from the participants' medical records. The primary outcomes are the prevalence of MG infection and MG resistance mutations. Secondary outcomes include the prevalence of CT, NG, syphilis, hepatitis C virus (HCV), and overall STI infections. The study aims to provide insights into the burden of MG and other STIs, as well as antimicrobial resistance patterns, among HIV-infected males in Hong Kong.

This is a randomized, open-label clinical trial investigating the efficacy of dalpiciclib in combination with endocrine therapy for the treatment of hormone receptor-positive (HR+) and HER2-negative advanced breast cancer patients who have previously received CDK4/6 inhibitor treatment. The study aims to evaluate the potential of dalpiciclib, a CDK4/6 inhibitor, to improve patient survival when combined with endocrine therapy after failure of other CDK4/6 inhibitors.

The study has two arms: Arm A receives dalpiciclib plus physician-selected endocrine therapy (letrozole, anastrozole, exemestane, fulvestrant, or tamoxifen), while Arm B receives physician-selected chemotherapy regimens.

The primary outcome measure is investigator-assessed progression-free survival (PFS). Secondary outcomes include objective response rate (ORR), disease control rate (DCR), and overall survival (OS).

Eligibility criteria include HR+/HER2- advanced breast cancer, previous treatment with CDK4/6 inhibitors, and at least one ER-positive lesion confirmed by 18F-

This is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter study evaluating the combination of XELOX (capecitabine and oxaliplatin), fruquintinib (a VEGFR inhibitor), and sintilimab (a PD-1 inhibitor) as regimen conversion therapy for gastric cancer or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with only liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastases. The primary outcome is progression-free survival, and secondary outcomes include overall survival, objective response rate, disease control rate, duration of response, translational rate (proportion undergoing surgery/ablation after treatment), and adverse events. Eligible patients are 18-75 years old with HER2-negative advanced gastric/GEJ adenocarcinoma limited to liver and/or retroperitoneal lymph node metastases, with no prior VEGFR-targeted or PD-1/PD-L1 therapy. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of this triplet regimen as a conversion therapy approach in this specific oligometastatic patient population.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the impact of incentives on physical activity levels among older adults aged 55 and above. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of two types of incentives - prosocial incentives (meal donations) and personal incentives (monetary rewards) - in increasing daily step counts.

The study will recruit 200 older adults who own smartphones and have low baseline physical activity levels. Participants will be randomly assigned to either the treatment group, which will receive meal donations to a food bank and monetary rewards for each day they reach a daily step goal of 7,500 steps, or the control group, which will not receive any incentives.

Step count data will be collected through Fitbit devices and the Fitabase platform for 8 weeks - 1 week for baseline measurement, 5 weeks of intervention, and 2 weeks of follow-up. The primary outcome is the change in average daily step count from baseline to the end of the study. Secondary outcomes include changes in depression scores measured by the CES-D scale.

The study aims to assess the impact of alternative incentives on promoting physical activity and habit formation among older adults, while addressing challenges of scalability,

This is an interrupted time series study evaluating the clinical impact and cost-effectiveness of a wireless vital sign monitor called neoGuard for hospitalized newborns in Kenya. The study is conducted at the Moi Teaching and Referral Hospital neonatal ward from April 2022 to June 2023. Newborns admitted from April-November 2022 comprise the pre-intervention arm receiving standard-of-care monitoring. In December 2022, neoGuard was installed in 4 sub-units (intervention group), while the remaining 4 sub-units (comparison group) continued with standard-of-care monitoring. The primary outcomes measured are the nurse's response time to patients in distress and the percentage of actionable alarms from neoGuard. Secondary outcomes include incidence of patient complications, in-hospital mortality, and frequency of key interventions. The study aims to assess neoGuard's ability to detect abnormal physiological signals, provide valid alarms, and its impact on newborn treatment outcomes compared to standard monitoring. Medical staff will participate in user surveys to capture their experience and perceptions on feasibility and sustainability of neoGuard.

This is a Phase II non-randomized, open-label, parallel assignment study evaluating pre-operative or post-operative hypofractionated radiation therapy in elderly (≥70 years) or frail (≥65 years) patients with limb or trunk soft tissue sarcoma. The study has two arms: 1) Neo-adjuvant cohort receiving hypofractionated radiation therapy (30 Gy in 5 fractions) prior to surgery, and 2) Adjuvant cohort undergoing surgery before receiving hypofractionated radiation therapy (40 Gy in 15 fractions). The primary outcome is the rate of patients free of major surgical complications within 6 months of surgery. Secondary outcomes include disease-free survival, surgical complications, wound disorders, healing time, quality of life, patient autonomy, geriatric parameters, and radiation therapy toxicities, evaluated over 3 years. The study aims to assess the safety and efficacy of hypofractionated radiation therapy in this specific patient population with soft tissue sarcoma.

This is a retrospective study conducted at the department of ENT-Head and Neck Surgery of Shree Birendra Hospital in Nepal, aimed at investigating the prevalence and clinicopathological profile of head and neck cancers. The study collected data from medical records of head and neck cancer patients who underwent treatment between May 2022 and April 2023. The data included demographic details, diagnosis, subsite-specific head and neck cancers, treatment modalities, and histopathology. The primary outcome measures were age-wise distribution, distribution according to subsite, histopathology, TNM staging, and treatment provided. The study population included patients aged 17 to 84 years, and both sexes were eligible. The data was analyzed using SPSS version 22, and Pearson's chi-square test was applied to determine statistical significance.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the impact of a health communication message (infographic) on the detection and management of pediatric obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) in primary care settings. The study involves children aged 2.0-13.9 years who screen positive for OSA symptoms during a pre-visit questionnaire.

Eligible children and their parents will be randomly assigned to one of two groups:

1. Intervention group: Parents will review a health communication message (infographic) informing them about their child's OSA symptoms, describing nighttime and daytime symptoms, and encouraging them to discuss with the child's primary care provider during the scheduled visit. The provider will also receive an alert about the child's positive OSA screening.

2. Control group (usual care): Parents will not receive any additional information about OSA or their child's risk. However, the provider will still receive an alert about the child's positive OSA screening.

The primary outcome is the rate of completed OSA referrals (polysomnogram, ENT referral, or sleep medicine referral) among children who screened positive for OSA, measured up to 9 months after study entry.

This is a multi-country, prospective, post-marketing study evaluating the speed of onset and durability of effectiveness of upadacitinib in adult participants with moderate to severe Crohn's disease for 3 years in real-world clinical practice. The study includes participants aged 18 years or older diagnosed with moderate-to-severe Crohn's disease who are initiating upadacitinib treatment as prescribed by their clinician. The primary outcomes measure the time to achieve first clinical response based on patient-reported outcomes, and the percentage of participants achieving clinical remission per Harvey Bradshaw Index among those with clinical response at the end of induction therapy. Participants will receive upadacitinib as per the local approved label under routine clinical care.

This clinical trial aims to test an online version of the QAPS (Qualitative Assessment of Prewriting Skills) tool for assessing prewriting skills in children aged 3 to 7 years. The study involves several assessments and surveys to evaluate children's abilities in drawing shapes on a tablet, copying shapes on paper, handwriting, using scissors, and related skills. The primary outcome measures include the online QAPS, Beery VMI (visual-motor integration), functional hand tasks, and surveys on demographics, emotionality, inattention/hyperactivity, and ego resiliency. The study is designed to assess the effectiveness of the online QAPS tool in measuring prewriting skills and related developmental factors in young children.

This is a randomized controlled trial evaluating the effectiveness of the Critical Time Intervention-Peer Support (CTI-PS) model for individuals with serious mental illness discharged from inpatient psychiatric treatment facilities in Portugal. The CTI-PS intervention is a 9-month recovery-oriented program delivered by Community Mental Health Workers and Peer Support Workers. It aims to collaborate with participants to develop durable connections to support systems, provide practical and emotional support, and help overcome the critical transition period after discharge.

The study includes individuals aged 18-65 years with a psychotic disorder diagnosis, discharged from inpatient psychiatric facilities within the previous month. The primary outcomes are health-related quality of life (WHOQOL-BREF) and unmet needs (Camberwell Assessment of Need) at 18 months. Secondary outcomes include psychopathology, disability, recovery orientation, self-stigma, and substance use.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the intervention group receiving CTI-PS and usual care or the control group receiving usual care alone. The CTI-PS intervention involves three phases (Initiation, Try-Out, and Transfer of Care) and focuses on strengthening the

This is a registry study for vascular trauma and follow-up examinations. The primary objective is to assess long-term outcomes after vascular injury through regular follow-up examinations, including ultrasound, ankle-brachial index (ABI) measurements, CT or MRI scans, to evaluate graft/vessel patency, vessel diameter, and endoleak formation. The key outcome measures are graft/vessel patency, ABI index, and reintervention rate for complications like graft occlusion or stenosis. Assessments will be performed at 3, 6, and 12 months after trauma, and annually thereafter for an average of 1 year. The study includes adult patients (aged 18 years or older) with vascular involvement in trauma, excluding those who lack consent. The registry aims to document long-term follow-up data and potentially develop treatment patterns for vascular trauma.

This is a prospective randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of blood flow restriction (BFR) therapy during rehabilitation after open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) surgery for distal radius fractures. The study aims to compare the outcomes of standard rehabilitation versus rehabilitation incorporating BFR exercises.

Key aspects:

- Participants: Adults aged 18+ with acute distal radius fractures requiring ORIF surgery.
- Intervention: The experimental group will undergo standard rehabilitation with the addition of BFR exercises using a tourniquet cuff during selected exercises. The control group will receive standard rehabilitation without BFR.
- Randomization: Participants will be randomly assigned to the control or intervention group, with groups normalized based on gender.
- Outcome measures: Primary outcomes include body composition/bone density (DEXA scans), forearm girth, grip strength, and pinch grip strength. Secondary outcomes include patient-reported outcome surveys (DASH, Michigan Hand Outcomes, Patient Rated Wrist Evaluation) assessing pain, symptoms, and functional ability.
- Measurements: Outcomes will be measured at baseline, 2 weeks, 6 weeks, and 12

This is a randomized clinical trial investigating the effects of a workplace intervention called "Stand up for your Health®" computer app on reducing sitting time, musculoskeletal symptoms, and improving cardiometabolic markers in sedentary office workers.
