The study has two arms: an experimental group receiving the computer app intervention plus educational information, and a control group receiving only educational information. The primary outcomes are sedentary behavior (occupational sitting time) measured objectively using accelerometers and subjectively using a questionnaire, assessed at baseline, 3 months, and 6 months. Secondary outcomes include cardiometabolic biomarkers (fasting blood glucose, insulin, cortisol, triglycerides, cholesterol), anthropometric measurements (height, weight, waist circumference, BMI), and musculoskeletal symptoms (pain and symptoms) measured at the same time points. The study aims to determine the effectiveness of the intervention in reducing sitting time and improving health outcomes, as well as identify barriers and facilitators to adherence.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled parallel-group study investigating the chronic effects of low-load blood flow restriction exercise and creatine supplementation in recreationally active women aged 18-35 years. The study aims to assess the impact of these interventions on strength, body composition, neuromuscular function, endothelial function, and mood states over a 9-month period.

Participants will be randomly assigned to one of five groups: 1) Control group with no intervention, 2) Creatine supplementation and blood flow restriction exercise, 3) Creatine supplementation and exercise without blood flow restriction, 4) Placebo and blood flow restriction exercise, or 5) Placebo and exercise without blood flow restriction.

The study involves a 5-day creatine/placebo loading phase, followed by 8 weeks of supplementation and exercise training. Assessments will be conducted at baseline, post-loading, during training, and at 4-week and 9-month follow-ups. Measurements include isokinetic strength testing, body composition analysis, electromyography, flow-mediated dilation

This clinical trial aims to investigate novel targetable biomarkers in anorexia nervosa (AN). The study will enroll 8 adult patients with restrictive type AN (non-exercising subtype), 8 adult patients with restrictive type AN (exercising subtype), and 16 age- and sex-matched healthy controls. The primary outcomes are the levels of Growth Differentiation Factor-15 (GDF-15) in the plasma and cerebrospinal fluid of AN patients compared to controls. Additional assessments include body composition via DEXA scans, energy expenditure via indirect calorimetry, and correlation of GDF-15, neurofilament light chain, glial fibrillary acidic protein, and cytokine levels with lean and fat mass measures and energy expenditure. The study aims to evaluate GDF-15 and cytokines as potential novel targets for AN treatment and lay the groundwork for future studies using neutralizing antibodies or inhibitors against these targets.

This is a prospective, observational study aimed at collecting data on complications and outcomes from patients undergoing pleural procedures such as thoracocentesis, chest drain insertion, indwelling pleural catheter placement, pleural biopsies, and medical thoracoscopy. The study will enroll patients aged 18 or older who are undergoing pleural interventions and can provide written informed consent. The primary outcome measure is the occurrence of complications, including bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, organ injury, pain, and re-expansion pulmonary edema, within 30 days of the procedure. Secondary outcomes include patient-reported measures of dyspnea and chest pain within 4 weeks. The study plans to involve at least 20 centers, including district general and tertiary referral centers with active pleural services. Data collection will include demographics, smoking history, pre-procedure observations, radiological findings, medical history, and details of the procedure and service. Patients will also be asked to complete visual analogue scales for chest pain and breathlessness before and after the procedure, and those receiving indwelling catheters or pleurodesis will complete additional questionnaires.

This is a single-center, observational study that aims to develop an artificial intelligence (AI)-based model for risk stratification of coronary artery disease (CAD) progression and adverse cardiovascular events. The study consists of two cohorts:

1. Retrospective cohort: 2500 patients who previously underwent coronary computed tomography angiography (cCTA) for CAD evaluation. No follow-up is planned for this cohort.

2. Prospective cohort: 500 patients undergoing clinically indicated cCTA for CAD evaluation. These patients will be followed up for 36 months.

The primary outcome measure is a composite of death by cardiovascular events or non-fatal myocardial infarction at 36 months from the cCTA examination. The secondary outcome measure is a composite of all-cause mortality, non-fatal myocardial infarction, hospitalization due to angina or angina-like symptoms, and late coronary revascularization at 36 months.

The study aims to develop an AI-based model that integrates various imaging and clinical parameters, including coronary artery plaque features, atherosclerotic

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled phase II clinical trial evaluating the efficacy and safety of different doses of edaravone dexborneol concentrated solution for injection combined with conventional medical therapy in the treatment of patients with cerebral hemorrhage. The trial has two periods: Period A is a dose escalation period with two dose levels (37.5 mg and 62.5 mg of edaravone dexborneol), and Period B uses the selected safe dose from Period A. The primary outcome is the incidence of serious adverse events up to 90 days after treatment. Secondary outcomes include mortality, adverse events, modified Rankin Scale scores, National Institutes of Health Stroke Scale scores, Barthel index, imaging endpoints (perihematomal edema volume, hematoma volume, edema extension distance), and pharmacokinetic and biomarker endpoints. Eligible patients are aged 18-80 years with a clinical diagnosis of cerebral hemorrhage in the basal ganglia, hematoma volume ≤30 ml, and onset within 6-24 hours before treatment initiation.

Here is a concise summary of the key aspects of the provided clinical trial document:

This is a multicenter, randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled clinical study to evaluate the efficacy and safety of Manzhi Guben granules in improving exercise tolerance and promoting recovery in convalescent COVID-19 patients aged 50-80 years old. 

The primary outcome is the 6-minute walk test results on day 14 after treatment. Secondary outcomes include 6-minute walk test on day 28 and pulmonary ventilation function on days 14 and 28.

Patients in the experimental arm will receive Manzhi Guben granules (10g twice daily) for 4 weeks, while the placebo arm will receive a placebo granule product on the same schedule. 

Key eligibility criteria include being aged 50-80, having fatigue/shortness of breath/cough after COVID-19 infection, and 6-minute walk test results less than 80% of predicted value at baseline.

The study aims to provide evidence on using the traditional Chinese medicine Manzhi Guben granules to improve exercise tolerance

This is a non-interventional functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) study aimed at investigating the neural bases of decision-making and executive functioning in healthy individuals. The study will enroll 150 healthy participants aged 18-60 years. Participants will undergo behavioral assessments to measure their decision-making skills (e.g., loss aversion, risk aversion, delay discounting) and executive functioning skills (e.g., selective attention, inhibitory control). They will also undergo a multimodal fMRI session to examine brain activity, structural morphometry, and structural connectivity associated with decision-making and executive performance in social and non-social contexts. The primary outcome measure is behavioral performance in decision-making tasks, specifically loss aversion. Secondary outcomes include behavioral performance in executive functioning tasks, brain activity patterns related to decision-making and executive performance, and brain structural measures (grey matter volume/density and structural connectivity) associated with individual differences in these cognitive domains. The study aims to provide insights into the relationship between executive and decision-making abilities, their potential changes with aging, and their neural underpinnings in healthy individuals.

This is a summative usability study investigating the use of Neutrocheck, a device for detecting neutropenia, among healthy volunteers and healthcare professionals. The study aims to identify potential use errors, close calls, and difficulties associated with the device's use, as well as assess the effectiveness of key safety information and user satisfaction.

The study has two participant groups: one using paper instructions and the other using app instructions for Neutrocheck. The primary outcomes include identifying use errors, close calls, and difficulties through hazard-related use scenarios, and assessing the effectiveness of key safety information through a questionnaire. Secondary outcomes involve measuring user satisfaction through a questionnaire and comparing task completion rates and user satisfaction between the two study groups.

The study will use descriptive statistics to analyze the questionnaire data and Fisher's exact test to determine the statistical significance of differences in task completion rates and user satisfaction between the two groups. The study accepts healthy volunteers aged 18 years or older, excluding those with HIV, active hepatitis B or C, needle or blood phobia, or recent immunosuppressive treatment.

The study aims to identify obstacles and solutions for people with Parkinson's disease (PD) in adopting technology to improve gait, and quantify changes in gait biomechanics, physical function, physical activity, motivation, and quality of life. It involves the use of the Heel2Toe™ sensor, which provides real-time auditory feedback when the person takes a good step with a strong heel strike.

The study uses an individualized, blocked, stepped-wedge design, where variable-sized clusters of participants are randomized to receive the Heel2Toe sensor, training, and remote supervised use at intervals of 3 weeks. The primary outcomes measure changes in angular velocity of the ankle during different phases of the gait cycle, and the coefficient of variation of angular velocity, averaged over at least 50 steps. Secondary outcomes include motivation, apathy, walking behavior (daily step count), health-related quality of life, self-reported cognitive ability, and cognitive performance.

The study targets people with PD who meet the criteria for technology readiness and have sufficient walking capacity to use the Heel2Toe sensor at home. The aim is to estimate the extent to which participants require support from

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial investigating the preliminary effects of a 4-week laughter yoga program on mood, anxiety, and loneliness among adolescents with intellectual and physical disabilities in a special school in Hong Kong. The study aims to assess whether the laughter yoga program can promote mental health by increasing happiness, laughter, and joy in this population.

The intervention group will receive an 8-session laughter yoga program over 4 weeks, with each session lasting 15 minutes and involving laughter exercises, deep breathing, and playfulness activities. The control group will receive routine care provided by the special school.

A total of 40 adolescents aged 10-19 years with mild to moderate intellectual or physical disabilities will be randomly allocated to the intervention or control group in a 1:1 ratio. Outcome measures include mood (assessed by a 5-point Mood Scale), anxiety (assessed by the 6-item State-Trait Anxiety Inventory), and loneliness (assessed by the 8-item UCLA Loneliness Scale). These measures will be collected before the intervention and immediately after the 4-week program for both groups.

The study aims to

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of decision aids on the participation of South Asian women (Indian, Pakistani, or Nepalese) aged 25-64 in cervical cancer screening. The study has three arms: 1) control group receiving a leaflet about healthy living, 2) experimental group receiving a printed decision aid booklet containing information on cervical cancer screening options, and 3) experimental group receiving a mobile app decision aid with the same screening information.

The primary outcomes are decisional conflict measured by the Decisional Conflict Scale at baseline and 2 weeks post-intervention, and cervical cancer screening uptake at 3 months post-intervention. Secondary outcomes include risk perception, choice predisposition towards screening, and screening decision at baseline and 2 weeks.

The study aims to evaluate if providing decision aids in printed or mobile app formats can increase cervical cancer screening participation and informed decision-making among South Asian women compared to a control group receiving general health information. Eligible participants are South Asian women aged 25-64 with no history of cervical cancer or hysterectomy, sexually active, able to communicate in certain South Asian languages, have not had recent cervical screening

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the additional effect of forward head posture correction on temporomandibular dysfunction (TMD). The study aims to evaluate the impact of using a cervical traction orthotic device (Denneroll) along with conservative management (stretching and relaxation exercises) for treating myogenic TMD patients with forward head posture.

The study involves two parallel groups: 
1) Active Comparator group receiving conservative management with placebo traction. 
2) Experimental group receiving conservative management along with Denneroll cervical traction for 3-15 minutes daily.

Participants aged 18-40 years with diagnosed myogenic TMD and forward head posture (craniocervical angle <50 degrees) will be recruited from the dental clinic of the University of Sharjah.

The primary outcomes are TMD severity assessed by the Fonseca Anamnestic Questionnaire and craniocervical angle measured through photographic method. Secondary outcomes include mouth opening range, orofacial pain (VAS), and mandibular opening.

Assessments will be done at baseline, 3rd week, and 7

This clinical trial aims to compare the efficacy of clindamycin phosphate 1% gel versus once-daily dapsone 5% gel in the treatment of moderate acne vulgaris. The study involves two parallel groups, one receiving clindamycin gel and the other receiving dapsone gel, for a duration of 3 months. The primary outcome measure is the change in the Global Acne Grading Score (GAGS) before and after treatment, which will be used to assess the efficacy of the two treatments. The study is open-label, randomized, and includes participants aged 20 to 50 years with moderate acne vulgaris. The key inclusion criteria are moderate acne vulgaris and age between 20 and 50 years, while the exclusion criteria include systemic treatment, pregnancy or lactation, and hematological abnormalities.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the relationship between the severity of rotator cuff tears and the activation patterns of scapular and rotator cuff muscles. The study will involve participants aged 18-60 years with a confirmed diagnosis of rotator cuff tear, classified into four groups based on tear size: small (<1 cm), medium (1-3 cm), large (3-5 cm), and massive (>5 cm). Surface electromyography (sEMG) will be used to assess the activation patterns of scapular and rotator cuff muscles (serratus anterior, upper and lower trapezius, supraspinatus, and infraspinatus) during functional tasks such as shoulder flexion, abduction, and external rotation. The primary outcome measure is the muscle activation amplitude, and the secondary outcome measure is the identification of differences in muscle activation patterns between varying tear sizes. The study aims to provide insights into the compensatory mechanisms and muscle activation strategies employed by individuals with different severities of rotator cuff tears.

The SENIOR RCT is a 24-month multicenter randomized controlled trial conducted in two hospitals in Pavia, Italy. The primary objective is to evaluate the efficacy of a 6-month sustainable nutrition protocol on malnourished older adults (≥65 years) compared to the hospital's standard care. The primary endpoints are changes in body weight and strength (handgrip) pre- and post-intervention between the experimental and control groups. Secondary endpoints include changes in blood biomarkers, dietary habits, quality of life, and sarcopenia indicators.

Participants are malnourished older adults diagnosed using GLIM criteria. The experimental group receives a personalized, sustainable nutritional protocol designed by dietitians, focusing on adequate energy, protein, and water intake. The control group receives the hospital's standard malnutrition care. Assessments include anthropometrics, blood tests, diet quality, quality of life, strength, and locomotion at baseline, 3, 6, and 12 months.

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of a sustainable nutrition intervention in improving the nutritional status, dietary habits, and overall health of malnourished older adults compared to standard care.

This is a double-blind, multicenter, prospective observational cohort study investigating the dynamic changes of Torquetenovirus (TTV) load in Chinese renal transplant recipients during immunosuppressive therapy. The study aims to evaluate the potential of TTV load as a biomarker for monitoring the risk of rejection, infection, and development of donor-specific antibodies (DSA) in renal transplant recipients. The primary outcome measure is biopsy-proven or clinically diagnosed acute rejection, while secondary outcome measures include infection events, development of de novo DSA or increase in preformed DSA, and changes in donor-derived cell-free DNA levels. The study includes renal transplant recipients aged 18-65 years, receiving standard immunosuppressive therapy, and excludes those with active hepatitis B or C infection or anticipated irregular follow-up. The study will monitor participants for up to 365 days post-transplantation.

This clinical trial aimed to investigate the effects of vitamin B12 versus vitamin B3 on nerve regeneration and functional recovery in children aged 6-15 years with severe traumatic brain injury (TBI). The study involved two parallel groups, with one group receiving vitamin B3 (up to 16 mg/day) and the other group receiving vitamin B12 (up to 250 mcg/day). The primary outcome measure was the change in Stair Climb Test (SCT) score, which assesses functional strength, balance, and agility by measuring the time taken to ascend and descend a specific number of steps. The study was designed as a non-randomized, open-label, parallel-assignment trial with a total sample size of 300 participants. Neurobehavioral testing, gait analysis, and pre- and post-treatment Glasgow Coma Scale measurements were also conducted at different time points (3 weeks and 18 months) to evaluate cognitive capacity, sensorimotor activity, and working and reference memory.

This is a single-arm, open-label study evaluating the efficacy and safety of pyrotinib after adjuvant anti-HER2 therapy in women with high-risk early or locally advanced HER2-positive breast cancer. The primary outcome is invasive disease-free survival at 2 years. Secondary outcomes include disease-free survival at 2 years, overall survival, invasive disease-free survival at 5 years, and adverse events. Eligible participants are women aged 18-75 years with HER2-positive stage II-IIIC breast cancer who have completed standard anti-HER2 therapy but did not achieve a pathologic complete response. Participants will receive pyrotinib 400mg orally daily for 1 year. The study aims to evaluate the efficacy and safety of pyrotinib as an additional treatment after standard anti-HER2 therapy in this high-risk patient population.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the impact of consuming pasta at different times of the day (lunch or dinner) on various health outcomes in normal-weight individuals. The study is designed as a randomized, controlled, crossover trial with two intervention phases. Participants will be randomly assigned to either consume pasta at dinner for 3 months followed by pasta at lunch for 3 months, or vice versa.

The primary outcome measure is sleep quality, assessed through actigraphy at the beginning and end of each intervention phase. Secondary outcomes include changes in weight, body mass index, fat mass, basal metabolic rate, blood glucose, glycated hemoglobin, lipid profile, liver enzymes, kidney function markers, gut microbiota composition and functionality, individual circadian rhythms, oxidative stress markers, and appetite-regulating hormones.

The study aims to determine whether the timing of pasta consumption (lunch or dinner) has differential effects on sleep quality, anthropometric parameters, cardiovascular risk factors, and gut microbiota composition and functionality in normal-weight individuals. The participants' individual chronotypes (circadian rhythms) will also be considered as a potential factor influencing the outcomes.

This is a phase 2, open-label, single-center study evaluating the use of 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT imaging in up to 55 participants with multiple myeloma. The primary objective is to determine the concordance between 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT in detecting multiple myeloma lesions. Participants will be enrolled into two cohorts: newly diagnosed multiple myeloma (NDMM) and relapsed/refractory multiple myeloma (RRMM). All participants will undergo 18F-fluciclovine PET/CT and 18F-FDG PET/CT at three timepoints: baseline, after induction treatment (NDMM) or 6 months (RRMM), and at disease progression or 5 years. The study will assess the concordance rate of scan positivity between the two imaging modalities. Secondary outcomes include evaluating the efficacy of 18F-fluciclovine in measuring disease volume compared to other indicators, its ability to identify minimal residual disease and evaluate treatment response compared

This clinical trial aims to evaluate arm swing during walking in patients with early multiple sclerosis (MS) and compare it with healthy controls. The study includes two groups: an early MS group and a healthy control group. The primary outcome measures are arm swing amplitude in shoulder, elbow, and overall flexion-extension direction, step-speed, Two Minute Walk Test (2MWT), Timed Up and Go (TUG), and Timed 25-Foot Walk Test (T25FW). The early MS group will undergo arm swing evaluation during gait, as well as functional tests (2MWT, TUG, and T25FW), while the healthy control group will only undergo arm swing evaluation during gait. The study will assess these measures at 3 months after the baseline. The inclusion criteria include patients diagnosed with MS within the last 30 days, clinically stable, and aged between 18-65 years. The exclusion criteria include acute medical illness in the past 6 months, other neurological or psychiatric diseases, orthopedic, rheumatologic, or vestibular conditions affecting walking, and exacerbations between the first and second evaluations.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group clinical trial investigating adjuvant pyrotinib and capecitabine for HER2-positive microinvasive breast cancer in women aged 18-70 years. The trial has two arms: the experimental arm receives pyrotinib (400mg daily) and capecitabine (500mg three times daily) for 6 months, along with endocrine therapy if hormone receptor-positive, and radiation therapy if needed. The control arm receives no adjuvant chemotherapy or targeted therapy, but endocrine therapy and radiation therapy are given as per the experimental arm. The primary outcome is invasive disease-free survival at 5 years. Secondary outcomes include distant disease-free survival and overall survival at 5 years. Key eligibility criteria include T1micN0 HER2-positive breast cancer, adequate organ function, and no prior systemic therapy.

This is a pilot randomized controlled trial (RCT) comparing the effectiveness of video biofeedback and laryngeal control therapy (LCT) in the treatment of paradoxical vocal fold motion (PVFM). PVFM is a condition characterized by episodic shortness of breath that can greatly impact daily life.

The study aims to enroll adults aged 18 or older with a referral for concerns of PVFM and a pre-treatment Dyspnea Index score of 11 or higher. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either video biofeedback or LCT.

The primary outcome measure is the change in Dyspnea Index score before treatment and one month after treatment. Secondary outcomes include Dyspnea Index score at 3 months, responder rates, Clinical Global Impressions - Improvement scale, and a qualitative survey on patient expectations and perceived utility of the treatment.

The study hypothesizes that there will be no clinically meaningful difference between video biofeedback and LCT in treating PVFM. The results of this pilot RCT will provide data for designing a fully powered trial comparing these two

This is a multicenter, quasi-experimental clinical trial aimed at evaluating the implementation of a multifaceted and multidisciplinary protocol to promote improvement in sleep quality in critically ill patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU). The study involves two phases: 

1. Assessing the sleep quality of sequential ICU patients and characterizing disruptive elements before implementing the sleep protocol. 

2. After training the multidisciplinary team, implementing a sleep protocol involving interventions such as adjusting sound intensity, reducing noise, providing earplugs and eye masks, dimming lights at night, rationalizing care activities during sleep hours, optimizing pain control and medication use, and offering hypnotic medications if needed. 

The primary outcome is the change in the Richards-Campbell Sleep Quality Score before and after implementing the protocol. Secondary outcomes include changes in sleep perception questionnaires, delirium incidence, family and staff perceptions, and long-term sleep quality assessments after discharge. The study aims to demonstrate improved sleep quality in critically ill patients through a multidisciplinary approach targeting modifiable environmental, physiological, and psychological factors.

This is a pilot cluster randomized controlled trial evaluating the feasibility and acceptability of the PACHA program, a community pharmacy-based intervention aimed at enhancing adherence to adjuvant endocrine therapy among breast cancer survivors. The trial has two arms: an intervention group where pharmacists provide the PACHA program components (web-based training, consultation guides, web resources) in addition to usual care, and a control group receiving usual care alone. The primary outcomes include changes in intention to adhere, knowledge, attitudes, social support, behavioral control, regret, coping planning, fear of recurrence, side effects, and cognitive representations of medication from baseline to 6-month follow-up. Secondary outcomes include proportion of days covered by endocrine therapy, quality of life, and qualitative feedback on program acceptability and feasibility. The study involves around 66 pharmacies and 132 breast cancer survivors in Quebec, Canada. The results will inform the optimization of the PACHA program and the design of a potential larger trial.

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled crossover study investigating the effects of Melissa officinalis (lemon balm) extract in phytosome form on sleep characteristics, anxiety levels, and quality of life in individuals aged 18-65 years with insomnia or sleep disturbances related to anxiety.

The primary outcome is sleep duration, including total sleep time and time spent in different sleep phases (deep, light, REM), measured using a wearable sleep monitoring device. Secondary outcomes include perceived sleep quality (Insomnia Severity Index), anxiety levels (State-Trait Anxiety Inventory), quality of life (Clinical Global Impression-Improvement scale), and adverse symptoms (DOTES scale).

Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either Melissa phytosome (550mg Berberis aristata root extract complexed with phospholipids) or placebo for 14 days, followed by a 7-day washout period, and then the alternate treatment for another 14 days. Sleep monitoring devices and questionnaires will be used at baseline, day 15, and day 36 to assess outcomes.

The study aims to

This is a multi-center, prospective, phase II study evaluating the efficacy of lenvatinib plus tislelizumab and CapeOX chemotherapy as first-line treatment for advanced gastric cancer or gastroesophageal junction adenocarcinoma with positive PD-L1 expression and low tumor microenvironment (TME) score. The study has two arms: an experimental arm receiving intensive treatment with lenvatinib, tislelizumab, and CapeOX chemotherapy followed by maintenance lenvatinib and tislelizumab, and an active comparator arm receiving tislelizumab and CapeOX chemotherapy followed by maintenance tislelizumab. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival, and secondary outcomes include overall survival, objective response rate, disease control rate, and duration of response. The study has detailed eligibility criteria regarding factors such as disease stage, prior treatments, performance status, and organ function.

This is a single-arm trial evaluating the effectiveness of Social Engage Coaching (S-ENG) in reducing loneliness, increasing satisfaction with social activities, and improving objective measures of social engagement among 30 adults aged 60 and older residing in senior living communities. The 16-week intervention involves 10 individual coaching sessions focused on increasing social connection through personalized action plans and psychoeducation. Outcomes are assessed using ecological momentary assessment (EMA) and passive sensing data collected via smartphones at baseline, 8 weeks, and 16 weeks. The primary outcomes are loneliness, satisfaction with social activities, time spent in conversations, and time spent outside the home. The study aims to promote social connection and prevent late-life suicide in a population experiencing loneliness and suicidal ideation.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the efficacy, safety, and tolerability of higher doses of transdermal estrogen therapy in women with premature ovarian insufficiency (POI). The study involves two treatment arms: 1) transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% 1.5mg/day, and 2) transdermal estradiol gel 0.1% 2.0mg/day, both combined with 200mg micronized progesterone administered vaginally for 14 days per cycle.

The primary outcomes include assessing the severity of estrogen deficiency symptoms using the Green scale questionnaire, changes in quality of life measured by the SF-36 and MENQOL questionnaires, after 3 months of treatment. Secondary outcomes include changes in levels of sex hormones (estradiol, testosterone, FSH, E1, E1S, SHBG) and bone mineral density after 12 months of treatment.

The study includes women aged 18-45 years with karyotypically normal spontaneous POI, diagnosed before age 40, who have been on standard-dose estradiol hormone replacement therapy for at least

The Symbiont-Restore Study is a randomized, triple-blinded, 2x2 factorial design intervention trial investigating the effects of synbiotic supplementation with the probiotic Limosilactobacillus reuteri PB-W1™ and a prebiotic blend (50% raffinose and 50% xylooligosaccharide) on markers of immune health, gut microbiome, and host metabolome in adults with a BMI of 30-40 kg/m². The study aims to systematically compare the immunological effects of the probiotic, prebiotic, synbiotic, and placebo interventions.

The study has four arms: probiotic arm (L. reuteri PB-W1™ and placebo sachet), prebiotic arm (prebiotic blend and placebo capsule), synbiotic arm (L. reuteri PB-W1™ and prebiotic blend), and placebo arm (placebo sachet and capsule). The primary outcome is the change in immune profile (serum cytokines and immune cell response) from baseline to 8 weeks

This is a single-center, randomized, placebo-controlled, double-blind, dose-escalating study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of AD16 tablets in healthy adult subjects after a single oral administration. The study involves 7 dosing cohorts receiving a single oral dose of AD16 (5mg, 10mg, 20mg, 30mg, 40mg, 60mg, or 80mg) or matching placebo. The primary outcomes include adverse events, serious adverse events, abnormal laboratory tests, vital signs, ECG, physical examination findings, concomitant medication, and pharmacokinetic parameters such as Tmax, Cmax, t1/2z, AUC, CL/F, Vd/F, λz, and MRT of AD16. Secondary outcomes include the amount of drug excreted in urine and feces, cumulative excretion rate, and renal clearance. Eligible participants are healthy adults aged 18-45 years with a specific BMI range. The study aims to evaluate the safety profile and pharmacokinetic characteristics of AD16 in preparation for further

This is a randomized, double-blind, placebo-controlled parallel study investigating the effects of urolithin A supplementation on endothelial function, cerebral blood flow regulation, and serum biomarkers of NO bioavailability and mitochondrial function in middle-aged adults with obesity. The study will recruit 54 adults aged 40-64 years with a BMI ≥ 30 kg/m2. Participants will be randomly assigned to receive either 1,000 mg of urolithin A daily or a placebo for 4 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the change in arterial function and local stiffness assessed by flow-mediated dilation. Secondary outcomes include changes in blood flow on the hand surface, homeostatic cerebral blood flow, plasma biomarkers of NO homeostasis (asymmetrical dimethylarginine, endothelin-1, bioactive nitrogen oxides), and plasma biomarkers of mitochondrial function (acylcarnitines). Measurements will be taken at baseline and after 4 weeks of supplementation. The study aims to investigate whether urolithin A supplementation improves endothelial function,

This clinical trial aims to investigate the effects of vibration therapy using a percussion massage gun on pain, functionality, proprioception (joint position sense), and kinesiophobia (fear of movement) in individuals with cervical disc herniation. The study involves two groups: a control group receiving conventional treatment (heat therapy, TENS, range of motion exercises, and isometric exercises) and an experimental group receiving the same conventional treatment plus vibration therapy. The vibration therapy involves applying vibration with a percussion massage gun to the trapezius, levator scapulae, and cervical paravertebral muscles for 3 minutes per muscle group, 3 days a week for 3 weeks. The primary outcome measure is the evaluation of joint position sense using the Laser Cursor Assisted Angle Repetition Test (LI-YATT). Secondary outcome measures include the Neck Disability Index, Visual Analogue Scale for pain intensity, and the Tampa Kinesiophobia Scale. The study includes individuals aged 40-50 years diagnosed with cervical disc herniation, with neck pain for at least 3 weeks and limited neck range of motion.

This is a descriptive, open-label, observational study aimed at creating a hospital register of patients with decompensated heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF). The study plans to enroll 120 patients hospitalized with acute decompensated HFpEF and 40 healthy controls. The primary objective is to comprehensively assess the influence of gender, clinical and anamnestic factors, body composition, congestion characteristics, instrumental data, and cellular inflammation and stress markers on immediate and long-term outcomes in patients with acute decompensated HFpEF. The study will collect data on patient demographics, comorbidities, medications, clinical and laboratory parameters, echocardiographic findings, bioimpedance analysis, and serum heat shock protein levels. The primary outcome measure is the number of secondary hospitalizations for decompensated HFpEF within 6 months. Secondary outcomes include hospitalizations for acute coronary syndrome, stroke, pulmonary embolism, and other cardiovascular events within 6 months. The study aims to develop diagnostic and treatment algorithms for HFpEF based on the findings.

This is a randomized, parallel-group pilot study aimed at adapting and testing the feasibility of delivering a group-level intervention called "Brothers Building Brothers by Breaking Barriers (B6)" via telehealth (tele-B6) for young Black gay, bisexual and other men who have sex with men (YB-GBMSM) living with HIV. The study involves two arms: an experimental arm receiving the tele-B6 intervention over 6 weekly group sessions, and a waitlist control arm receiving the intervention after a delay. The primary outcomes focus on assessing the acceptability, recruitment rates, retention, intervention fidelity, and safety of the tele-B6 intervention. Secondary outcomes include measures of perceived structural racism, discrimination, HIV stigma, internalized homonegativity, intersectional stigma, logistical barriers, individual resilience processes (identity affirmation), community resilience processes (social capital), and minority stress (depression, general well-being). The study targets YB-GBMSM aged 18-29 years, living with HIV in the Atlanta area. Qualitative interviews and surveys are used to collect data at multiple timepoints up

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effects of caregiver training on treatment outcomes for children with childhood apraxia of speech (CAS) receiving Dynamic Temporal and Tactile Cueing (DTTC) therapy. The study involves 40 children aged 2.5 to 7.11 years with CAS who will receive DTTC treatment twice a week for 8 weeks, along with home practice with a caregiver. Participants will be randomized into two groups: 1) Direct Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Direct Caregiver Training), where caregivers receive direct coaching from the speech-language pathologist (SLP) on administering DTTC during half of each session; 2) Indirect Training Group (DTTC + Home Practice + Indirect Caregiver Training), where caregivers only observe the SLP-administered DTTC sessions. In both groups, caregivers will review home practice guidelines and engage their children in 30-minute practice sessions 3 times per week during treatment and 6 times per week during the 4-week follow-up phase. The primary outcome

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the effectiveness of workshops and exchange groups for laryngectomized patients in improving their quality of life. The study will include two groups: an exchange group and a control group. The exchange group will participate in four sessions over four months, covering topics such as understanding their body image and coping with the consequences of laryngectomy. The control group will not attend the sessions but will complete quality of life questionnaires at the beginning and end of the four-month period.

The primary outcome measure is the difference in quality of life scores, assessed using the WHOQOL-BREF questionnaire, between the exchange group and control group before and after the program. Secondary outcomes include changes in overall and ENT-specific quality of life scores within the exchange group, and the participation rate in each session.

The study aims to validate the creation of self-help and support groups for laryngectomized patients, as there are currently very few organizations assisting these patients in adjusting to the significant life changes resulting from the surgery.

The MS-DETECT clinical trial aims to evaluate the performance of the MSCopilot® Detect mobile application in detecting disability worsening and disease progression in patients with relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) or secondary progressive multiple sclerosis (SPMS). The key aspects of the trial are:

- Participants: Adults aged 30-65 years with RRMS or SPMS, EDSS score 2.5-6.5, disease duration >5 years, clinically stable, and able to use a smartphone.

- Intervention: Participants will use the MSCopilot® Detect mobile app, which includes active tests for walking, cognition, dexterity, vision, and questionnaires on fatigue and quality of life.

- Primary Outcome: Evaluate the sensitivity of MSCopilot® Detect scores in detecting disability worsening based on the revised Multiple Sclerosis Functional Composite (MSFC) scores.

- Secondary Outcomes: Assess the ability of MSCopilot® Detect to detect disability worsening earlier than EDSS, detect progression independent

The PCOS Challenge Study is a research study aimed at collecting information to advance research and improve care for patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS). The study includes two groups: the target population diagnosed with PCOS or exhibiting PCOS symptoms, and a control population of individuals born biologically female without PCOS diagnosis or symptoms. Eligible participants are females aged between 12 and 80 years, willing to sign the consent form and able to understand the registry surveys. The primary outcome measure is the information collected through survey responses over a one-year period. The study aims to gather data to further the understanding and treatment of PCOS.

This is a cluster-randomized, open-label, parallel-group trial comparing the use of two low molecular weight heparins, dalteparin and tinzaparin, in patients with indications for anticoagulant therapy. The primary outcome is a composite of 30-day all-cause mortality and bleeding requiring blood transfusion. Secondary outcomes include 30-day and 365-day all-cause mortality, risk of blood transfusion, pulmonary embolism, deep vein thrombosis, heparin-induced thrombocytopenia, liver failure, length of hospital stay, and days alive out of hospital. Patients will be randomly allocated to receive either dalteparin or tinzaparin through a software module in the electronic health record system, with randomization occurring in hourly clusters. The study aims to evaluate whether the use of either heparin increases the risk of bleeding or mortality in patients requiring anticoagulant therapy.

This clinical trial aims to compare the effectiveness of two respiratory muscle training protocols, inspiratory muscle training (IMT) and expiratory muscle training (EMT), in acquired brain injury patients. The study is a randomized, parallel-assignment trial with triple masking.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the IMT group or the EMT group. The IMT group will perform inspiratory muscle training at 50% of their maximum inspiratory pressure (MIP) using a pressure threshold device, while the EMT group will perform expiratory muscle training at 50% of their maximum expiratory pressure (MEP) using a similar device. Both groups will undergo an 8-week training program, with one session per day, five days a week, consisting of five sets of one-minute training with one-minute rest intervals.

The primary outcome measures are inspiratory muscle strength, measured by MIP, and expiratory muscle strength, measured by MEP. Secondary outcome measures include pulmonary volume, assessed by forced expiratory volume in one second (FEV1), and pulmonary flow, assessed by peak expiratory flow (PEF).

The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of these

This is a randomized, controlled, crossover pilot study investigating the effects of technological balance and gait rehabilitation using the Hunova® robotic platform in patients with multiple sclerosis (MS). The study aims to evaluate the impact of this rehabilitation approach on functional, motor, and cognitive outcomes in MS patients.

The study will recruit 24 patients with MS who meet the inclusion criteria, such as definitive MS diagnosis, age between 18-65 years, EDSS score between 2-3, ability to stand without support, and cognitive ability to follow instructions. Patients will be randomly assigned to two groups: the experimental group (HO) will receive technological rehabilitation using the Hunova® platform for 4 weeks, followed by 4 weeks of observation, while the control group (OH) will undergo 4 weeks of observation first, followed by 4 weeks of technological rehabilitation.

The primary outcome measure is the Berg Balance Scale, which assesses balance abilities. Secondary outcome measures include the Modified Fatigue Impact Scale, Fatigue Scale for Motor and Cognitive Function, Timed Up and Go test, Ambulation Index, Walking Handicap Scale, Functional Ambulation Classification,

The ASARD-TMA study is a clinical trial aimed at evaluating an automated algorithm for the surveillance, alert, and rapid diagnosis of thrombotic microangiopathies (TMA). The primary outcome measure is the time of diagnosis and treatment of TMA, with the goal of speeding up the process, particularly in smaller hospitals without 24-hour hematological services. The study includes patients aged 18 to 100 years admitted to the emergency ward or as inpatients with suspected TMA, based on clinical evaluation or alerts issued by the automated algorithm. Patients with a predictive probability of TMA less than 90% according to the diagnostic algorithm are excluded. The study is designed to measure the effectiveness of the automated system in reducing the time to diagnosis and treatment of TMA over a 24-month period.

This clinical trial aimed to develop and test the feasibility of the Access-H2O faucet, a sensor-driven smart faucet designed to enable individuals with spinal cord injuries (SCI), particularly quadriplegics, to access water more independently for basic activities of daily living such as drinking, rinsing, and grooming. The faucet incorporates electromechanical controls, software programs, and sensors (proximity, voice recognition, and camera) to allow hands-free operation and precise dispensing of water at desired temperature and volume.

The study recruited individuals with SCI, primarily quadriplegics with injuries above C7, and healthy controls from an outpatient rehabilitation clinic. Participants were assessed for their levels of functional independence and interviewed about their current methods of drinking, rinsing, and grooming. They were then asked to test the Access-H2O faucet by using motion sensors, voice commands, and eye gaze to control the water stream for the aforementioned activities.

The primary outcome measure was the participants' ability to successfully complete tasks such as getting water to their mouth for drinking, rinsing their mouth, and rinsing soap from their cheeks using the f

This is a cluster-randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of an activity wristband-based intermittent teaching unit in physical education on students' physical activity levels and psychological mediators. The study involved secondary school students (aged 12-16 years) who were randomly assigned to either an experimental group or a control group.

The experimental group received an intermittent teaching unit twice a week for eight weeks, aimed at promoting healthy physical activity habits. During the last 15 minutes of each lesson, students wore activity wristbands and received strategies to modify their behavior towards physical activity.

The control group attended regular physical education lessons without any specific intervention related to physical activity promotion.

The primary outcomes measured were changes in perceived autonomy support, basic psychological needs (autonomy, competence, and relatedness), motivation toward physical education, self-determined motivation toward physical activity, intention to be physically active, and habitual physical activity levels. These outcomes were assessed at three time points: pre-intervention, immediately post-intervention, and after a 6-week follow-up.

The study aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of the intermittent teaching unit, combined with the use of activity wristbands, in promoting physical activity and

This is a study evaluating the agreement between a non-invasive investigational device (Task Force® CORE/CARDIO) and a reference device in measuring various hemodynamic parameters during autonomic function testing in patients with orthostatic intolerance. The study aims to assess the agreement in measurements of blood pressure, heart rate, and cardiac output between the two devices during different phases of autonomic function testing, including baseline, Valsalva maneuver, deep breathing, and head-up tilt table testing. The primary outcomes are the agreement between the devices in measuring these parameters during each phase of testing, analyzed using scatterplots and Bland-Altman analysis. The study includes adult patients with orthostatic intolerance and intact hand perfusion, excluding those with certain vascular conditions, atrial fibrillation, valvular disease, or significant blood pressure differences between arms.

This clinical trial aims to develop and evaluate an online mental health hub for post-secondary students in the Kingston, Frontenac, Lennox & Addington region of Ontario, Canada. The hub will offer two main interventions: a 6-week online psychoeducation program and a 12-week diagnosis-specific online cognitive behavioral therapy (e-CBT) program. 

The study has three phases:

1. Pre-adoption: Assess students' current mental health needs through surveys and focus groups. Use this information to develop the psychoeducation and e-CBT programs.

2. Delivery: Determine the efficacy and cost-effectiveness of the online programs compared to treatment as usual, using validated clinical assessments.

3. Post-adoption: Monitor the success and fidelity of the programs through surveys and focus groups, and build capacity to scale the project to other Canadian municipalities.

The psychoeducation program will be followed by 6 months of AI-assisted journaling to monitor students' mental health and determine if they need to step up to the e-CBT program. The e-CBT programs will target the most common mental health disorders in students: generalized anxiety

This is a randomized, parallel-group, quadruple-blinded clinical trial assessing the efficacy of a combination therapy (AV2-salicylic acid) versus standard salicylic acid treatment for cutaneous warts, with emphasis on persistent warts. The primary outcomes are cure rate at 12 weeks and recurrence rate at 6 months after enrollment. Secondary outcomes include adverse events, time to clearance, change in wart size, number of remaining warts, genotype distribution of HPV types, and prevalence of mucosal HPV types in cutaneous warts. Eligible participants must be 12 years or older with cutaneous warts, able to use WhatsApp for follow-up, and meet other criteria. The study aims to evaluate if the combination therapy can improve wart clearance and prevent recurrence compared to standard treatment.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study assessing the efficacy of letrozole compared to methotrexate in the treatment of ectopic pregnancy. Around 75 women aged 18-40 years with confirmed ectopic pregnancy will be randomly assigned to one of three groups: 1) single dose of methotrexate, 2) letrozole 2.5 mg twice daily for 10 days, or 3) letrozole 2.5 mg three times daily for 5 days. The primary outcomes are β-hCG levels measured on day 14 and anti-mullerian hormone levels measured 3 months after treatment. Secondary measures include blood cell counts, liver enzymes, urea, and creatinine levels. The study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of letrozole, an aromatase inhibitor, as an alternative treatment option for ectopic pregnancy compared to the standard methotrexate therapy.

This is a cross-sectional study investigating the effect of fenestrated versus non-fenestrated patch closure of atrial septal defects (ASD) on left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole in patients with ASD and pulmonary hypertension. The study compares two groups: patients who underwent ASD closure with a fenestrated patch, and those who underwent closure with a non-fenestrated patch. The primary outcome measure is the change in left ventricular diameter during systole and diastole, measured preoperatively and postoperatively between January 2017 and October 2021. The study aims to evaluate whether fenestrated closure, which allows some blood flow between the right and left heart, can improve left ventricular size compared to complete closure, particularly in cases of small left ventricles. Patients with complete preoperative and postoperative echocardiography data, or those willing to complete missing postoperative data, are included in the study.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the role of oxidative stress and mitochondrial TERT (telomerase reverse transcriptase) in the progression and therapeutic resistance of papillary thyroid cancer. The primary outcomes include measuring H2O2 generation, TERT mitochondrial localization, the effect of exogenous oxidative stress and therapeutic agents on TERT nuclear to mitochondrial translocation, mitochondrial oxidative stress generation, proliferation, apoptosis, and migration in thyroid cancer cell lines treated with Src kinase inhibitors. Secondary outcomes involve genetic characterization and expression profiling of tumor tissues. The study includes patients with papillary thyroid cancer whose tumor and healthy tissues can be collected for analyses.

This is a phase III, prospective, multi-center, open-label, two-arm randomized controlled trial comparing whole-body hypothermia (cooling) to targeted normothermia (normal body temperature) in newborns with mild neonatal encephalopathy. 

Key aspects:

- Includes newborns ≥36 weeks gestation with evidence of intrapartum hypoxia-ischemia and mild hypoxic-ischemic encephalopathy based on specific criteria.

- Babies randomized within 6 hours of birth to either:
    1) Whole-body hypothermia (33.5±0.5°C) for 72 hours followed by rewarming
    2) Targeted normothermia (36.5±0.5°C) for 80 hours

- Primary outcome is mean cognitive composite score on the Bayley Scales at 22-26 months. 

- Secondary outcomes include neonatal seizures, duration of intensive care/hospitalization, infections, brain injury on MRI, survival without neurological impairment, and behavioral assessments.

- Neurodevelop

This is a first-in-human, phase I/IIa, open-label, non-randomized trial investigating the safety and tolerability of pTTL, an immunotherapy consisting of autologous T cells activated and expanded in vitro using patient-specific tumor neoantigens, in patients with advanced colorectal cancer (stage IV). The trial has three parts: Part I involves patient identification, screening, and production of pTTL; Part II includes pre-conditioning chemotherapy, administration of a single dose of pTTL, and 26 weeks of safety follow-up; Part III is a long-term follow-up for up to 4.5 years. The primary outcome is safety, assessed by incidence and severity of adverse events. Secondary outcomes include objective response, time to response, duration of response, time to progression, kinetics of tumor progression, overall survival, progression-free survival, and disease-specific survival. Eligible patients must have received or be ineligible for standard therapies, have accessible tumor lesions for biopsy, and undergo surgical excision of tumor-draining lymph nodes as the starting material for pTTL production.

This clinical trial aims to investigate the diagnostic and prognostic role of serum amyloid A (SAA) in patients with intrathoracic sarcoidosis. The study involves two groups: patients newly diagnosed with intrathoracic sarcoidosis and healthy controls. The primary outcomes measure the correlation between SAA levels at diagnosis and various factors, including disease stage, radiological patterns, other biomarkers, pulmonary function tests, and radiological extent of disease. Additionally, the study evaluates the correlation between SAA levels at diagnosis and changes in lung function, radiological extent, and the need for therapy after a 3-year follow-up period. The trial does not involve any interventions and aims to assess the diagnostic and prognostic utility of SAA in intrathoracic sarcoidosis.

This is a randomized, single-blind, multicenter controlled trial investigating the benefit of early intrauterine transfer of blank culture medium prior to transfer of a thawed embryo from the first in vitro fertilization (IVF) cycle. The study aims to compare the clinically progressive pregnancy rate between two groups: an experimental group receiving a transfer of a small amount of gassed embryo culture medium into the uterine cavity 2-3 days before the embryo transfer, and a sham comparator group undergoing a mock transfer without any medium.

The primary outcome measure is the clinically progressive pregnancy rate at 12 weeks of amenorrhea, determined by first-trimester ultrasound. Secondary outcomes include the occurrence of pregnancy, biochemical pregnancy, clinical pregnancy, early miscarriage, live birth, differential cost-result ratio, and total estimated expenditure for the two care strategies.

The study includes women aged up to 39 years who have had a failed first fresh or frozen embryo transfer and have at least two embryos eligible for transfer or freezing from their first IVF attempt. The embryos must be at least at the day 3 stage.

This is a multicenter, observational cohort study aimed at constructing a database of prognostic risk factors and quality of life for patients with primary solid malignant cancers receiving immunotherapy for the first time. The study will collect baseline information before treatment (demographic characteristics, tumor and anti-tumor information, gene testing information, blood samples, and questionnaire evaluations) and follow-up information after treatment from patients receiving immunotherapy at multiple clinical centers, including the First Affiliated Hospital of Xi'an Jiaotong University. The primary outcome measure is progression-free survival (PFS), and secondary outcomes include overall survival (OS) and questionnaire scores (e.g., PHQ-9). The study aims to provide evidence-based medical evidence for selecting immunotherapy regimens, preventing and managing adverse reactions, and improving survival prognosis for these patients.

This is a randomized controlled experimental study aimed at examining the effect of acupressure on back pain in the late postpartum period after cesarean section. The study will involve 70 participants (35 in the acupressure group and 35 in the control group) who have undergone cesarean section, are experiencing back pain, and are in the late postpartum period (1st week and 4th week). The acupressure group will receive acupressure treatment at specific points, while the control group will receive routine care. The primary outcome measure is the Visual Analog Scale (VAS) for assessing back pain, which will be filled out by participants before and after the intervention in the 1st week and 4th week postpartum. The study aims to test the hypothesis that acupressure reduces back pain levels in postpartum women after cesarean section.

This is a randomized, open-label, parallel-group study investigating the effectiveness of confidential social network referrals for HIV testing in Moshi, Tanzania. The study aims to compare the uptake of HIV testing between two groups: 1) an experimental group receiving both SMS-based confidential social network referrals (CONSORT referrals) and physical invitation cards (card referrals), and 2) an active comparator group receiving only physical invitation cards. The primary outcome measure is the number of referred clients presenting for HIV testing at participating study sites within 30 days of the testing offer, per 100 index clients. Eligible participants must be at least 18 years old, literate, and live, work, or regularly receive care in Moshi, Tanzania. The study is designed for health services research purposes.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled trial investigating the effects of paroxetine on cardiovascular function in septic patients. The primary outcome measure is the time to vasopressor discontinuation within 28 days of enrollment. Secondary outcomes include cumulative vasopressor dose, variation in cardiovascular and total sequential organ failure assessment (SOFA) scores, length of ICU stay, and mortality during ICU stay. Eligible participants are adults diagnosed with septic shock for less than 48 hours and requiring noradrenaline. The study has two arms: paroxetine (40mg once daily for up to 5 days or 24 hours after shock resolution) and placebo. The study design includes an interim analysis after 20 patients to determine if the fluoxetine arm should be continued, which was subsequently removed due to lack of anticipated benefit.

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of a tele-education program for patients with moderate depressive episodes in primary care. The trial has two arms: an experimental group receiving the tele-education program in addition to usual care, and a control group receiving only usual care with an educational booklet on depression.

The tele-education program consists of 5 weekly individual remote sessions of 60 minutes each. The sessions cover topics such as identifying depression symptoms, hygienic and dietary measures, the role of family and friends, information on antidepressants, and a summary of the program to be shared with the patient's general practitioner (GP).

The primary outcome is medication adherence, measured by the rate of continuous antidepressant use at 6 months post-inclusion. Secondary outcomes include changes in self-efficacy feelings and barriers to treatment, assessed at 3 months post-inclusion using validated scales.

Eligible participants are adults aged 18 and above with a moderate depressive episode according to DSM-V criteria, prescribed antidepressants within the past 2 months, able to use the digital platform, and whose health status allows follow-up by their GP

This is a pilot observational study aimed at assessing the ability of continuous 'home' EEG using the Dreem Headband to accurately diagnose narcolepsy type 1 and hypersomnia, and demonstrate response to treatment. The study will measure the sensitivity, specificity, positive predictive value, and negative predictive value of the Dreem Headband-derived EEG in predicting a final diagnosis of narcolepsy type 1, compared to the gold standard in-patient clinical testing with polysomnography and multiple sleep latency test (ICSD-3 protocol). The study will recruit participants aged 12 to 25 years who are already under investigation for hypersomnolence within the Guy's and St Thomas' NHS Foundation Trust children and adult sleep service. The study aims to evaluate the potential of continuous 'home' EEG as a diagnostic tool for narcolepsy and hypersomnia.

This is a prospective, phase I/II, randomized, triple-blind, two-parallel group, active controlled trial to evaluate the safety, tolerability, pharmacokinetics, and efficacy of a lignocaine-loaded maltose microneedle array patch compared to a standard 5% EMLA patch for topical analgesia before venepuncture procedures in adults undergoing cataract or glaucoma surgeries.

Phase I is a non-randomized, open-label, single-group study to assess the safety, tolerability, and pharmacokinetics of a 12.5mg lignocaine-embedded microneedle patch in 20 healthy adults. Blood samples will be collected at various time points to measure lignocaine concentrations.

Phase II is a randomized, double-blind, two-parallel group study comparing the efficacy of the 12.5mg lignocaine-loaded microneedle patch to a standard 5% EMLA patch containing 12.5mg lignocaine and 12.5mg prilocaine. The primary outcomes are the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS) pain score and skin conductance algesimeter

This is a randomized clinical trial investigating the effectiveness of different interventions for perinatal distress (depression and anxiety) in couples. The study aims to evaluate the impact of psychopharmacological treatment, cognitive behavioral couple therapy (CBCT), and their combination on reducing distress symptoms, improving dyadic coping strategies, social support, quality of life, and well-being among perinatal couples.

The study has five groups:

1. Psychopharmacological intervention (antidepressants and/or anxiolytics)
2. CBCT intervention (with or without Zikr)
3. Combined psychopharmacological and CBCT intervention
4. Combined psychopharmacological, CBCT, and Zikr intervention
5. Placebo or no intervention (control group)

Participants will undergo pre-test and post-test assessments using various scales (Parental Perinatal Distress Scale, Multidimensional Scale for Perceived Social Support, Dyadic Coping Inventory, Flourishing Scale, and WHOQOL-BREF). The primary outcomes include changes in scores on these scales,

This is a Phase 1/Phase 2 open-label, dose-escalation and dose-expansion study to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of SAR444836, an adeno-associated viral vector-mediated gene transfer of human phenylalanine hydroxylase, in adult participants aged 18-65 years with phenylketonuria (PKU) due to phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) deficiency.

The study aims to assess the incidence of treatment-emergent adverse events as the primary outcome measure. Secondary outcomes include the proportion of participants achieving sustained plasma phenylalanine (Phe) levels below certain thresholds without dietary Phe restriction, changes in dietary protein intake and Phe:Tyrosine ratio, and the duration of viral vector shedding.

Participants will receive a single intravenous infusion of SAR444836 on Day 1. The study has an open-label, single-group design with no control arm. Eligibility criteria include a confirmed diagnosis of PKU, elevated plasma Phe levels, and no significant underlying liver disease or active viral infections.

This clinical trial aims to evaluate the applicability of pseudo-continuous arterial spin labeling (pCASL), a non-invasive MRI technique, as a substitute for fluorodeoxyglucose positron emission tomography (FDG-PET) in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and subjective cognitive decline (SCD). The primary outcomes measure the correlation between brain hypoperfusion (measured by pCASL) and brain hypometabolism (measured by FDG-PET) at baseline, both overall and according to cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) biomarker profiles. Secondary outcomes include analyzing differences in brain hypoperfusion patterns based on amyloid and tau status, correlating brain hypoperfusion with neuropsychological test scores, assessing the predictive value of brain hypoperfusion and hypometabolism for conversion to dementia, and correlating brain hypoperfusion with CSF and blood biomarkers. The study includes patients aged 18-80 years with MCI or SCD, and excludes those with contraindications to MRI, PET, or lumbar puncture, as well as those with

This is a prospective, single-arm, multicenter, observational safety surveillance study of Tafamidis (VyndaMx®) capsules in patients with transthyretin amyloid cardiomyopathy (ATTR-CM) in India. The study aims to assess the safety of Tafamidis capsules by monitoring adverse events occurring within 6 months from the first dosing. Adult patients (aged ≥18 years) diagnosed with wild-type or hereditary ATTR-CM, prescribed Tafamidis capsules, and without hypersensitivity to the drug or excipients, rare hereditary fructose intolerance, or contraindications according to the approved local product label, are eligible for the study. The primary outcome measure is the number of adverse events with Tafamidis within 6 months from the first dosing. Investigators will collect safety-related data until 6 months from the first dosing and record it on the case report form.

This is a randomized controlled clinical trial evaluating the STERN FIX device as a sternal stabilization system in patients undergoing median sternotomy. The study aims to assess the sternal stability, safety, and efficacy of the STERN FIX device in combination with wires compared to the standard wire closure method.

The primary outcome measure is sternal stability evaluated using the sternal instability scale at 1 month after surgery. Secondary outcomes include safety measures such as adverse events, device deficiencies, and reinterventions, as well as sternal wound infections, dehiscence, closure time, ease of use, surgeon satisfaction, chest pain, blood loss, upper limb function, quality of life, sternal union/malunion, alignment, and integrity of the sternum and closure system assessed through CT scans at 6 months.

Eligible participants are adults undergoing median sternotomy with at least one risk factor such as obesity, diabetes, COPD, osteoporosis, renal disease, or scheduled for bilateral internal mammary artery grafting. Patients are randomized to receive either the STERN FIX device in combination with wires or the standard wire closure

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effect of an active break intervention on nonspecific low back pain and musculoskeletal discomfort during prolonged sitting among young people aged 18-25 years. The study aims to evaluate if taking an active break with lumbar and hip extension exercises every 30 minutes of sitting can reduce low back pain, disability, and perceived musculoskeletal discomfort compared to a control group receiving self-care recommendations.

The study has two parallel arms: an experimental group receiving the active break intervention, and a control group receiving self-care recommendations. The primary outcomes measured are pain intensity (Visual Analogue Scale), disability (Oswestry Disability Index), perceived musculoskeletal discomfort during sitting (Borg scale), and global perceived effect (7-point Likert scale). A secondary outcome is a post-intervention questionnaire assessing subjective opinions about the active break program.

The intervention period is 12 weeks, with assessments done at baseline and post-intervention. The study is designed as a randomized, parallel-group trial with double masking. Eligibility criteria include nonspecific low back pain for at least 3

This is a clinical trial investigating the performance and safety of vaginal administration of tocopherol acetate (vitamin E) in pre-, peri-, and postmenopausal women aged 50-70 years. The intervention involves the use of Filme Gyno-V® Vaginal Ovules, a device containing tocopherol, administered vaginally for 14 days.

The primary outcome measure is the acidity measure of vaginal secretions, assessed using a pH strip, which serves as an indicator of the vaginal environment and the balance of microorganisms present.

Secondary outcome measures include:

1. Rate of vaginal mucosa dryness
2. Rate of vaginal mucosal integrity
3. Rate of mucosa pallor
4. Quantity of vaginal discharge assessment
5. Whiff test for detecting amines
6. Rate of Lactobacillus grade according to Ison Hay's classification by bacterioscopic smear
7. Microbiological evaluation by culture examination of the vaginal swab
8. Molecular sequencing-based microbiological analysis of vaginal microbiota by next-generation sequencing (

This is a clinical study investigating the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in patients with polycythemia vera and secondary erythrocytosis. The study aims to collect data on clinical manifestations, thrombosis history, complete blood picture (including hematocrit, hemoglobin, and red blood cell distribution width), serum uric acid, JAK2V617F mutation status, and bone marrow aspiration and biopsy with reticulin stain. Patients aged 18 years and older, newly diagnosed with polycythemia vera between September 2014 and November 2022 at Sohag University Hospital, will be included in the polycythemia vera group. Patients with secondary erythrocytosis, recruited from the internal medicine and chest departments at the same hospital, will serve as the control group. The primary outcome measures are the hematocrit to hemoglobin ratio and red blood cell distribution width in both groups. The study is expected to enroll participants from December 2022 to September 2023.

This clinical trial aims to determine the effect of measuring perfusion index (PI) on the emergency triage classification in patients presenting with dyspnea (shortness of breath). The study includes adult patients over 18 years old who were admitted to the emergency department with dyspnea. The PI values were measured using the Masimo Radical-7 device at the time of admission, after the first hour, and after the second hour of admission. The study compares the PI measurements and oxygen saturation measured by finger probes and evaluates their impact on the emergency triage classification. The primary outcome measures are the use of PI for determining the triage status of patients with dyspnea at the time of admission, after the first hour, and after the second hour. The study is designed as a single-group, open-label, diagnostic study.

This is a randomized, double-blind, active-placebo controlled phase II clinical trial investigating the use of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) in palliative care. The study aims to evaluate the effects of LSD on anxiety, pain, depression, demoralization, psychological distress, quality of life, caregiver burden, fear of death, and existential distress in patients with end-stage fatal diseases.

Participants will be randomly assigned to either the treatment arm, receiving 100 μg LSD in the first session and 100 or 200 μg LSD in the second session, or the active placebo control arm, receiving 25 μg LSD in both sessions.

The primary outcome measure is changes in state anxiety assessed by the State-Trait Anxiety Inventory (STAI-S) questionnaire compared to the active placebo. Secondary outcomes include changes in pain levels, opioid use, spiritual well-being, demoralization, quality of life, depression, anxiety, fear of death, caregiver burden, and subjective experiences.

The study will assess the acute and long-lasting effects of LSD, as well as

This is a randomized controlled trial investigating the effectiveness of a text messaging program called SmartMom in promoting healthy behaviors during pregnancy. The study aims to evaluate the impact of the SmartMom text messages, which provide evidence-based information and guidance, on various outcomes compared to a control group receiving general pregnancy-related text messages.

The primary outcomes include appropriate gestational weight gain and attendance at prenatal care visits. Secondary outcomes include changes in health knowledge, health literacy, fear of childbirth, depression, anxiety, substance use, rates of planned vaginal birth after cesarean, exclusive breastfeeding, adverse pregnancy outcomes, and cost-effectiveness.

Eligible participants are pregnant individuals at or before 15 weeks of gestation, able to read and understand English at an 8th-grade level, comfortable with online surveys, and residing in Canada (excluding British Columbia). The intervention group receives three SmartMom text messages per week with content focused on promoting healthy behaviors, while the control group receives one general pregnancy-related text message per week.

The study aims to assess the effectiveness of the SmartMom text messaging program in improving various health outcomes and behaviors during pregnancy, ultimately promoting healthier pregnancies and better maternal and child
